Online travel services provider Expedia (EXPE) reported fourth-quarter results after the market close Thursday that missed on the bottom line, but edged views on the top line.Expedia reported revenue of $2.1 billion, beating the consensus estimate of $2.07 billion and up 23% year over year.Earnings per share minus items came in at $1.17, up 52% but well below the Wall Street consensus of $1.37.Expedia stock was down more than 3% in after-hours trading, following its earnings release. Shares rose a fraction in Thursday's regular session to 123.25.Expedia's main competitor, Priceline (PCLN), is scheduled to report earnings Feb. 27 after the market close.Last month, Credit Suisse started coverage of several online travel stocks, giving leaders Priceline and Expedia outperform ratings, while TripAdvisor (TRIP) got a sector perform nod.RELATED:Nvidia Earnings, Sales Crush Views As Demand Booms In All Markets, But Guidance Is So-SoYelp Q4 Mostly In Line, Revenue Outlook Light, Stock Falls

Security and protection firm Brink's (BCO) and railroad transport company CSX (CSX) received buy ratings on Tuesday, while online travel service TripAdvisor (TRIP) and solar-energy firm First Solar (FSLR) were downgraded by Wall Street analysts.SunTrust Robinson Humphrey initiated coverage of Richmond, Va.-based Brink's with a buy rating and price target of 62.Brink's, known for its bullet-resistant armored trucks for transporting cash and valuables, rose 1.6% to finish at 53.45, hitting a new all-time high of 54.97 intraday.Brink's stock blasted out of a cup-with-handle base with a buy point of 45.20 on Feb. 8, when it reported strong earnings.Deutsche Bank upgraded CSX to buy with a price target of 56. Shares dipped 0.3% to 48.56 on the stock market today. CSX is trading near its record high of 49.13, reached on Jan. 26.Last week, the Jacksonville, Fla.-based company announced a management streamlining and realignment plan expected to deliver at least $175 million of annual productivity savings. The management streamlining plan is expected to impact up to 1,000 employees, representing over 20% of CSX's management workforce. It is expected to be complete by mid-March.Needham analyst Laura Martin cut her rating on TripAdvisor to underperform from hold. She thinks TripAdvisor is worth 37 to 38. TripAdvisor closed down 3% at 41.47.TripAdvisor's strategic pivot from review site to booking engine is proving more expensive than hoped, Martin said. Also, TripAdvisor is unlikely to win the marketing war against Priceline (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE), which have deeper pockets, she said.Priceline jumped 5.6% following its better-than-expected Q4 earnings late Monday.Axiom Capital initiated coverage of First Solar with a sell rating and price target of 21.First Solar fell 4.3% to 36.19.A year ago, First Solar shares were trading near 70.Argus Research downgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to hold from sell.Shares of the enterprise hardware, software and services firm rose rose 2.3% to 22.82. The stock fell 2.8% on Monday and 6.9% last Friday following its earnings late Thursday.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

Online travel site TripAdvisor (TRIP), striving for growth amid competition from Priceline (PCLN) and others in a tough field, late Wednesday posted earnings and sales that missed Wall Street targets, and shares were down in after-hours trading.The company now has had little or no year-over-year EPS ex items or revenue growth for the past four quarters.The company — which says it had 390 million unique monthly visitors during the peak summer season — bills itself as the world's largest travel site. It's used for travel research and bookings, focusing on hotels and thus competing directly with Priceline's Booking.com site. Travel site Expedia (EXPE) spun off from TripAdvisor in 2011.Wall Street Q4, Q1 estimates: Analysts expect Q4 earnings per share minus items of 31 cents, down 31% from the year-earlier quarter. Revenue is expected to rise 5.7% to $326.5 million. For Q1, analysts model EPS ex items of 33 cents, down a penny, on sales of $379.3 million, up 7.8%.Q4 results: The company reported EPS ex items of just 16 cents, down 64%. "As expected, our significant investments in these growth initiatives dampened full-year 2016 financial results," CFO Ernst Teunissen said in the earnings release. Revenue rose 2% to $316 million. As usual, TripAdvisor didn't provide guidance in its earnings release. Its earnings conference call with analysts is slated for 8:30 a.m. ET on Thursday.Q3 results: Last quarter, the company posted EPS ex items of 53 cents, the same as in Q3 2015, while revenue edged up 1% to $421 million. It said the number of user reviews and opinions posted on its site jumped nearly 50% to 435 million.Stock: TripAdvisor stock down nearly 5% in after-hours trading, following the earnings release. Shares rose 1% to 52.70 in Wednesday's regular session, but it's been trading below its 200-day line for the past three months, since disappointing Q3 earnings sent shares plunging 17%. Company executives emphasized at the time that the company was focused on building for the long term. Shares plunged 47% in 2016 but are up 15% in 2017.RELATED:Why TripAdvisor Got A Price-Target Cut

Investment bank Cowen initiated coverage of hotel bookings provider Trivago (TRVG) with an outperform rating, saying the company is well positioned to increase consumer awareness in the online travel business.Trivago, a spinoff of online travel firm Expedia (EXPE), held its initial public offering on Dec. 16, pricing 26.1 million American depositary receipts at $11 each, below its projected range of $13 to $15, despite big-name lead underwriters JPMorgan (JPM), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS).Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman set a price target on Trivago of 15. Trivago stock dipped 0.4% to 11.84 at the close on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: IPOs are a seedbed of innovation and can be huge stock winners, but can also reverse quickly. IBD writes in the IPO Leaders column about fast-growing companies that went public within the past three years. You can also read this Investor's Corner to maximize your chances for success with IPOs.The downsized Trivago IPO comes on the end of a rough year for IPOs. There were 105 IPOs in 2016, down 38% from the prior year, according to Renaissance Capital. Proceeds raised of $18.8 billion also were down 38%. The IPO market is expected to rebound this year, with high-profile names such as Snapchat-owner Snap, Spotify and Pinterest waiting in the wings.Founded in 2005 and headquartered in Dusseldorf, Germany, Trivago is a global hotel search platform that helps users search for and compare hotels. It helps shoppers find better prices and selection by aggregating hotel room inventory from across numerous online booking sites, known as a "meta-search" business model.Trivago's platform offered access to some 1.3 million hotels in over 190 countries as of Sept. 30, the company says. The company says its platform can be accessed via 55 localized websites and via apps in 33 languages."While not yet generating meaningful profit, we see favorable risk/reward for Trivago given it has the fastest organic growth rate among large public online travel companies, a leadership position in meta-search, and established margin expansion in its oldest markets," Kopelman said in a research report.Trivago will continued to be controlled by Expedia, its largest shareholder, which as of Sept. 30 had a 63.5% stake.Expedia stock was up a fraction, to 117.62. Rival Priceline (PCLN) stock ticked up 0.4% to 1,535.25.Priceline reported third-quarter results last month that beat expectations on the top and bottom lines.RELATED:Airbnb Flight-Booking Service Poses Threat To Priceline, ExpediaExpedia's Trivago, HomeAway Seen Topping $1 Billion In Sales: Cowen

Shortly after Donald Trump was elected, leaders from Apple (AAPL), Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon (AMZN) and many others met the president-elect for a cordial tech summit.But that honeymoon is over after President Trump's executive order to temporarily close off the U.S. to refugees and people from seven largely Muslim nations in the Middle East and Africa.Since the order was signed Friday, the tech sector has been particularly vocal in its opposition to the ban compared with other areas of the business world. Apple, Facebook (FB), Alphabet, Amazon, and Microsoft (MSFT) are among the chorus of firms denouncing the order or expressing concern and support for their employees.Software development company GitHub is reportedly organizing a meeting Tuesday in which tech leaders will discuss filing a friend-of-the-court brief to back a lawsuit against Trump's order.The meeting, reported by Reuters, marks the latest attempt by the tech industry, which has turned to workers outside the U.S. to fill highly skilled positions, to hit back at the ban. The White House says the order is intended to strengthen national security against terrorism, not to target Muslims.But tensions between the White House and Silicon Valley appear likely to become more charged. Bloomberg reported that a draft executive order from the White House would change work-visa programs in an attempt to steer businesses toward American workers when making hires.GitHub has invited Google (whose parent company is Alphabet), Netflix (NFLX), Adobe (ADBE), Salesforce.com (CRM), Box (BOX) and others to attend, according to Reuters. It's not clear which tech firms will send representatives.Amazon and Expedia (EXPE), both based in the Seattle area, have already sent in filings expressing their support for the Washington state attorney general's suit against the ban, and the Council on American-Islamic Relations has filed its own suit, Reuters noted. What lawsuit the companies might get behind is not clear, Reuters said.IBD'S TAKE: Trump's executive order also suspends the Visa Interview Waiver Program, which could slow the visa-renewal process for frequent international travelers, some analysts say, potentially leaving airlines exposed. Apple closed down 0.2% in the stock market today but rose late after reporting strong quarterly earnings and sales, while Facebook, Alphabet and Amazon lost 0.5%, 0.4% and 0.9%, respectively.  Alphabet shares have tumbled below a buy point this week following last week's earnings miss. Facebook and Amazon are testing their recent breakouts.Facebook reports Wednesday and Amazon Thursday.RELATED:Apple, Electronic Arts, Match Group, AMD, Oclaro Earnings On TapWhy Trump Immigration Order May Weigh On StocksApple, FANG Stocks Up In January Amid Trump Tumult, Testing Buy PointsPfizer Reports Lagging Q4 EPS; Rebounds On Trump Commentary

Credit Suisse analyst Paul Bieber assumed coverage of several online travel stocks, giving leaders Priceline (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE) outperform ratings, but giving TripAdvisor (TRIP) a sector perform nod.He set a price target of 1,900 on Priceline stock, where CS had a PT of 1,790. The price target on Expedia stock rose to 145 from 133, but TripAdvisor's PT was lowered to 51 from 65.In his research note Wednesday, Bieber pointed out that "despite intense competition and increasing sector maturity, the global travel market remains very fragmented, with Priceline only commanding approximately 10% of room night share."He expects Priceline to notch 20%-plus gains in room-night sales in 2017. He also expects Priceline to benefit from Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google's expanded text-ad format. A rebound in China's outbound travel also will help, Bieber says.IBD'S TAKE: The Leisure-Travel Booking industry group ranks a lowly No. 135 out of 197 groups tracked by IBD. Which groups are hot? Check out IBD's Industry Snapshot for deep dives on hot fields.Of Expedia, Bieber wrote that the company's 2017 is shaping up well, after it spent much of 2016 digesting acquisitions, led by its $3.9 billion purchase of home-rental online site HomeAway. Expedia completed that acquisition, its biggest, in December 2015."We think Expedia's focus will return to driving higher conversion rates on Expedia.com, which we think will help support mid-to-high teens room night growth in 2017," Bieber wrote.TripAdvisor, though, faces continued strong competition from Priceline's Booking.com "review ecosystem," Bieber said. Its shift to more sales via mobile users is another near-term headwind, the analyst said, though he also said "we are positive on TRIP's leadership position at the top of the marketing funnel for travel. ... "Priceline stock, in its seventh straight up-day, rose a small fraction in the stock market today to 1,536.11. But it's current buy point is a distant 1,601.03, after shares touched a record high of 1,600.93 on Nov. 10. Priceline stock, despite its current streak, has a poor IBD Accumulation/Distribution Rating of D+, indicating more institutional selling than buying.Expedia has an A/D Rating of B-, but shares fell a fraction Wednesday to 117.20. Expedia stock hit a 14-month high of 133.55 on Oct. 28.TripAdvisor also notched a seventh straight day of gains, rising 0.68% Wednesday to 51.66. The stock regained its 50-day line this week but remains way down since its disappointing September-quarter guidance and earnings report.Bieber recently joined Credit Suisse. Analyst Stephen Ju, who had covered online travel, remains with CS but is focusing his coverage on internet companies such as Alphabet and on the online gaming sector.RELATED:Priceline, Expedia Get Buy RatingsAirbnb Flight-Booking Service Will Compete With Priceline, Expedia

Hotel bookings company Trivago (TRVG) a spinoff of online travel firm Expedia (EXPE), received its first coverage since making a public debut Friday.Susquehanna analyst Shyam Patil placed a neutral rating and 14 price target on Trivago stock.Trivago raised $287 million in an initial public offering Friday, but it priced below expectations. Germany-based Trivago priced 26.1 million American depositary receipts at $11 each, below its projected range of $13 to $15, despite big-name lead underwriters JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.Trivago stock, which closed at 11.85 in its debut Friday, fell 2.8% to 11.81 in the stock market today.Founded in 2005 and headquartered in Dusseldorf, Germany, Trivago is a global hotel search platform that helps users search for and compare hotels. Trivago's platform offered access to some 1.3 million hotels in over 190 countries as of Sept. 30, the company said in its IPO filings.IBD'S TAKE: IPOs are a seedbed of innovation and can be huge stock winners, but can also reverse quickly. IBD writes about fast-growing companies that went public within the past three years in the IPO Leaders column. IBD can also help you understand strong IPO bases. You can also read this Investor's Corner to maximize your chances for success with IPOs.Analyst Patil, in a research report, said Trivago is one of the leading "Big 5" players in the travel metasearch space and is well positioned to capitalize on the secular shift from offline to online accommodations bookings and advertising spend.The two largest online travel companies are Priceline Group (PCLN) and Expedia. Priceline reported third-quarter earnings last month that beat on the top and bottom lines.The downsized IPO for Trivago comes on the end of a rough year for IPOs. There have been 105 IPOs thus far this year, down 38% from the year-earlier period, according to Renaissance Capital. Proceeds raised of $18.8 billion are down 38%.Trivago will continued to be majority-owned by Expedia, which as of Sept. 30 had a 63.5% stake. Expedia stock rose 0.75% Tuesday to 117.09, finding support at its 200-day line.For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Trivago reported revenue of $657.4 million, up 67% year over year, with a net loss of $57.8 million, vs. a net loss of $37.4 million."We believe Trivago's 'secret sauce' in advertising has been its innovative approach to combining aggressive, yet highly optimized, TV and search advertising," Patil wrote. "We see this expertise around TV and search differentiating Trivago's ability to penetrate markets and drive growth and has allowed the company to create a moat in a highly competitive space."RELATED:Airbnb Flight-Booking Service Poses Threat To Priceline, ExpediaExpedia's Trivago, HomeAway Seen Topping $1 Billion In Sales: CowenExpedia, Priceline, TripAdvisor Dip On Google Travel Push

Priceline Group (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE) could face increased competition from Airbnb, which is developing a service for booking air travel, according to a report from Bloomberg.Development of the flight-booking feature is early and Airbnb is considering various routes to break into the business, the Bloomberg report said, citing people familiar with the plans. It said Airbnb may acquire an online travel agency or license data from a provider, such as Amadeus IT Group or Sabre (SABR).Last month, Delta Air Lines (DAL) announced a partnership with Airbnb. The partnership allows Airbnb guests to earn SkyMiles redeemable for Delta flights.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Leisure-Travel Book group has been a laggard, as it ranks 165 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Priceline is the top-rated stock in the group. Priceline has an IBD Composite Rating of 74, meaning it has outperformed 74% of stocks on a variety of metrics over the past year. Here's a look at other Tech Leaders.Priceline shares closed 0.3% higher at 1,488.83 in the stock market today, still below their 50-day moving average. Shares touched a record high of 1,600 on Nov. 10. Expedia dipped 0.4% to end at 116.22.Airbnb plans to get airline booking service off the ground before it pursues an initial public offering, which is likely in the next 18 months, the Bloomberg article said. Airbnb declined to comment on the flight-booking plans and said the company doesn't plan to go public in the near future.Hotel bookings company Trivago (TRVG) a spinoff of Expedia, had its IPO last week, raising $287 million. Trivago priced 26.1 million American depositary receipts at $11 each, below its projected range of $13 to $15. Trivago stock climbed 2.5% to 12.15.The move by Airbnb into flight booking could put pressure on profits at Priceline and Expedia, as profit margins for online travel are typically higher in hotels and property rentals.RELATED:Priceline Earnings Beat, Shares Rise After HoursExpedia, Priceline, TripAdvisor Dip On Google Travel Push

Among the names being shuffled around by analysts today are Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Tesla Motors (TSLA), Apple (AAPL), Priceline (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE), Salesforce (CRM) and Microsemi (MSCC).RBC Capital Markets upgraded the oil giant to outperform from sector perform. Shell wasn't the only energy stock getting a thumbs up Wednesday morning; Chevron (CVX) and EOG Resources (EOG) were upgraded to buy by Merrill Lynch.Shell shares ended trading up 1.1% at 55.82 in the stock market today, just below a 56.39 cup-base buy point.Guggenheim started coverage on both names with a buy rating, according to CNBC. Analysts at Guggenheim reportedly called next-generation automotives a sector to watch, and said the iPhone is "tech's most valuable piece of real estate."Tesla shares jumped 4.6% to 226.99 despite missing its 2016 delivery target. Apple dipped 13 cents to 116.02.Needham initiated coverage on the two major online travel agencies, awarding each one a buy rating. Analysts at the firm gave Priceline an 1,800 price target and Expedia a 140 price goal.Airbnb could pose a greater challenge to Priceline and Expedia as it works on an air-travel booking service, according to a recent Bloomberg report.Expedia spinoff Trivago (TRVG), a hotel bookings service, went public just last month at 11 a share.Priceline rose 0.7% to 1,487.29. Expedia added 1.2% to 113.74.Meanwhile, Wedbush named Salesforce its top software sector pick.The software titan also got a "top pick" nod from Drexel Hamilton as well as Morningstar last week for its strong fundamentals. Apple, Twilio (TWLO), Splunk (SPLK) and Box (BOX) were other Drexel picks.Salesforce rose 3.2% to 72.80.Chipmaker Microsemi got a bump down to neutral from Goldman Sachs. The company is also one of three publicly traded chip firms that are likely acquisition targets this year, according to Susquehanna Financial Group analysts.Microsemi fell initially but reversed higher to a 1.4% gain at 55.33.

Hotel bookings company Trivago (TRVG), a spin-off of online travel firm Expedia (EXPE), rallied modestly in its stock market trading debut Friday after raising $287 million in an initial public offering that priced below expectations.Trivago priced 26.1 million American depositary receipts at $11 each, below its projected range of $13 to $15 despite big-name lead underwriters JPMorgan (JPM), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS).Trivago rose 7.7% to 11.85, rising intraday as high as 12.43.Founded in 2005 and headquartered in Dusseldorf, Germany, Trivago is a global hotel search platform that helps users search for and compare hotels. Trivago's platform offered access to some 1.3 million hotels in over 190 countries as of Sept. 30, the company says.The company says its platform can be accessed via 55 localized websites and via apps in 33 languages.IBD'S TAKE: IPOs are a seedbed of innovation and can be huge stock winners, but can also reverse quickly. IBD writes about fast-growing companies that went public within the past three years in the IPO Leaders column. IBD can also help you understand strong IPO bases. You can also read this Investor's Corner to maximize your chances for success with IPOs.The downsized IPO comes on the end of a rough year for IPOs. There have been 105 IPOs thus far this year, down 38% from the same period a year ago, according to Renaissance Capital. Proceeds raised of $18.8 billion is down 38%.Trivago will continued to be controlled by Expedia, its largest shareholder, which as of Sept. 30 had a 63.5% stake. Expedia fell 0.3% to 116.66.Expedia rival Priceline (PCLN) sank 1.1%. Priceline late Thursday named Glenn Fogel as CEO effective Jan. 1. Chairman Jeff Boyd had returned as chief executive on an interim basis in April.RELATED:Priceline Earnings Beat, Shares Rise After HoursExpedia's Trivago, HomeAway Seen Topping $1 Billion In Sales: Cowen

San Francisco-based AppDynamics, which makes software companies use to analyze the performance of their apps, on Wednesday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to make an initial public offering, looking to raise up to $100 million.The company filed under the JOBS (Jumpstart Our Business Startups) Act. It did not set an expected price range, but it listed as underwriters some of Wall Street's biggest firms, including Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley.AppDynamics reported revenue of $158.4 million for the nine months ended Oct. 31, up 54% from the year-earlier period. It reported losses of $95.1 million for the recent nine-month period, vs. $92.4 million in losses for the year-earlier period.IBD'S TAKE: Arista Networks had been among the best-performing IPOs this year. What are some others? Check IBD's IPO Leaders to track the best of the new issues.It listed competitors ranging from tech giants Microsoft (MSFT) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to New Relic (NEWR), which made its IPO two years ago and remains in the red.The company listed among its customers Capital One Financial (COF), IBM (IBM), Charter Communications (CHTR), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Expedia (EXPE).AppDynamics estimates its total addressable market at $12 billion, with products that touch on the markets for IT operations, data analytics and business intelligence."Our integrated suite of applications monitors the performance of software applications and IT infrastructures, down to the underlying code, and automatically correlates them into logical 'business transactions,' such as booking a flight in a web browser, transferring money on a mobile device, getting directions through a car's navigation system or locating physical goods in an inventory system," the company said in its S-1 filing.It's been the slowest IPO market since the Great Recession, though things are expected to heat up early in 2017 with an IPO by Snapchat owner Snap. Some expect that could open the door to other so-called "unicorns," the nickname for tech startups valued at more than $1 billion. AppDynamics' investments reportedly value the company near $2 billion.Nutanix (NTNX) and Twilio (TWLO) were among the few unicorns to launch in 2016, and both stocks had their moments. Acacia Communcations (ACIA) also had been a hot IPO after its May launch, but Acacia, Nutanix and Twilio are now trading well off their highs. RELATED: Tech Unicorn Nutanix Gets Positive CoverageSnapchat Owner Files For Confidential IPO

Dutch private company Travel B.V. filed Monday for the initial public offering of global hotel search platform Trivago at a price of 13-15 per American depositary receipts (ADR).According to the SEC filing, the offering will include Class A and Class B shares. Travel B.V., which will rename itself Trivago, plans to sell 18.1 million ADRs with shareholders selling 10.4 million ADRs. Proceeds could hit $428 millionExpedia (EXPE), a majority shareholder in Trivago with a 63.5% stake as of the end of September, will be the sole holder of Class B shares upon completion of the IPO.Trivago, which initially filed in November to go public, will trade under the ticker TRVG on the Nasdaq.Expedia shares rose 2.2% at 123.69 on the stock market today, retaking its 50-day average. Rival Priceline (PCLN) climbed 1.8% to 1499.76, also retaking its 50-day line. TripAdvisor (TRIP) added 3.3% to 47.98.In July, Cowen projected that Trivago and HomeAway, both Expedia subsidiaries, would each hit $1 billion in sales next year.IBD'S TAKE: Last month, online travel agency leader Priceline (PCLN) topped third-quarter expectations: "Priceline Earnings Beat, Shares Rise After Hours."Following the IPO's completion, Travel B.V. said it plans to undergo a post-IPO corporate reorganization in order to simplify its structure.Expedia and its founders will "determine how to proceed with the post-IPO corporate reorganization within twelve months of the completion of this offering," with plans to be implemented within four months of the decision.RELATED:Expedia's Trivago, HomeAway Seen Topping $1 Billion In Sales: Cowen

Most everyone has heard about The Cloud over the past decade. Most investors have read about companies "shifting toward" it or being "disrupted" by it. Some have been "slow to adapt" to it. Others have become "game changers" by using it to disrupt companies that have been slow to adapt. The technology sneaked up on the scene, and there is…

Online travel company Priceline Group (PCLN) is expected to maintain double-digit growth rates when it reports third-quarter earnings after the market close Monday.The Wall Street consensus is for Priceline to report revenue of $3.6 billion, up 16% year over year, with earnings per share minus items of $29.92, up 18%.Priceline Group is the leading online travel company by revenue, followed by Expedia (EXPE). It offers hotel and accommodation reservations, airline tickets, car rentals, cruises, and vacation packages. Priceline brands include Booking.com, Kayak, Agoda and restaurant-reservations site OpenTable.The company generates about 80% of its gross bookings from its international business, primarily from Booking.com. Expedia is more focused on North America.IBD'S TAKE: Priceline Group has a strong IBD Composite Rating of 96, meaning it has outperformed 96% of other stocks over the past 12 months in key metrics. Check out which other stocks have strong ratings at Stock Spotlight.Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman, in a research note, maintained an outperform rating and price target of 1,550 on Priceline stock.Priceline stock fell 1% in the stock market today to 1,424.28, and this week fell below the key 50-day moving average support line, after touching an all-time high of 1,501.79 on Oct. 5."We note Priceline has been solidifying its leadership position and see upside to our target over time as the company continues to generate solid EPS growth," Kopelman wrote in his research note.Priceline posted higher-than-expected Q2 earnings, and shares rose 4% on that report though the top-line missed analyst estimates.RELATED:Expedia Hits 10-Month High, Hurricane Matthew Impact MinimalExpedia, Priceline, TripAdvisor Dip On Google Travel Push

Graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), along with Walt Disney (DIS), Expedia (EXPE), Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Kohl's (KSS) all had their price target raised by analysts.Nvidia had its price target raised to 80 from 66, with a buy rating. Nvidia late Thursday smashed Wall Street's fiscal Q3 sales and earnings estimates and guided analysts higher for the current quarter. Nvidia stock jumped into record high territory on the news. Nvidia has been boosted lately by sales of chips for gaming PCs, data centers and auto infotainment systems.Nvidia stock soared 30% to a record 87.97 in the stock market today.RELATED:Nvidia Stock Soars On Q3 Beat And RaiseWalt Disney's price target was raised to 101 from 98 by RBC Capital Markets, which maintained a sector perform rating. Disney missed fiscal Q4 estimates after the close Thursday on more ESPN subscriber losses, but the media and entertainment giant sees earnings growth picking up in the coming years. RBC said expense guidance for 2017 is better than the market feared. "We think this will drive a short-term relief rally. However, more robust EPS growth is still a full year away so we  remain Sector Perform."Disney shares rose 2.9% to 97.68.RELATED:Disney Sees Earnings Growth Picking Up, ESPN Weakness EasingOnline travel firm Expedia was upgraded to a hold from sell by Stifel Nicholas, and its price target raised to  130 from 116. Expedia  posted weaker-than-expected earnings on Oct. 27. But a Cowen report said it now has "increased confidence in a meaningful acceleration in Q4" for Expedia.Expedia fell 2% to 121.20.Hewlett-Packard Enterprise had its price target raised to 27 from 23.55 by Jefferies Group. Hewlett-Packard Enterprise reports fiscal Q4 earnings on Nov. 22. The consensus is revenue of $12.8 billion, down 4.5% year over year and EPS of 61 cents, up 13%. "While there exist some macro uncertainties, we believe HPE have many levers to pull to deliver decent results," said a report from Credit Suisse.Hewlett-Packard Enterprise rose 1% to 23.31.Kohl's had its price target raised to 58 from 51 by Telsey Advisory Group, with an outperform rating. Kohl's rose sharply after it released better-than-expected Q3 earnings Thursday that beat expectations.Kohl's climbed 4.4% to close at 53.22, a high not seen since August 2015. Shares had soared 11.5% to 50.97 on Thursday.

Online travel company TripAdvisor (TRIP) reports third-quarter earnings after the market close Tuesday, following cautious warnings on its Q2 call.The consensus is for earnings per share minus items of 52 cents, down 2% and the third quarter in a row of declines year over year, as polled by Thomson Reuters. But the 2% drop is an improvement from the 30% drop the previous quarter. Revenue is expected to rise 5% to $436.3 billion, reversing two quarters in a row of declines.TripAdvisor has about 350 million monthly active users who can post reviews, plan and book accommodations, and arrange to visit attractions and restaurants, among other features of its website.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney, in a research note Monday, maintained a sector perform rating and price target of 55 on TripAdvisor stock, but his financial estimates lag Wall Street consensus. "We view Q3 estimates as somewhat aggressive, with greater chance of downside variance vs. upside variance," Mahaney wrote.IBD'S TAKE: TripAdvisor is well off highs reached in 2014 but recently moved above its 50-day moving average. The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 47, meanings it's underperforming 53% of stocks. Learn more about How To Find and Evaluate Stocks.Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman maintains a market perform rating and price target of 60 on TripAdvisor stock."We are looking for more positive commentary on the forward outlook, vs. cautious warnings on the Q2 call," Kopelman wrote in a research note Monday.TripAdvisor stock dipped 0.3% to close at 63.43 on the stock market today.Priceline Group (PCLN) is schedule to report earnings after the market close Monday. The Wall Street consensus is for Priceline to report revenue of $3.6 billion, up 16% year over year, with earnings per share minus items of $29.92, up 18%.Priceline is the leading online travel company by revenue, followed by Expedia (EXPE). Priceline offers hotel and accommodation reservations, airline tickets, car rentals, cruises, and vacation packages. Expedia reported Q3 earnings on Oct. 27.TripAdvisor will hold a conference call to discuss earnings Wednesday at 8:30 a.m. ET.RELATED:Expedia Hits 10-Month High, Hurricane Matthew Impact MinimalExpedia, Priceline, TripAdvisor Dip On Google Travel Push

Online travel company Priceline Group (PCLN) reported third-quarter earnings after the market close Monday that beat on the top and bottom lines.Priceline reported earnings per share minus items of $31.89, beating the consensus estimate of $29.92, up 23% year over year. Revenue rose 19% to $3.69 billion, beating the consensus of $3.6 billion, as polled by Thomson Reuters.Priceline stock was up 4.7% in after-hours trading, following its earnings release. Shares rose 3.9% in Monday's regular session to 1480.33. Shares peaked Oct. 5 at 1501.79.The company said Q3 was "negatively impacted by a non-cash charge of $941 million relating to an impairment of OpenTable's goodwill."It said the impairment charge is a result of a change in business strategy as it relates to OpenTable's international expansion and other growth opportunities. The change in strategy resulted in OpenTable updating its forecasted financial results to reflect a material reduction in forecasted long-term financial results from these initiatives."While OpenTable will continue to pursue these growth opportunities, they will do so on a more measured and deliberate basis," Priceline said.Priceline Group is the leading online travel company by revenue, followed by Expedia (EXPE). Priceline generates about 80% of its gross bookings from its international business, primarily from Booking.com, whereas Expedia is more focused on North America.Online travel company TripAdvisor (TRIP) reports Q3 earnings after the market close Tuesday, following cautious warnings on its Q2 call, and EPS is expected to fall for a third straight quarter.RELATED:Expedia Hits 10-Month High, Hurricane Matthew Impact MinimalExpedia, Priceline, TripAdvisor Dip On Google Travel Push

The Nasdaq has pulled back about 5% since its all-time closing high Sept. 22. Which of the Big Cap 20 stocks have outperformed the Nasdaq in that same period? Actually quite a few, but many still pegged a loss on the chart, just smaller than the market's loss. Losing less than an index isn't IBD's idea of success. So, we looked at…

Match Group (MTCH) said it earned 23 cents per share minus items in the third quarter, topping views, but revenue of $316.4 million, up 18%, came in below expectations, though strong paid-subscriber growth continued at its mobile dating app, Tinder.Shares in the online dating firm were down 3% in after-hours trading Tuesday, after the earnings release.Analysts had projected EPS ex items of 19 cents and $318 million in revenue.The online dating firm said the location-based Tinder mobile app had 1.5 million paid subscribers as of Sept. 30, up 284,000 from the June quarter. Tinder added 209,000 paid subscribers in Q2, 219,000 in Q1 and 221,000 in Q4 2015.IBD'S TAKE: Shares of Match Group, a member of the IBD 50, have shot up 49% since its November IPO, but the stock has dropped 10% from its all-time high of 19.74 touched on Oct. 24. Facebook is the top-rated stock in the Internet-Content group. Facebook, a Leaderboard stock, reports earnings Wednesday.Match Group boasts 45 brands — among them Match.com, OKCupid, Chemistry.com, Europe's Meetic, Canada's PlentyOfFish, Japan's Pairs and Couples, and HowAboutWe."We grew revenue 22% and expanded margins in our dating businesses, delivering results ahead of expectations, driven by great growth at Tinder, as well as PlentyOfFish and Meetic," Match Group CEO Greg Blatt said in the earnings release.Match.com said it had 5.54 million paid subscribers overall as of Sept. 30, up from 5.3 million in the June quarter. Analysts had modeled 5.51 million. While Tinder is growing fast, some of Match Group's older-bracketed services are struggling, analysts say. One worry is that the online dating industry is shifting to free apps.Media mogul Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp. (IAC) spun off Match Group in 2015. IAC owns 85% of Match Group post-IPO and consolidates the online dating firms' financial results. IAC also spun off travel service Expedia (EXPE) in 2005.Match Group launched Tinder in 2012 in California as a mobile app for college students and young adults. With Tinder's express dating, users at first see only a photo along with a couple of lines of profile text often including a name, age or job description. A match between two users happens only if they both swipe right. The pair can chat using Tinder's messaging service.Tinder, too, faces plenty of competition from free mobile apps, such as Bumble, Hinge, Happn and Zoosk.Match Group has been investing heavily in Tinder, with employee head count more than doubling in the past year. It launched the Tinder Social feature, enabling users to go on group dates. Match Group aims to grow Tinder's advertising revenue.RELATED:Sparks Fly When Dating Firm Match Group Lights Up Its Tinder Site

Hurricane Matthew packed a punch but didn't deliver a knockout blow, an investment bank said Monday in hiking its price target for online travel company Expedia (EXPE), which is slated to reports Q3 earnings after the close Thursday.Matthew hit the Southeast U.S. in early October, potentially a big blow for Expedia because it was counting on a back-half-weighted boost for 2016, Benchmark analyst Daniel Kurnos wrote in a research note Monday.While pointing out that Moody's says the hurricane's total economic damage could approach $70 billion, Kurnos said it had a minimum impact on the travel industry. While saying he's "somewhat cautious" heading into the Q3 report, he hiked his price target on Expedia stock to 150 from 135.Expedia stock rose as much as 1.2%, to a 10-month high of 129.17, on the stock market today, but shares finished the trading day up only 11 cents to 127.69, less than a 0.1% gain.IBD'S TAKE: What top stocks are being bought and sold the most by institutions, those big investors that move stocks? Expedia earlier Monday was on the list, with a large number of techs making IBD's Stocks on the Move, a list that, by its nature, can change quickly.The impending IPO of Expedia's Trivago business, a metasearch engine focused on hotels, keeps "an identifiable catalyst on the table near term," Kurnos said. "The Trivago IPO remains a bit of a wild card, with recent reports indicating the move could be completed by Thanksgiving."He said based on what Expedia rival Priceline (PCLN) paid for travel metasearch engine Kayak, Trivago could be valued at about $4.2 billion, though he says Wall Street has talked about a $5 billion valuation.For Q3, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EPS ex items of $2.48, up 20% from Q3 2015 after Q2 EPS slipped 7%. Sales are seen jumping 32% to $2.55 billion, matching Q2.For Q4, though, analysts expect a 95% jump in EPS ex items, to $1.50, on a 24% rise in revenue, to $2.1 billion.RELATED:Potential For HomeAway Sparks Expedia UpgradeExpedia, Priceline Dip On Google Travel Push

Airbnb's claim that it's just a conduit for user-generated content was rejected by a judge who said the company may not be able to duck a San Francisco law punishing it when hosts book units that aren't registered with the city.U.S. District Judge James Donato on Tuesday rebuffed Airbnb's argument that because it operates on the internet, it can't be held responsible if users circumvent local laws. Still, the judge stopped short of letting San Francisco enforce its measure, saying he needs more information to decide whether the city has adequate procedures for verifying registrations.Had the world's fourth-most valuable startup succeeded in its early attempt to block the ordinance enacted in June by its hometown, the strategy might have served as a template for other gig economy firms challenging regulations across the U.S. Instead, while Airbnb may appeal Donato's ruling, other cities struggling with high housing costs may now be emboldened to follow San Francisco's model."While we appreciate that the judge has acknowledged our concerns about the inadequacy of the screening obligations in the new law and has continued to postpone enforcement of these rules as a result, we respectfully disagree with the remainder of his ruling," Airbnb spokesman Nick Papas said in an email. "No matter what happens in this case, we want to work with the city to fix the broken system long before the legal process runs its course."City Attorney Dennis Herrera said the ruling reinforces that "online businesses don't get a free pass from the types of regulations that apply to other businesses in San Francisco.""They have to play by the rules, just like everybody else," he said in a statement. "These platforms have numerous options to verify whether hosts have registered with the city and comply with the law."Airbnb is already fighting its next major legal battle against the city and state of New York, using the same arguments that failed in San Francisco to challenge a law that fines residents who rent out their apartments for illegal short-term stays.The company also has a pending case against beachfront Santa Monica in Southern California. Anaheim, home to Disneyland, dropped its effort to regulate Airbnb less than two weeks after it was sued by Airbnb.San Francisco's measure imposes a fine of as much as $1,000 a day on rental platforms for every booking of an unregistered host, plus possible misdemeanor charges, and blocks the companies from collecting fees from those bookings.Michael Risch, a professor at Villanova University School of Law in Pennsylvania, said it's not certain that other cities will follow San Francisco's lead in adopting home-sharing regulations because the judge's "logic is difficult to follow" in Tuesday's ruling."The court has clearly held that Airbnb is not immune due to its marketplace functions," Risch said. "It may embolden other states and judges to find creative ways to circumvent the 'content from users' rule. Or, other courts may simply disagree with the logic here, creating a split of authorities."Airbnb argued a 20-year-old U.S. law shields it from liability tied to users in the same way eBay (EBAY) isn't responsible for sales of bootleg recordings or StubHub for scalped tickets. Airbnb's online transactions and fees are protected by the Communications Decency Act of 1996 because they are "part and parcel" of its service, it claimed.San Francisco contended the company's attack on the ordinance was absurd because it wasn't intended to police what rental hosts upload to the website. The ordinance "regulates only conduct — an unlawful commercial transaction, not speech," the city argued.The San Francisco law "does not threaten the liability plaintiffs fear," Donato wrote in his ruling. It doesn't treat Airbnb as a publisher of the rental listings provided by hosts or regulate what's said in the listings, he wrote. Instead, the law holds the company liable only for providing and collecting a fee for booking services for unregistered units, Donato ruled.Airbnb is "perfectly free to publish any listing they get from a host and to collect fees for doing so — whether the unit is lawfully registered or not — without threat of prosecution or penalty," Donato wrote.The judge said San Francisco shouldn't enforce the law until after he hears further discussion of the city's mechanism for verifying whether rentals are legally registered. Donato left open the possibility that Airbnb could still win an order blocking the law based on the company's objections to possible criminal sanctions without a clear verification system.In October, the city and state of New York said they would hold off enforcing new restrictions on short-term apartment sublets against Airbnb until the company's lawsuit in that state is resolved. The move was a reversal from earlier indications that the restrictions would be enforced immediately after New York Governor Andrew Cuomo signed them into law on Oct. 21. The home-sharing company sued to block the measure just hours after Cuomo's action.In the San Francisco fight, Airbnb, with a valuation of $30 billion, garnered support from competitor Expedia's (EXPE) HomeAway, as well as a group representing Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google. The Internet Association, whose members also include Uber Technologies and ride-hailing rival Lyft, said the dispute has wide-ranging implications for free speech on the internet.MORE ABOUT AIRBNB:Airbnb Could Bring Riches, Even If You're Not A Property OwnerFull-Time Landlords Bring $500 Mil On Airbnb: StudyKey To A Great Airbnb Vacation Is Taking Other Guests' Word For It

Online travel agent Expedia (EXPE) will get a big lift from newly acquired HomeAway despite mounting competition with Airbnb, says Pacific Crest Securities, which upgraded Expedia stock to overweight.Expedia last year acquired HomeAway, a vacation-rental website, for $3.9 billion. Privately held Airbnb, a home-sharing website valued at a heady $30 billion, has been growing fast but faces regulatory hurdles expanding into new markets.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Leisure Travel Booking group is ranked No. 82 out of 197 industry groups. Priceline has the highest Composite Rating, a metric that's part of CANSLIM investing. You can find leaders in better performing groups at IBD Sector Leaders, which include Facebook, Broadcom, Gigamon and GrubHub. Brad Erikson, a Pacific Crest analyst, set a price target of 160 on Expedia stock."Conversations with property owners indicate overall high satisfaction with the HomeAway platform, very limited desire and ability to move to competing platforms," said Erickson in his research report.Expedia stock was down a fraction to 124.66 at the close on the stock market today, after earlier rising as much as 2.7% to a nearly 10-month high. Expedia stock is about even in 2016 but shares last month moved above their 50-day moving average, a bullish sign.Media mogul Barry Diller serves as Expedia's chairman and controls the company's voting shares. Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp. (IAC) spun off Expedia in 2005. IAC also spun off online dating service Match Group (MTCH) last year.Some analyst speculate Expedia will launch an IPO for its Trivago subsidiary.Expedia reports earnings on Oct. 27. Analysts expect revenue to rise 32% year over year to $2.56 billion, with EPS rising 20% to $2.48."Expedia can deliver bottom line upside with overexposure to the still solid U.S. travel market and drive continued cost synergies as it digests Orbitz and HomeAway," said Michael Nathanson, an analyst at MoffetNathanson, in a report. He rates Expedia stock a buy.Expedia made other deals last year, acquiring Orbitz Worldwide for $1.6 billion including debt, and Travelocity, for $280 million. Other Expedia brands include Hotels.com and Hotwire.com.,RELATED:Sparks Fly When Dating Firm Match Group Lights Up Its Tinder SiteExpedia, Priceline, TripAdvisor Dip On Google Travel Push

The conventional wisdom is to buy low and sell high. But great stock winners tend to have superior ratings before they make big moves.After Monday's market close, Priceline (PCLN), Microchip Technology (MCHP), Fabrinet (FN), MaxLinear (MXL) and Align Technology (ALGN) reported earnings. All five have Composite Ratings of 95 or better, which means that they outperform at least 95% of all stocks based on fundamental and technical factors. Priceline, MaxLinear and Align are among six IBD 50 stocks with quarterly results on tap this week.Here are the results:Estimates: Adjusted EPS rising 16% to $29.32, with revenue climbing 17% to $3.62 billion.Results: Adjusted EPS rose 23% to $31.18, excluding various items such as a $941 million OpenTable write-down. Revenue climbed 19% to $3.69 billion, its best yearly gain in seven quarters.Outlook: Priceline sees adjusted Q4 EPS of $12.20-$12.80 vs. analyst estimates of $13.57.Stock: Priceline shares shot up 5% to 1555 in early after-hours action. Shares closed up 3.9% to 1480.33 on the stock market today, back near on its all-time high of 1501.79 set on Oct. 5. The stock has retaken its 50-day moving average in heavy volume, triggering an aggressive buy point. The stock has not consolidated quite long enough to form a proper base.A powerful, high-volume rebound above the 50-day (currently just above 1453) could provide an aggressive buy point. Hurricane Matthew and the strong dollar may weigh on results. Late last month, rival online travel site Expedia (EXPE) reported earnings that fell short of forecasts, though revenue topped.TripAdvisor (TRIP) reports late Tuesday. Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week.Markets around the world will look to the results of the U.S. presidential race, which has tightened in the past week. Earnings season slows down but highly rated stocks like Nvidia (NVDA), NetEase (NTES) and Acacia Communications (ACIA) will report, along with Walt Disney (DIS) and department store chains. Also keep an eye on shares of Apple (AAPL) and Facebook (FB).Political scores will finally be settled on Tuesday, when Americans vote. Stock indexes in the U.S. and elsewhere sold off over the past week as poll numbers showed Hillary Clinton's once-comfortable lead over Donald Trump shrinking or even disappearing. The S&P 500 dropped for eight consecutive sessions, marking its longest losing streak since the financial crisis in 2008.Some analysts believe that the possibility of a Trump victory still isn't fully priced into markets, suggesting a further dive if he wins Tuesday night. Results of House and Senate races will also determine how much gridlock the next president could face. But close calls in key battleground states may add another wrinkle, if any recounts delay a final result for the presidential contest.With the market uptrend under pressure and distribution days piling up, growth stocks presenting actionable buying opportunities have been few and far between. But three names — VMWare (VMW), T-Mobile (TMUS) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) — are trading in or near buy range.IBD 50 member VMWare, a provider of corporate data center software, jumped past a 77.09 buy point from a flat base after issuing an estimate-beating quarterly report on Oct. 26. The stock dipped below buy range Friday but is just 0.3% away from it.T-Mobile also cleared a buy point on its better-than-expected earnings Oct. 24. The stock gapped up 9.5% that day and has since pulled back within buy range from a flat base with a 48.21 buy point.Take-Two Interactive on Thursday popped into buy range from a flat base with a 46.88 pivot with a nearly 8% gain, as adjusted EPS surged 50% to top views late Wednesday. The video game publisher is now 3% above the buy point, with a stock's buy range extending 5% past a buy point.Meanwhile, tech giants Facebook and Apple have been trading lower since issuing their quarterly earnings reports.Facebook triggered sell signals after plunging well below its 132.08 and 128.43 buy points. The stock is 9.6% below its all-time high reached Oct. 25. And after breaching its 50-day line, the social media leader is now looking for support at the 200-day line.Apple hit its lowest level since mid-September on Friday after breaking below the 50-day line several sessions prior. With a loss of 4.3% for the week, the iPhone maker's shares are now below a 110.33 buy point initially cleared several weeks ago.RELATED:Facebook, Alphabet Fall Below Recent Buy PointsCloud Deals Drive Top Software Stock To HighsThe graphics chipmaker is expected to post its sixth consecutive quarter of accelerating sales growth when it reports Q3 earnings on Thursday. Analysts expect the company to earn 57 cents a share, up 30%, on sales of $1.69 billion, up 29%. But revenue growth should slow down to 20% in Q4. Nvidia is best known for graphics cards used in PCs and video game consoles, but it has charged into hot growth markets such as self-driving cars and artificial intelligence. The stock has more than doubled this year and is ranked No. 1 in IBD's Electronic-Semiconductor Fabless industry group.Among other highly rated chip stocks, MaxLinear (MXL) reports Monday (EPS flat at 40 cents, revenue up 0.7% to $95.9 million), Microchip Technology (MCH)P also Monday (EPS up 32% to 87 cents, revenue up 54% to $559.4 million, and Microsemi (MSCC) on Thursday (EPS up 23% to 90 cents, revenue up 36% to $328.8 million).RELATED:New Stock Buys Of Top Mutual Funds: Netflix, Zions Bancorp, Chip StocksAcacia Communications is expected to maintain its fast growth when it reports Q3 earnings after the close Thursday. Analysts expect the fiber-optics components maker to post EPS ex items of 81 cents, up from 26 cents in the year-earlier quarter, while sales double to $130.85 million. But shares of the once-hot IPO are in a downtrend since it announced, and completed, a secondary stock offering in early October. Fabrinet (FN), also part of the fiber-optic boom, reports Monday after the close. The sector overall has also cooled of late, with Oclaro (OCLR) and Inphi (IPHI) recently releasing good earnings and guidance, but Lumentum (LITE) and NeoPhotonics (NPTN) disappointing.RELATED:Applied Optoelectronics Earnings Beat, NeoPhotonics MissesInphi Beat-And-Raise Q3 Helps Lift Fiber-Optic StocksThe developer of some of China's most popular video games reports Wednesday, and consensus estimates call for EPS of $2.89, up 30% from a year ago, with sales surging 36% to $1.43 billion. In late September, NetEase and Activision's (ATVI) Blizzard Entertainment unit extended their mainland China collaboration, which includes blockbuster titles such as "World of Warcraft," "StarCraft II," "Diablo III" and "Overwatch." NetEase also offers advertising services, e-commerce platforms and is a leading email service provider.RELATED:Will Strong Earnings Fuel More Upside For NetEase?China-based Momo (MOMO), a video streaming website and mobile social platform, is set to report Q3 earnings before the market open Tuesday. The consensus is for EPS to shoot up to 14 cents from 2 cents a year earlier on revenue of $130.5 million, up 259%. After trading largely sideways for most of the year, Momo shares broke out in August and are now more than 50% extended past a buy point, though they recently lost support at their 50-day average. Still, the IBD 50 stock is among the top-ranked companies in IBD's Internet-Content group.Online travel website Priceline (PCLN) reports late Monday, and analysts see EPS rising 16% to $29.32, with revenue expected to climb 17% to $3.62 billion. TripAdvisor (TRIP) reports early Wednesday, and EPS is seen flat at 53 cents, on 5% revenue growth to $436 million. Hurricane Matthew and the strong dollar may weigh on results. Late last month, rival Expedia (EXPE) reported earnings that fell short of forecasts, though revenue topped.RELATED:What To Expect When Priceline Reports Q3 EarningsThe media and entertainment giant, which reports fiscal Q4 late Thursday, is expected to log EPS of $1.16, a 3% year-over-year decline, on flattish revenue of $13.52 billion. Despite the success of "Finding Dory," the quarter lacks the string of blockbusters that fiscal Q3 enjoyed, though home video sales will benefit. The theme parks business will likely see a bounce from the June opening of Disney's Shanghai resort. Still, subscriber losses at ESPN and other cable channels remain a sore point.Comparisons in the current quarter will get more difficult as results come up against year-ago results from the megahit "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," which is unlikely to be topped by the December release of "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story."Management's conference call with analysts may also shed some light on Disney's streaming strategy as AT&T's (T) $84.5 billion deal for Time Warner (TWX) is the latest sign of the tech and media sectors converging.RELATED:Hulu Live Service Gets Fox And Disney, Waiting On CBS, NBCU Disney-Netflix Deal? Now Is The Time To Take The Risk, Says Barclays The retail environment has not been kind lately, and Q3 results as well as guidance for the current holiday quarter probably won't offer much relief. Analysts see Nordstrom's (JWN) EPS falling 8.8% to 52 cents with revenue down 4.8% to $3.49 billion, when it announces results Thursday. Kohl's (KSS), which is also on tap Thursday, is seen reporting a 6.7% drop in EPS to 70 cents and a 2% dip in sales to $4.34 billion. Also Thursday, Wall Street sees Macy's (M) EPS tumbling 26.8% to 41 cents and revenue falling 3.7% to $5.67 billion. J.C. Penney (JCP) is scheduled for Friday, and its per-share loss is seen narrowing to 20 cents from 47 cents, and sales are seen rising 2.4% to $2.97 billion.On Thursday, ophthalmic medical tech company Glaukos (GKOS) is seen breaking even for Q3 vs. a prior-year loss, on 44% revenue growth. The iStent maker, which went public last year, is considered a pioneer in micro-invasive glaucoma surgery, or MIGS. Shares broke out in September, but have since tumbled out of buy range and are now below their 50-day average.RELATED:This Firm Wins Battle Against Glaucoma By Putting A Stick In Your Eye Even as election-related uncertainty weighs on the market, builders like D.R. Horton (DHI) and LGI Homes (LGIH) have benefited from a low-interest-rate environment and improving wage growth, though costs for materials and labor have weighed. D.R. Horton reports fiscal Q4 results on Tuesday and is expected to grow EPS by 26% to 77 cents with revenue up 20% to $3.67 billion. LGI Homes, which reports Q3 results on Tuesday, is expected to report EPS up 12% to 85 cents, with revenue rising 22% to $213.78 million. LGI Homes late Thursday said October home closings rose 33% vs. a year earlier. Year-to-date closings are up 24%.

For Tinder mobile app users, it's all about swiping right or left on their smartphones, thereby signaling whatever interest they may have in meeting potential dating partners.For shareholders in Tinder-owner Match Group (MTCH), it's all about how many Tinder users will pay up. Lately, that's been a lot.Until early last year, Tinder was little more than a free mobile app, one of many dating apps that use Facebook (FB) links to verify users. That changed in March 2015 when Match Group rolled out a premium version of Tinder, priced in a range of $9.99 to $19.99 monthly."The strength of Match Group right now has been the Tinder results. They're adding more than 200,000 subscribers per quarter," said Brandon Ross, an analyst at BTIG, a financial services firm. "There's amazing brand equity. You think of dating, you think of Tinder. It's in the zeitgeist."Tinder had 1.23 million paid members as of June 30. It accounted for 23% of Match Group's overall 5.3 million paid members in the June 2016 quarter, up from 11% in the year-earlier period, and was the driving force behind Match Group's stock doubling from a low in February.Match Group has been investing heavily in Tinder, with employee head count more than doubling in the past year. It launched the Tinder Social feature, enabling users to go on group dates.While Match Group aims to grow Tinder's advertising revenue, what matters most near-term is converting more free users to paying ones. Early on, most Tinder users signing up for the paid version were men."The engine of this company is the paid member count across the portfolio and Tinder is a big part of that," said Dan Salmon, analyst at BMO Capital Markets.Match Group launched Tinder in 2012 in California as a mobile app for college students and young adults. With Tinder's express dating, users at first see only a photo along with a couple of lines of profile text often including a name, age or job description. A match between two users happens only if they both swipe right. The pair can chat using Tinder's messaging service.Tinder Plus, the premium matchmaking service, gives users unlimited swipes, more "Super Likes," and the ability to match with users when traveling outside their home turf, including other countries. One of Tinder's strengths is the use of smartphone location data to make it easier for users to hook up. Once considered mostly a casual dating app for barhopping millennials, analysts say more Tinder users are seeking long-term relationships or getting married. That may play into Tinder Plus. Some online dating services users, analysts say, view pay walls as a filter for people that are looking for more serious relationships. The down side is that people stop using dating services if they find that special someone.Growing advertising revenue is a priority, says Salmon. Tinder allows companies to create profiles to promote their products; users can swipe right to see more and perhaps get exclusive offers.With an estimated 50 million or more active monthly users globally, Tinder's brand has emerged as the crown jewel in Match Group's dating empire. "Swipe right" has taken off as a buzzword in digital marketing generally."If Tinder keeps up this momentum it could be worth more than Match's entire market cap today," said Ross Sandler, a Deutsche Bank analyst in a report. On Match Group's second-quarter earnings call, management said it has no long-term plans to spin off Tinder.Media mogul Barry Diller's IAC/InteractiveCorp. (IAC) spun off Match Group in 2015. IAC owns 85% of Match Group post-IPO and consolidates the online dating firms' financial results. IAC also spun off travel service Expedia (EXPE) in 2005.Match Group boasts 45 brands — among them Match.com, OKCupid, Chemistry.com, Europe's Meetic, Canada's PlentyOfFish, Japan's Pairs and Couples, and HowAboutWe. Match Group acquired Vancouver-based PlentyOfFish for $575 million in July 2015.IBD'S TAKE: Match Group emerged from a base in late September and since has stayed in a fairly tight range. It ranks fourth in IBD's Internet-Content group, but the competition is tough. Tops on that list is investor darling Facebook (FB), but Match Group is tied with another favored stock on the list, Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL).Owing to its broad offerings, Dallas-based Match Group holds nearly 26% of the $2.5 billion online dating market, says research firm IBISWorld. It garners most revenue from membership fees for website Match.com and others.Growth has slowed for Match Group's older-age brands as Tinder goes gangbusters. Match Group's challenge, analysts say, is getting better at mobile marketing and developing apps that cater to older adults as well as millennials. BMO's Salmon says OKCupid and PlentyOfFish are becoming more Tinder-like, with faster matches."The biggest issue Match is facing is its lagging core business relative to the trends at Tinder," said Deutsche Bank's Sandler. Some 85% of Tinder users are under 35 while 70% of Match.com U.S. users are over 35, analysts say.Christopher Merwin, analyst at Barclays, in a report said paid member growth for Match Group's older brands may return in the second half of 2016, as it ramps up marketing and rolls out new mobile apps.Match Group in August lowered its 2016 guidance on earnings before taxes due to investments. Shares have been hovering around 17 to 18 after breaking out of a flat base late last month. In trading Friday, shares ended the day up 0.8% to a new closing high of 17.88. Shares managed another high mark on Monday, rising 0.4% to 17.95."We expect to continue to be an R&D shop, a product shop, a technology shop," said Match Group Chief Executive Greg Blatt, on its second-quarter earnings call. "When you look across the category, there is no one else who can come anywhere close to that."Match Group takes in slightly more than 10% of revenue from non-dating services. They include educational websites Tutor.com and the Princeton Review.One of Match Group's worries is the proliferation of free mobile dating apps that may siphon away customers of its older brands, says Goldman Sachs analyst Heath Terry."We believe dating as a category remains in the midst of a transition to freemium models," Terry said in a report. JPMorgan's Doug Anmuth agrees that "cannibalization" of Match Group's older brands by freemium startups is a risk.Free apps may change the online dating industry. The annual revenue growth rate of the online dating industry will slow to 3.7% from 2016 through 2021, down from 4.9% from 2011 to 2016, IBISWorld forecasts.Tinder, too, faces plenty competition from free mobile apps, such as Bumble, Hinge, Happn and Zoosk. Bumble was co-founded by Whitney Wolfe, a former vice president of marketing at Tinder. At Bumble, only women can initiate male-female conversations. Hinge, another Tinder rival, this week updated its mobile app with a $7 monthly fee, aimed at people looking for serious relationships.Many millennials use multiple dating apps at the same time. Rather than pay up for premium Tinder, they could switch to other apps, analysts say.Tinder look-alikes can rely on Facebook links to verify logins. That's one reason competition has intensified amid venture capital funding.Salmon says he doesn't expect Facebook to get into the dating business itself, though he says: "It's always possible."
