Here's your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. There will be an embarrassment of riches as the highest of the highly rated stocks report earnings, including Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL), Gigamon (GIMO), Lumentum (LITE) and Silicon Motion (SIMO). Apple (AAPL) will also unveil new Mac computers. Apple Event Apple…

Any individual investor who's on the lookout for the best stocks to buy -- or a top mutual fund -- can take inspiration from Michael Carmen, a portfolio manager of $4.4 billion Hartford Growth Opportunities (HGOAX).Carmen knows exactly what he likes. He seeks companies with -- to put it simply -- giddyap."We call it ATOM. We look for companies with accelerating tangible operating momentum," Carmen said. That means latching on to good stocks whose revenue growth and margin improvement will both speed up.Those traits open the door to positive earnings surprises and share-price gains.And the fund is an IBD Best Mutual Funds of 2016 award winner, having outperformed the S&P 500 over the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods ended Dec. 31. Only 9% of U.S. diversified stock funds met that standard.Click Here To See A List Of IBD Mutual Fund Quarterly LeadersCarmen is 54 years old and a senior managing director of Wellington Management, subadvisor of Growth Opportunities. His sidekicks on the Opportunities fund are Mario Abularach and Stephen Mortimer. Carmen is also a manager of additional funds, including $1.1 billion Hartford Global Capital Appreciation. From his office in Boston, overlooking the city's historic harbor, he talked with IBD about his investment approach with Opportunities.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Six-Month LeadersIBD: What makes this fund different from rival large-cap growth portfolios?Carmen: We're looking for companies where we have a differentiated view. So even if we find a company with accelerating revenue growth but that's already reflected in the market price, that's not interesting to us. It's interesting when we have a higher view one or two years out than the consensus view. Our approach is less about getting the next quarter right and more about getting the next couple of years right.IBD: How important is valuation in your buy-sell decisions?Carmen: We do have a valuation overlay, which looks at every company's upside case vs. their downside case. We want to skew the portfolio to those companies where the ratio is greater than 2-to-1 on the upside vs. the downside ratio.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Category Performance LeadersIBD: The fund is in the top 3% of its large-cap-growth peer group of mutual funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. over the past five years as of Sept. 30. But year to date, it's in the middle of the pack. Why has this year been so challenging for the fund?Carmen: Investors need to stick to their knitting. The biggest mistake managers make is to meander and try to do the (investment) style du jour. We've stuck to our knitting. But over the past year the style that worked best (seeks) high-stability, low-volatility stocks (in) consumer staples, utilities, telecom services.Those are groups that are typically not in the sweet spot of what we do.IBD: Yet the market has been uniformly favorable to those defensive sectors. Do you expect that to help you?Carmen: Yes, it's been a tale of two markets. January to early February, the market got pummeled after a solid 2015. Stocks we invest in got hit hard. But it was a great buying opportunity for the types of stocks we like. We didn't pivot to safer stocks. We doubled down on companies we like with great long-term prospects. It was one of the better buying opportunities in the last five years.IBD: What were some of your moves earlier this year?Carmen: We sold Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan (JPM) because our thesis on those companies was predicated on interest rates moving back up. But coming out of the second quarter and in view of Brexit, the ability of the Federal Reserve to raise rates in a meaningful manner was compromised.IBD'S TAKE: How will investors react once the Fed finally hikes rates? Understanding the stock market's prevailing trend is a key factor when you are choosing between growth and defensive stock buys. For pointers, visit IBD University.IBD: What buys did you make?Carmen: We added to some positions. We've been buying some Chipotle (CMG) and other stocks like Expedia (EXPE), and we added to Priceline (PCLN).IBD: Facebook's (FB) earnings-per-share growth has sped up for four quarters. Why have you trimmed your exposure in recent disclosures?Carmen: Facebook remains one of our largest holdings, as of Aug. 31. It has been about their ability to monetize mobile traffic. When they first came public, they didn't have a great solution. They finally came up with one, particularly with advertising geared to small and medium-size businesses. But our trims were not fundamentally related. They were to take profits off the table and reinvest in other ideas.IBD: As of your latest disclosure, what's your view on Alibaba (BABA)? You've boosted your stake several portfolio reports in a row.Carmen: They are the premier e-commerce site in China. Investors tried to put them into a U.S. box -- are they Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL)? The answer was all of the above and none of the above. They're a little different.Alibaba's core is a business-to-business platform. Their Taibao is a small/medium business-to-consumer and consumer-to-consumer site. It's a big bazaar. Their Tmall is a brands-to-consumer retail site. They also have a similar product to Amazon Web Services (which is called Alibaba Cloud). And they have investments they (often) don't get credit for.Some people are a little confused by it all. In recent months they've taken steps to make themselves more transparent with financial reporting for each business line. That was a big driver. We added to the stock. When Alphabet and Amazon took steps like that, both stocks took off. We felt Alibaba would make a similar move once investors got more comfortable with the business model.IBD: You've trimmed Amazon recently. Why?Carmen: It's still a big overweight. There isn't a lot we dislike. Over the last 18 months the stock has made a huge move. We like to take profits as a company becomes larger. It puts risk-reward back into balance.IBD: Summarize what you do like there, please.Carmen: What amazes me most is that they are taking 50 cents of each incremental dollar spent online. Regardless of everyone coming at them (with competitive challenges), they have become almost a habit (for online users). And they are willing to take risks. They created their AWS business out of nothing. It is fast-growing, profitable, far ahead of the competition in terms of innovation.IBD: Align Technology (ALGN) is a newcomer to your portfolio. Why?Carmen: They make clear aligners or braces for people's teeth. They're a less invasive way of moving people's teeth (than old-fashioned braces). So they have a great product and great distribution.Their growth rate accelerated. We had a view that this would transpire. We bought it a few quarters ago, and it's up about 50% from our purchase price.IBD: American Tower (AMT) looks like a steady Eddie. Is that why you like it?Carmen: The stock came under pressure last year because growth was slowing. The strong dollar hurt them in emerging markets. But their underlying business is very stable. If they have, let's say, two customers renting space on a tower and a third comes along, that's very profitable because they have fixed costs. Their incremental profits are strong.International markets offer them greater opportunities for upgrades to 4G service. So returns on equity and on invested capital will improve in the next several years, which will reverberate with investors.IBD: You took profits on Alphabet in Q2. What's your view?Carmen: We still have an overweight (vs. the Russell 3000 Growth Index). They have been penalized because their investments (in such things as Care.com (CRMC)) mask the strength and growth of their core search business. So an investor is not compensated now for some investments that could pay off.They just put up one of their strongest quarters in years. They have a run rate (in revenues) of $70 billion and are growing revenue north of 20% last quarter. The stock is inexpensive. At a teens multiple, you're not paying much for the cash on their balance sheet.Their (old) name has become a verb. Not many companies do that. It's a strong position.IBD: I hear you enjoy yoga exercise. How did you get interested? And have you -- you're 5-foot-9 -- given up basketball for exercise?Carmen: I started yoga about 12 years ago in order to increase flexibility and clear my mind. I usually do yoga about twice a week in a good week, and I feel great afterwards. It helps supplement other stuff I do like running, spin and lifting weights.I "retired" from basketball about five or six years ago when I realized that I was one cut away from blowing out my Achilles heel, the bane of older guys' existence. Plus, I was getting hit in the head and legs too much.RELATED:Janus Forty Managers Win With Bets On Proven Champs, Up-And-Comers And Calculated RisksThis Top Mutual Fund Manager Wins With 3 Flavors Of Growth StocksMutual Fund Awards 2016: Top U.S. Equities Funds

Online travel firms Priceline (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE) had their price targets raised, as did e-commerce companies Shopify (SHOP) and IAC/InterActiveCorp (IAC). But Wal-Mart (WMT) had its price target lowered.The web travel agencies received big price target raises by RBC Capital Markets. Analyst Mark Mahaney raised his price target on Priceline to 1750 from 1500. Expedia was raised to 165 from 160. Both have outperform ratings.The changes followed RBC's annual survey of 2,700 internet users. It said Expedia remains far and away the leading online travel agency in the U.S., while both show "very positive consumer value propositions." Of those surveyed, 58% of U.S. travelers reported making an online booking for leisure travel over the past year with 50% stating they expect to use online travel agencies more over the next 12 months.Priceline stock closed down 0.7%at 1,479.82 on the stock market today. Expedia dipped 0.6% at 117.77.Shopify had its price target raised to 52 from 43 by Pacific Crest Securities, with an overweight rating. Merchants use Shopify's software to support sales channels over the web, mobile devices, social media and retail outlets.Pacific Crest analyst Monika Garg in a research note said data and company announcements "increase our confidence in continued momentum in Shopify's business." Among the announcements is that Shopify added new features that enable merchants to sell directly in Facebook (FB) Messenger.Shopify climbed 1.6% to finish at 44.36.The retail giant's price target was lowered to 75 from 76 by RBC Capital, with an underperform rating. The report said Wal-Mart continues to spend heavily on people, processes, and technology to improve its long-term strategic positioning."While it is difficult to move a ship this large, we feel the company is making intelligent moves, including investing in e-commerce and moderating store growth," said RBC analyst Scot Ciccarelli. "Nevertheless, we expect these investments will continue to weigh on earnings growth for the foreseeable future, creating headwinds for Wal-Mart shares."On Thursday, Wal-Mart gave weak guidance and said the pace of store openings will slow as it makes e-commerce investments.Wal-Mart fell 1% to 68.70.IAC/InterActiveCorp had its price target raised to 80 from 74 by Axiom capital, with a buy rating.IAC lost 0.9% to end at 61.55.

Google's push into the online travel market took a new turn Monday as the internet search leader unveiled a new smartphone app, sending shares of Expedia (EXPE), Priceline Group (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) down.The app helps users plan and organize their trips, Google said in a blog post.Expedia stock fell 1.6% in the stock market today and TripAdvisor stock fell 2%, while Priceline stock fell a fraction. Shares of Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) were fell a fraction Monday, to 795.39. Alphabet stock has a possible buy point of 813.98, out of a flat base.While Google might pose a threat to Priceline, Expedia or TripAdvisor, just how far it plans to go in the travel business is unclear. E-commerce leader Amazon.com (AMZN) in 2015 shut down its travel business, Amazon Destinations. A hotel booking site, Amazon Destinations aimed to collect consumer reviews like TripAdvisor, Yelp and Expedia.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Leisure-Travel Book group has been a laggard even before Google's latest move. The group is ranked No. 117 out of 197 industry groups. Priceline is the top-rated stock in the group. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Google in 2015 launched an advertising program called Google Hotel Ads.The smartphone app, called Google Trips, automatically organizes users' travel reservations. The app recommends restaurants, attractions and "local gems" based on data gleaned from other travelers, said Google, which also offers a flight information app. Google bought travel guide publisher Frommer's in 2012.RELATED:Priceline Stock Climbs Late On EPS Beat And Raise

No. 3 online travel agency Expedia (EXPE) is partnering with Washington-based Red Lion Hotels (RLH), but larger chains like Hilton Worldwide (HLT) and Marriott International (MAR) are still guarding their discounted rates.Expedia stock rose 0.3% to close at 112.25 on the stock market today, a day after it announced Red Lion would extend its discounted rates to Expedia customers. Red Lion stock fell 0.45% to6.83.The deal requires Expedia customers to sign up for Red Lion's rewards program and agree to receive Red Lion marketing emails. Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman calls the move a departure from Expedia's typical practice of withholding customer emails.The arrangement "may be considered a major benefit by other hotels looking to boost loyalty program enrollment and direct email marketing lists," Kopelman wrote in a research report. "Expedia noted it is in 'deep discussions' with 'a lot of other chains' about member rates."But the Red Lion deal is technically a test and Expedia could decide to shutter the program. Red Lion is also a smaller chain and has typically supported online travel agencies (OTAs) as marketing partners.IBD'S TAKE: Expedia subsidiaries HomeAway and Trivago are each expected to reach $1 billion in sales next year. Meanwhile, Expedia says it's considering filing an initial public offering for Trivago.Larger chains like Hilton and Marriott have been steadily chipping away at discounts offered by Expedia, Priceline (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) by offering steeper discounts to customers who book directly with the hotel. This allows the hotel to avoid paying OTA fees.Kopelman estimates about half of Expedia's business stems from the hotel chains, while TripAdvisor and Priceline are 40% and 15% exposed, respectively. He reiterated his outperform rating and 135 price target on Expedia stock, which is down 10% in 2016.In related news, TripAdvisor announced Thursday it had acquired New York-based Citymaps, a social mapping platform that helps tourists "uncover hidden gems and hot spots." The terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.TripAdvisor stock eased less than 0.1% to 61.90 Thursday. Priceline rose 0.4% to 1,415.64.RELATED:Priceline, TripAdvisor Jerked Ahead Of Earnings On Sabre's Mixed Q2Priceline, Expedia Call Truce On Google Battle; But Airbnb Clash Due

This week's noteworthy insider transactions were led by executives from Netflix (NFLX), United Airlines (UAL), Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Nvidia (NVDA) and GoPro (GPRO).Director Richard Barton, who is also executive chairman of the Zillow Group (Z) and founder of Expedia (EXPE), filed for the sale and options exercise of 6,300 shares of Netflix. The shares were valued at $630,000.While the streaming service's shows are well-reviewed, its stock hasn't been a big hit lately, and there are several reasons why its latest breakout wasn't a winner.Netflix dipped 0.3% for the week.CFO Andrew Levy, appointed to the position last month as part of other recent leadership moves, acquired 15,000 shares of the carrier.Late last month, United named Scott Kirby as its president. Kirby had until then been the president of American Airlines (AAL).United shares rose 2.7% this week.CEO Jen Hsun Huang was active this week, with the sale and options exercise of 43,727 shares worth $2.75 million, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.Nvidia shares lost 4.8% for the week.Director Dennis Eck acquired 11,000 shares of the specialty beauty retailer, according to a Thursday SEC filing. That follows last week's sales by CEO Mary Dillon and CFO Scott Settersten.The company recently bested quarterly expectations while issuing slightly cautious guidance. Shares on Aug. 26 sliced below their 50-day line in heavy volume, tumbling 6.1% that day.Ulta shares retreated 3.1% this week.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia and Ulta Beauty are two featured stocks on the IBD 50, a flagship screen of leading growth stocks.The action-camera maker's president, Anthony Bates, was also active in the last week with the sale and options exercise of 9,704 shares valued at $137,389.The latest Apple (AAPL) iPhone appears to have a pretty heavy-duty camera for a smartphone, and that could dissuade consumers from shopping for a GoPro, said Pacific Crest on Wednesday.Shares gapped down 9.1% vs. a week ago.RELATED:Apple iPhone 7 Camera Improvements Rile GoProUnited Airlines 'Aggression' Seen With Kirby; Hawaiian Tries BreakoutDear Millennial Investor: Focus On What You Know, But Also The Stock Chart Do Male Investors Not 'Get' Ulta Beauty And The Beauty Business?

Priceline (PCLN) executives impressed analysts by addressing -- and mostly shrugging off -- global economic concerns, including the "scourge of terrorism," with the online travel company's shares rising Friday after it posted a Q2 earnings beat late Thursday.Priceline EPS guidance for Q3 also exceeded Wall Street estimates, with executives on the company's earnings conference call "noting that while there was some

uncertainty due to prevailing economic conditions and the 'scourge of terrorism,' business was not expected to be materially impacted," Benchmark analyst Daniel Kurnos said in a research note Friday.Kurnos also wrote that Priceline's comment "stands in sharp contrast to Expedia's (EXPE) more cautious outlook" in that company's earnings comments last week. Kurnos hiked his price target on Priceline stock to 1600 from 1440.Priceline stock closed 4% higher at 1414.22 in the stock market today, hitting a nine-month high and rising back into a buy zone from a June 6 breakout from a flat base.IBD'S TAKE: Priceline Relative Price Strength -- which looks at stock performance against all stocks over the past 12 months, with an emphasis on the most recent six months -- is not good, at 64. But all other metrics get a green, as you can see in IBD's Stock Checkup."Against a fear of cautious management commentary on macro/competition, PCLN delivered an earnings report that demonstrated across-the-board strength," UBS analyst Eric Sheridan wrote in a research report Friday. He hiked his price target on Priceline stock to 1600 from 1475, citing the company's "best-in-class" execution.Priceline late Thursday said Q2 EPS ex items and sales each rose 12% from Q2 2015, to $13.93 and $2.56 billion, respectively. Revenue, though, fell just shy of analyst estimates. Priceline guided to Q3 revenue rising 14.5% at the midpoint of its outlook, meeting the views of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Priceline's web properties include travel sites Priceline.com, Booking.com and Kayak.com, as well as restaurant reservations service OpenTable.Late Wednesday, online travel review service TripAdvisor (TRIP) missed Wall Street's targets for Q2 sales and earnings. TripAdvisor stock fell 8.5% Thursday and lost another 4.4% Friday. Expedia stock dipped 0.25%.

Travel stocks retreated Tuesday ahead of Priceline (PCLN) and TripAdvisor's (TRIP) second-quarter earnings later this week after Sabre (SABR), a provider of tech services for the travel industry, posted a mixed quarterly report.IBD's 10-company Leisure-Travel Booking industry group dropped 1.2%, approaching its 50-day moving average, at the close on the stock market today. Stocks were hurt by an 8.3% plunge in Sabre shares, which fell to 26.86.Early Tuesday, Sabre reported $845.2 million in sales, missing views for $849.7 million. Its 37 cents earnings per share, however, topped the 35-cent consensus of 12 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.IBD'S TAKE: Priceline stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 93, meaning it's performing among the top 7% of all stocks in terms of key metrics. It's ranked first in its 10-company industry group. The group has climbed to No. 79 out of 197 groups tracked, from No. 180 over 13 weeks.Priceline stock slipped 0.8% to 1,345.38. For Q2, analysts expect Priceline on Thursday to report $2.58 billion in sales and $12.69 EPS ex items, up 13% and 2%, respectively, vs. last year.EPS would brake following three quarters of acceleration, including robust 30% year-over-year growth in Q1. Sales accelerated the prior two quarters, rising 17% in Q1.After a Q2 slowdown, the consensus of 30 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters sees both metrics re-accelerating in Q3 to midteens growth.TripAdvisor stock finished trading down 1.5% Tuesday to 69.41. For Q2, TripAdvisor is expected to report late Wednesday $402.85 million in sales and 42 cents EPS ex items, flat and down 22%, respectively, vs. the year-earlier period.Both metrics are re-accelerating from Q1. The consensus of 25 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters sees a robust return to growth in Q3.Last Thursday, online travel site Expedia (EXPE) posted a mixed Q2, including a $150 million sales miss partially offset by major growth in its HomeAway and Trivago segments. The company said it's exploring an initial public offering for Trivago.Expedia fell 3.3% to 113.55.

In what could be the first of many such moves in the hotel industry, Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT) on Friday said it will spin off most of its real estate business into a publicly traded real estate investment trust (REIT) and will also split off its timeshare business, Hilton Grand Vacations, into a separate, publicly traded company.The spin-offs are designed to increase shareholder value at Hilton, which owns brands such as Waldorf Astoria and Embassy Suites. The moves not only should increase Hilton’s combined market value, analysts say. They also would reduce the amount of capital Hilton has to pour into its non-hotel businesses.The upshot is that Hilton Worldwide can focus solely on managing its hotels business, hoping it will help it better compete against direct rivals such as Marriott International (MAR), Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) and Wyndham Worldwide (WYN), as well as online travel sites like Priceline Group (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE) and Airbnb.“The transactions we announced today will result in three pure-play companies, enabling dedicated management teams to fully activate their respective businesses, taking advantage of both organic and inorganic growth opportunities as well as capital market and tax efficiencies,” Chief Executive Christopher Nassetta said in a prepared statement. “We intend to have the appropriate leadership, strategies and capital structures in place to set up all three companies for further success.”Hilton Worldwide’s newly formed real estate company will include around 70 properties and 35,000 rooms, the company said, while the timeshare business will manage nearly 50 club resorts in the U.S. and Europe. If the spin-offs pay off for Hilton, other hotel companies with a diverse range of assets, including Marriott and Starwood, might feel pressure to follow suit.Meanwhile, Hilton also reported fourth-quarter results on Friday. Adjusted earnings came in at 22 cents a share, up 22% from the prior year and in line with the consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue climbed 1% to $2.86 billion, below views for $2.96 billion.Shares of Hilton closed up 2.5% on the stock market today. Marriott’s dipped 0.2%, while Starwood added 0.4% and Wyndham increased 1.3%.Shares of Priceline lost 0.7%, while Expedia stock gained 0.3%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Ongoing negative themes in the online travel sector have convinced Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman to lower his price target on three of the largest firms in the business, according to a research note sent to investors on Monday.Due to the possibility of a global recession, problems with the Chinese economy, weaker U.S. hotel metrics and geopolitical turmoil such as the shootings in Paris and the Zika virus in Latin America, "the issues paint a bleak backdrop of online travel agency reporting season," Kopelman wrote.Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline (PCLN) have additional exposure to Airbnb -- a San Francisco-based startup that lets people rent their homes, apartments or rooms online. Though at the moment Airbnb "is experiencing unprecedented growth," it hasn't begun to "de-rail" online travel agencies (OTAs)."While Airbnb is clearly affecting pricing in gateway cities, esp. on peak nights, we estimate Airbnb will only have cannibalized about 2% of lodging industry demand growth cumulatively by year-end 2016."Kopelman favors Priceline over Expedia because its financials are sound and it has a proven track record and strong quarterly earnings. Also, Kopelman says, Priceline offers detailed quarterly guidance, which he believes is a significant benefit "in the current environment." He dropped the Priceline price target from 1500 to 1290.Priceline rose 1.9% to 1084.87 in the stock market today.For its part, Expedia, Kopelman says, is going to have "messy results" clouded by its Orbitz and HomeAway acquisitions. Expedia lifted 1.1% to 102.15, and Kopelman dropped its price target from 180 to 135.The investment bank adjusted its outlook for TripAdvisor (TRIP), dropped the price target from 70 to 65.TripAdvisor's implementation of its instant bookings feature has been costly for the firm and left "little visibility into near-term results," Kopelman wrote.Needham analyst Laura Martin does not think TripAdvisor's prospects for Q4 earnings are good."The stock we worry most about in a bear market in 2016 is TripAdvisor, owing to its 1) travel-based revenue risk; 2) near-term investment requirements; 3) growing corporate complexity; 4) mobile monetization gap; and 5) instant booking adoption."TripAdvisor gained 0.6% to 67.19 in the stock market today. The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 56, while 99 is the highest.

Goldman Sachs analyst Heath Terry downgraded Priceline to neutral from buy and cut its price target to 1,200. Priceline is well positioned for Asia growth, Terry wrote in his research report,…

Several tech companies reporting earnings over the latest week lifted in the stock market Friday as major stock indexes perked 1% to 2%. It's been a volatile trading week amid a market in correction.Twitter (TWTR) vaulted 11% Friday, closing at 15.88 and erasing the week's losses around its fourth quarter report that showed slowing user growth. It's tweaking its user interface to be a little more like Facebook (FB), which currently gets a top stock rating from IBD: a best-possible Composite Rating of 99. (See the video for who's highly rated or not, and more on the week's earnings reports.)Akamai (AKAM) lifted 3.3% in the stock market today after surging earlier in the week on its quarterly report. IRobot (IRBT) rose 4.6%. Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Yelp (YELP) gained close to 2% each.Pandora Media (P) plunged 12% Friday, amid a declining number of users for the streaming music service revealed in its quarterly report Thursday, plus competition from Apple (AAPL), highly rated Alphabet (GOOGL) (with a 99 IBD Composite Rating) and Amazon (AMZN) in its business."Pandora's core profitability appears challenged by higher royalties and diminishing productivity gains, and its new service efforts appear expensive given the poor history of profits in the space," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Andy Hargreaves said in a research report.Security firm CyberArk (CYBR) fell 10.8% for the day. Travel sites TripAdvisor (TRIP) and Expedia (EXPE) gave back 1.9% and 1.1%, respectively, on Friday. (Both rose Thursday.) Tesla Motors (TSLA) edged up 0.4% Friday.Before Friday's action, tech companies whose stocks had lifted this week around their quarterly reports included Cisco, Akamai and TripAdvisor, with big jumps, as well as Tesla and Expedia. On the downside were Pandora, iRobot, CyberArk, Yelp and Twitter.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Is digital currency bitcoin in Netflix's (NFLX) future as the Internet video streamer goes global? Netflix on Jan. 6 announced its expansion to 130 new countries, bringing its total to 190 countries worldwide. The same day, CFO David Wells brought up Bitcoin during a Q&A at a Citigroup investor conference in Las Vegas.Satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), Dell, Expedia (EXPE) and Overstock.com (OSTK) are among U.S. companies that accept bitcoin in transactions.Netflix, meanwhile, faces challenges as it expands its video streaming service globally. Acquiring content rights is a biggie, but payments and pricing are other issues. Netflix plans to roll out its service in China later this year.Netflix accepts payments in some local currencies, Wells noted at the Citigroup conference. The Netflix CFO says Netflix has aimed to keep pricing comparable to the U.S., where its service starts at $8 monthly.Wells says it's possible that Netflix may offer wireless-only subscriptions in some countries where mobile broadband is actually faster than fixed-line Internet services.Wells says Netflix aims to keep its log-in procedure and payment systems as simple as possible as it expands to more countries."The world in general from an e-commerce perspective is balancing security and fraud detection with friction-less sign-up," Wells said.Bitcoin, a decentralized, peer-to-peer, digital-payment network, is not designed for recurring payments and the digital currency is non-refundable. Still, it may work better in the future with payment systems such as PayPal (PYPL), some analysts say."You have to authenticate, you have to make sure you have the right person, the right bank account, but you don't want to run people through a 20-step process, because that's not going to work," Wells added.Wells has learned from rolling out its service in markets such as Mexico, Brazil and parts of Europe, he says."Payments are becoming more of a global world," said the CFO. "You still have central banks. We'll see where we go from here in the next 10, 15 years. Countries still want to hold onto their monetary policy. But, it sure would be nice to have bitcoin in terms of a global currency that you could use globally."Follow Reinhardt Krause on Twitter @IBD_RKrause.

Expedia (EXPE) and Airbnb are being sued for patent infringement in federal court in the Easter District of Texas by a tech company called Encoditech. Encoditech is accusing both firms of illegally infringing on the "encryption technologies" claimed in the patent. The patent in question was granted in 2001 and originally filed by a Colorado man, Sherman Gavette. It is…

The story for online travel in 2016 is consolidation. As it stands, Priceline and Expedia control more than two-thirds of the market, show no signs of giving up the gains and, if anything, will continue to gobble up more small firms — it's impossible for the tiny companies to compete with either of the giants, according to analysts. But Priceline's…
Expedia (EXPE) completed its acquisition of alternative lodgings company HomeAway (AWAY) on Tuesday, paving the way for more competition with Airbnb.

The purchase comes as the lodging industry is evolving, with Airbnb creating what analysts say is a new market from untapped traveler demand and unused inventory. Investors have valued privately held Airbnb upward of $25 billion, though mutual funds have been criticized for the methods used to value such private companies.
At $3.9 billion, this is Expedia's largest acquisition yet. The company announced the deal on Nov. 5.

HomeAway is the closest thing to a competitor to Airbnb in alternative accommodations. Airbnb is a website that people use to rent out their home or apartment, or rooms in their home or apartment. HomeAway, though, focuses more on vacation rental properties.

"This is a business that does (an) estimated $15 billion of vacation rental bookings, which is substantially larger than Airbnb, currently, and is monetizing the 3% to 4%, vs. Airbnb at 10% to 12%," Expedia CFO Mark Okerstrom said at the Credit Suisse Technology, Media & Telecom Conference in December, talking about HomeAway. "We think there's huge opportunity there.

"... to the extent that the Airbnb-type inventory becomes a true substitute for the mainstream lodging product, I think, for us, the HomeAway acquisition provides not only a perfect hedge but a perfect opportunity to actually go after that new market."
Okerstrom also called Airbnb a "threat" that Expedia takes "seriously."

Expedia announced the HomeAway acquisition on the same day as an Airbnb political victory in San Francisco, where it spent $8 million to defeat a ballot measure that would have tightened regulations. Analysts called the victory both meaningful and meaningless — meaningless in part because the staunchly Democratic city is a relatively small market, but meaningful because of the precedent that it set and the nature of the debate preceding the vote.

RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney has said that Expedia's largest competitor, Priceline (PCLN), is well-hedged in the alternative accommodations space. That online travel agency is growing its inventory of alternative lodgings, currently at 361,000 properties on Booking.com, by 80% year over year, according to Mahaney.

Sometimes it's tough to cut out the middleman. In a world where personal travel agents are a "Mad Men"-style relic and consumers are savvier about Googling deals online, one might think travel intermediary Sabre Corp. (SABR) is at risk of going the way of indoor smoking and three-martini lunches. But the company's vast network and information technology strength have put…

Airbnb is a fast-emerging travel accommodations disrupter valued at $25 billion — but it had a humble beginning. When co-founders Brian Chesky and Joe Gebbia couldn't pay their San Francisco rent, they bought three air mattresses and launched a website to rent each mattress for $80 a night. When they found takers, the proverbial light bulb went off.The company runs a website where traveler "hosts" rent their homes and apartments — or rooms in their homes and apartments — to travelers for short stays of usually a month or less. Airbnb generated Q3 revenue of $340 million on bookings of $2.2 billion, according to a presentation to investors leaked to the Wall Street Journal.The company is losing some $150 million a year, reported the WSJ, but it's also nipping at the heals of online travel agencies (OTAs) such as Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline (PCLN), upending hotel chains such as Hilton (HLT) and Marriott (MAR) and helping establish a regulatory beachhead in the 34,000 cities where it boasts listings, which could also help rivals such as HomeAway (AWAY)."The online travel agencies and (Priceline's) Bookings.com in particular have said they are happy to let Airbnb blaze the (regulatory) trail and bear a lot of those costs," Douglas Quinby, an analyst with online travel research firm Phocuswright, told IBD. "The big OTAs see opportunities, but they would prefer to let Airbnb drive the regulations."Airbnb's staunchly Democratic home city of San Francisco has been a battlefield for crafting regulations for Airbnb and similar businesses. Those regulations include requiring such firms to pay hotel taxes and limiting how long hosts can rent out their homes or apartments.Critics have hammered on the company's strategy of begging for forgivingness vs. asking for permission, meaning they start up operations in a city and only respond to concerns as they surface.But the company notched a big win in a November election, when San Francisco voters resoundingly rejected Proposition F, a restrictive measure that, among other provisions, would force Airbnb to provide a quarterly report saying how many days hosts had listed their properties for rent. Prop F would have limited that 75 days a year, and make violations a misdemeanor.After the dust settled, with Airbnb spending $8 million to defeat the item, the question remains: What does the vote mean for Airbnb and the travel industry?"On the one hand, it's an important win in a key market — the birthplace of Airbnb," Quinby said. "On the other hand, it's kind of meaningless because regulations are all being decided on a local level. And there's no reason to think that because San Francisco does one thing, someone else wouldn't do another."OTAs Say Impact 'Immaterial'On Oct. 29, Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshaki brushed off Airbnb's impact on his company, speaking on Expedia's earnings conference call. Less than a week later, Expedia announced an agreement to acquire the closest thing Airbnb has to a competitor in public markets: HomeAway. Unlike Airbnb, HomeAway's focus is more tightly centered around renting out entire homes for long vacations. HomeAway, founded in 2005, is valued near $3.48 billion and is expected to end the year with revenue of $500 million. But unlike Airbnb, HomeAway makes money. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimate it will end 2015 with an operating profit of $102.5 million.Expedia decline to comment for this story."It's disingenuous to say that (Airbnb is) not having an impact," T. Rowe Price (TROW) portfolio manager Joe Fath told IBD. "I tend to pay attention to what companies do, instead of what they say."Fath manages T. Rowe Price's Growth Stock Fund .The fund bought private stock in Airbnb more than two years ago and has hiked its stake's value some 150% since then. Fath is looking for a "home run" from Airbnb. "Supply is Airbnb's biggest constraint," he said.Analyst Quinby agrees."Without question Airbnb has been a phenomenon in the travel industry over the last several years," he said. "They've created an entirely new category in the travel industry. In 2011, 10% of U.S. travelers stayed in private accommodations. In 2014, that number was up to 25%."For a second straight year, an RBC Capital Markets survey found that one-third of respondents said they have used some form of alternative accommodations, such as Airbnb or HomeAway subsidiary VRBO.One of Fath's largest holdings is Priceline, which he acknowledged hasn't been performing that well in the last 12 months. But he expects the stock will perform better.Also, Priceline is "well hedged" against Airbnb and similar firms because of its growing inventory of alternative lodgings, says RBC analyst Mark Mahaney. In a recent research note, he said Priceline's inventory of 361,000 properties is up 80% over the past year.Hyper-Local Regulations BattleThe regulations fight for short-term rentals is hyper local. The hotels and short-term rentals field isn't regulated federally and there are few state laws, so companies must work with each municipality. But while the impact of the San Francisco vote was geographically limited, it was closely watched because of the precedent it would set.Airbnb "needed to fight this because ... if Proposition F passed, it would have stymied their ability to do business," Ed Zitron, an SF-based tech public relations executive uninvolved in the Prop F election, told IBD. "A defeat would have ... scared investors."The Airbnb win was a loss for the hotel industry, which led the fight to pass the measure. Still, the benefit of Prop F is that a lot of issues got aired "in a public forum," Troy Flanagan, vice president of state and local affairs for the American Hotel and Lodging Association, told IBD. "This is one of the first times, if not the first time, such a comprehensive proposal for online, modern short-term rentals was floated. It was a public, open debate in the hometown of Airbnb."People renting out multiple units are hoteliers, but they aren't being held to the same standards (as hoteliers)."Airbnb, in fact, says it currently collects taxes only in 24 cities in two states, according to a spokesman.When IBD asked Airbnb what the stakes were in the Prop F vote, company spokesman Christopher Nulty wrote in an email that "Proposition F was a hotel-funded campaign attempting to scare San Franciscans into believing this measure would do a single thing to address affordability in San Francisco. We remain committed to working with policymakers across the country and around the globe to develop smart, common sense regulations that allow regular people to share their homes while contributing to their communities."Airbnb declined to make any executive available for this story. But CEO Chesky told Re/Code that losing the S.F. vote would have hurt. "... You can win 10 cities in Europe but you lose your home city and it basically just seems like you're losing ground completely," Re/Code quoted Chesky saying. "We have 130,000 members (hosts and guests) in San Francisco. They ended up winning the ballot, not us. I used to say they're on the ballot, not us. Because we're going to be in 33,999 cities and they're the ones really at stake here, for us it's more of a brand issue."Affordable housing is a huge issue in San Francisco and the greater Bay Area amid skyrocketing rents and home prices, so renting out a room can help a homeowner.HomeAway says its preferred tactic is to train property owners and managers to lobby their city governments, rather than get embroiled in a Prop F-type election."That's our traditional path," Matt Curtis, HomeAway's director of government relations, told IBD. "We don't do campaign donations."Curtis agrees with Airbnb that Prop F was too restrictive, and he says HomeAway wants to ensure "fair and effective" regulations in cities where the company operates."Communities that have chosen to make burdensome restrictions have driven short-term rental activity underground," Curtis said. So, those businesses are "not paying taxes, operating outside the existing framework."

As global economies continue to wrestle with weak or stagnant growth, the travel industry has remained a hot spot of consumer spending. One of the high-temperature segments of the business is the $1.3 trillion-a-year travel booking industry. Online brokers and travel-deal sites, which own about a third of that picture, have maintained strong standing over the past six months among…

For many investors, 2015 was the year of FANG stocks: Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google, now a unit of Alphabet (GOOGL).Investment bank RBC Capital Markets believes 2016 could be the year for BAGEL stocks: Alibaba (BABA), Amazon, Google, Expedia (EXPE) and LinkedIn (LNKD).As of Wednesday, the FANG stocks are up an average of 81% this year. RBC believes those companies as well as other large-cap Internet stocks like Alibaba, Expedia, LinkedIn and Priceline (PCLN)will show strength in 2016."While valuations today aren't nearly as compelling as they were going into 2015, we remain very positive on fundamental trends, view valuations as offering modest upside, and believe 2016 could be the year of the BAGEL: BABA, AMZN, GOOGL, EXPE and LNKD," RBC analysts said in a report Wednesday.Those large-cap Internet companies are benefiting from their massive scale, deep competitive moats and "extraordinarily large secular growth opportunities," RBC said.Some of those companies have "enormous new market opportunities," such as Amazon with Amazon Web Services and Alphabet with Google's autonomous vehicles. Others have "very large monetization veins," such as Facebook with messaging; Expedia and Priceline with alternative accommodations; Alibaba with mobile; and Netflix with international expansion.RBC sees demand growth continuing to boost the leading companies in online advertising (Google and Facebook), online retail (Amazon) and online travel (Expedia and Priceline).For 2016, RBC forecasts global advertising revenue rising 17% to $189 billion, global online retail sales climbing 22% to $2 trillion and global online leisure travel increasing 9% to $534 billion.RBC lists the BAGEL stocks as its "top large cap picks" for 2016. It has price targets of 95 for Alibaba (vs. Wednesday's close of 84.63), 775 for Amazon (vs. 675.77) , 880 for Alphabet (vs. 776.59), 180 for Expedia (vs. 131.16) and 300 for LinkedIn (vs. 234.51).Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter @IBD_PSeitz and on Facebook.

Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline (PCLN) continue to take different approaches in handling the competitive threat from Airbnb, says RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney.While Expedia executives continue to describe Airbnb's impact as "immaterial" — though less than a week later announcing an agreement to acquire Airbnb home-rental competitor HomeAway (AWAY) — Priceline has been willing to acknowledge the potential impact to online travel agency growth, Mahaney wrote in a research note.Calling Airbnb the "800-pound elephant in the room," Mahaney wrote in a research note late Sunday that "an average adult elephant weighs more like 10,000 pounds, so our point here is that Airbnb is still developing a presence."We do believe Airbnb to be a competitive headwind to Priceline and Expedia but believe the market opportunity is large enough to support all three players. We increasingly view Airbnb as creating a double whammy for online travel agencies, both by drawing away consumer demand and by putting pressure on hotel average daily rates."Expedia stock fell 1.1% Monday, while Priceline stock fell 1.3%.The analyst, commenting on last week's Phocuswright Online Travel Conference, one of the largest in the industry, was that Airbnb is no longer an "alternative" accommodation. The Airbnb website is used by people looking to rent a home or a part of a home for various lengths of stays. Citing yet-to-be released data from a new Phocuswright survey of 800 Airbnb users, he says the study found that 95% of respondents considered Airbnb as an option along with hotels, vacation rentals and other forms of inventory.Surveys See CompetitionThe results were consistent with a study RBC conducted in September. For a second straight year, the RBC survey found that one-third of respondents said they have used some form of alternative accommodations, such as Airbnb or HomeAway subsidiary VRBO. Airbnb was the largest source of alternative-accommodations bookings, with 23% of respondents saying they used it. VRBO's share fell to 17% from 32% in last year's survey.Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshahi said at the conference that Airbnb's growth rate is more likely to add new business to the industry rather than cannibalize existing booking options, Mahaney wrote."Our major concern with Expedia is with the company's (over?)reliance on mergers and acquisitions as a growth strategy," Mahaney wrote, adding that the concern is offset by execution and financials.Priceline has a substantial alternative-accommodations inventory of some 6.6 million rooms around the world, Mahaney wrote.Meanwhile, at the conference TripAdvisor (TRIP) told attendees that its transition to its instant booking feature is going to be a "multi-, multi-year transition," Mahaney wrote. "We continue to view TripAdvisor as a great asset embarking on a risky strategy."TripAdvisor stock fell a fraction Monday.

Delta Air Lines (DAL), Priceline (PCLN), Carnival (CCL) and other travel-related stocks were down Tuesday after the State Department issued a global travel warning late Monday in the wake of the attacks in Paris and the lockdown in Brussels. The travel alert will run until February as "ISIL (aka Daesh), al-Qaida, Boko Haram and other terrorist groups continue to plan…

Stocks rallied to session highs despite a sell-off by travel stocks in the wake of the tragic events Friday in Paris. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each gained 1%, while the Nasdaq rose 0.9%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. the same time Friday.

Automakers, defense contractors and energy stocks were among the biggest gainers in the stock market today. Lockheed Martin (LMT) advanced 3%, Northrop Grumman (NOC) 4% and Raytheon (RTN) 4%, to a new record best.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose 3% in slow trade. The stock is still well below its 50-day and 200-day moving average lines. But Ferrari (RACE) skidded 3% to trade lower than its Oct. 21 offering price of 52. JPMorgan began covering the race car maker with a neutral rating, while UBS gave it a buy.

Department stores, biotech and travel stocks underperformed. Priceline (PCLN) gapped down and fell 3% as it sought support at its 200-day moving average. The stock is now 14% off its Nov. 5 intraday high. On Nov. 9, it dropped 10% after its Q4 guidance missed views.

Expedia (EXPE) gave up 3%, falling well below its 50-day line for the first time since late September; it was on track to extend its losing streak to seven sessions. Among major airlines, Delta Air Lines (DAL) shed 3%, American Airlines Group (AAL) 2% and United Continental (UAL) 2%.

The hotel sector saw plenty of activity as well. Marriott International (MAR) reversed slightly higher from an early 3% slump. It's paying $12.2 billion to buy Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT), which fell 4% in heavy volume. Hilton Worldwide (HLT) slid 3% in brisk trade.
On the IBD 50 , Noah Holdings (NOAH) led with a 6% jump to halt a five-session slide, while Universal Insurance (UVE) was the biggest loser, down 3%.

Expedia (EXPE), Priceline (PCLN) and other travel stocks were down in afternoon trading today in the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday. "There's always an immediate kind of knee-jerk reaction in the market," said Douglas Quinby, an analyst at travel market research company Phocuswright. "This is a short-term blip. A lot of these things you have to…
Priceline stock, which hit a record high Thursday, tumbled 9.6% Monday after the online travel company's Q4 guidance missed Wall Street expectations.

Early Monday, the firm said its revenue rose 9.2% from the year-earlier quarter to $3.1 billion, edging the $3.05 billion consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Earnings per share minus items rose 14% to $25.35, above views of $24.23.
But for Q4, Priceline (PCLN) expects EPS of $11.10 to $11.90, up 6% from Q4 2014 at the midpoint but well below Wall Street's expectation of $12.38.
Priceline sees its Q4 revenue rising 1% to 8%, to $1.86 billion to $1.99 billion, vs. views of $2.04 billion.

"We are incrementally less enthusiastic on Priceline," RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney wrote in a research note Monday, citing slowing international bookings growth and total hotel room nights sold. RBC cut its target price on the stock to 1,700 from 1,725.

But Mahaney said Priceline's approach to growth — a push in the Chinese and Latin American markets and alternative accommodations — suggests "growth rates should be sustainable for a substantial period. Priceline continues to execute well, though beginning to slow, largely, we believe, as a result of its massive size." Since 2006, Priceline's top line has grown eightfold.
Priceline said its Q3 bookings rose 6.9% as international gains offset a slowdown in America. Bookings, though, fell 1.2% from Q2, hurt by a soft U.S. market.

But the U.S. is a relatively small market for Norwalk, Conn.- based Priceline. Non-U.S. gross bookings accounted for $13.08 billion of the Q3 tally, vs. just $1.7 billion for the U.S. That makes the strong U.S. dollar a bigger issue for Priceline.
On a constant currency basis, bookings rose 25% year over year, but they rose just 8.3% at the quarter's exchange rate.

For the first time, Priceline disclosed that it has about 21 million potentially bookable rooms in all, about two-thirds in traditional hotels. Assuming a 70% occupancy rate, Mahaney wrote, Priceline accounts for about 3% of global bookings. He said 3% leaves much room for growth.
Priceline closed Monday at 1,311, down 11% from Thursday's all-time high of 1,476.

"The Priceline Group delivered strong growth and operating results during its high travel season," Priceline CEO Darren Huston said in the company's earnings release. "We will continue to focus on making the right investments across our six brands — in people, systems and demand — to continue to profitably grow our business."

Last week, after Expedia (EXPE) announced a deal to acquire alternative accommodations firm HomeAway (AWAY), Priceline said it did not intend to make a bid, Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman wrote in a research note Friday.

He said any new bid for HomeAway was "extremely unlikely," even from privately held Airbnb, which rents homes or rooms in private homes via its website. Phocuswright analyst Douglas Quinby says that last year, 25% of U.S. travelers said they stayed in private accommodations. And for a second straight year, an RBC poll found that one-third of respondents said that they have used some form of alternative accommodations such as Airbnb.

On Priceline's earnings conference call, Huston said that his company offers 1.8 million bookable home vacation rental rooms, "in the ballpark of HomeAway and Airbnb."Priceline stock, which hit a record high Thursday, tumbled 9.6% Monday after the online travel company's Q4 guidance missed Wall Street expectations.Early Monday, the firm said its revenue rose 9.2% from the year-earlier quarter to $3.1 billion, edging the $3.05 billion consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%. Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.

Stock were mixed in light volume, but travel websites and airlines were sharply lower in the aftermath of the Paris attack. The Nasdaq fell less than 0.2%, while the S&P 500 rose nearly 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained close to 0.3% in the stock market today. Volume was running lower on both exchanges.

Travel websites were the worst performing industry group among 197 tracked by IBD. Priceline (PCLN), already reeling from a disappointing earnings report, gapped down and was trading 4% lower. It was trying to find support at its 200-day moving average. Expedia (EXPE) was also down 4% and sliced through its 50-day moving average. Chinese travel site Ctrip.com (CTRP) dropped 3%.

Those moves made the travel booking industry group the day's worst performer among 197 groups. Airlines were also among the day's worst performers. American Airlines Group (AAL) was trading 3% lower, and United Continental (UAL) was down 2%.

European markets were quiet in the aftermath of Friday's terrorist attack. The euro fell 0.5%, but was holding above $1.07. iShares Europe, a widely followed U.S. ETF that tracks European stock markets, rose 0.2%. U.S. Treasuries and the U.S. dollar index rose moderately.
Universal Insurance (UVE) dropped 5%. It has now retraced a 29% increase from a breakout from a cup-with-handle base Sept. 30.
A 2% gain by Tesla Motors (TSLA) helped make auto manufacturers the top-performing group out of a 197.

Stocks were modestly higher in choppy fashion after bouncing back from a lower start Monday. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2% each while the Nasdaq was fractionally higher in the stock market today. Volume was tracking lower across the board compared with the same time Friday.
In stocks, Noah (NOAH) and Paycom Software (PAYC) rallied 4% and nearly 3%, respectively, leading the upside action in the IBD 50. The latter retook a 41.68 buy point.

JD.com (JD) rallied 7% as its Q4 sales outlook offset weaker-than-expected Q3 results. Revenue for the current quarter is expected between at 51 billion renminbi to 52.5 billion renminbi. Views are for 50.5 billion renminbi.

Travel-related stocks were under pressure following Friday's attacks in Paris. Priceline (PCLN) fell 3% in fast trade, putting it further below its 50-day line breach in huge trade last week. The stock slid more than 8% below a 1394.10 buy point from a consolidation, marking a sell signal.
Rival Expedia (EXPE) gapped below its 50-day line and lost 3.5% before cutting losses.
Delta Air Lines (DAL) dropped nearly 3%. It fell below its 50-day line and a 48.40 buy point from a consolidation.
American Airlines (AAL) and United Continental (UAL) each lost 2%.

Software maker Nuance Communications (NUAN) and apparel retailer Urban Outfitters (URBN) are a couple of notable firms reporting earnings after the close. Ahead of its quarterly results, Urban announced plans to buy the Vetri Family group of restaurants. Shares were off their session lows, but still down more than 4%.

Some familiar leaders from the Leisure sector are making waves, pushing leisure industry groups into the top 40 of IBD's rankings. Shares of Priceline Group (PCLN) broke out in low volume past a 1264.10 buy point Monday.
The stock stalled a bit, but held up well on Tuesday when the Nasdaq plunged 1.5% in heavy trading.
Priceline, which is No. 48 in Wednesday's IBD 50 list, has earnings due Thursday before the market open.
Analysts are looking for a slight decline in earnings per share and a 10% increase in revenues.

The stock hit an all-time high in March 2014 and has been in a year-long consolidation since then. Priceline's current cup base rounded out over nine weeks and corrected just 11%. It's part of a larger base-within-a-base structure. Shares are still trading near the 1264.10 entry.
Investors should be cautious holding a stock without a profit cushion into an earnings report.
This is especially the case in light of recent high-profile declines from stocks like LinkedIn (LNKD), Twitter (TWTR) and Harman International Industries (HAR).
On April 30, rival Expedia (EXPE) reported a 3-cent-per-share loss and revenue growth of 14%.
Shares reacted positively the following session, bouncing off the 50-day line and gapping to a record high. The stock is extended from a consolidation breakout in February.

Chinese online travel companies Qunar Cayman Islands (QUNR) and Ctrip.com International (CTRP) have strong sales growth and recent price action, but have posted earnings losses in recent quarters. Qunar is well extended from a cup-with-handle breakout in March. Ctrip.com is shaping a handle with a 67.56 buy point in an excessively deep cup base.

The Leisure-Movies and Related group also has shot up in the rankings, thanks in large part to Netflix's (NFLX) recent surge. The movie-streaming giant gapped up 18% on April 16 after reporting first-quarter results. Earnings declined in the period, but investors were enthusiastic about better-than-expected subscriber growth.
Shares are holding near highs and are close to a 20% profit target, past a 486.60 buy point from a deep cup-with-handle base.

For those who still prefer the theater experience, Imax (IMAX) shares are in a buy range past a 35.83 buy point. The stock broke out from its flat base in early April. The giant-screen operator boasts an impressive 96 Composite Rating. Analysts are forecasting full-year 2015 earnings growth of 53%, followed by 17% growth in 2016. The company will be presenting at a JPMorgan (JPM) investor event on May 19.

An Industry Themes column last week visited the stock chart action from the Leisure-Lodging industry group. TripAdvisor (TRIP) got downgraded Tuesday on concerns about both the rise of automated programmatic ad buying and industry consolidation. RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney downgraded TripAdvisor to sector perform from outperform, but he maintained his price target of 91. TripAdvisor will likely face pressure from the rise of programmatic ad buying, said Mahaney in research note Tuesday. He called…
Ctrip.com International (CTRP) said on Wednesday that it's no longer interested in pursuing a merger with Qunar Cayman Islands (QUNR) after the China online travel company rejected its offer.
Qunar disclosed the unsolicited offer from Ctrip to acquire all outstanding shares when it posted first-quarter earnings late Monday.

Qunar, majority owned by China online search leader Baidu (BIDU), also disclosed that private equity firm Silver Lake Partners would lead a "strategic investment round" totaling $500 million. Silver Lake would invest $330 million, with another, unnamed investor adding $170 million. Qunar also announced plans for a secondary public offering of 8 million American Depositary Receipts.

Ctrip, China's largest online travel company, sent a confidential, non-binding, preliminary proposal to Qunar's board in early May, indicating its interest in pursuing a potential transaction with Qunar. Qunar earlier this week rejected the proposal but indicated that it was open to further discussions, Ctrip said.

Summit Research analyst Henry Guo on Tuesday reiterated a buy rating on Ctrip, with a price target of 122. He based it in part on Ctrip's recent alliance with eLong (LONG) and the growing addressable online travel market in China. Guo also credits Ctrip's "continuing market share gain and mobile momentum in the space."
Ctrip picked up a 37.6% stake in eLong for $400 million when Expedia (EXPE) shed its majority stake last month.

Ctrip said in a statement, "Ctrip is confident about its future and its ability to continue to be the most profitable, the largest and (most) fast-growing OTA (online travel agency) in China based on its years of experience, innovation and strong operation capability."
Ctrip stock was down 2.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 75.

Expedia's  (EXPE) stock jumped to a record high as the online travel services provider reported strong Q1 bookings, overcoming the currency headwinds that have hit many technology stocks during the earnings period. Shares in Expedia were up 8.4% to 102.13 in early afternoon trading in the stock market today, though the online travel firm late Thursday reported a Q1…

Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Huntington is trading below a 136.55 buy point in a long cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. Facing increased competition and foreign currency headwinds, global online travel agency Expedia (EXPE) is set to report declining Q1 earnings and revenue after the market close Thursday. The consensus analyst revenue estimate is $1.35 billion, up 12% from the year-earlier period and the third quarter in a row of deceleration.
The consensus estimate on earnings per share minus items, as polled by Thomson Reuters, is 9 cents, down from 16 cents in Q1 2014.
Expedia missed Q4 earnings and revenue estimates due to adverse currency factors and China-unit losses. The stock plunged 11.5% the next day to 77.87.
But shares have been rebounding, trading near 96 this afternoon on the stock market today, down 1.5%. The stock last week touched an all-time high above 100.
On April 7, two analysts issued positive reports on Expedia, reaffirming a price target increase.
Among analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, 14 have a hold rating on Expedia. Seven say buy and two say strong buy. One analyst has an underperform rating.
RBC Capital Markets, in a research report Monday, maintained a sector perform rating on Expedia stock and a price target of 87.
"We believe Expedia has demonstrated an ability to work through industry challenges, while laying the foundation for strong growth," wrote RBC analyst Mark Mahaney.

Expedia, which includes brands such as Hotels.com and Hotwire, announced in February that it would acquire travel-booking site Orbitz Worldwide (OWW) for $1.6 billion. In January, Expedia announced it would buy Travelocity from Sabre (SABR) for $280 million.

Expedia has been expanding as it and leading competitor Priceline Group (PCLN) face pressure from new rivals such as Google (GOOGL) and Airbnb, as well as from airlines and hotels that have improved their own websites.
Priceline is scheduled to report Q1 earnings before the market open May 7.

Stocks were higher in early-afternoon trading Friday, but volume was still tracking markedly lower on both exchanges after Thursday's drubbing. The Nasdaq gained 0.7%; the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average also rose 0.7%.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 40 were higher and 10 were lower. The worst performer by a mile was LinkedIn (LNKD), whacked for a 21% loss after reporting guidance well below expectations. But there were some good performances on the day, too.
United Therapeutics (UTHR) rose 7%. But it might find resistance at its 50-day moving average after selling off in the days around its earnings report Tuesday.
Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) rose nearly 6% after an upbeat earnings report . The stock is forming a flat base with a 102.87 buy point and has found support at its 50-day moving average.
Harman International (HAR) was down for a second day in high volume, dropping nearly 3%. It fell 7% Thursday after reporting disappointing results.
Monster Beverage (MNST) rose 1% ahead of its May 7 earnings report. The stock tried a breakout from a tightly constructed flat base, but has fallen back to support at its 50-day moving average.

Expedia (EXPE) gapped up 8% and broke through upside resistance at 100 after reporting sales that rose a better-than-expected 14% from a year ago. It also reported a 3-cents-per-share loss for the quarter.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) was off 1% and was losing support at its 200-day moving average after CEO Elon Musk announced a suite of batteries for homes, businesses and utilities. He said he wanted to change the way the world uses energy at "an extreme scale."
LinkedIn (LNKD) was smashed after Q1 earnings and sales beat the Street, but the company offered guidance dramatically below estimates. The stock was trading 20% lower.

Monster Beverage (MNST) rose 1% ahead of its May 7 earnings report. The stock tried a breakout from a tightly constructed flat base, but has fallen back to support at its 50-day moving average.

Stocks traded mixed in midafternoon trading Friday, with volume tracking lower on the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges.The Nasdaq rose 0.2%, the S&P 500 was virtually flat and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.1% in the stock market today.

Burger joint Shake Shack (SHAK) was up more than 2% in heavy volume Friday, its sixth straight daily advance. It reported earnings May 13. A report Thursday said the company has filed a trademark application for a chicken shack. Shares are up 33% for the week, but they're trading in the lower half of their daily range. The company came public Jan. 30 with an offering price of 21 and now trades above 90.

IBD 50 name Horizon Pharma (HZNP) was working on its seventh straight daily advance. Shares are up more than 1% after Leerink Swann started coverage with a buy rating and a 37 price target. The stock trades near 31.
Among IBD 50 stocks, 27 were higher and 23 were lower. The best performer was Autohome (ATHM), up nearly 4%. It's trying to retake its 50-day moving average.

Travel websites Ctrip.com (CTRP), eLong (LONG) and Expedia (EXPE) were all sharply higher after Ctrip.com announced it would buy a 37.6% stake in eLong for $400 million from sellers, including Expedia.

Synaptics (SYNA) rose 3% and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) was up nearly 1%. Synaptics hit an all-time high, and Skyworks Solutions is just above a 102.87 buy point from a flat base. Mizuho Securities started coverage with buy ratings and 115 price targets. Synaptics trades just below 97, and Skyworks trades above 105.

Foot Locker (FL) sprinted past estimates and posted a 17% year-over-year EPS gain. Travel apps will be the biggest category of software for Apple's (AAPL) new smartwatch at launch, a new report says.Strategy Analytics says travel and local apps will account for 15% of Apple Watch apps when the device goes on sale Friday. That's a big change from smartphones, where travel apps make up just 3% of apps, the research firm says. These include apps for hotels, airlines and online travel agents.News and entertainment apps will be the second-largest category of apps for the Apple Watch at launch, accounting for 13% of apps, Strategy Analytics said. Health and fitness apps tied for third with lifestyle and shopping apps, with 12% each.By contrast, the biggest category of apps for smartphones is games at 52% of apps. Games will make up just 3% of Apple Watch apps at launch.Apps for the Apple Watch will be built for utility, convenience and quick-glance information.Built-in travel apps for the Apple Watch include Maps and Passbook (for storing boarding passes, tickets, and loyalty cards). Third-party travel apps for the Apple Watch include those from American Airlines (AAL), Citymapper and Expedia (EXPE).There also will be apps from Priceline's (PCLN) restaurant reservation's unit, OpenTable, and from travel site TripAdvisor (TRIP).Apple CEO Tim Cook said on April 6 that the company had received more than 1,000 Apple Watch apps. Global Equities Research analyst Trip Chowdhry said Tuesday that about 4,000 Apple Watch apps have been approved so far.After attending a recent Apple WatchKit Hackathon, Chowdhry came away with the impression that "Apple Watch will be the most addictive device ever created."He says the best designed Apple Watch apps so far are Facebook's (FB) Instagram, Uber and Yo.RELATED:Apple Watch has a female problem.

TripAdvisor (TRIP) stock tumbled Friday after the company's aggressive rollout of its Instant Book feature ate into revenue, according to analysts, and the company's Q3 EPS and revenue missed expectations. TripAdvisor stock was near 77, down 7% in afternoon trading in the stock market today after earlier falling as much as 11.5%. The online travel company grew its top line…

Online vacation rental marketplace HomeAway (AWAY) stock surged on Thursday, the day after major online travel site Expedia (EXPE) announced it would acquire HomeAway in a $3.9 billion deal. Expedia is buying Austin, Texas-based HomeAway to gain more clout as it aims tomake a mark in the alternative lodging sector — Airbnb's strength. The HomeAway acquisition is the latest expansion…

Amid rising popularity of alternative-lodging sites like Airbnb, travel-booking service Expedia said late Wednesday that it will acquire VRBO parent HomeAway for $3.9 billion. Expedia (EXPE) will pay $10.15 cash plus 0.2065 share for each HomeAway (AWAY) share. That was worth 37.86 at Wednesday's close, but closer to 39 after hours. HomeAway rose 21.7% to 39 late; Expedia climbed 3.2%…

Priceline (PCLN) says ahead of its Q3 earnings report that it isn't going to bid for HomeAway (AWAY), according to published reports, after Expedia (EXPE) on Wednesday announced plans to acquire HomeAway. Though as an industry leader it's been a top candidate to put in a competing bid, Priceline has also been an unlikely candidate due to its current vacation…

Stocks were trying to claw their way back from a morning sell-off, as trading headed into the noon hour Thursday. The Nasdaq fell 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.3% each in the stock market today. But the Nasdaq had been down 0.9% earlier in the session.
In economic news, U.S. productivity rose 1.6% in the third quarter, better than the expected 0.1% forecast gain but lower than 3.5% increase in Q2.
Among leading stocks, Facebook (FB) gapped higher and was trading up almost 5% to a new high after multiple analysts raised price targets on the stock.
After the close Wednesday, Facebook reported earnings of 57 cents a share vs. estimates of 52 cents. It issued guidance above Wall Street views.

Facebook was the best performer on the IBD 50, where 26 stocks were higher and 24 were lower. Celgene (CELG), another IBD 50 name, was down 5.4% after reporting Q3 results. Adjusted EPS was $1.23, a 27% increase from a year ago. Damage was limited as the stock attempted to build a new base. The stock was finding support at its 50-day moving average.

Airbnb competitor HomeAway (AWAY) exploded for a 26% gain after Expedia (EXPE) announced it was buying the company for $3.9 billion. Expedia rose 4.6% in above-average volume and had touched a new high.

Elsewhere, Pacific Ocean container-ship operator Matson (MATX), part of the Dow Jones transportation average, jumped more than 13% in huge volume after reporting Q3 results.Stocks were trying to claw their way back from a morning sell-off, as trading headed into the noon hour Thursday.
