Expedia rose 4.6% in above-average volume and had touched a new high.Elsewhere, Pacific Ocean container-ship operator Matson (MATX), part of the Dow Jones transportation average, jumped more than 13% in huge volume after reporting Q3 results.
Stock futures were up, but had pulled back from early highs ahead of Thursday's open despite a surprise jump in mid-Atlantic region manufacturing.

Dow futures traded 19.8 points above fair market value, down from a 33-point gain an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures held a 16.3-point gain, sticking close to earlier highs. S&P 500 futures pulled back to a 5.3-point gain.

The stock market today carries a bit less weight on its shoulders after the S&P 500 decisively punched past its 50-day moving average and the Nasdaq gained more altitude above that important line of support on Wednesday.

Investors drew confidence after minutes from the Fed's Oct. 28 meeting showed a majority of the Federal Open Market Committee in favor of a rate hike in December. Apple (AAPL) also factored into the day's gains, gapping up to a better-than-3% gain after an upgrade from Goldman Sachs.

The current uptrend still bears a heavy load of distribution days: six on the Nasdaq, five on the S&P 500. That is good cause to keep a cautious stance toward new purchases or stocks flashing sell signals.

A relatively light economic calendar opened with the Labor Department reporting weekly jobless claims eased to 271,000 in the week ended Nov. 14, down from 276,000 in the prior week. Economist consensus had forecast a pullback to 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average continued higher, to 270,750, marking its third straight advance.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing survey firmed up for November, rising to 1.9. That beat consensus expectations for a flat outcome. The index fell to a minus 4.5 reading in October following a minus 6 tally in September.
The Conference Board is set to release its leading economic indicators index for October at 10 a.m. ET.

On the Dow, UnitedHealth (UNH) dropped 6% in premarket action. The Minnetonka, Minn.-based managed care provider trimmed its full-year EPS guidance to $6, down from $6.25 to $6.35 and below consensus views for $6.32. The company said claims activity deteriorated and individual participation in insurance exchanges lagged.

Sellers kept up the pressure on retail and apparel makers, sending Best Buy (BBY) down 9% and Perry Ellis (PERY) to a 4% loss after mixed quarterly reports. Buckle (BKE) and Bon-Ton Stores (BONT) reported Q3 earnings misses, although the stocks remained unchanged in premarket trade.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) swept ahead 17%, topping the S&P 500 in premarket action. The owner of the K-cup coffee franchise trounced analysts' Q4 earnings expectations. Revenue fell less than forecast, and management boosted the quarterly dividend by 13% to 32.5 cents. Keurig shares ended Wednesday down 75% from a November high.

Salesforce.com (CRM) jabbed up 5% before the bell. A 50% EPS leap and a 24% gain in Q3 revenue narrowly cleared analyst consensus projections. Revenue and earnings projections for Q4 were in line with analyst views, and management hoisted full-year EPS guidance to just above consensus. The software-as-a-service leader ended Wednesday in buying range, a bit more than 1% above a 76.31 cup-base buy point.
Some China-based plays chalked off strong premarket moves.
Ctrip.com International (CTRP) soared 13% higher after delivering its Q3 results. The online travel site ended Wednesday 18% above an 80.30 buy point in a double-bottom base.

China-based micro-blogging site Weibo (WB) shot up 8% in premarket trade. It reported EPS of 10 cents, up from a 1-cent, per-share loss a year ago and above views for 6 cents. Revenue surged a better-than-forecast 48%. Stocks rolled out to narrowly mixed action in muted trade Thursday, with earnings reports driving a number of dramatic early moves. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 gained 0.1% apiece. The Nasdaq eased 0.3%.
Trade was quiet, down about 3% each on the NYSE and Nasdaq exchanges, relative to action at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today received mixed jobs news, with weekly unemployment claims jumping more than expected, while layoffs slowed sharply in October. The Labor Department also estimated that Q3 productivity slowed and costs rose vs. the second quarter. However, the Q3 figures were still better than the Street expected.
The Dow was primarily positive, with JPMorgan (JPM) and Apple (AAPL) leading, up a bit less than 1% each. AutoDesk (ADSK) led the Nasdaq 100 with a 7% gain.

Among the morning's biggest moves, fashion brand Ralph Lauren (RL) surged 16%, mattress retailer Select Comfort (SCSS) bounced 13% and Argentina-based online retailer MercadoLibre (MELI) logged an 11% gain after reporting quarterly results. HomeAway (AWAY) spiked 22% after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to pay $3.9 billion to acquire the vacation rental site. Expedia shares rose 3%, taking a new high 7% above a cup-base buy point of 128.57.

Facebook (FB) bolted ahead 5% gain in early action. Its solid Q3 report late Wednesday included better-than-expected revenue and earnings. Average daily users climbed above the 1 billion mark. The stock plowed easily to fresh highs and is extended 14% above a 96.59 buy point.
Also on the IBD 50 list, Noah (NOAH) knocked out a 3% gain, moving further up the right side of a cup base.
There were plenty of losers to go around in early action.
Qualcomm (QCOM) dived 10% after reporting healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results, but offering weak Q1 guidance.

Among leaders, Epam Systems (EPAM) crumbled 9%. Its Q3 profit rose 17% to 70 cents a share, above views for 68 cents. Sales growth of 22%, to $236.1 million, missed estimates of $240.5 million. The loss sent shares 11% below a 75.93 buy point triggering an automatic sell rule.

New Jersey-based biotech Celgene (CELG) slumped 5%. Its earnings narrowly beat expectations, but revenue stopped short of forecasts and management pared its full-year sales guidance for breast, lung and pancreatic cancer treatment Abraxne. The tumble pulled shares back to a test of the stock's converged 10- and 40-week moving averages.Stocks rolled out to narrowly mixed action in muted trade Thursday, with earnings reports driving a number of dramatic early moves. The social media giant said daily active users rose 17% to 1.01 billion. Ad revenue jumped 45% to $4.3 billion. TripAdvisor (TRIP) received a price target increase Thursday, as two analysts cited strong fundamentals for its hotel business and growing potential in vacation rental, restaurant and attraction segments. Cowen and Co. analysts Kevin Kopelman and Andrew Marok, in a research report, boosted their price target on TripAdvisor stock to 85 from 80 and reiterated a market perform rating. The analysts…
Stocks improved from mixed trade into moderate gains early Thursday, as investors looked to wrap up a short holiday week.
The Dow Jones industrial average chiseled out a 0.6% gain. The S&P 500 jumped 0.5% and the Nasdaq climbed 0.4%.
Volume was sharply lower in the stock market today, down 23% on the Nasdaq and 16% lower on the NYSE.

Early U.S. unemployment data was positive, but a number of important international factors exerted a mixed influence on early trade. Talks between Greece and its eurozone creditors improved, aided by the country's submission of a detailed proposal of economic reforms that it was willing to undertake in order to unlock sorely needed bailout funds.

Multinational talks with Iran, spearheaded by the U.S., dragged into a second day beyond Tuesday's (already extended) deadline, raising concerns that the situation was once again headed toward stalemate.
Oil prices pulled back after Wednesday's strong gains. The euro advanced vs. the dollar.
In stocks, CarMax (KMX) ran to the head of the S&P 500 with a 7% gain after a strong fourth quarter report.

Courting tobacco makers Reynolds American (RAI) and Lorillard (LO) jumped 4% each. Executives from the two companies have been meeting with the Federal Trade Commission this week, attempting to address antitrust concerns related to their proposed $25 billion merger. Lorillard is trading just below a fresh high. Reynolds is below a 76.33 buy point in a flat base.
Expedia (EXPE) jumped 3%, taking a new high. The stock has been struggling to gain headway above a 92.18 buy point that it initially cleared in February.

A majority of IBD 50 stocks opened higher, but action was light. Cambrex (CBM) and Asbury Automotive Group (ABG) advanced almost 2%, topping the list. Both are trading just below their highs. Gentherm (THRM) dropped more than 1% to post the group's biggest loss.Stocks improved from mixed trade into moderate gains early Thursday, as investors looked to wrap up a short holiday week.The Dow Jones industrial average chiseled out a 0.6% gain. Online travel giant Expedia's (EXPE) core margin improvement has gone largely unnoticed and its Trivago brand remains underappreciated, two analysts conclude in a research report Tuesday, reaffirming a price target increase.Cowen & Co. analysts Kevin Kopelman and Andrew Marok updated clients about their April 2 report, "Sum of Parts Yields $115 Per Share, With Upside Potential," in which they raised their price target to 115 from 90.Expedia stock was up 0.6% to 99.16 in midafternoon trading in the stock market today (Tuesday). Expedia stock touched an all-time high near 100 earlier in the day after climbing 12% over the past 90 days and 37% over the past 12 months.Kopelman and Marok said that they spoke with investors about last Thursday's report, which noted that while Expedia's overall margins declined by 60 basis points in 2014, its core margins actually expanded when adjusted for declining margins for subsidiaries Trivago and Egencia as well as eLong (LONG), a China-focused travel agency of which Expedia is part owner.The analysts noted that Trivago is the second-fastest-growing large online travel brand in the world, trailing only Airbnb (a website for people to rent out lodging), and just ahead of Skyscanner. Trivago revenue increased 68% to $410 million last year and continued to accelerate at year's end, the analysts said."In our conversations with investors, we confirmed that recent margin improvement at core Expedia has gone largely unnoticed, as it was masked by lower margins in all other segments in fiscal 2014 (eLong in China, Trivago and Egencia)," the analysts said. "This is the first margin improvement at core Expedia in five years. Expedia plans to begin disclosing detailed segment metrics starting in Q1, which should make core margin trends clear and provide a potential positive catalyst for shares."Expedia, which includes brands such as Hotels.com and Hotwire, announced in February that it had reached an agreement to acquire travel-booking site Orbitz Worldwide (OWW). In January, Expedia announced that it had agreed to buy Travelocity from Sabre (SABR).Expedia has been expanding as it and leading competitor Priceline Group (PCLN) face pressure from new rivals such as Google (GOOGL), as well as from Airbnb and from airlines and hotels that have improved their own websites.Kopelman and Marok say that Expedia is well-positioned to continue gaining market share of the hotel-booking industry, given its strong portfolio of global brands and competitive technology platform and hotel network. They expect Orbitz to add to Expedia profits, but they note that it may take a few quarters before there is detailed information on cost synergies as a result of the Orbitz-Expedia deal, given that the deal awaits regulatory approval and has not yet closed.Expedia said Thursday that it had agreed to pay $228.9 million for Amgen's (AMGN) campus in Seattle, where it plans to move its headquarters from Bellevue by 2018.

Chinese travel portal Ctrip.com International (CTRP) stock surged Friday after the company projected better-than-expected revenue for the current quarter and posted Q4 earnings that topped Wall Street expectations. Amid intense competition, the company says it is investing heavily in more than a dozen key initiatives, from building its brand name to improving travel financing services. Ctrip late Thursday reported that…

Ctrip.com International (CTRP), a leading Chinese travel site, reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter results late Thursday and predicted its best revenue growth in years, sending its stock higher in after-hours trading.Ctrip reported an adjusted loss of 26 cents a share — or an 11-cent loss excluding stock compensation. Either way, it topped Wall Street forecasts of a 28-cent loss. Revenue rose 30% to $308.4 million. In local currency, revenue rose 33%, higher than Ctrip's forecast of 30%."Our main business lines demonstrated strong momentum," said Chairman and CEO James Liang. "Accommodation reservation and transportation ticketing services reached 53% and 102% year-over-year volume growth respectively."But what got investors' attention was Ctrip's Q1 forecast for a revenue gain of 40%-50%, which suggests the best sales gain since the end of 2010.Ctrip shares rose more than 8% in late trading to 50, after briefly spiking above 54. During the regular session, Ctrip fell 0.2 to 46.15 on the stock market today.Ctrip has been finding resistance just below its 50-day moving average. Its stock hit a peak of 69.74 on Sept. 4.Ctrip's bullish outlook is the latest good news for the Chinese online travel market, despite slower economic growth in China.Qunar (QUNR) late Monday said that its revenue doubled over a year earlier to $83.8 million, while its per-share loss was less than expected. Qunar stock spiked 10% on Tuesday and 6% on Wednesday, breaking out of a consolidation to a 52-week high. The stock fell a fraction on Thursday.Qunar is majority owed by Baidu (BIDU), China's dominant search engine. But Qunar's reliance on Baidu is fading as its mobile organic growth improves.Priceline (PCLN) owns a stake in Ctrip. Priceline and its main rival, Expedia (EXPE), are eager to get a piece of the big and growing China travel market. Expedia is the top shareholder in China's eLong (LONG).Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.

With the announced rollout of more than 20 new nonstop routes and the purchase of eight used planes, Allegiant Travel Co. seems to be on a spending spree. But the low-cost air carrier isn't prone to splurging. Its unique strategy has led some analysts to call it "the best business model in the industry," venturing that it will be "the…

If Airbnb executives were to fail in the nascent shared-hospitality industry, they might have enough hard-won experience in government relations and trust-building to start a chain of neighborhood nuclear power plants.The 7-year-old firm has built a global peer-to-peer accommodations network, processing rental transactions between those wanting to rent part or all of their home to adventurous travelers happy to spend less on travel.The San Francisco-based company's three founders, Nathan Blecharczy, Brian Chesky and Joe Gebbia, originally called their venture Airbed and Breakfast. They saw profit in a hyperlocal, hyperpersonal, bohemian lodging segment, hence "Airbed."The trio appealed largely to a generation of young adults who came of age during the Great Recession and were used to sleeping on friends' couches.But besides some rough-and-ready experiences, Airbnb now lists dramatic and dramatically upscale offerings. Guests choose from 1 million listings, including castle redoubts, a converted Tesla electric car and a ski-mountain cable car in France.According to Cowen & Co., Airbnb already has helped put up 30 million guests, cumulatively. About 2 million guests per month used the service during the second half of 2014, up 275% year over year, says Cowen.The investment bank estimates 2014 bookings reached $5.5 billion. In comparison, online travel leader Priceline's (PCLN) estimated bookings were $46 billion last year, and No. 2 Expedia's (EXPE) were $20 billion, reports Cowen.An executive with Airbnb who spoke on background only if not identified said staff levels now exceed 1,000. The company opened a 220-person North American operational headquarters in Portland, Ore., last spring.The venture capital-funded company is valued near $10 billion and is among a cadre of high-flying Internet companies expected to make an initial public offering this year. Publications including Fortune have reported that Airbnb is preparing an employee stock sale that would boost its valuation to $13 billion.The firm has closed six rounds of funding, according to CrunchBase, amounting to about $800 million. Investors include TPG Growth, T. Rowe Price, Founders Fund, Crunch Fund, Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, Amazon.com (AMZN) founder Jeff Bezos, actor Ashton Kutcher and seed accelerator Y Combinator.That's some serious backing, especially for a company facing serious regulatory and trust issues.Many of the 34,000 municipalities, in 190 nations, with Airbnb hosts are debating how to accommodate the lodging-sharing field, if they should allow it all. Worries range from the safety of residents and guests to the stability of neighborhoods and access for disabled people.Has Trust & Safety DivisionThe market has spoken about Airbnb's trustworthiness when it comes to safety, says Mike Munger, director of Duke University's Philosophy, Politics and Economics program. There have been guest/host problems, but not so many as to slow the company's growth.Airbnb formed a Trust & Safety division in 2011 after a San Francisco host's home was vandalized. That division has more than 150 employees, said a company executive. Today, algorithms search for suspicious behavior, and guests and hosts are encouraged to check each other out via Airbnb.com, where they can also privately message each other before booking."Guests already know more about their hosts than they know about the person behind the desk of a hotel," Munger told IBD.Hosts are covered by a limited $1 million property-damage guarantee.Then there are the hospitality taxes and license fees that Airbnb only recently has begun paying in a few cities. Avoiding those costs has helped keep Airbnb rates low, much to the ire of hoteliers, who have paid them since the inception of commercial travel.Crain's Chicago Business says its hometown has 2,800 Airbnb host sites, but only 146 are licensed.But taxes don't have to be a big problem for Airbnb, says Munger.Airbnb executives "could save themselves a world of heartache and buy a lot of good will" by finding a comprehensive way of paying hospitality taxes, he said. "I don't think Airbnb will take much of a hit by adding taxes," given its lower prices compared to hotel costs.Hoteliers, of course, don't like the idea of being undercut on price by legions of mini-Conrad Hiltons. Yet quantifying the effects of Airbnb on hotels is tricky because hospitality offerings are so diverse.A report on New York City accommodations commissioned by Airbnb and done by industry consulting firm Lodging Advisors indicates that Airbnb, at least for now, does not pose a significant threat to hoteliers. The startup, though, has put small downward pressure on lodging rates, the report found.Available Airbnb rooms made up 11% of NYC's entire 2014 available room inventory, up from 6.5% two years earlier, according to Lodging Advisors. New York room revenue for Airbnb was $245 million for the year ended April 2014. Hotels pulled in $8.2 billion over the same period.A little more definitive is a 2015 Boston University study titled "The Rise of the Sharing Economy: Estimating the Impact of Airbnb on the Hotel Industry." It found that in Austin, Texas, "each additional 10% increase in the size of the Airbnb market (has) resulted in a 0.35% decrease in hotel room revenue."Some major online general-travel firms, such as Expedia, have been more sanguine about Airbnb, but Munger points out that they have more revenue sources than do hotels, or Airbnb for that matter. They present buyers options for ground and air transportation and entertainment beside lodging.Beyond LodgingBut Airbnb co-founder Chesky is on the record as saying his company will expand to include more aspects of guests' travel.While the media portrays his online vacation-rental property company as being in Airbnb's crosshairs, HomeAway (AWAY) CEO Brian Sharples seems less than stressed."Airbnb's primarily oriented toward cities," Sharples told IBD. And that, he says, isn't HomeAway's focus."We're more family-oriented," while Airbnb's customers are likely to be younger and value the social network aspects of that service, he said.Airbnb seems to be gaining respectability. The past two years, billionaire investor Warren Buffett has recommended that shareholders in his Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) looking to attend the company's annual shareholders meeting in Omaha, Neb., use Airbnb because the city has a relatively small number of hotel rooms. In December, American Express (AXP) added Airbnb to its membership rewards program.Trade publisher and data-analyst firm STR contributed hotel industry data to the NYC report.Addressing the tax, license and safety issues, and planning broader service offerings "is making Airbnb more of a force," said STR analyst Jan Frietag. Whether it's going to increase the pie or eating away at market share, he said, remains "the $120 billion question."

Most analysts expect Expedia (EXPE) to report solid results driven by hotel bookings and deals from its marketing agreement with Travelocity when it reports fourth-quarter earnings after the close Thursday.The consensus estimate of 25 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for the Bellevue, Wash.-based online travel agency to post earnings per share excluding items of $1.02, up 11% from 92 cents in the year-earlier quarter, on revenue of $1.37 billion, up 19% from $1.15 billion.In the current quarter, Expedia is expected to post average EPS of 20 cents a share, up 25%, on sales of $1.37 billion, up 14.2% from $1.2 billion.For 2014, analysts expect revenue of $5.77 billion, up 21%, on EPS of $4.10 a share, up 27%.Edward Woo, an analyst with Ascendiant Capital Markets, said in a research report last week that he expects in-line Q4 results and solid 2015 guidance. He noted Expedia's leadership position in online travel, adding that a strong global travel industry energized by low oil prices and surging hotel bookings will help drive Expedia stock in 2015.He also said that Expedia will benefit from deals tied to its earlier marketing pact with Travelocity and increased business from its acquisition of Wotif, an Australia-based travel website last year. While the marketing pact dates back to August 2013, last month Expedia announced that it acquired Travelocity from Sabre (SABR) for $280 million in cash.Woo raised his price target on Expedia to 102 from 100 and kept his buy rating on the stock.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney said in a report last month that he expects Expedia to post in-line Q4 results."Expedia has demonstrated an ability to work through industry challenges, while laying the foundation for strong growth — both abroad and in the U.S.," Mahaney wrote.RBC has a sector perform rating on Expedia and a 95 price target on the stock.Expedia has an IBD Composite Rating of 87, putting it among the top 13% of companies on a number of key factors, including profit and sales growth. Expedia stock rose nearly 2% in the stock market today, to near 88.
Priceline calmed investor fears with Q4 earnings that flew past estimates and a boost to its stock buyback program, sending shares higher despite weak guidance.

Helped by stronger-than-expected growth of bookings in Europe, Priceline (PCLN) early Thursday posted earnings per share minus items of $10.85. That was above the Wall Street consensus of $10.10 and up 23% from the year-earlier period.

The world's largest travel service company by bookings reported revenue of $1.85 billion, up 19% and edging the consensus of $1.8 billion as polled by Thomson Reuters. The company also said it would add $3 billion to its stock repurchase program. Priceline purchased $505 million of its common stock in Q4.
Priceline stock rose 8.5% Thursday to 1,218, a three-month high.

Priceline forecast Q1 EPS of $7.20 to $7.75. That's well below the consensus of $8.52, though Priceline tends to beat by a lot. The company forecasts its revenue will rise 4% to 11%, or up to $1.82 billion. Analysts were modeling $1.86 billion.
"The results were mixed," Tuna Amobi, an analyst at S&P Capital IQ, told IBD. "While Q4 came in above guidance, Q1 guidance was very cautious."
Amobi rates Priceline stock a hold, but he hiked his price target to 1,300 from 1,200.

"There seems to be an underlying slowdown in domestic bookings, but international remains bright spot," Amobi said. "A few months ago Priceline warned of a deceleration in Europe, but it seems they overcame that despite significant foreign exchange headwinds."
About 90% of Priceline's revenue comes from overseas, where currencies are weaker than the dollar, causing revenue and profit to shrink when exchanged into U.S. dollars.
"Priceline is weathering" the currency issue, Mark Mahaney, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets, said in a research report.
The key guidance, he wrote, was Q1 international bookings growth estimated at 17% to 24% excluding the foreign currency exchange impact. That "suggests an acceleration path for 2015," he said.
Mahaney maintained an outperform rating and raised his price target to 1,450 from 1,300.
Bookings Rose 28% In 2014
Q4 bookings rose 17% to $10.7 billion, up 23% on a local currency basis. Bookings for the year rose 28% to $50.3 billion.

Priceline said bookings benefited from growth in hotel supply from its Booking.com unit, which now has over 600,000 hotels and other accommodations worldwide, up 41% over last year. Much of that growth in supply is driven by vacation rentals, which more than doubled to 247,000 properties.

"We continue to believe in the large, untapped potential of the global vacation rental opportunity, which has historically been burdened by a high friction research and fulfillment process," said Priceline CEO Darren Huston in an earnings conference call with analysts.
Huston also spotlighted strong growth at Kayak.com, Rentalcars.com and restaurant reservations firm OpenTable.com, which Priceline bought for $2.6 billion in July.

"OpenTable remains very busy laying the groundwork for its cloud-based re-platforming and international expansion," Huston said. "As we enter 2015, we see continued strong momentum in our business across the board."
OpenTable generated Q4 revenue of $59 million.
Analysts maintained a positive outlook on Priceline heading into the Q4 report, despite heightened competition and FX issues.
Top rival Expedia (EXPE) announced last Thursday that it would acquire Orbitz Worldwide (OWW) for $1.6 billion. The deal got good reviews.
In January, Expedia announced it had acquired Travelocity from Sabre (SABR) for $280 million in cash. Expedia also operates Hotels.com.

Huston said that the Expedia-Orbitz merger "consolidates and clarifies competition" and was not a negative for Priceline. He said Priceline is focusing on acquiring companies to expand its geographic reach and build new business lines.
In August, Priceline said it would invest $500 million in China's online travel leader, Ctrip (CTRP).

"From an acquisition standpoint, we're focused on buying premium winning brands that either add new geographies or business verticals for competencies, new channels that we can add to our existing brands," Huston said.Priceline calmed investor fears with Q4 earnings that flew past estimates and a boost to its stock buyback program, sending shares higher despite weak guidance.Helped by stronger-than-expected growth of bookings in Europe, Priceline (PCLN) early Thursday posted earnings per share minus items of $10.85. Online travel booking service Expedia (EXPE) has earned positive reviews from analysts for its planned purchase of rival Orbitz Worldwide. On Thursday, Expedia announced its intent to buy Chicago-based Orbitz (OWW) for $1.6 billion. The move comes just three weeks after Expedia bought Travelocity for $280 million. The acquisitions will give Expedia more ammunition to compete with market leader Priceline…

Expedia (EXPE) is an elephant with a mosquito on its back: Airbnb. Online travel juggernaut Expedia posted mixed earnings late Thursday, but executives foresaw better-than-expected efficiencies from the Orbitz merger, and Expedia stock soared to an all-time high Friday above 139. Yet, alternative-lodgings company Airbnb is nipping at the heels of online booking companies such as Expedia and Priceline (PCLN).…

Expedia late Thursday reported a mixed Q3, with sales slightly missing views and earnings slightly beating, in its first financial report since acquiring rival online travel agency Orbitz on Sept. 17.

Expedia (EXPE) reported Q3 revenue of $1.94 billion, up 16% from $1.66 billion in the year-earlier quarter. Earnings per share ex items rose 6% to $2.07. The company said the results included 14 days of Orbitz financials.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had estimated EPS ex items of $2.05 on revenue of $1.95 billion.

"The third quarter was another strong one for Expedia," Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshahi said on the firm's earnings conference call with analysts. "We continue to invest in people, processes and technology, and our organization is on-boarding hotels in record time at higher quality than we ever have."

Expedia stock was up 7% in after-hours trading, after the company released its results. Shares rose 1% to 127.06 in Thursday's regular session. Expedia stock hit a record high of 131.51 on Oct. 21. Expedia has an IBD Composite Rating of 84, where 99 is the highest possible.

Q3 gross bookings, a key metric, rose 21% to $15.4 billion, which excludes the year-earlier figure for eLong. Expedia in May sold its majority stake in China online travel firm eLong to investors that included China online travel company Ctrip.com (CTRP).

Expedia didn't give a Q4 outlook other than to say it expects 2015 EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) to rise 12% to 15%. Expedia CFO Mark Okerstrom said the company now expects greater efficiencies by adding Orbitz. The company's EBITDA rose 17% in 2014.
Analysts see Q4 EPS ex items at $1.20 on sales of $1.7 billion.

In February, Expedia announced its agreement to acquire Orbitz and said the completed deal had an enterprise value of $1.6 billion. The U.S. Justice Department ultimately waved the deal through. Hotel and airline industry groups had opposed the merger.
Most Integration In Year
"The bulk of the integration work is expected to take place in the next nine months," with some units taking more than a year, Khosrowshahi said.
The deal has left two dominant U.S. online travel agencies: Expedia and Priceline (PCLN), which is set to report Q3 earnings on Nov. 9.

Online travel agencies accounted for 16% of gross travel bookings in the U.S. last year, while the three other sources of travel bookings — supplier websites, travel management firms, and phone or walk-ins — each accounted for a 28% share, according to Phocuswright.
The rise of alterative accommodations is cutting into hotel demand, RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney says.

Khosrowshahi, though, on the call said Airbnb has had an "immaterial" effect on the business. "If anything, it might be getting into a new class of travel," he said,"typically with a lower price point, and that appeals to millennials.

"That said, Airbnb is adding supply into the lodging marketplace, and that supply is addressable to a certain portion of the population. It will put pricing pressure in markets where you see a significant amount of Airbnb inventory."

For a second straight year, an RBC survey found that one-third of respondents said they have used some form of alternative accommodations, such as privately held Airbnb or HomeAway (AWAY) subsidiary VRBO. Airbnb was the largest source of alternative accommodations bookings, with 23% of respondents saying that they used it. VRBO's share fell to 17% from 32%. Airbnb and VRBO list private homes and apartments for short-term rentals aimed at vacationers.
Expedia is conducting beta tests in a partnership with longer-term vacation home rental firm HomeAway in Europe, to bolster its inventory.
Meanwhile, Priceline is "well hedged" and is growing its inventory, at 361,000 properties on Booking.com, by 80% year over year, according to Mahaney.

With the total addressable market at greater than $1.3 trillion and consistent online travel demand trends, Mahaney said in a research note ahead of Expedia's earnings release, "we remain long-term bulls on both Expedia and Priceline, because we see industry demand trends as consistently strong and view current valuations as reasonable . .. (but) not overly compelling."Expedia late Thursday reported a mixed Q3, with sales slightly missing views and earnings slightly beating, in its first financial report since acquiring rival online travel agency Orbitz on Sept. 17.Expedia (EXPE) reported Q3 revenue of $1.94 billion, up 16% from $1.66 billion in the year-earlier quarter. (but) not overly compelling."

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.

Expedia (EXPE), hot off the heels of its $1.3 billion Orbitz takeover, is expected to post its first year-over-year EPS increase in four quarters when it reports Q3 earnings after the close Thursday. Analysts expect the online travel agent's Q3 revenue to increase 12% from the year-earlier quarter, to $1.95 billion. Earnings per share minus items are expected to rise…
The relative strength line pits a stock's performance against the benchmark S&P 500, and a stock with a rapidly rising RS line is one to keep an eye on.
Two companies that continue to outpace the market, MSCI (MSCI) and Ctrip.com International (CTRP), are featured on IBD's Bolting RS Lines Screen of the Day.
MSCI, a supplier of analytical tools for institutional investors, said Monday that it will add American Depositary Receipts — i.e. China shares listed overseas — to its emerging market indexes.

The decision allows for exposure to Chinese companies listed on U.S. exchanges, including Alibaba (BABA) and Baidu (BIDU). It follows the massive selloff in Chinese shares earlier this year and the subsequent stabilization, testing investors' appetite for jumping back in.
MSCI shares finished down 1.2% in the stock market Tuesday after surging 6% on Monday. Alibaba shares dipped 1.1%. Baidu shares were down 1.4%.

MSCI, which has been forming a cup base since early August, cleared a 68.93 buy point to hit a new high and enter buy territory Monday following a 6-cent Q3 beat of 60 cents in earnings per share. Revenue of $268.8 million slightly missed forecasts.
UBS and Keefe, Bruyette & Woods upgraded the stock following earnings results. MSCI merits an IBD Composite Rating of 93, which means it has outperformed 93% of publicly traded companies.

Meanwhile, online travel agency Ctrip and Chinese Internet giant Baidu completed a share exchange last week that left Ctrip with a 45% voting interest in travel site Qunar (QUNR) and Baidu with a 25% voting interest in Ctrip. Qunar had previously rejected an unsolicited buyout offer from Ctrip.

Summit Research Partners has estimated that the deal will leave Ctrip and Qunar with 70%-80% of the Chinese hotel and air ticket market. Ctrip is also expected to benefit from Baidu's extensive Internet user coverage and mobile penetration, accelerating Ctrip's further growth.
Ctrip shares spiked 22% on Oct. 26, breaking out of consolidation, and on Monday climbed even higher to hit a fresh high of 97.98. Shares rose 0.8% Tuesday.
Earlier in the year, Expedia (EXPE) sold its majority 62.4% stake in struggling China online travel agency eLong (LONG) to a group of investors that included Ctrip.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

Amazon (AMZN) may be king of cloud services and e-commerce, but its dreams of taking on Priceline (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE) in online travel just got shipwrecked. Last week, the tech giant pulled the plug on its Destinations travel site, which launched in April. How did Priceline investors react? On Monday, they pushed the stock to an all-time high and…

Stocks wrapped up a busy earnings week on a down note Friday after hovering near the flat line most of the session. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each closed with a 0.5% loss, while the Nasdaq shed 0.4%. Volume was slightly higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq in the stock market today, according to preliminary data. All three indexes ended with fractional gains for the week.

Winners outpaced losers by a 6-5 margin on the NYSE, while decliners edged past advancers on the Nasdaq. Consumer electronics retailers, solar power and alcoholic beverage stocks lagged; transportation, security software and online travel bookers led.

Expedia (EXPE) gapped up 7% to a new high in fast trade. Cantor Fitzgerald and RBC Capital Markets boosted their price targets after the Internet travel agent's Q3 results late Thursday beat views. Priceline Group (PCLN) rose 2%, also a new high. Piper Jaffray reiterated an overweight rating ahead of the travel site's Nov. 9 earnings report.

LinkedIn (LNKD) gapped up and soared 11% in massive turnover, retaking its 200-day moving average for the first time since July 30. The professional-networking website reported Q3 results above forecasts Thursday after the close.

Electronic Arts (EA) fell 5% in fast trade, slipping below a 75.86 buy point it cleared Wednesday. The video game publisher late Thursday reported fiscal Q2 earnings and sales that beat views. Jefferies raised its price target to 95 from 80 and reiterated a buy rating.
EA also boosted its sales forecast for the highly anticipated "Star Wars: Battlefront" video game, which lands Nov. 17.
On the IBD 50 , 23 stocks advanced and 27 fell. Universal Insurance (UVE) staged a bearish reversal and gave up 11% despite reporting better-than-expected Q3 results late Thursday.
Integrated Device Technology (IDTI) led the upside with a 5% jump in heavy volume. The chip designer's shares are still in buy range from a 24.63 cup base entry cleared last week.

Companies reporting quarterly results Monday include Clorox (CLX), Fitbit (FIT) and Visa (V). Key economic data on tap for Monday include October existing-home sales and the Purchasing Managers' Index for November.

Transportation ETFs skittered into losses Monday, as airline and travel-booking stocks slumped in the wake of the Paris terrorist attacks Friday. Exchange-traded funds tracking major indexes got off to a slow start but closed sharply higher, buoyed by an oil rally. Energy led S&P 500 sector ETFs higher as oil prices recovered from last week's big dip. Investors in consumer…

Dips in travel after terrorist attacks don't usually last long, but tourism might be slightly slower to return after the attack in Paris, while the defense sector is unlikely to see a sustained rally from the military response, analysts said Monday. Iconic French landmarks like the Eiffel Tower, Paris Opera and Louvre have already reopened, but tourists are rethinking decisions…

The acquisition announcement of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide came as no surprise, but its buyer — Marriott International — certainly did. Starwood (HOT) said on April 29 that it was exploring "strategic" alternatives, including a possible sale, but as recently as late October the focus had turned to Hyatt Hotels (H) and several Chinese companies as potential bidders. Marriott[ticker…
Priceline (PCLN) reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and a new stock buyback program Thursday morning, sending its stock higher despite lower-than-expected guidance.
The world's largest travel service company by bookings reported earnings per share minus items of $10.85, above Wall Street consensus of $10.10 and up 23% from the year-earlier period.

Revenue of $1.85 billion was up 19% and above the consensus estimate of $1.8 billion, as polled by Thomson Reuters. The company said that it was adding an additional $3 billion to its stock repurchase program.
Priceline stock was up 8% in midday trading on the stock market today, near 1,212 and near a five-month high.
Bookings rose 17% to $10.7 billion, while bookings for the year rose 28% to $50.3 billion.

Priceline forecast Q1 EPS of $7.20 to $7.75. That's well below the consensus of $8.52, though Priceline tends to beat by a lot. The company forecasts that its revenue will rise 4% to 11%, or up to $1.82 billion. Analysts were modeling $1.86 billion.
Analysts maintained a positive outlook on Priceline heading into the Q4 report, even though Priceline faced heightened competition and an unfavorable foreign currency exchange rate.
Top rival Expedia (EXPE) announced last Thursday that it would acquire Orbitz Worldwide (OWW) for $1.6 billion. The deal got generally favorable reviews.
In January, Expedia announced that it had acquired Travelocity from Sabre (SABR) for $280 million in cash. Expedia also operates Hotels.com.

In an earnings conference call with analysts, Priceline CEO Darren Huston said that the Expedia-Orbitz merger "consolidates and clarifies competition" and was not a negative for Priceline. Huston said that Priceline is focusing on acquiring companies to expand its geographic reach and build new business lines.

In recent years, Priceline has acquired Booking.com, Kayak and OpenTable. In August, Priceline said that it would invest $500 million in Ctrip (CTRP), the biggest Chinese online travel agency. Both companies agreed to increase the cross-promotion of each other's hotel inventories and other travel services. Ctrip also agreed to promote Priceline's other services, including OpenTable.

Facing heightened competition and an unfavorable foreign currency exchange rate, Priceline (PCLN) is expected to reveal slower earnings growth when it posts its Q4 earnings before the market open Thursday.
The consensus estimate is for Priceline to report earnings per share minus items of $10.10, up 14% from the year-earlier period and down from 28% year-over-year growth in the previous quarter.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect revenue to rise 17% to $1.8 billion. Sales rose 25% in Q3.
Competition in the online travel business is intensifying.
Expedia (EXPE) announced last Thursday it would acquire Orbitz Worldwide (OWW) for $1.6 billion.
And in January Expedia announced it acquired Travelocity from Sabre (SABR) for $280 million in cash. Expedia also operates Hotels.com.

Priceline has acquired Booking.com, Kayak and OpenTable in recent years. In August, Priceline said it would invest $500 million in Ctrip (CTRP), the biggest Chinese online travel agency. Both companies agreed to increase the cross-promotion of each other's hotel inventories and other travel services. Ctrip also agreed to promote Priceline's other services, including OpenTable.

Mark Mahaney, an analyst at RBC Capital markets, on Feb. 6 cut his price target on Priceline stock to 1,300 from 1,400, due mainly to foreign currency exchange headwinds, but maintained an outperform rating. Priceline was down a fraction in early trading in the stock market today, near 1,118.

"Based on intraquarter data points, channel checks and model sensitivities, we view Wall Streets Q4 estimates as slightly high, given foreign exchange," he wrote in a research report. Most of Priceline's revenue comes from outside the U.S. The weak euro exchange rate continues to hinder Priceline's performance in Europe.
Naved Khan, an analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald, expects Priceline to report earnings at the higher end of the estimate range. Kahn has a buy rating and price target of 1,350.

"This is supported by our checks of worldwide traffic and hotel pricing trends during the quarter," he wrote. Kahn expects Priceline to issue a cautious outlook for Q1 based on foreign exchange and economic weakness in Europe.

JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth also expects Priceline to report earning toward the high end of estimates and guide conservatively. Anmuth has an overweight rating on Priceline stock, with a price target of 1,225.
"We remain confident in Priceline's ability to drive further share gains globally," Anmuth wrote in a report.
Expedia stock fell 11.5% the day after reporting Q4 earnings late on Feb. 5 that missed views on adverse currency factors and China-unit losses.

TripAdvisor (TRIP) stock jumped 22% the day after it reported Q4 earnings late Wednesday that beat on revenue but fell short on earnings. The jump in stock price coincided with the news that Expedia was buying Orbitz. Expedia stock rose 15% that day.

Zillow stock jumped Wednesday as the company's morning merger conference call with analysts laid out how the two biggest websites for house hunters — Zillow.com and Trulia.com — will make money as a combined company, Zillow Group. Executives said the 2.5 billion stock-swap merger, finalized late Tuesday, comes with 280 immediate job cuts, with 70 more slated in about three…

Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq were each down 0.7%.
Volume was running higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared to the same time Wednesday.

Economic news was mixed, with unemployment claims falling a little less than expected in the week ended Dec. 12, while manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region fell much more than expected in December. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.4% in November, down from the prior month's 0.6% increase but ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Mining and energy stocks were hit hardest in the stock market today on declines in oil and metals prices.
Newmont Mining (NEM), a Colorado-based miner of gold and silver, lost 8%, leading the S&P 500 lower. Oil transportation stock Oneok (OKE) also dropped about 8%.

Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, led by Global Payments (GPN), which fell more than 2% in heavy volume. The stock plunged 8% on Wednesday, slicing through its 50-day line, after agreeing to buy rival credit card payments processor Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.
Total System Services (TSS), another credit card payments processor in the IBD 50, fell 2.7% but remains well above a 48.18 buy point of a cup-with-handle base that it cleared in October.
But Chinese social media stock Weibo (WB) was a bright spot. It jumped more than 4% in heavy volume, closing in on a 20.80 buy point of a deep, cup-shaped base.

The stock boasts a rising Relative Strength line and an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A, indicating strong demand for the shares. The stock has more than doubled since falling to a low of 8.78 on Aug. 24.Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. Just weeks after completing the purchase of Travelocity, online travel service Expedia (EXPE) said it is also acquiring rival Orbitz Worldwide (OWW) for an enterprise value of $1.6 billion, or $12 a share in cash. Shares of Hotels.com and Hotwire operator Expedia rose 12.8% to 88.23 in the stock market today. Shares of Orbitz, which operates CheapTickets and HotelClub, surged…

Strong earnings from Cisco Systems (CSCO) fueled a nice tech rally Thursday. In early afternoon trading, the Nasdaq gained 0.9% and the S&P 500 added 0.7%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.4% gain. Nasdaq volume was tracking sharply higher than Wednesday's levels. NYSE volume was tracking close to Wednesday's pace.It was an impressive market performance in light of disappointing January retail sales released before the open.In the stock market today, online travel firms were in the spotlight after Expedia (EXPE) announced plans to buy rival Orbitz (OWW) for $1.6 billion. Expedia soared 16% on the news. Orbitz jumped 22%.Skechers (SKX) gapped out of a base, rising 6%, after the company reported strong earnings late Wednesday. Q4 surged 71% from a year ago to 48 cents a share. Sales rose 26% to $569.7 million.Shares of ComScore (SCOR) surged 25%. It gapped out of a base after the company reported earnings before the open and its third straight quarter of accelerating sales growth. In addition, U.K.-based WPP (WPPGY) agreed to buy a stake in ComScore for $300 million.CyberArk Software (CYBR) jumped 6% ahead of its earnings report after the close. The stock broke out of an irregular double-bottom base with a 43.59 buy point.

Expedia (EXPE) stock plunged Friday, after the global online travel agency late Thursday reported fourth-quarter earnings and revenue that missed views on adverse currency factors and China-unit losses. Some analysts cut their price target on the stock.

Bellevue, Wash.-based Expedia earned 86 cents a share excluding items, down 7% from the year-earlier quarter and 15 cents below the average estimate of 25 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Sales rose 18% to $1.36 billion, but analysts expected $1.37 billion.
CFO Mark Okerstrom said on a conference call that Expedia expects a deceleration in revenue growth, in part from currency headwinds.
Analysts estimate Q1 revenue of $1.37 billion and EPS of 20 cents per share.
Expedia reported $79.4 million in foreign exchange losses on cash, its equivalents and short-term investments for 2014, up 40% from 2013.

ELong (LONG), in which Expedia owns a stake, posted an adjusted EBITDA loss of $26.9 million in Q4, up from a loss of $3.4 million in Q4 2013. The Chinese company's revenue dipped 12% to $37.5 million in a tough market where it competes with Ctrip.com International (CTRP). Ctrip is partnered with Expedia rival Priceline Group (PCLN).
Expedia stock was down 10.8% to 78.48 in afternoon trading on the stock market today, plunging through its 200-day moving average to the lowest levels in more than three months.
Priceline stock was down 2.6%. It's been in a downtrend for the past 11 months.
JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth dropped his price target on Expedia stock to 83 from 92. He kept his neutral rating.

"We continue to find (Expedia) well positioned to benefit from favorable travel trends, internal initiatives including its platform upgrade and recent acquisitions, but increasing customer acquisition costs globally and bigger investments in China keep us on the sidelines in the near term," Anmuth wrote.
Oppenheimer lowered its rating on Expedia to market perform from outperform.
Expedia announced in January that it's acquired Travelocity from Sabre (SABR) for $280 million in cash.

Stock futures pointed to a strong open Tuesday amid strength in most overseas markets. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 17 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures climbed 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64 points.
Stocks reversed higher Monday to solid gains, but volume was lower.
Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.
After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.
On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.
Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.

In stocks, Home Depot (HD) rallied 3% in premarket trading in the stock market today after beating views. The home improvement retailer posted Q3 earnings of $1.35 a share on sales of $21.8 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.32 on revenue of $21.76 billion. It also pegged full-year earnings at $5.36 a share or a nickel above views.
Rival Lowe's (LOW) was also up 3% in premarket trading. It reports quarterly results Wednesday.

Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 2% in the premarket despite posting mixed quarterly results. The world's biggest retailer reported fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.03 a share. But excluding a gain from leases, earnings were 99 cents a share. Sales came in at $117.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $117.79 billion.

Fitbit (FIT) gained more than 2% in premarket activity after being upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank Of America/Merrill Lynch. Shares of the maker of fitness trackers bounced back Monday after hitting a record low Friday.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) plunged 15% in premarket trade following disappointing earnings for Q3 and a weak outlook. The retailer posted adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $1.64 billion. Views were for EPS of 47 cents on sales of $1.64 billion. The retailer guided Q4 earnings at $1.10 to $1.25 a share vs. views for $1.43. On Monday, shares fell to their lowest levels since January 2012.

Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, the Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and the S&P 500 ended up 0.3%, with the latter two finishing just 1% below their all-time peaks. Volume was about 10% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.

In the stock market today, oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and driller Diamond Offshore (DO) each rose 6%, leading the S&P 500. Oil prices jumped more than 3% to just below $48 a barrel amid a strike by oil workers in Brazil and a port shutdown in Libya.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) led the IBD 50, jumping 10% in heavy volume as it climbs the right side of a deep base. The provider of wealth management services in China is due to report Q3 results Nov. 16. Profit for the period is seen rising 21% to 41 cents a share, which would be the biggest gain in four quarters.
Medical products stock Cambrex (CBM) rose more than 6% after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. It's also climbing the right side of a new base.

In post-session trading, luxury electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose sharply on a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss. The stock fell more than 2% during the regular session, ending 27% off its 52-week high.
Shares of real estate website Zillow (Z) was down about 5% after hours following its Q3 results.

Also after the close, Groupon (GPN) edged higher after its Q3 report. The provider of discounts from retailers also announced that COO Rich Williams will replace Eric Lefkofsky as CEO. Lefkofsky will become chairman.
LGI Homes (LGIH), Facebook (FB), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Stocks were near their session highs midday Friday amid another raft of corporate earnings and strong jobs data.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were each up 0.4%, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%. Volume was running higher across the board in the stock market today.

LinkedIn (LNKD) gapped up and skyrocketed 14% in reaction to late Thursday's upbeat fourth-quarter results. The stock opened well above a 243.35 buy point in a flat base. Bank of America/Merrill Lynch upgraded shares to buy from neutral Friday.

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) gapped up and rallied 8% as strength in the first quarter offset weaker-than-expected Q4 results. At Friday's high, the stock was 19% past a 164.58 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. In most cases, investors should take profits at 20% to 25%. But in choppy markets, investors can take profits sooner.

NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) jumped 5% and cleared resistance at the 80 level. The stock reversed lower Thursday despite reporting Q4 earnings and sales above views late Wednesday. Thursday's move puts it 5% past a 78.44 buy point from a flat base.
On the downside, Expedia (EXPE) was up off its session low, but still down by 11% on late Thursday's disappointing earnings. Oppenheimer and Atlantic Securities both downgraded the stock Friday.

Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, the Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and the S&P 500 ended up 0.3%, with the latter two finishing just 1% below their all-time peaks. Volume was about 10% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.

In the stock market today, oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and driller Diamond Offshore (DO) each rose 6%, leading the S&P 500. Oil prices jumped more than 3% to just below $48 a barrel amid a strike by oil workers in Brazil and a port shutdown in Libya.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) led the IBD 50, jumping 10% in heavy volume as it climbs the right side of a deep base. The provider of wealth management services in China is due to report Q3 results Nov. 16. Profit for the period is seen rising 21% to 41 cents a share, which would be the biggest gain in four quarters.
Medical products stock Cambrex (CBM) rose more than 6% after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. It's also climbing the right side of a new base.

In post-session trading, luxury electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose sharply on a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss. The stock fell more than 2% during the regular session, ending 27% off its 52-week high.
Shares of real estate website Zillow (Z) was down about 5% after hours following its Q3 results.

Also after the close, Groupon (GPN) edged higher after its Q3 report. The provider of discounts from retailers also announced that COO Rich Williams will replace Eric Lefkofsky as CEO. Lefkofsky will become chairman.
LGI Homes (LGIH), Facebook (FB), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Expedia's purchase of Travelocity from Sabre for $280 million in cash last month represents a final exchange of wedding vows in what's been a successful partnership between two online travel pioneers.
The merger solidifies Expedia's (EXPE) position in online travel, where it's No. 1 in U.S. gross travel bookings but faces pitched competition from Priceline (PCLN).
Priceline leads in overseas bookings and is allied with China's Ctrip.com International (CTRP). Expedia and Priceline are also being challenged by Alibaba Group's (BABA) Alitrip Web travel business.

"The acquisition simply consummates a move that began in 2013, when Expedia reached a deal with Sabre to assume the booking volume of Travelocity," Douglas Quinby, an analyst with travel research firm PhoCusWright, told IBD. "The acquisition brings another really strong domestic travel brand into the Expedia portfolio."
Quinby says the deal gives Expedia more leverage with suppliers and vs. Priceline in the U.S. market.
Expedia needs all the help it can get against Priceline, says Quinby.

"What often goes overlooked is how rapidly Priceline's European brand Booking.com has grown in the U.S., because 100% of Booking's volume is reported in Priceline's international business," he said. "Booking.com has become the largest seller of (hotel rooms) in the U.S."

Expedia's many brands, besides Expedia.com, include Hotels.com, China-based eLong (LONG), discount travel website Hotwire, metasearch site Trivago, CarRentals.com, hotel reservation specialist Venere.com and business travel provider Egencia. Expedia says it will retain the Travelocity brand.
Integrating Travelocity's systems and business had a big impact on Expedia's U.S. bookings starting in Q1 2014, RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney said in a research report last month.

"Overall, Expedia is maintaining a high absolute rate of bookings growth, indicating that it has substantially worked through the various business challenges that came up in 2013," Mahaney wrote. Competition and a slip in revenue per room night added to profit margin pressures for Expedia in 2013.
He says Expedia outpaced Priceline's U.S. bookings growth in the first three quarters of 2014.
Mahaney estimates Expedia's global bookings rose 23% in 2014. The company is set to post Q4 earnings after the close Thursday.

FBR Capital Markets analyst Jake Fuller said in a Jan. 23 report that FBR estimated the Travelocity price tag at just $180 million-$190 million, but he still sees the deal as adding to Expedia's bottom line even at the $280 million price.

The merger is "bad news" for lagging Web travel firm Orbitz Worldwide (OWW), he says. Orbitz, which trails Priceline and Expedia in gross travel bookings, reportedly has hired a financial adviser to explore a possible sale. Expedia now is not a likely buyer.

Expedia in August 2013 agreed to power Travelocity's back-end systems and provide its travel inventory in exchange for half of Travelocity's revenue. The deal was seen as a raising of the white flag by Travelocity, which had gradually lost ground to Expedia and Priceline.

Travelocity, known for its "Roaming Gnome" mascot, was created in 1996 as a unit of Sabre Holdings. Sabre (SABR) then was a subsidiary of American Airlines, charged with running the carrier's computerized reservation system. Travelocity's launch was overseen at the time by Terry Jones, a top Sabre IT executive who became its CEO.

Sabre spun off Travelocity as a publicly traded company, but brought it back in-house in 2002.Expedia's purchase of Travelocity from Sabre for $280 million in cash last month represents a final exchange of wedding vows in what's been a successful partnership between two online travel pioneers.The merger solidifies Expedia's (EXPE) position in online travel, where it's No. 1 in U.S. gross travel bookings but faces pitched competition from Priceline (PCLN).Priceline leads in overseas bookings and is allied with China's Ctrip.com International (CTRP). The Nasdaq showed Tuesday it's not just going to keep breezing to record highs. The composite fell 0.6%, its largest loss since Jan. 30. It closed back below 5,000, the last major milestone before the Nasdaq can top a record high that has stood for nearly 15 years. The S&P; 500 fell nearly 0.5%. Both broad indexes trimmed losses and…

Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. Stocks closed with a flourish Thursday, although volume dwindled on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 rose 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.2% in the stock market today.
Generic drugmakers were the top-performing group, up more than 7%.

Dow component Pfizer (PFE) agreed to buy Hospira (HSP), a member of the 17-member group, for a 39% premium over Wednesday's close. Favorable reactions to earnings reports from Lannett (LCI), Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) and Perrigo (PRGO) also boosted the group.
Akorn (AKRX), another generic drugmaker with a specialty in injectables, vaulted out of a base to a new all-time high.
Oil stocks were also strong as the price of a barrel of West Texas intermediate crude finished over $50, a nearly 5% increase.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 38 rose and 12 fell. The best performer was O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), up 8%. The auto parts retailer reported better-than-expected earnings in the morning. It roared out of a flat base in heavy volume.

The worst performer was Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR). The stock initially jumped in reaction to its earnings report, then finished down more than 7% in heavy volume. The move put a serious crimp in the right side of a potential base.
Good gains in DuPont (DD), Pfizer and Visa (V) helped boost the Dow.

Stocks were again mixed in late trading Friday, but they were looking to close out a short trading week with big gains.The Nasdaq was still up 0.3%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%. All three were on pace to end a three-week losing streak. Volume was again tracking lower on both major exchanges.In stocks, Box (BOX) was back near its session high at 24.73. Shares made a strong debut in the stock market today. Late Thursday, the cloud-storage provider sold 12.5 million shares at 14 each or above the expected range of 11 to 13. Shares opened at 20.20 and ran as high as 24.73.Inphi (IPHI) bolted 6% to its best levels in nearly four years. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based firm makes semiconductor products for the communications, data center and computing markets. It has delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit profit growth. Analysts see that streak continuing when it reports Q4 results Feb. 9. Inphi was recently featured in The New America.Expedia (EXPE) rallied 3% and regained its 50-day line. Earlier, the company announced that it bought online booking website Travelocity from Sabre (SABR) for $280 million in cash. Expedia runs its namesake website, as well as Hotels.com, Hotwire.com and CarRentals.com.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) turned tail and lost 2%. The stock is sandwiched between its 10-week and 40-week moving averages as a potential base forms. Earlier this month, the company announced that it would offer soda from Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) for its upcoming cold-beverage machine.

For Expedia, the big change came when it began to listen to what its customers wanted instead of treating them as just another sale."Years back, we treated customers as though they were transactions, with little care of who they were or what they wanted to buy," David Doctorow, Expedia's (EXPE) chief marketing and strategy officer, told IBD. "We've made the move from treating them as transactions to treating them as people. It sounds simple, but there's a combination of science and art to get that correct."The Bellevue, Wash., company is one of the largest full-service travel sites. This one-stop shop offers customers everything in travel: hotels, airfare and rental cars. Including its namesake site, the company's portfolio contains 12 brands such as Hotels.com, Hotwire, Trivago, CarRentals.com and Expedia Cruise Ship Centers. It also runs international travel sites such as Egencia, a global full-service travel company; Venere.com, a hotel specialist in Europe; and eLong, which sells hotel rooms in China.Ryan Jacob, portfolio manager of the Jacob Internet Fund , says that a lot of the company's growth has come from its international business."The vast majority of the profits come from hotels, which is a fragmented market that will always be fragmented, and Expedia has scale in a market that needs a middleman," Jacob told IBD. "And the hotel market outside the U.S. is even more fragmented."Smarter Is BetterWith more than 5 billion flight searches per year, Expedia has always been a Big Data company. However, to understand its customers better, Expedia became a "smart data" company. This means recognizing customers whether they use a personal computer, tablet or mobile phone. It also means remembering what the customer searched for previously, even on a different device.This part of the strategy is called "test and learn." Doctorow says that the company does thousands of tests to find out what does, and doesn't, work with customers, who let them know what they like through their behavior and feedback. The company quickly and seriously follows up on customer complaints, using technology to analyze and fix issues as they arise.Expedia's Scratchpad app came from such testing. The company said that over the past four years, the average number of flight searches a customer makes per booking has jumped from 15 to 48. Realizing that most consumers jot down handwritten notes to keep track of the info, Expedia created Scratchpad as a place to record all a person's searches instantly while simultaneously updating the pricing. To maximize efficiency, the app keeps the information even if the consumer switches devices in between searches."Customers tend to shop in patterns, and this gives insight to help serve them better in the future," said Doctorow. "We use the data to shop 24/7 in order to make offers that are relevant to them and lower in price. The customers appreciate that we recognize what they are shopping for and care about."Actions that provide value and savings to the customer show Expedia's loyalty to the consumer, who then begins to trust the company and return its loyalty, says Doctorow. This strategy includes the Expedia Plus program, which lets customers earn points that they can trade in for automatic upgrades at 1,400 hotels around the world.Bookings Are Bookin'Expedia's way seems to work. In the third quarter, domestic bookings of hotel rooms grew 24% over the year-earlier quarter, while international hotel room bookings jumped 31%.Helping the results are two big moves that Expedia made last year. In March 2013, Expedia bought a majority stake in Trivago, one of Europe's largest and fastest-growing travel sites. Then in August 2013, Expedia agreed to run the technology platform for one of its chief competitors, Travelocity. Basically, all of Travelocity's content, inventory, customer service and technology come from Expedia, which then receives most of the revenues.A Rising Tide In 2014Travelocity accounted for 400 basis points of the growth in domestic hotel rooms, plus a large part of the 30% year-over-year increase in air tickets sold, according to financial services company Raymond James. Meanwhile, Trivago grew 50% in the third quarter."Overall travel was healthy in 2014, a lot of companies did well, not just Expedia," Aaron Kessler, a senior research analyst at Raymond James, told IBD. "Still, they are executing much better today than a few years ago."Kessler says that Expedia has added more hotel rooms because it's allowing consumers to pay the hotels directly instead of collecting the fees and paying hotels later. By letting smaller hotels control the cash flow, it has expanded the amount of inventory that a hotel is willing to give Expedia.Still, not everyone is gung ho. Google (GOOGL) is one concern."They have done things to improve the consumer experience," said Ken Sena, a research analyst at investment banking advisory firm Evercore ISI, told IBD. "But long term, we see their position as tenuous. We see Google moving further into Expedia's line of business."

Stocks were holding near their session highs late Monday after staging a big upside reversal in the morning. A weak jobs report pressured equities at the open.
The S&P 500 rallied 0.9%, while the Nasdaq gained 0.8%. The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average led with a 1% gain.

Epam Systems (EPAM) stretched its gain to 8%, pushing further into new-high territory. The stock, which was No. 11 in Monday's IBD 50, earlier cleared a 63.60 buy point in a flat base. Epam had traded tightly in recent weeks, showing supporting action. The stock previously broke out in February and has now reached the 20% profit zone from a 52.99 buy point from a cup base.

JD.com (JD) rose 2%, clearing resistance at the 30 area. On Thursday, JD.com announced that a former Yahoo China executive, Chen Zhang, had joined the company and will head research and development for JD Mall. Shares of JD.com are 3% past a 28.59 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared March 3.

Lennar (LEN) lost 2% after reversing from a multiyear high. The stock is on pace to snap a five-session win streak. Despite the reversal, the stock is still about 8% past a 48.10 buy point from a cup base.
In a recent Inside Real Estate article, real estate agents expect sales of new homes to surge this year.
