Stocks fell in the final hour of trading Wednesday after the European Central Bank and Germany made statements about Greek debt that seemed harsher than before, but the indexes still finished mixed.
The Nasdaq fell 0.2% and the S&P; 500 dropped 0.4%. But the Dow Jones industrial average clung to a tiny gain. Volume tracked higher than Tuesday on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.
In the stock market today, the Dow was buoyed by Disney (DIS), up nearly 7% on the heels of a better-than-expected earnings report Tuesday evening. Visa (V), another Dow component, rose 2%.
Energy stocks were among the worst performers. Oil plunged 8% after a report that oil inventories were higher than expected.
Airlines were the top-performing group for the day, up 3.2%.
After the close, Tableau Software (DATA) rose sharply after reporting EPS of 42 cents a share compared with estimates of 11 cents. Revenue of $142.9 million topped estimates of $122.5 million.
Under Armour (UA) was volatile after the close. It reported earnings and revenue that beat estimates and offered revenue guidance in line with analysts' forecast.
Before the open Thursday, the Commerce Department will report jobless claims for the week ended Jan. 31. Economists estimate 290,000 new claims vs. 265,000 for the prior week.
January chain-store sales will also be reported.

The major stock indexes closed with losses of more than 1% Wednesday after the indexes made bearish price reversals.
The Nasdaq, which had been up about 1% earlier, closed nearly 1.2% lower. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average slid about 1.4%.
Volume rose across the board, early indications showed. Declining stocks led advancers by more than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq and by 11-to-4 on the NYSE.
The way the indexes reversed course Wednesday quickly dampened the bullish tone of the prior session, when the main indexes made a follow-through rally confirmation.
The number of stocks rising in big volume rapidly diminished in the final two hours of trading.

Apple (AAPL) was a highlight in the stock market today after the company unveiled a series of new products. It introduced the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus, a larger tablet dubbed the iPad Pro, major improvements to its Apple TV franchise and other product upgrades.

But Apple shares fell 2%. Suppliers of components for Apple products were weaker, too. ARM Holdings (ARMH) fell 3%, Avago Technologies (AVGO) nearly 2%, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) more than 1%, Qorvo (QRVO) 3%, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) 1%.

MasterCard (MA) dropped 3%, sinking back to its 200-day moving average, after the credit-card company warned that profit growth would slow in the next few years. The stock has been below the 50-day moving average for a couple of weeks already.

Stericlycle (SRCL) tumbled 6%, dropping to its 50-day moving average, where it now looks for support. The stock closed 5% below the 143.79 buy point of flat base. The medical-waste handling company announced an offering of 7 million depositary shares that represent 10% of certain preferred stock.

Analysts at FBR & Co. are watching to see how online travel agency TripAdvisor (TRIP) weathers the current deceleration in online hotel shopper growth."Hotel shopper growth has slowed from 36% in 2013 to the teens so far in 2014, but cost-per-click revenue growth has accelerated with ramping revenue per shopper," wrote FBR & Co. analyst Jake Fuller in a research report Tuesday.To counter the falloff, TripAdvisor has rolled out Assisted Book, a product designed to "keep shoppers in the TripAdvisor environment vs. being sent off to an advertiser's site," Fuller wrote.But the question remains whether TripAdvisor "can sustain cost-per-click revenue growth in excess of shopper growth," Fuller said.The investment bank maintained its market perform rating for TripAdvisor stock, as well as its price target of 85.TripAdvisor stock was up a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 74. Earlier, TripAdvisor stock briefly hit a 10-month low of 72.54.TripAdvisor stock is down 33% since late June, when it brushed an all-time high of 111.24.In August, TripAdvisor cut the number of ads shown per hotel on its site from four to two, a move Fuller said could stimulate pricing. Now, he said, TripAdvisor is showing three ads. "We see the increase as a positive from a user experience standpoint, as it provides the shopper with a better picture of market pricing," he said.Fuller added that the addition of ads "significantly increases available inventory — 320 available slots in our August survey to 480 — but could be offset by lower pricing."TripAdvisor competes against Expedia (EXPE), Priceline (PCLN), which have each acquired metasearch businesses, Fuller said. And Google (GOOGL), the online search leader, is developing its own travel search products.That is making for "stiff" competition for TripAdvisor, Fuller said, "which could make it difficult (for TripAdvisor) to sustain both hotel shopper growth and margin."RELATED:TripAdvisor Carries Uber Offers; Shared Services Grow.

OpenStack could soon be the software that runs the non-Amazon cloud.Open-source software available for free, OpenStack helps corporate IT departments manage data centers packed with computer servers.OpenStack has also gained popularity as a tool to connect data centers to public clouds, where computing resources are shared via the Internet.But Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services (AWS) is by far the biggest provider of infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS). And it uses its own software, not OpenStack.Still, OpenStack has gained popularity among enterprises that want to use multiple cloud platforms.For investors, the question is: which companies will gain the most from OpenStack's rise as a cloud operating system?"There's a big roster of household name IT vendors that are backing OpenStack — Intel (INTC), IBM (IBM), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Dell and HP (HPQ) — a lot of companies have placed a bet," said Al Sadowski, an analyst at 451 Research.Worries over whether OpenStack could handle large business workloads have eased. So OpenStack seems primed for wide adoption, though there are open-source rivals such as Citrix Systems' (CTXS) CloudStack, points out James Staten, a Forrester Research analyst."The concerns now are less about the platform itself and who is influencing its development," Staten told IBD. "The concerns instead are about who takes OpenStack successfully to market and begins to lead through market power. That's a key theme worth watching in 2015."Rackspace, NASA DevelopedRackspace Hosting (RAX) and government space agency NASA co-developed OpenStack in 2010, aiming to make the software a cloud computing standard. Rackspace's main business has been hosting websites. Rackspace stepped up investments in OpenStack in 2012 and 2013, but its revenue growth slowed as companies lingered in testing OpenStack's capabilities.Rackspace now supports multiple cloud platforms and has become less dependent on OpenStack near term."While Rackspace continues to develop solutions on the OpenStack platform, management is providing managed cloud solutions across multiple technologies," wrote James Breen, a William Blair analyst, in a research report last month.The OpenStack ecosystem is growing, says 451 Research. The market research firm says that OpenStack-related revenue will rise to $3.49 billion in 2018 from $890 million in 2014."All OpenStack needs to do is get to the same reliability and resiliency as the computing platforms it's replacing," Sadowski said. "It's clear, though, that OpenStack is gaining mindshare and marketing power."Early backers hoped that OpenStack would slow the march of AWS. Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan estimates that AWS revenue will jump 40% to roughly $5 billion in 2015. Even so, "OpenStack is starting to mature as enterprises shift legacy IT workloads to cloud environments," Horan said.Expedia (EXPE), Walt Disney (DIS), Time Warner Cable (TWC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and BMW are among recent OpenStack adopters, says 451 Research. Earlier users included eBay's (EBAY) PayPal, Best Buy (BBY) and Fidelity Investments.To attract corporate customers, OpenStack supporters positioned the open-source software as an alternative to VMware 's (VMW) software, widely used in data centers to make servers more efficient.Red Hat (RHT), the leading provider of Linux open-source server software and a VMware rival, has lined up behind OpenStack.But pushing its own cloud platform is still VMware's top priority, analysts say. With partners such as the privately held Mirantis, VMware sells software that helps its customers use OpenStack for building so-called "private" cloud data centers that are accessible by branch offices, clients and others.Analysts say that most enterprises are interested in a public-private hybrid cloud model — running the most important business apps on their own servers behind a private corporate firewall and accessing public IaaS providers as needed.Many tech vendors are focused on providing tools for hybrid clouds. Rackspace aims to provide managed services in the hybrid cloud market rather than struggle vs. much bigger IaaS firms AWS, Microsoft (MSFT) and Google (GOOGL).Positioned As Cloud Concierge"Rackspace continues to remain technology agnostic even as the company's OpenStack is increasingly attractive as a platform for public cloud," said Barclays analyst Sandeep Gupta in a report. "As AWS, Microsoft and Google continue to put pressure on pricing, we wouldn't be surprised if Rackspace positions itself as a cloud concierge to a hybrid cloud environment."Many tech suppliers aim to use OpenStack to bridge private and public clouds."The strong leaders in OpenStack today are a mix. Hewlett-Packard and Red Hat are clearly strong voices in the community, as is SuSE, Mirantis, Internap (INAP) and arguably Cisco Systems due to their recent moves," said Forrester's Staten. "Rackspace still has a strong voice, IBM to a lesser degree, as they are really only focusing on it for their private cloud initiatives."IBM last year acquired cloud-service firm SoftLayer for $2 billion. HP has said that it'll spend $1 billion over the next two years on products and services around OpenStack.451 Research says that Europe-based OVH and startup Blue Box have gained traction with OpenStack customers. Some companies are using acquisitions to gain a foothold in cloud computing services and OpenStack. EMC (EMC), another cloud company, acquired Cloudscaling in October, Cisco bought Metacloud in September and Red Hat purchased eNovance in June.Lydia Leong, an analyst with research firm Gartner, agrees that OpenStack has gained momentum. The OpenStack Foundation, with more than 430 members, has regularly rolled out improved versions of the software."OpenStack is gaining more traction than it had before as the product starts to become more useable," Leong told IBD. "The primary beneficiaries are those that sell (software) distributions, such as Red Hat, HP and Mirantis."

Uber's decision this summer to release its application programming interface (API) could be a game changer for the travel industry.An API is software code that lets other applications and websites easily integrate each other's functionality.By making its API public, Uber lets customers book rides directly from TripAdvisor (TRIP), Hyatt Hotels (H), United Airlines (UAL) and a handful of other apps and sites, including Starbucks (SBUX).Previously, "shared services" providers like Uber and its rival taxi service Lyft, as well as private-accommodations marketplaces such as Airbnb and HomeAway (AWAY), distributed their listings directly to consumers only through their websites and mobile apps.Shared services offer convenience but also have brought legal and regulatory issues.Still, the integration of shared services into the listings of TripAdvisor and other online travel agencies, or OTAs, promises more wide-ranging implications.And we can expect to see a lot more activity on this front, says a longtime industry observer."Just as department stores change their merchandise mix, you'll see OTAs evolve similarly," said Henry Harteveldt, co-founder of Atmosphere Research, a travel industry advisory firm.Harteveldt says that OTAs have to offer shared services if they want their customers to find what they're looking for, since they are increasingly looking for Uber and Lyft rides and private accommodations via Airbnb and HomeAway."Those companies are reshaping how people travel," he said.Lyft Could Follow SuitUber is the only one of the above firms to have released a public API. Observers expect that Lyft will have to respond in kind.Airbnb and HomeAway have built APIs for specific partners but have yet to release public code.Harteveldt says his research indicates that 12% of leisure travelers stay at least once a year at a rented condo or home, the types of places that people book with Airbnb or HomeAway."That's definitely a noticeable number, and the OTAs are taking steps to embrace that," Harteveldt said. "They do not want to be left out of the loop."OTAs decline to discuss a topic that's touchy with hotel chains, car rental agencies and their other longtime partners.Online travel leaders Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline (PCLN), which have not adopted the Uber API, didn't respond to requests for comment.TripAdvisor spokeswoman Erin Millard said via email that the company wouldn't comment on strategy, revealing only that the firm's integration with Uber is a commission-based relationship.But John Samuel, a senior vice president at Sabre (SABR), a travel industry tech provider and parent of online travel agency Travelocity, suggests that the playing field could get crowded sooner rather than later.Samuel runs Sabre's fast-growing TripCase travel itinerary-management app.In response to a question about linking with Airbnb, Samuel implied that TripCase — which is among the apps that have integrated with Uber — is investigating how to integrate with other shared accommodations providers."We are having lots and lots of conversations with everybody," Samuel said.While the taxi industry and government officials in the U.S. and other countries are trying to deal with the impact of Uber and Lyft, the growing prospect of online travel sites exposing travelers to shared-services alternatives is certainly causing consternation at car rental firms and hotels, all of which reluctantly pay healthy commissions to OTAs in exchange for the bookings that they generate."I'm sure there are some very tough negotiations that will take place between traditional hotel companies and the OTAs over the fact that OTAs are selling these alternative accommodations," said Harteveldt. "If I was the brand manager or CEO of a major hotel company where we already have issues working with OTAs because of perceived high costs, I would not be at all happy to hear them say they'll be selling alternative services."Travel Agencies Must AdaptBut traditional travel services providers will have to adapt, says Harteveldt. He points out that shared services like Uber and Airbnb have become popular with younger, tech-savvy travelers. Sabre's Samuel argues that the proverbial genie is out of the bottle."Mobile unlocked an opportunity in travel that didn't exist before, and that's to connect with a traveler in a pretty sophisticated way while they're traveling," he said. "We know when you've gotten off your flight, and we know what hotel you're staying at, so it's only logical that we offer Uber as a complimentary service."But travel industry observers don't expect shared service providers to duplicate the OTA-centric models of hotels and rental car companies. They prefer that customers use their smartphones to deal with Uber or Airbnb directly."Shared services won't ever let themselves be reliant on OTAs," Harteveldt said. "They want the majority of business to come directly from consumers."In other words, the Ubers and Airbnbs of the world are likely to approach their integration efforts with online travel agencies as incremental revenue streams.
The major averages were little changed at midday Tuesday in light Veterans Day trading.
The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were all flat in a seesaw session.
Holiday trade was quiet in the stock market today, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 9% on the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.

Automakers paced the early gains. Tesla Motors (TSLA) is attempting to climb back above its 50-day moving average after rising 3% in heavy volume. The maker of luxury electric vehicles is working on a new base.
Travel stocks were also faring well. Expedia (EXPE) was up 1% as it works on an irregular base.

Meanwhile, Sierra Wireless (SWIR) continued to rise after gapping up and clearing a 30.65 buy point of a cup-without-handle base Nov. 6 following a strong quarterly earnings report. The stock was up nearly 2% at a new high in heavy turnover at midday Tuesday. It's 19% past its buy point, near the 20% profit-taking zone.

On the downside, Alibaba (BABA) was down nearly 4% in active trade even though the Chinese e-commerce giant racked up more than $9 billion in sales on the Singles Day shopping event. As the Zhuhai air show in China takes off, Boeing (BA) and Airbus both plan to boost the amount of aircraft components they source from the nation.
Airbus' COO says the European aerospace giant plans to source $1 billion in aircraft components from China, double its current amount, by 2020.
At a separate briefing at the air show, Boeing's Commercial Airplane VP, Kent Fisher, said it plans to double its $2 billion in aircraft parts sourced from China over the next several years.
Boeing shares rose fractionally on the stock market today.

China has become a new battleground for the two aerospace giants as the Chinese middle class grows rapidly and wants to travel more. (For similar reasons, U.S. online travel giants such as Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline (PCLN) also see China as the new frontier, with the latter recently taking a stake in local online site Ctrip (CTRP).)
In its September outlook, Boeing forecasts China needing 6,020 new airplanes over the next 20 years, valued at $870 billion.
China is seen taking delivery of nearly 45% total demand for airplanes in the Asia-Pacific region over the next two decades.
Also Tuesday, Boeing inked a deal with Aviation Industry Corporation of China to make composite tail parts for Boeing 777s starting in 2017.
China already produces the emergency doors in some Airbus A330s and Boeing 787 jets and some composite materials from locally sourced products.

Several investment houses lowered their price targets. Travel review and metasearch firm TripAdvisor issued Q3 EPS that missed analyst estimates, but sales beat. CEO Steve Kaufer said in a conference call with analysts that the…

Online travel stocks crashed Tuesday as a trio of companies posted earnings or gave guidance that lagged Wall Street expectations.Priceline (PCLN) started the damage early Tuesday, issuing disappointing guidance for the current quarter, partly on the currency and travel fallout from the Ukraine crisis.Late Tuesday, TripAdvisor (TRIP) reported third-quarter earnings that missed analyst earnings, while vacation home rental firm HomeAway (AWAY) gave Q4 revenue guidance that missed views.Priceline stock fell 8.4% Tuesday. TripAdvisor stock was down more than 11% in after-hours trading Tuesday, while HomeAway stock was down more than 12%, after both issued their Q3 reports.Online travel firm Expedia (EXPE), which late Thursday posted better-than-expected results but — as is its custom — gave no guidance, had risen the two trading days after its report. But its stock fell 2.4% in Tuesday's regular session and was down nearly 1% after hours.The news wasn't all bad, though. Priceline's Q3 EPS, as usual, crushed analyst views, and sales beat. TripAdvisor's Q3 revenue beat, and HomeAway beat on Q3 EPS and sales.Norwalk, Conn.-based Priceline, which trailblazed a name-your-price service, earned $22.16 a share minus items, up 28% vs. the year-earlier quarter. That beat by $1.05 the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. It beat earnings by 47 cents in Q2.Revenue rose 25% to $2.84 billion, edging views of $2.83 billion.For Q4, Priceline expects to earn $9.40 to $10.10 a share ex items, on an 11% to 18% revenue gain. That's well below the 24% sales jump and earnings per share of $10.91 forecast by analysts.Analysts note, though, that Priceline typically provides conservative guidance."Hopefully, (Priceline's) guidance is a little bit conservative because it's definitely a sharper drop off (in revenue and EPS) than we've typically seen from them," Raymond James analyst Aaron Kessler told IBD. But Kessler said Q3 showed good growth for Priceline despite expected weakness in its core European market."I believe our teams are executing very well in an intensely competitive marketplace and against a mixed global economic and political backdrop," Priceline CEO Darren Huston said in a conference call with analysts Tuesday.Analysts estimate more than 60% of Priceline's bookings come from Europe. They are denominated in euros and other local currencies that have weakened vs. the U.S. dollar in recent months. CFO Daniel Finnegan said on the call that the "deterioration in European exchange rates is indicative of weakening economic conditions in key markets."Finnegan said Priceline's Q4 outlook also reflects higher ad costs, partly spent to help "reposition" OpenTable, the restaurant-reservation website Priceline acquired in July for $2.6 billion.Gross bookings, the dollar value of all travel services bought by consumers, surged 28% in Q3 to $13.8 billion, rising just 10% in the U.S. but 32% outside the U.S.S&P Capital IQ equity analyst Tuna Amobi predicted in a post-earnings report Tuesday that Priceline's full-year revenue will close the year up 26% despite European economic uncertainties, reflecting market share gains, healthy volumes and stable pricing in key markets. With full-year contributions from OpenTable, Amobi sees Priceline revenue rising 22% in 2015.Late Tuesday, TripAdvisor CEO Steve Kaufer said Q3 was impacted by lower-than-expected click-based revenue growth. "These results, while strong, were not as strong as contemplated by our Q1 and Q2 guidance commentary," Kaufer said in a conference call with analysts.Kaufer said the slower clicks trend surfaced in August. He attributed it to seasonal factors in the wake of TripAdvisor's shift to a metasearch business model.Q3 sales surged 39% to $354 million, beating analyst forecasts of $348.8 million. The Newton, Mass.-based company said it earned 48 cents a share minus items, up 6.7% and 12 cents below the consensus analyst forecast.TripAdvisor didn't issue a formal outlook for the quarter. But CFO Julie Bradley said on the conference call that the company is reiterating its full-year 2014 guidance for revenue growth "in the high 20s to low 30s." It rose 24% in 2013.HomeAway, meanwhile, forecast revenue of $107 million to $109 million for the current quarter, below the $112.4 million analysts had forecast, according to Yahoo Finance. Its EPS ex items rose a penny from Q3 2013 to 20 cents, and sales rose 30% to $117.1 million, both above views.

Priceline (PCLN) stock skidded more than 8% in morning trading on the stock market today after the online travel agency issued disappointing guidance for the current quarter on the adverse currency and the Ukraine crisis, but the company posted Q3 earnings that beat forecasts.
Priceline's Q3 sales also edged views, but the company sees trouble ahead.

"The deterioration in European exchange rates is indicative of weakening economic conditions in key markets," Priceline CFO Dan Finnegan said in a conference call with analysts early Tuesday. But company executives also noted that Priceline ended the summer travel season with strong operating performance and market-share gains in all regions.

The Norwalk, Conn.-based company, which trailblazed a name-your-price service, earned $22.16 a share minus items, up 28% vs. the year-earlier quarter. That beat by $1.05 the estimate of 26 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Priceline beat earnings by 47 cents in Q2.
Revenue rose 25% to $2.84 billion, edging analyst views of $2.83 billion. Q3 gross travel bookings, the value of all travel services bought by consumers, jumped 28% to $13.8 billion.
For the current quarter, Priceline expects to earn $9.40 to $10.10 a share ex items, on a 11% to 18% revenue gain. This is below the 24% sales jump and $10.91 per-share EPS expected by analysts.

Analysts estimate that more than 60% of Priceline bookings come from Europe and are denominated in local currencies that have weakened vs. the U.S. dollar in recent months as the Ukraine crisis deepened.
Priceline CEO Darren Huston noted on the call that the weaker euro also encourages travelers from that region to book cheaper accommodations, hurting Priceline's revenue.

CFO Finnegan said on the call that Priceline's Q4 guidance also reflected higher ad costs, with a portion aimed at helping to "reposition" OpenTable, the restaurant-reservation website that Priceline acquired in July for $2.6 billion.
Analysts pointed out that Priceline typically provides conservative guidance.
Rival online travel agency Expedia (EXPE) reported Q3 earnings and revenue last week that topped Wall Street views, boosted by a partnership with Web travel firm Travelocity.
Online travel site TripAdvisor (TRIP) reports earnings after the close Tuesday. TripAdvisor stock was down more than 1% in morning trading Tuesday.

Midcap core and value mutual funds have played performance cat and mouse in the past 15 years, while midcap growth funds have lagged far behind.

An investment of $10,000 in the average midcap value fund on Sept. 30, 1999, would have grown to $42,015 by Oct. 13 this year, according to Morningstar Inc. data. The same investment in midcap core funds, which invest in both growth and value stocks, would have swelled to $40,696.
Investors in midcap growth funds would be looking at $23,250, a lot smaller than value and core.
That was still ahead of the $19,419 from the S&P 500, a proxy for the broad stock market and large-cap stocks.

The bear market of 2000-02 was growth funds' undoing. Loaded with highflying te`ch stocks when the dot-com bubble burst, midcap growth funds fell like a rock, while value and core funds coasted lower.

Since the market bottom in October 2002, midcap growth funds have done a better job of keeping up with core and value. The growth contingent has generated an average annual return of 11.74% vs. core's 12.08%, value's 11.85% and the S&P 500's 9.23%.
Value has an edge again this year, as the latest market pullback has hit highflying growth stocks the hardest.
Of the top-performing midcap funds of the past 15 years, JPMorgan Mid Cap Value , Wells Fargo Advantage Special Mid Cap Value and Perkins Mid Cap Value have done the best at hanging on to gains.

JPMorgan Mid Cap Value's recent holdings include Expedia (EXPE). Expedia has been a consistent earnings grower, but the stock has been beat up in the market sell-off, sliding 16% from its all-time peak hit in September.

Analysts see earnings rising 23% this year and 18% next year. Q2 earnings grew 61%, beating estimates. The Internet travel site reports Q3 earnings at the end of the month. Analysts expect growth of 22%.

Another holding is Ball (BLL), which has held up better. The stock halted its recent slide to just under its 50-day moving average and 5% off its recent all-time high. The container maker is the biggest stock in its Container/Packaging industry group and also has the group's best IBD Composite Rating: 78. That goes along with its Earnings Per Share Rating of 94 and Relative Strength Rating of 91.

Multisector bond mutual funds and unconstrained bond funds, which are lumped into Morningstar's nontraditional bond fund category, shift assets among various types of bonds — from Treasuries to high yield — depending on opportunities and risk.

Of the top-performing multisector bond funds for the past five years with assets of at least $100 million, Pimco Income Fund has given investors the best year-to-date return: 7.26%. Barclays' aggregate bond fund index is up 6.08%.

Pimco Income, with $38.6 billion in assets, is yielding 4.09% and has an average effective duration of 4.09 years, according to Morningstar data. The fund uses a complex strategy that involves shorting government-related bonds while investing in a variety of fixed-income sectors.

MainStay Unconstrained Bond Fund fits in among the top-performing funds of the past five years in Morningstar's nontraditional bond fund category. The $2.5 billion fund has risen 0.91% year to date. MainStay Unconstrained has about 76% of its assets in corporate bonds and 13% in government bonds.Midcap core and value mutual funds have played performance cat and mouse in the past 15 years, while midcap growth funds have lagged far behind.An investment of $10,000 in the average midcap value fund on Sept. 30, 1999, would have grown to $42,015 by Oct. 13 this year, according to Morningstar Inc. data. Stocks traded lower soon after Friday's opening bell, with earnings reports and disappointing second-quarter GDP estimates factoring into early trade.The Dow industrials fell 0.4% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq dropped 0.2%.The economy grew 1.2% in the second quarter, according to an initial GDP estimate from the Commerce Department, effectively level with the first quarter's 1.1% gain and far below expectations for a 2.6% increase. Prices, on the other hand, jumped more than expected -- up 2.2% vs. a  0.4% increase in the first quarter and above views for a 1.8% gain.Labor costs were in line with expectations, with the Labor Department's Employment Cost Index up 0.6% during the second quarter.An update on July Midwest manufacturing from Kingsbury International's Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index is up next at 9:45 a.m. ET, followed by the University of Michigan's July Consumer Sentiment Index at 10 a.m.San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams speaks at 9:30 a.m. ET.  Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan speaks at 1 p.m.Techs were on the move ahead of Friday's open, with Alphabet (GOOGL) and Amazon.com (AMZN) pacing the pack after strong quarterly reports late Thursday.Google parent Alphabet rose 3.7% in morning trade as its second-quarter earnings bounced back from a first-quarter miss, topping analysts' expectations.Amazon climbed less than 1% after handily clearing analysts' second-quarter targets and giving generally healthy guidance, but gains were moderated somewhat by weaker-than-expected third-quarter operating income guidance. One of IBD's Leaderboard stocks, Amazon ended Thursday's session just off its July 12 high and extended after a June rebound from its 10-week moving average.IBD 50 stock Gigamon (GIMO) swung up 4% after a nice beat on its Q2 results. The network security firm's stock is extended above a 34.24 cup-with-handle buy point.Beyond tech stocks, Rubbermaid products maker Newell Brands (NWL) climbed 7% on stronger-than-forecast second-quarter earnings and revenue. The report marked Newell's first quarter since its $15.4 billion acquisition of Jarden in April.Stamps.com (STMP) was an early winner, but reversed to trade down nearly 8%.Railcar manufacturing and leasing operation Trinity Industries (TRN) surged 6.5% after its quarterly results.On the downside, Expedia (EXPE) dropped 3% after a mixed second-quarter report. Expedia is considering spinning off its majority stake in Trivago, a unit that brought in $201 million in second-quarter sales, up 41% vs. the year-earlier period.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dived 7.5%, despite stronger-than-forecast Q2 revenue and earnings. The company said it had received far fewer table permits than requested for its new $4.2 billion casino in Macau, China.Other earnings-related losses included a 18% plunge for Stericycle (SRCL), Western Digital (WDC) falling 9%, and Baidu (BIDU) down 5%.Oil prices were under some early pressure, with West Texas Intermediate down a fraction and near $41 a barrel, and Brent crude off more than 1% and just above $42. Gold ticked up 1% to above $1,344 an ounce. The dollar moved broadly lower, and the 10-year Treasury yield reversed, slipping 2 basis points to 1.49%.In the other global markets, China's leading indexes slipped on Friday, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 bumped up 0.6% after the Bank of Japan voted for a mild increase in its monetary stimulus measures. Europe's markets were mixed, with up and down gaps widening in afternoon trade.As the stock market heads into the final trading session of July, tech stocks and small caps have been the month's clear leaders. The Nasdaq climbed 6.5% for the month through Thursday, giving the index a 2.9% year-to-date gain. The S&P 500's July gain was 3.4% through Thursday, its fifth straight monthly advance, putting it 6.2% above its Dec. 31 close.Blue chips lagged the market, with the Dow industrials up 2.9%. Among the small-cap gauges, the Russell 2000 showed a 5.7% gain through Thursday and the S&P Smallcap 600 advanced 4.9%, rising to new highs mid-month, then holding its ground.

Expedia (EXPE) subsidiaries HomeAway and Trivago will each reach $1 billion in sales next year, Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman predicted Friday after the online travel agency's mixed Q2 earnings report late Thursday.But that will follow share loss to No. 1 rival Priceline (PCLN) and hotel chains like Marriott International (MAR) and Hilton Worldwide (HLT), he said. Euromonitor analysts said this week that Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and TripAdvisor (TRIP) are pressuring online travel agencies.By the closing bell on the stock market today, Expedia stock fell 2.2% to 116.65. Shares are down 6% for the year, as IBD's 10-company Leisure Booking-Travel has risen 3%. On Friday, the travel stocks were up, with Priceline climbing nearly 2% to 1350.81. TripAdvisor lost 1.8% to 69.97.IBD'S TAKE: Priceline tops IBD's 10-company Leisure Booking-Travel industry group, but the group itself is only ranked No. 106 out of 197 groups tracked. Priceline stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 89, meaning it performs in the top 10% of stocks in terms of key metrics.For Q2, Expedia reported $2.1 billion in sales and 83 cents earnings per share ex items, up 32% and 7%, respectively, vs. last year. Sales missed analysts' view for $2.25 billion, but EPS beat the 78 cent expectation.Adjusted earnings before interest taxes depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) came in at $330.9 million, topping the consensus for $294.5 million, Credit Suisse analyst Stephen Ju wrote in a research report.HomeAway contributed $35 million to EBITDA, topping models by Kopelman and the consensus for $3 million and $17 million, respectively. HomeAway revenue accelerated 36% to $172 million on its new online booking commission fee model.But overall organic room night growth slowed to 12% year over year, from 24% in Q1. Kopelman noted headwinds including Orbitz's integration following its $1.3 billion acquisition last September, as well as share losses to Priceline and traditional hotels, and a weaker macroeconomy.Online travel has steadily improved since bottoming in 2009, Benchmark analyst Daniel Kurnos wrote in a report, but he says an uptick in terror attacks is likely to weight in the near term. Still, Expedia's international and domestic gross bookings increased a respective 16% and 31% in Q2.Expedia reiterated its full-year EBITDA model for 35%-45% growth. The company said the year will include greater contributions from HomeAway and Orbitz, which are already ahead of earlier guidance for $275 million to $325 million, Cowen's Kopelman said.That effectively lowered Expedia's core EBITDA expectations from 8%-13% growth, he wrote. And if room nights don't modestly accelerate in the second half of 2016, EBITDA will wrap the year close to the lower end of guidance.Kopelman lowered his 2016 EBITDA expectation to $1.635 billion, but he boosted his price target on Expedia stock to 135 from 130. He has an outperform rating on shares and in a research report highlighted bright spots like HomeAway's "blowout quarter" and a potential Trivago initial public offering.

Expedia (EXPE) stock fell after hours Thursday after the No. 3 online travel agency reported Q2 sales that missed views by nearly $150 million, though earnings topped Wall Street's expectations by a nickel.In after-hours trading, Expedia stock was down more than 7% after the company posted its Q2 earnings. Shares rose 1.8% in the regular session Thursday, to 119.27. Shares are down 4% for the year, but have risen 12% this month. Meanwhile, travel stocks are up 7% over the last four weeks and are up 3% this year.For Q2, Expedia reported sales of $2.1 billion and earnings per share ex items of 83 cents, up a respective 32% and 7% vs. the year-earlier quarter. Sales missed the consensus of 27 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $2.25 billion, but EPS beat the 78-cent view.Expedia pulled in $18.86 billion in gross bookings (excluding eLong), up 25% vs. the year-earlier quarter. The company reported 20% room-night growth, also excluding eLong. Expedia sold its majority stake in China online travel firm eLong in May 2015.Along with Trivago's founders, Expedia is exploring the potential of filing an initial public offering for Trivago, the unit that brought in $201 million in Q2 sales, up 41% vs. the year-earlier period. Expedia has a controlling stake in Trivago.HomeAway pulled in $172 million in sales, growing 36% vs. last year. Expedia completed its $3.9 billion acquisition of vacation-rental site HomeAway in December.Expedia didn't provide Q3 guidance in its earnings release, but analysts had modeled sales of $2.62 billion and EPS minus items of $2.61, which would be up 35% and 26%, respectively.Priceline (PCLN) and Ctrip.com (CTRP) lead Expedia in terms of market cap, but Expedia's IBD Composite Rating of 84 only trails Priceline, which has a CR of 89. Both perform in the top 15% of stocks in terms of key metrics like growth and earnings.Industry research Euromonitor expects Expedia to generate $70 billion in bookings in 2016, up 15%. Expedia completed its $1.3 billion acquisition of Orbitz last September.But rivals like Google (GOOGL) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) will challenge traditional online travel agencies like Expedia, Priceline and Ctrip, analysts say."Online travel agencies are expected to respond to this challenge by changing their business models, shifting their focus from that of pure online-bookings providers to offering services throughout the travel experience," according to Euromonitor.

Hotel chains like Hilton Worldwide (HLT) and Marriott International (MAR) likely hurt No. 3 online travel agency Expedia (EXPE) during Q2, Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman said Tuesday. But Wall Street consensus expectations are for double-digit sales growth.At the close on the stock market today, Expedia shares shaved off 3 cents to 117.64. The shares are down 5% this year, while IBD's 10-company Leisure-Travel Booking industry group is up 2%. The group ranks a low No. 117 out of 197 groups tracked.IBD'S TAKE: None of the 10 companies in the Leisure-Travel Booking industry group is rated very highly. No. 1 online travel agency Priceline leads the group with an IBD Composite Rating of 87, meaning it performs in the top 15% of all stocks in key metrics. Get Priceline's Stock Checkup.In June, hotel chains upped their assault on Priceline (PCLN), Expedia and TripAdvisor (TRIP), offering "member rates" that undercut online travel agencies by 2%-20% in an effort to avoid 10%-15% online travel agency (OTA) fees, Kopelman said in a research report. He models 18% organic room-night growth vs. last year.That would decelerate from 24% growth in Q1, which enjoyed Easter Weekend and Leap Day tailwinds, Kopelman wrote.Priceline is the No. 1 OTA by market valuation, with China's Ctrip (CTRP) No. 2.For Q2, the consensus of 27 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters models Expedia to post $2.25 billion in sales, up 35% year over year, and 78 cents earnings per share ex items, down 12%. But analysts project a return to EPS growth in Q3.That's vastly too high, according to marketing analysis firm Jumpshot. Based on historical bookings trends and Jumpshot's tracking of 160 billion user clicks monthly, the firm predicts Expedia's Q2 sales coming in at $1.9 billion, up 26%.

Amazon (AMZN), Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and CBS (CBS) all topped quarterly estimates Thursday, while Expedia (EXPE) plunged after reporting and Baidu (BIDU) rallied.Estimates: EPS of $1.11, up more than five-fold from a year earlier. Revenue is seen climbing 27% to $29.55 billion.Results: EPS of $1.78 on revenue of $30.4 billionOutlook: Q3 revenue $31 billion-$33.5 billion vs. views for $31.6 billion.Amazon shares closed up 2.2% to 752.61 on the stock market today, then rose 1.8% after the close.Estimates: EPS up 15% to $8.04. Revenue is forecast to rise 17% to $20.76 billion.Results: Adjusted EPS of $8.42 on revenue of $21.5 billion.Shares climbed 0.5% to 765.84 at the close, then rose 4.5% late.Results: EPS $1.22 of on revenue of $2.75 billion, topping estimates.Outlook: Q3 revenue of $2.714 billion-$2.796 billion, below consensusBaidu, Chinese search leader, edged up 0.1% at 165.63 at the close then fell 2.3% lateEstimates: EPS to rise 23% to 91 cents on revenue down 2% to $1.02 billion.Results: EPS of $1.07 on revenue of $1.06 billion.Casino giant Wynn Resorts' stock climbed 2.4% to 104.66 at the close. The stock fell 4.8% late.Estimates: EPS of 78 cents, up 12%, on revenue of $2.25 billion, up 35%.Results: EPS of 83 cents on revenue of $2.195 billion.Online travel site Expedia closed up 1.8% to 119.27 but fell 3.9% late, recovering steeper, earlier losses after saying it may spin off its Trivago unit in an IPO.Estimates: EPS is expected to rise 27% to 86 cents, with revenue edging down to $3.21 billion.Results: EPS of 93 cents on revenue of $3.29 billionTV broadcaster CBS closed up 0.6% to 54.42. Shares edged down 0.4% late.

Delta Air Lines (DAL), Carnival (CCL), Expedia (EXPE) and other travel-related stocks plunged early Friday after a suspected terror attack left more than 80 people dead in southern France, but many pared losses.Delta shares fell 2.4% to 39.98 in the stock market today. The airline has the most exposure to France of any U.S. airline. American Airlines (AAL) stock erased losses and turned up 1 cent. United Continental (UAL) was off just 0.9%. All three carriers are up sharply for the week.Hilton Worldwide (HLT) shares rose 0.3%. Marriott (MAR) dipped 0.35% and Hyatt Hotels (H) turned up 0.3%.Travel booking site Expedia shares edged down 0.4%. Priceline (PCLN) shares fell 1.2%.Among cruise lines, Carnival fell 2.2%, Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH) 3.7% and Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL) 2.1%.IBD'S TAKE: Most industry groups in the travel and leisure sector are well off highs, but have mounted a rebound of late. Airlines are back up to early June levels after dipping for much of the last month. Hotels recovered to March levels after a four-month drought. The travel booking sector that includes Priceline and Expedia is back up after a brief, Brexit-inspired sell-off. And cruise lines recently broke out to reach prices not seen since December.The attack in Nice happened late Thursday night as revelers were at a parade celebrating France's Bastille Day. A truck, reportedly filled with weapons and explosives, slammed into the crowd killing at least 84 people and wounding 100 others.The suspected terror attack comes eight months after gunmen opened fire at a Paris nightclub and cafes frequented by tourists.But, like prior attacks, the incident in Nice is unlikely to have long term effects on travel.In an prior interview with IBD, Jack Plunkett, CEO of global market research firm Plunkett Research, said that airlines were busy again within a few weeks after the 9/11 terror attacks and the same was true after the 2002 nightclub bombing in Bali, Indonesia, and the transit bombings in Madrid in 2004 and London in 2005.

Stocks opened lower Thursday as more earnings reports came out.The Dow industrials slid 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Nasdaq 0.2%.Earnings reports provided the central force driving the stock market, with Facebook (FB), Ford (F), Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Infinera (INFN) among the movers. NetSuite (N), however, soared on confirmation of a takeover bid from Oracle (ORCL).Unemployment claims jumped to 266,000 in the week ended July 23, the Labor Department estimated, up from 252,000 claims in the prior week and above consensus views for an increase to 264,000 claims. The four-week moving average dipped to 256,500, a fourth straight decline.The U.S. trade deficit widened to $63.3 billion in June, the Commerce Department said. That was up from May's $60.6 billion trade gap, and more than the $61.1 billion estimated by economists.In premarket trades, NetSuite spiked 18% after confirming Oracle had agreed to buy the cloud-based customer-relationship management programs leader in a deal valued at $9.3 billion. Oracle shares rose 2%.A host of names big and small were in motion in a busy reporting session early Thursday: AstraZeneca (AZN) gained 5% at the open. Total (TOT) added 2%.Facebook posted a 3% gain in early trading after reporting a 94% surge in earnings late Wednesday, along with a 60% revenue increase in its second quarter, easily clearing consensus views. Facebook, an IBD 50 and Leaderboard stock, ended Wednesday's session in a buy range above a 121.18 buy point from a flat base.Cirrus Logic stormed ahead 14%. The Austin, Texas-based chip designer reported after Wednesday's close that its second-quarter earnings fell for a fourth straight quarter, but both sales and earnings slipped much less than anticipated. The stock is working on its 11th consecutive weekly advance, and taking new highs.Cirrus peer Marvell Technology (MRVL) opened less than 1% higher. Its after-hours fiscal first-quarter report on Wednesday showed earnings and revenue falling for a sixth-straight quarter and further than forecast by analysts. But management guided second-quarter earnings and revenue above consensus views.Matress maker Tempur Sealy International (TPX) popped 15% after a strong second-quarter beat.Fiber-optic gear maker Infinera plummeted 33%, despite better-than-expected second-quarter sales and earnings. Chief Executive Tom Fallon said in a statement that "demand is softening in certain areas of our business, and we face a difficult near-term revenue outlook."Ford dropped 9% after a mixed second-quarter report, in which management said it may have trouble meeting its full-year earnings and revenue outlook. General Motors (GM) felt some of the downdraft, slipping 4%.Oil prices were little changed, with West Texas Intermediate rising a fraction to near$42 a barrel. Brent crude was down a half percent and just above $43. Gold added more than 1% to top $1,342 an ounce. The dollar was again mixed: up vs. the pound and the yen, but weaker against the euro. The 10-year Treasury yield gained 3 basis points to 1.53%.Markets overseas were generally quiet. China's leading indexes ended Wednesday's session mixed and in a tight range. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slipped 1.1% ahead of Friday's Bank of Japan policy meeting.In Europe, benchmark indexes were narrowly lower in afternoon trade.A busy after-hours earnings schedule includes reports from Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon.com (AMZN), Baidu (BIDU) and Expedia (EXPE), among others.

Hotel chains such as Hilton Worldwide (HLT) and Marriott International (MAR) are chipping away at discounts offered by online travel agencies (OTAs) Priceline (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP), Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman said Tuesday.No. 1 OTA Priceline is least exposed, with only 10%-15% of its business stemming from the U.S., where the online donnybrook is mushrooming. Half of TripAdvisor's and 52% of Expedia's sales are tied to the U.S., he said."These (hotel chain direct) discounts are in addition to loyalty program points and other offers/benefits being provided to customers only when they book direct with the hotel," Kopelman wrote in a research report.Direct discounts range between 2% and 20% cheaper than booking with OTAs, Kopelman wrote. He estimates 50% and 40% of Expedia and TripAdviser's sales are exposed to hotel chains. Only about 15% of Priceline is exposed.Importantly, he said, the direct-booking trend threatens to undo the reputations of OTAs like Priceline and Expedia which offer "Best Price Guarantees" that don't appear to cover the new "member rates" by hotel chains."If the chains are successful in getting the message out that their own sites carry cheaper rates, they may be able to train customers to check the hotel website first before booking, decreasing OTA conversion rates," he wrote.But consumers largely aren't loyal to specific hotel chains, and most hotel chains have yet to buy in on the direct-booking game, Kopelman wrote. Plus, Expedia has a series of popular loyalty programs.On the stock market today, Priceline erased small losses to close up 0.6% at 1275.03. Expedia stock closed down 1.65% to 105.93. TripAdvisor stock dipped 0.5% to 64.30.Hilton shares lost 2.2% while Marriott fell 1%.

Priceline's (PCLN) cease-fire to a four-year Google (GOOGL) ad war with top rival Expedia (EXPE) allowed advertising spending to hit equilibrium in Q1, Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak said Thursday as he upgraded Priceline stock.Ad spending was 35% of Priceline's 2015 gross profit. But incremental bookings per incremental ad dollar (how Morgan Stanley measures return on investment) declined 25% for the year. In Q1, it climbed 78% year over year, he says.Nowak attributed this to lower Google cost-per-click (CPC) bidding competition between leader Priceline and No. 2 online travel agency Expedia. CPCs for half of the top 50 travel keywords on Google are down vs. last year. The median keyword is down 6%.This means the cost of acquiring incremental bookings is falling, Nowak said."After consolidating the market through acquisitions over the past two years, (Priceline and Expedia) are showing the first signs of acting as rational players in a global duopoly," Nowak wrote in a research report Thursday.Nowak expects Priceline's adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) margins to climb in 2016, which be the first time in five years. He also boosted his room-night-stay view for 2017 by 2%.Priceline's 422,000 vacation rentals help it bulk up against alternative accommodations like Airbnb. Alternative accommodations will drive 28.5% of Priceline's bookings through 2018, on a 34% three-year compound annual growth rate.Nowak upgraded Priceline stock to overweight from an equal weight rating and boosted his price target to 1,525 from 1,330. He views the Brexit pullback on Priceline stock -- Priceline felll 11% on Friday and 3.7% on Monday after the U.K. last Thursday voted to leave the EU -- as providing an attractive entry point for stock buyers, noting that only 6% of Priceline's revenue comes from the U.K.Priceline stock edged up 0.7% to 1248.41 on the stock market today. Expedia stock rose 2% to 106.30.

The stock market was mixed with just a few minutes left in Friday's session. Biotechs outperformed with Nasdaq 100 names like BioMarin (BMRN), Biogen (BIIB) and Vertex (VRTX) leading the way.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 eased 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average turned up, rising less than 0.1% amid solid showings by General Electric (GE), Boeing (BA) and Caterpillar (CAT). Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking close to Thursday's levels.Besides biotech, telecom, paper and food stocks outperformed. Retail stocks and online travel firms lagged; the latter hurt by news overnight of a terror attack in Nice, France. Priceline (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) all fell but were near session highs.In economic news, June retail sales came in better than expected. Meanwhile, one day after wholesale prices came in a little hotter than expected, consumer prices rose 0.2% in June, below the consensus estimate of 0.3%. Core prices rose 0.2%, in line with expectations. Core consumer inflation climbed to 2.3%, matching February's peak. It hasn't been higher since September 2008.On the manufacturing front, the New York Fed's Empire State Manufacturing Index softened to 0.55 in July from June's reading of 6.01. Economists expected a reading of 5.0.In the stock market today, Herbalife (HLF) was well off session highs but still rose 10% after the FTC concluded the company is not a pyramid scheme. Pershing Square's Bill Ackman has been a long-time critic of the company while billionaire investor Carl Icahn has defended it.Elsewhere, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) dropped 3% to 405.34 ahead of its July 21 earnings report after Morgan Stanley downgraded shares and lowered it price target to 405 from 500. Morgan Stanley says it could be years before Chipotle fully recovers from the fallout from food-borne illnesses.Chipotle reports Q2 results on July 21.IBD's TAKE: Signs of institutional selling were apparent in Chipotle late last year. Those who recognized it were able to sell the stock before getting hurt. To learn more about recognizing sell signals in a stock, visit IBD University.Inside the IBD 50, Yirendai (YRD) was by far the best percentage gainer, up 13%. News was hard on Yirendai to come by, but Morgan Stanley brought the China-based lending platform public in December at 10.

Stocks opened modestly higher Friday as earnings reports and positive economic data from China bolstered investor sentiment.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose less than 0.2%. The Nasdaq was up 0.1%.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each go into Friday's session up 1.6% for the week. The Nasdaq is bucking to end its first week above the 5000 mark since December, and the S&P 500 is lined up for a record high weekly close. The Dow is tracking toward a third straight weekly gain, up nearly 2% for the week through Thursday and also taking out new highs.Small caps have been even more lively, with the Russell 2000 ahead 2.1% through Thursday, though still below its June 2015 peak. The S&P Smallcap 600 heads into today's stock market up 2.4% this week, and just a heartbeat below its June 2015 record.Big banks continued to roll out quarterly results.Citigroup (C) rose 0.2% and Wells Fargo (WFC) slipped 2%, while PNC Financial (PNC)  and U.S. Bancorp (USB) added 0.5% and 1.5%, respectively, after reporting results.India's Infosys (INFY) tumbled 9% after reporting lower-than-expected fiscal first-quarter earnings and revenue., and slashing its full-year sales guidance.Herbalife (HLF) spiked 18% on news that the Federal Trade Commission determined the network marketer was not a pyramid scheme.Rite Aid (RAD) popped 4%, as news reports said the company and Walgreens (WBA) had entered new discussions with the Federal Trade Commission to rescue what is seen as an endangered $17 billion merger. Walgreens shares slipped 0.1%.A wide segment of travel-related stocks were feeling some premarket pressure, possibly from investors reacting to the attack on a Bastille Day crowd in Nice, France. Delta Air Lines (DAL), Expedia (EXPE), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL) slipped 1% to 3% at the open.Retail sales rose 0.6% for June, the Commerce Department estimated. That was a nice jump up from May's 0.2% increase, and far above estimates for a 0.1% advance. Minus autos and gas, sales rose 0.7%, vs. 0.3% in May, and better than double consensus views for a 0.3% improvement.June consumer prices were steady. The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index ticked up 0.2%, equal to May's gain and a shade below projections for a 0.3% rise. Core prices -- stripping out food and energy -- were the same, up 0.2%, and in line with expectations.New York region manufacturing flattened in July, the New York Federal Reserve reported, with its Empire State Manufacturing Survey showing reading 0.55 for the month. That was sharply below June 6.01 tally, disappointing consensus forecasts for 5.00. New orders and shipment fell to scant gains, and employment and hours worked dipped slightly for the month.June factory capacity and utilization numbers are due out from the Federal Reserve at 9:15 a.m. ET. The University of Michigan delivers its preliminary July consumer sentiment estimate, and the Commerce Department releases May business inventories data, both at 10 a.m. ET.Oil prices could see some effect from Baker Hughes (BHI) weekly rig count, expected at 1 p.m. ET.Oil prices rose nearly 0.6%, putting West Texas Intermediate just below $46 a barrel. Gold slipped a fraction to $1,330 an ounce. The dollar strengthened and the 10-year yield rose 3 basis points to 1.57%.Strong second-quarter GDP growth data out of China helped Asia's markets end a very strong week on a positive note. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.5% Friday to take a 5.3% advance for the week. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 added 0.7% Friday, ending up 9.2% in its best week since December 2009.Europe's markets showed mild losses in afternoon trade. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were tracking toward weekly gains just below 4%. London's FTSE was on to track to end the week up less than 1%.

Online travel companies Priceline Group (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) were the hardest hit tech stocks Friday, as global markets were rattled by Britain's vote to exit the European Union.Priceline, with its key Booking.com hotel reservations unit based in the Netherlands, and which is big in Europe, was falling the hardest. Priceline stock closed down 11.4% at 1,232.14 in the stock market today. Priceline stock broke out of a flat base at a 1,369.13 buy point on June 7, in anticipation Britain would vote to stay, but it's triggered sell rules.Expedia stock sank 7.4%, while TripAdvisor stock lost 6.2%.Other techs also tumbled.Business software giant SAP (SAP), based in Germany, was among the hardest hit. SAP stock dropped 8.8%, hitting a four-month low.The unexpected U.K. vote to leave the European Union led to much uncertainty about how the EU's second-largest economy will disentangle itself from the economic and political union.The tech-laden Nasdaq composite index dropped 4.1% Friday, but the S&P 500 and Dow industrials lost 3.6% and 3.4%, respectively.U.S. tech stocks with above-average exposure to Europe largely mirrored those two stock market indices.Apple (AAPL) shares fell 2.8% to 93.40. About 22% of Apple revenue comes from Europe.IBM (IBM) dropped 5.6%. It gets about 33% of revenue from Europe. Oracle (ORCL), a key SAP rival, tumbled 3.9%, while Intel (INTC) stumbled 4.4% and Microsoft (MSFT) gapped down 4%.

Priceline's (PCLN) expected shift to Facebook (FB) from Google (GOOGL) advertising will yield strong 2017 earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) , Barclays analyst Christopher Merwin said Wednesday as he upgraded Priceline stock.The No. 1 online travel agency spends about 80% of its marketing dollars on Google, Merwin estimated in a research report. But the return on investment in Google advertising has started to drop."We believe Priceline will slowly divert spending to Facebook and other higher ROI channels, which should cause margins to improve," he wrote. "We are 170 base points above Street on our 2017 EBIT."For 2017, Merwin expects Priceline to report $4.86 billion EBIT. The consensus of 24 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expects $4.65 billion.Merwin also boosted his 2016 and 2017 earnings per share ex items models to $67.88 and $80.55, respectively. More broadly, 30 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters average a respective $67.13 and $78.48.Priceline stock closed up 1.3% at 1360.10 on the stock market today. Shares are up 5% for the year, but Merwin says that prices in bearish views of falling take rates, margin deleverage and disappointing Q2 guidance.Last month, Priceline guided to $11.60-$12.50 EPS ex items for Q2 and $740 million to $795 million earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, down 3% and 5%, respectively, at the midpoints. The firm expects 7%-14% year-over-year sales growth.That sales guidance missed, as did earnings, where the consensus is $14.98 EPS ex items and $948.1 EBITDA. Priceline blamed the early 2016 timing of the Euro Cup and Ramadan for slow growth this quarter. Long term, Merwin sees the timing issue working itself out."In fact, we believe take rates are stabilizing as the shift to the agency model is mostly complete," he wrote. "We think margins will improve (in the long term) as Priceline begins to shift ad spend to higher ROI channels like Facebook."Merwin upgraded Priceline stock to overweight from equal weight rating. He has a 1,500 price target on shares.Priceline has an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a possible 99. No. 2 and No. 3 rivals Expedia (EXPE) and Ctrip.com (CTRP) have middling 61 and 53 CRs.IBD's 10-company Leisure-Travel Booking industry group is up 3% for the year, and was up 1.2% Wednesday afternoon. But the group ranks just No. 150 out of 197 groups tracked by IBD.

SolarCity (SCTY) was downgraded to underweight, while Under Armor (UA) and Yelp (YELP) were upgraded to a buy, and Expedia (EXPE) saw its rating raised to overweight from neutral.Barclays downgraded SolarCity to underweight with a price target of 28. Stock in the No. 1 residential installer is down 58% this year.SolarCity, Sunrun (RUN) and Vivint Solar (VSLR) were torched on June 10 after net-metering negotiations in Arizona suddenly combusted, raising a huge question about solar demand in the state after July 2017. Arizona could cut payments to solar customers for excess energy fed back into the grid. That follows similar action by Nevada utility regulators.On Monday, SolarCity announced its service is available to the greater Houston area for the first time. SolarCity climbed 2.6% to 21.88 on the stock market today after rising to 22.50 intraday.Under Armour was upgraded to a buy by Buckingham Research, with a price target of 48. Buckingham predicts future margin expansion for Under Armour despite current promotions. Under Armour shares rose 2.4% to 38.11.Deutsche Bank upgraded Yelp to buy from hold. It set a price target of 33 from 26, citing "stabilized salesforce productivity, more confidence in management and improvements in ad units and systems bolstering our long-term outlook."Yelp shares jumped 5.65% to 28.44.Atlantic Equities upgraded online travel company Expedia to overweight from neutral. Expedia last announced its quarterly earnings on April 28 and beat the consensus estimate. Expedia is down sharply this year but rose 2.9% on Monday to 107.19.Drexel Hamilton reiterated a buy rating on Linux software provider Red Hat (RHT). On Wednesday, Red Hat is scheduled to report first-quarter earnings after the market close. While the stock is down 7% this year so far, Drexel analyst Brian White believes the shares will soon be in positive territory, reflecting Red Hat's strong fundamental trends. Share added 2% Monday.

Online global travel company Expedia late Thursday reported Q3 earnings and revenue that topped Wall Street views, boosted by a partnership with Travelocity. Expedia reported Q3 earnings per share excluding items of $1.93, a 35% increase from the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose 22% to $1.71 billion, primarily driven by growth in hotel revenue and advertising and media. Analysts polled by…
Marriott International (MAR) will be the first of a trio of top hotel companies to announce third-quarter earnings this week in a different economic climate than last quarter.

Reports indicate hotels outperformed the market last quarter, but the spread of Ebola to New York City and other locales in the U.S. could dampen enthusiasm for domestic travel this quarter. The companies may be asked in earnings calls whether they expect an Ebola impact.
Marriott is slated to announce Q3 earnings Tuesday after the market closes. Hyatt Hotels (H) will report on Wednesday morning, and Hilton Worldwide (HLT) is slated for Friday before the market opens.

The reports will provide a better picture of how hotels fared in the quarter after Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) last Friday beat Q3 expectations but sank nearly 3% after its full-year 2015 forecast fell short of analyst estimates. Wyndham shares fell 0.1% to 76.27 in Monday trading in the stock market today.

Consensus of 24 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Marriott's earnings to rise 19% to 62 cents per share, up from 52 cents in Q3 2013. Marriott topped estimates the prior two quarters. Revenue is projected to climb 20.4% to $3.43 billion.
The Bethesda, Md.-based company has said it plans to invest $2.5 billion to $2.7 billion from 2014 to 2017, primarily to develop new hotels and add rooms to existing ones.
Marriott shares rise 0.6% to 69.70 intraday.

Hyatt is also expected to see gains, with EPS projected to rise 13% to 26 cents on a 12.6% increase in revenue to $1.16 billion. Hyatt on Monday announced an agreement with an Atlanta real estate firm to develop the Hyatt Regency Houston Galleria hotel, which will be located near the Houston Galleria shopping mall and is slated to open in fall 2015. Hyatt rose 1.7% to 62.03.

Wall Street forecasts Hilton will report 17 cent EPS. That would be down from 21 cents EPS in Q2 but significantly above the 13 cents it earned in Q1. There are no Q3 comps because it just went public in December. Hilton is expected to see Q3 revenue of $2.6 billion compared with $2.36 billion in Q1 and $2.67 billion in Q2.
Hilton launched its initial public offering in December. After pricing at $20 per share, it began trading on Dec. 12 and its stock has risen about 20% since then. Hilton fell 0.7% to 24.06 Monday.

In addition to the hotels, investors will get another data point about the travel sector when website Expedia (EXPE) reports Q3 earnings Thursday after the market closes. Consensus is for EPS to jump nearly 22% to $1.74 and for revenue to rise 20% to $1.68 billion. Its shares fell 2% to 79.93 on Monday.

Expedia's  (EXPE) improving hotel bookings and profit margins prompted Cowen and Co. Monday to raise its price target on the Web travel firm's stock to 90 from 80, as Expedia stock touched another record high. Analysts Kevin Kopelman and Andrew Marok, in a research report, noted that Expedia's Q2 earnings late Thursday beat views most notably in profitability in…

Analysts expect Expedia (EXPE) to reaffirm full-year 2014 guidance when it reports second-quarter earnings late Thursday. The consensus estimate of 26 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for the online travel agency to earn 76 cents a share, up 18.8% from a year ago, on revenue of $1.44 billion, up 19%. In Q3, Expedia is expected to earn $1.78 a…
Stocks opened lower, then quietly whittled losses Thursday.
The Nasdaq was down 1.5%, up from a nearly 2% drop at the open. The Dow Jones industrial average showed a 0.5% loss and the S&P 500 was down 0.6%. Trade was quiet on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE.

The stock market today opened under some pressure from overseas markets, but losses in Europe moderated in afternoon trade, and quarterly earnings reports moved to the center of investor attention in U.S. trade.

Netflix (NFLX) posted the morning's headline loss, down 23% after reporting disappointing subscriber growth in its third quarter. The loss plunged shares below their 200-day moving average and to their lowest level since mid-May.

Goldman Sachs (GS) slipped 1%, despite third-quarter results that blasted past analyst consensus revenue and earnings views. Expenses rose 18%, however, to $2.8 billion. The slip left shares down a bit more than 3% so far this week.

Delta Air Lines (DAL) vectored up 4% after posting healthy Q3 results. Revenue and earnings, excluding one-time charges, both topped consensus forecasts. The stock dropped out of a base-building effort in late August and is 22% below its June high.
Among leaders, losses were broad but generally mild on the IBD 50 list. About 20% of the list posted losses in the 2% range.
Hardest hit were Epam Systems (EPAM), which dipped 2%. The stock continues to shape a handle on a four-month cup base.
Expedia (EXPE) also shed 2%, putting it down 10% so far for the week and well below its 40-week moving average.

In economic news, positive weekly unemployment claims numbers were followed by an equally solid read on industrial production from the Federal Reserve. production rose 1% in September, reversing a 0.1% decline in August and topping projections for a 0.4% gain. Capacity utilization rose to 79.3%, up from 78.8% and just clearing views for 79%.
Other data was less rosy.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve reported a downshift in regional manufacturing, sending the Philly Fed's October Business Outlook Survey to 20.7, down from 22.5 in September in its second straight monthly decline. The reading was better than the slip to 20 forecast by economists.

Builder confidence also sifted lower, with the National Association of Homebuilders' October Housing Market Index dipping to 54. The decline, the first in five months, put the index well below September's 59 level, disappointing projections for a flat performance.Stocks opened lower, then quietly whittled losses Thursday.The Nasdaq was down 1.5%, up from a nearly 2% drop at the open. Stocks shaved early losses but remained down hard Wednesday as weak economic data hammered away at investor confidence.
The S&P 500 showed a 1.7% loss, up from a more than 2% dive in early trade. The Dow Jones industrial average recovered to a 1% decline, and the Nasdaq narrowed its decline to 0.6%.
Volume rose sharply, up 41% on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE.
The stock market today opened to a wave of disappointing economic news, beginning with September producer price data and topped by a sharp manufacturing slowdown in the New York region.
Another disappointing piece of data: Business inventories eked up 0.2% in August, the Commerce Department reported. That was half of July's increase and estimates for a 0.4% gain.
Oil futures rose slightly, to above $82 a barrel, but remained near enough to multi-year lows to continue pressuring energy-sector stocks.

Drugmaker Shire (SHPG) opened to a 22% loss. A statement from larger suitor AbbVie (ABBV) late Tuesday said the Chicago-based company was reconsidering its $54 billion offer to merge and relocate its headquarters overseas to Shire's Dublin base. AbbVie cited a recent shift in U.S. Treasury rules affecting the benefits of such a strategy. AbbVie opened down 2%.
Online travel issues Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) both slumped more than 4%, the worst losses on the Nasdaq 100. Intel (INTC) dropped more than 4%, dragging on the Dow.
Regional bank KeyCorp (KEY) narrowed to less than 6% its 10% gap-down loss at the start of trade. The Cleveland-based lender reported weaker-than-forecast revenue and earnings.
Essentially all of the IBD 50 stocks opened lower Wednesday. Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) and Expedia notched the heaviest losses, down 4% each.
Salix is below its 10-week moving average and appears headed for a test of support at its 40-week moving average in the fourth week of a steep pullback.
Expedia punched below its 40-week line in heavy trade on Tuesday and is 20% below its Sept. 5 high.

The Federal Reserve releases its October beige book at 2 p.m. ET. A busy after-hours reporting schedule includes reports from American Express (AXP), eBay (EBAY), Netflix (NFLX) and the Kinder Morgan complex of companies.Stocks shaved early losses but remained down hard Wednesday as weak economic data hammered away at investor confidence.The S&P 500 showed a 1.7% loss, up from a more than 2% dive in early trade.
