Ctrip.com International (CTRP) got upgraded by at least three investment banks Thursday after the company's Q1 earnings and revenue forecast for the current period blew past analyst estimates. Ctrip stock touched a record high of 76 early Thursday and was up more than 10% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 72. Ctrip stock has jumped more than…

Priceline Group (PCLN), Expedia and TripAdvisor posted hotel demand gains and share growth in Q1, according to an analyst's report on Monday."Hotel industry demand remained strong on Q1 and the 'Big 3' in online travel — Priceline, Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) — continued to take market share," wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Kevin Kopelman in a Monday research note. "We estimate that the 'Big 3' will generate a combined $80 billion in hotel and vacation rental bookings in fiscal year 2015."Expedia stock was up a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 104. Priceline was up 1%, near 1,214. TripAdvisor was down a fraction, near 82.Kopelman noted that Expedia stood out in Q1 with 6% acceleration in room nights and EBITDA margins, excluding its stake in China online travel agency eLong (LONG), up 80 basis points year over year, "as Expedia benefitted from scale, strong marketing, hotel supply investments and success at Trivago," the German metasearch company that Expedia acquired in 2012."Priceline grew in line, but shares remain under-appreciated largely due to foreign exchange (pressures)," he said.For TripAdvisor, Kopelman said, "we see less upside on estimates risk and concerns over ad spend, but remain bullish on long-term fundamentals."TripAdvisor's ad budget has risen between 40% to 50% year over year for the past four quarters, Kopelman said, "and may accelerate in Q2. Barring meaningful traffic and revenue acceleration, TripAdvisor may need to rein in ad spend in (the second half of 2015), which could impact hotel shoppers growth."Cowen guided Priceline's non-GAAP EPS growth to 8% in Q2, compared to a 15% rise in Q1 2015 and a 23% rise in Q4 2014.Expedia's EBITDA, minus results for eLong, are expected to rise 10% to 15% in fiscal 2015, said Kopelman. In 2011, Expedia boosted its stake in eLong to roughly 57%, while China Web giant Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) also unveiled a strategic investment in eLong.TripAdvisor is expected to post a rise in EBITDA in the "mid-to-high 20s" in fiscal year 2015, Kopelman said.RELATED:'Tale Of Two Cities' On Priceline Growth ConcernsExpedia Stock Flies Higher As Bookings Beat ViewsTripAdvisor Downgrade Cites Consolidation Risks.

Expedia's (EXPE) adjusted earnings swung to a loss but the online travel agency topped revenue forecasts as it reported first-quarter results after hours Thursday.Shares hopped up 4.9% to 98.82 in late trading in the stock market today after briefly spiking above 104 after hours. The stock broke support at the 50-day line Thursday, closing down 2.1% to 94.23. Expedia hit a record 100.51 on April 24.The company said it lost 3 cents a share in adjusted earnings, down from earnings of 16 cents a share last year. Management said a higher effective tax rate hurt adjusted EPS.Expedia reported diluted earnings of 34 cents a share, compared to an 11-cent loss a year ago.Analysts had forecast earnings of 9 cents a share.Revenue grew 14.4% to $1.37 billion, above views for $1.35 billion.Gross bookings rose 19%, and room night growth accelerated to 32%, up from 24% during the same period last year.Expedia rival Priceline (PCLN) rose fractionally in after-hours action. Priceline will report quarterly results on May 7.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Amid a cutthroat price war in China's $116 billion travel market, Expedia cut its losses Friday and shed its majority stake in eLong, potentially allowing rival Ctrip International to tighten its grip on the country's booming online booking sector. Expedia sold its 62.4% stake in the struggling Chinese online travel agency (OTA) for $671 million. Ctrip (CTRP) picked up a…

Priceline Group (PCLN), the world's biggest Internet travel agency through its many websites, is expected to post strong bookings when it reports Q1 results after the close on Thursday, even as foreign exchange headwinds nick the company, which operates heavily in Europe.
Priceline lets customers book hotels, airline tickets and rental cars and makes money from transaction fees. The business has expanded into China and Latin America.

Priceline stock was up a fraction in midday trading on the stock market today, near 1,269. Priceline is trading below its all-time high of 1,281.84, touched in late August 2014. Since the start of the year, Priceline stock has gained 29%.

Acknowledging that Priceline has beaten its own guidance every quarter in 2013 and 2014, the company's growth rates will nonetheless likely "trend lower" in Q1, given the online travel group's immense market size, heavy presence in Europe and the resulting foreign exchange exposure that brings, according to an April 29 report from Ascendiant Capital Markets analyst Edward Woo.
"As Priceline gets 80% of its gross bookings from international (mainly Europe), its impact will be larger than its peers," Woo said.
Ascendiant maintains a buy rating and price target of 1,400 on Priceline Group stock.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters have modeled Priceline to post Q1 revenue of $1.79 billion, up 9%. Priceline's EPS ex items is expected to fall 1% year over year to $7.72, according to Thomson Reuters.
Priceline has guided Q1 revenue to rise 4% to 11% year over year. The company reported total revenue of $1.64 billion in Q1 2014.
Priceline has forecast EPS ex items of $7.20 to $7.75, down 0.7% to 7.8%. In Q1 2014, Priceline reported EPS ex items of 7.81.

Matching the merger mania rocking the online travel industry, Priceline has been expanding, taking over Booking.com, Kayak and OpenTable in recent years. In August, Priceline said it would invest $500 million in Ctrip, the biggest Chinese online travel agency. Both companies agreed to increase the cross-promotion of each other's hotel inventories and other travel services. Ctrip also agreed to promote Priceline's other services, including OpenTable.

Expect Priceline to report increased investment spending in Q1, Woo said. "The company plans to invest more in its recently acquired OpenTable, along with continued investment in offline advertising in 2015 (comparable to 2014). Priceline's high growth and strong momentum (even if moderating) is likely to continue into 2015," he said.

Woo said he expects Priceline to provide initial Q2 guidance "slightly below consensus estimates." Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are modeling Q2 revenue to rise 8% year over year to $2.3 billion and are expecting EPS ex items to rise nearly 5% year over year to $13.11.
The company's moves come as competition in the online travel business is intensifying.

Rival Expedia (EXPE) announced in February that it would acquire Orbitz Worldwide for $1.3 billion. Expedia's buying streak continued in January, when it acquired Travelocity for $280 million in cash.

On Tuesday, Priceline rival TripAdvisor (TRIP) received a downgrade on concerns that it and other online firms face risks from the increasing use of automated "programmatic" ad buying as well as industry consolidation. As more companies promote their products and services through online ads, they could be missing what Marchex CEO and co-founder Peter Christothoulou calls "the $4 billion blind spot."

That's the amount Christothoulou estimates marketers spent last year on mobile search ads that come with click-to-call buttons, which quickly connect consumers via voice contact with the company that placed the ad.
There's no easy way to determine which search keywords led those mobile buyers to the company's website, so there's no way to track offline purchases that began with a mobile customer's Web search.
Christothoulou says that Marchex (MCHX) works with businesses to help them figure out the most effective keywords in order to create effective online ad campaigns.
Advertisers are moving more ad spending to mobile channels to reach the rising number of consumers who shop using their smartphones or other mobile devices.

The shift has been underscored by gains in U.S. mobile Internet search ad revenue attained by companies such as Web portals Google (GOOGL)and Yahoo (YHOO), YP (the privately held company formerly known as Yellow Pages) and crowdsourced online review site Yelp (YELP).
In 2015, U.S. search ad spending on mobile devices is estimated to reach $12.85 billion, passing desktop search ad spending's $12.82 billion, says eMarketer.
By 2017, mobile search ad spending will have pulled significantly ahead — $21.73 billion vs. $9.12 billion for desktop, eMarketer says.
Google estimates that 70% of mobile consumers use click-to-call features. Marchex expects mobile click-to-call ads to generate more than 1 billion calls in the U.S. in 2015.
The advertising technology firm's "$4 billion blind spot" estimate is based on its analysis of call advertising and a weighted average of the cost of call-based ads.
Seattle-based Marchex aims to pare down the size of the blind spot by developing call analytics software that identifies which of a company's online keywords actually are generating offline sales.
Christothoulou recently spoke with IBD about that effort.
IBD: What's the key service your company provides?
Christothoulou: We are able to extract a bunch of interesting metadata (that) the business is able to use strategically to improve their overall marketing tactics.
Our technology tells the marketer which ad the consumer clicked and called on, or which keywords (the consumer used to see the ad in the first place).
The goal for our analytics is really to close the loop and give our clients an understanding of how their mobile marketing is translating to offline purchases, primarily using click-to-call.
IBD: Less than 5% of your company's revenue comes from international business, but Marchex recently announced an expansion into Europe, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Why those markets?

Christothoulou: We're seeing that mobile is global. The clients we work with are enterprise clients. Those businesses want solutions that extend to all their regions. We are going where our customers tell us to go.
People in Australia are clicking to call. We are seeing the same trends in many different parts of the world.
Anywhere you're clicking to call — that's a market that will be interesting to us. So we are just going where the customer demand is.
IBD: You've mentioned your company's focus on 'real world analytics.' What is that?

Christothoulou: Internally, we just call it 'measuring the real world.' What is literally happening right now is brands are forced to spend more on mobile, because that's where the consumers are. But they don't have the tools to really help them determine what the return is and how well they are doing (on mobile ad spending). So we just help shed light on that.
The more we can provide our clients (with) real-time data that tells them how they're doing, the faster they will grow ... because they will spend more money on the right mobile campaigns.
IBD: Are competitors trying to fill the same role?

Christothoulou: The way we think about it is: We have been trying to build these products for four years now and have spent about $100 million on our platform. So the barriers to entry are fairly significant, and the technology is very complex.

The team that built a lot of our products built the Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One's Kinect platform, which is about understanding voice analysis. They are the team that built Expedia's (EXPE) global call center footprint. We call it conversational analytics and processing. This is a new space. I'm sure there will be competition. Right now, we feel good about what we're building.

Clients who use our analytics are seeing their cost per acquisition — meaning the amount of money they spend on a per-customer basis — fall by 30% or 40%. In other words, they are now able to connect the dots between which ads drove the transaction ... and which ads didn't. They can take advantage of understanding what to do in the future and which campaigns to focus on.As more companies promote their products and services through online ads, they could be missing what Marchex CEO and co-founder Peter Christothoulou calls "the $4 billion blind spot."That's the amount Christothoulou estimates marketers spent last year on mobile search ads that come with click-to-call buttons, which quickly connect consumers via voice contact with the company that placed the ad.There's no easy way to determine which search keywords led those mobile buyers to the company's website, so there's no way to track offline purchases that began with a mobile customer's Web search.Christothoulou says that Marchex (MCHX) works with businesses to help them figure out the most effective keywords in order to create effective online ad campaigns.Advertisers are moving more ad spending to mobile channels to reach the rising number of consumers who shop using their smartphones or other mobile devices.The shift has been underscored by gains in U.S. mobile Internet search ad revenue attained by companies such as Web portals Google (GOOGL)and Yahoo (YHOO), YP (the privately held company formerly known as Yellow Pages) and crowdsourced online review site Yelp (YELP).In 2015, U.S. search ad spending on mobile devices is estimated to reach $12.85 billion, passing desktop search ad spending's $12.82 billion, says eMarketer.By 2017, mobile search ad spending will have pulled significantly ahead — $21.73 billion vs. $9.12 billion for desktop, eMarketer says.Google estimates that 70% of mobile consumers use click-to-call features. Marchex expects mobile click-to-call ads to generate more than 1 billion calls in the U.S. in 2015.The advertising technology firm's "$4 billion blind spot" estimate is based on its analysis of call advertising and a weighted average of the cost of call-based ads.Seattle-based Marchex aims to pare down the size of the blind spot by developing call analytics software that identifies which of a company's online keywords actually are generating offline sales.Christothoulou recently spoke with IBD about that effort.IBD: What's the key service your company provides?Christothoulou: We are able to extract a bunch of interesting metadata (that) the business is able to use strategically to improve their overall marketing tactics.Our technology tells the marketer which ad the consumer clicked and called on, or which keywords (the consumer used to see the ad in the first place).The goal for our analytics is really to close the loop and give our clients an understanding of how their mobile marketing is translating to offline purchases, primarily using click-to-call.IBD: Less than 5% of your company's revenue comes from international business, but Marchex recently announced an expansion into Europe, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Why those markets?Christothoulou: We're seeing that mobile is global. The clients we work with are enterprise clients. Those businesses want solutions that extend to all their regions. We are going where our customers tell us to go.People in Australia are clicking to call. We are seeing the same trends in many different parts of the world.Anywhere you're clicking to call — that's a market that will be interesting to us. So we are just going where the customer demand is.IBD: You've mentioned your company's focus on 'real world analytics.' What is that?Christothoulou: Internally, we just call it 'measuring the real world.' What is literally happening right now is brands are forced to spend more on mobile, because that's where the consumers are. But they don't have the tools to really help them determine what the return is and how well they are doing (on mobile ad spending). So we just help shed light on that.The more we can provide our clients (with) real-time data that tells them how they're doing, the faster they will grow ... because they will spend more money on the right mobile campaigns.IBD: Are competitors trying to fill the same role?Christothoulou: The way we think about it is: We have been trying to build these products for four years now and have spent about $100 million on our platform. So the barriers to entry are fairly significant, and the technology is very complex.The team that built a lot of our products built the Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One's Kinect platform, which is about understanding voice analysis. They are the team that built Expedia's (EXPE) global call center footprint. We call it conversational analytics and processing. This is a new space. I'm sure there will be competition. Right now, we feel good about what we're building.Clients who use our analytics are seeing their cost per acquisition — meaning the amount of money they spend on a per-customer basis — fall by 30% or 40%. In other words, they are now able to connect the dots between which ads drove the transaction ... and which ads didn't. They can take advantage of understanding what to do in the future and which campaigns to focus on.

Priceline Group (PCLN) stock fell Thursday after the online travel agency gave a soft outlook for Q2, saying the strong dollar continues to hamper its growth, even as the online travel site's Q1 earnings beat analyst expectations.
Priceline forecast Q2 EPS ex items of $10.95 to $11.75, down 12% to 6% from the year-ago quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had modeled $13.10, up nearly 5%.
Priceline sees Q2 revenue as ranging from flat to up 7% vs. a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters have modeled Q2 revenue of $2.3 billion, up 8% from $2.12 billion in Q2 2014.
Priceline, which is the No. 1 Web travel service company by bookings, reported EPS minus items of $8.12 for Q1, beating Wall Street consensus of $7.72 and up 4% from the year-earlier period.
Priceline posted revenue of $1.84 billion, up 12% and above the consensus estimate of $1.79 billion.
Priceline stock fell 4% to 1213.49 on the stock market today. Priceline hit an all-time high of 1,281.84 touched in August 2014. Shares are up this year.
Gross bookings growth slowed to 12% in Q1 from 34% in Q1 2014.
Expedia Gains In Hotels

Priceline lets customers book hotels, airline tickets and rental cars and makes money from transaction fees. The business has expanded into China and Latin America. In August, Priceline said it would invest $500 million in Ctrip (CTRP), the No. 1 Chinese online travel agency. Both companies agreed to increase the cross-promotion of each other's hotel inventories and other travel services.

Priceline competes with rivals Expedia (EXPE), TripAdvisor (TRIP) and others. A year ago, search leader Google (GOOGL) entered the online travel fray when it licensed hotel-booking software from Room 77, a startup backed by Expedia.
In 2011, Google spent about $700 million to buy ITA Software, a provider of flight information.

RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney said in a research note that Priceline's acceleration in Q1 of international bookings growth, hotel room night growth and rental car days growth "were all positives."

However, Mahaney also wrote that "for the first time, Priceline's hotel room night growth (25%) was surpassed by Expedia's growth (28% ex-acquisitions), highlighting the material improvement in (Expedia's) fundamentals."

TripAdvisor (TRIP) stock was down 5% in early trading in the stock market Thursday, a day after the provider of travel reviews and metasearch services issued Q3 results that largely met analyst views but revealed weaknesses in its click-based ad business amid its shift to a metasearch business model. Some analysts downplayed the problems and raised their price target on…

TripAdvisor (TRIP) upped its full-year guidance late Tuesday, landing an upgrade and sending the stock traveling north on Wednesday. New initiatives and improving monetization from hotel shoppers are laying the runway for "a meaningful pick-up in TRIP's top-line growth for the remainder of the year," wrote Cantor Fitzgerald analyst Naved Khan, who upgraded the stock to buy from hold. "We…

Earnings season is more than half over, but there are still some big-name tech companies to watch after the market closes on Thursday. Online travel agency Expedia (EXPE) is seen earning 76 cents a share, up 18.8% from a year ago, on revenue of $1.44 billion, up 19%. And the recent acquisition of Wotif Group, Expedia's leadership position in online…
TripAdvisor (TRIP) is expected to return to earnings growth in Q1 following two quarters of year-over-year declines.
Per-share profit ex items is seen climbing 10% to 55 cents, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. EPS had fallen 28% to 21 cents in Q4 and 2% to 45 cents in Q3.
TripAdvisor traded up 1.6% in the stock market today. The stock has advanced 1.3% this year.
The travel-review company is expected to report sales up 23% to $282.9 million from $229.9 million in the year-earlier period.

Global travel growth was "solid" in Q1, notes Ascendiant Capital Markets analyst Edward Woo, who rates TripAdvisor stock as a buy. Global air travel jumped 8% year over year in January and 5.4% in February, according to International Air Transport Association data.

"Despite some weather issues in the U.S. and a later (in Q2) Easter this year, we believe the overall travel industry is positive and is likely to remain so near term, which should provide TripAdvisor momentum for 2014," Woo wrote.

TripAdvisor announced on Monday that it has acquired Tripbod, a London-based website where travelers can connect with locals, for an undisclosed price. That follows closely on the heels of TripAdvisor's May 1 acquisition of Vacation Home Rentals, a Massachusetts-based website that lists some 14,000 rental properties.
Rival travel-booking site Expedia (EXPE) in early May topped views for Q1, although it posted a 36% decline in EPS on higher costs.
Travel-booking site Orbitz Worldwide (OWW), however, on Monday missed Wall Street's per-share loss forecast, sending its stock down nearly 5% in early afternoon trading.
Orbitz posted a 5-cent per-share loss ex items, while analysts expected a 2-cent per-share loss, according to Thomson Reuters.
TripAdvisor's earnings are scheduled for late Tuesday.

During the recession, many people took staycations or short road trips close to home. But now vacationers are ready for more exotic locales. Around…

After several chilly earnings seasons for revenue growth, the second quarter's results have been considerably warmer as S&P 500 companies near the halfway mark for reporting their performance. Boeing (BA) inked an order for 50 of the 737 aircraft from China's Juneyao Airlines, according to a Bloomberg News report Wednesday. China has seen a boost in travel due to the rising middle class and an easing of government airline restrictions.
The deal for Boeing's single-aisle plane is valued at $3.8 billion to $5.5 billion. Airlines typically pay less than the list prices for large orders.
Boeing shares were flat at 133.60 in the stock market today.

In February, China's Civil Aviation Administration announced plans to lessen regulations and consider tax breaks that could bring the rise of more budget carriers. The news has Boeing and European rival Airbus scrambling to secure market share in the booming region.

In March, China Eastern Airlines ordered 70 Airbus A320s as narrow-body planes grow more popular worldwide and jumbo jet orders slow. With rising fuel costs and increased traffic to regional outposts, airlines want smaller, more fuel-efficient jets.
Boeing has deliveries scheduled for 140 aircraft to China this year, slightly less than its record of 143 in 2013, according to an announcement from Boeing's China president in January.
Travel has been booming in China in recent years, which is good news for aircraft makers and others in the travel industry.

According to a report by Cowen & Co. in April, hotel industry revenue per available room in China rose 4% in January and February. Expedia (EXPE) has the greatest exposure to China through its majority-owned subsidiaryeLong (LONG).

American e-travel sites aren't the only ones cashing in on China. Ctrip International (CTRP) is a China-based aggregator of hotel reservations. Qunar Cayman Islands (QUNR) is a recent IPO and subsidiary of Chinese Web giant Baidu (BIDU).

Both companies have been struggling in recent months, however, on the costs of their expansion plans into ship cruises, car rentals and group buying for hotels, as well as promotions on mobile devices, according to an anonymous analyst interviewed by IBD this year.
Still, the travel industry in China looks bright. In a November report, Pacific Crest said China's online travel market is projected to grow at a 28% compound annual rate through 2015.

The global hotel industry posted solid numbers in Q1, a positive trend for online travel companies such as Priceline Group (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP), investment bank Cowen & Co. said in a research note Monday.

Cowen analysts Kevin Kopelman and Andrew Marok said hotel-industry revenue per available room, or RevPAR, has been stable or improving across all major regions. RevPAR is a key hotel performance measure.

In the U.S., RevPAR rose 6% in Q1, vs. 6% in Q4 and 5% in Q3. "We note that the U.S. has been the major driver behind stable growth in the Americas region, with Canada, Brazil, and Mexico growth slower through February," the report said.

In Asia, Cowen said China and Singapore have been standout regions for travel. In January and February, China hotel RevPAR rose 4%, vs. 0% for all of Q4 and a decline of 3% in Q3, Cowen said. Singapore RevPAR rose 9%, vs. 0% in both Q4 and Q3.

"We note that among the major U.S. online travel companies, Expedia has the greatest exposure to China, through its majority-owned subsidiary eLong (LONG), and Priceline has the greatest exposure to Singapore (albeit relatively small), through its Agoda brand," the report said.

Priceline ranks No. 32 in the latest IBD 50 listing of top-performing stocks over the past 12 months, though Priceline stock has been trading below the key 10-week line for most of the past three weeks.
RELATED: Priceline latest tech firm to play the name game

Globally, 42% of business travelers age 18-30 report that they will spend more of their company's money on high-end meals than they would their own money while traveling. This compares to 26% of business travelers age 46-65, says a study by Harris Interactive on behalf of Web travel firm Expedia (EXPE) and its Egencia business travel unit.

Millennials are also fans of room service: 37% would spend more of the firm's tab on room service, vs. only 21% of 46- to 65-year-olds. Americans 34 and younger are slightly more likely to spend company money on a flight upgrade to business- or first-class than are their peers who are 35 or older.Globally, 42% of business travelers age 18-30 report that they will spend more of their company's money on high-end meals than they would their own money while traveling. Priceline Group has come a long way since 1998 when a serial inventor and entrepreneur named Jay Walker won a patent for buyer-driven pricing, setting the stage for the first online system that let consumers bid for plane tickets and later, hotel rooms.

The company has morphed into the biggest global online travel agency based on revenue, with an especially strong presence in Europe, where it was early to recognize consumers' fading resistance to electronic bookings. Its shrewd overseas expansion has been a lightning bolt that has shot its shares to record highs, making Priceline Group (PCLN) one of the top stocks of the past 30 years.

Priceline CEO Darren Huston sees many more opportunities for Priceline going forward. The biggest, Huston told IBD in an interview, is to be "truly loved by customers worldwide as the global leader in online travel."

"Our brands are recognized for the outstanding consumer experience they provide," he said. "The way they do that is build it off the best product selection and travel options, great pricing and most simple online experience. That's a big deal. We're now the largest player in the space. Travel is a trillion-dollar industry and our share of that is still less than 5%. So we have lots of opportunities to grow and make a difference."

When Priceline began, Walker's unique reverse auction let travelers specify what they would pay for an airline seat or hotel and ask sellers to match it. The prices were "opaque" since buyers didn't know provider names or details like flight times (in the case of air tickets) until after they made a nonrefundable purchase. This system allowed Priceline to hit critical mass as one of the first successful dot-com companies because it offered a novel way for airlines to sell empty plane seats online.

After a successful 1999 IPO, Priceline quickly transformed into a poster child of the dot-com boom. It proved that consumers would embrace its name-your-own price service at a time when some travel industry professionals and analysts doubted people would buy travel online without the hand-holding of traditional travel agents and hotel reservation desks.

The company got sideswiped in the dot-com bust of 2000-01. Its stock price and business prospects tanked. Walker resigned as vice chairman. Anxious months followed as the company treaded water in the tech recession. A $100 million stock investment by Saudi billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal helped pull Priceline through the tough times.

Priceline then found the right person to take the helm. Jeffery Boyd, a multitalented corporate attorney, joined the online travel agency as an executive vice president and general counsel in 2000. The low-key but far-sighted Boyd quickly ascended the corporate ladder, becoming CEO in November 2002.
Boyd, now 57, led the online travel agency for 11 years on a phenomenal growth journey. The stock began its most sustained move in May 2006, rocketing 5,366% to an all-time high last month.

"We've always been a very lean company and looked after our expenses very carefully," Boyd told IBD. "As a result, we've been able to deliver substantial growth in cash flow and earnings to our shareholders."

The most crucial decision in Boyd's revamp of the company took place in July 2005 when Priceline acquired a then little-known European hotel reservation website called Booking.com for $135 million. Priceline grasped early on that Europeans, who had been slower than Americans to buy travel online due to a more conservative consumer culture, were starting to take the plunge, especially when it came to booking hotels.

The bet proved right. Europe's online travel market soared and Priceline soared with it, ahead of rivals like Expedia (EXPE), Travelocity and Orbitz (OWW), which focused more on the U.S. Booking.com blossomed into the company's most outstanding acquisition, outdoing Internet mogul Barry Diller's acquisition of travel sites Hotels.com and Expedia.com in 2003.

"Priceline identified international opportunities earlier and made some very, very smart, savvy acquisitions," Douglas Quinby, vice president for online travel tracker PhoCusWright, told IBD. Quinby noted that Priceline concentrated at the get-go on booking hotels, unlike rivals like Travelocity, which also entered Europe but spread themselves thin by also offering flights and other travel products.
Almost nine years later, well over 60% of Priceline's bookings come from Europe, mostly via Booking.com, and Priceline has more customers in Europe than the U.S.

Boyd says Priceline's "been very pleasantly surprised" by what he terms the long-term rollout of Booking.com's business throughout Europe and around the world. Netherlands-based Booking.com now advertises heavily in the U.S. and is making inroads with American travelers.
"We've been very happy to see (Booking.com's model) establish traction in virtually all the markets we've moved to," Boyd said.

Boyd says the original thinking was that Priceline already had made an investment in the U.K. in a hotel site called Active Hotels. It believed the international online travel business and hotels would grow faster in the coming years than the U.S. business.

"Booking.com was an excellent fit with Active Hotels because Active had strength in the U.K. with U.K. hotels and customers and Booking.com had strength on the continent of Europe. When we put the two brands together, the blending of those customer bases and hotels created a very significant inflection point for the growth of the business," Boyd said.
Travel Provider Ties

Booking.com also offered hotels in the region the lowest commission rates, flexibility and the largest traveler-user base of any European hotel reservation website. Like North America-based Priceline.com, the company went out of its way to partner well with travel suppliers.

Boyd as CEO also began to de-emphasize name-your-price auctions, which were leveling off in popularity, and added regular fixed-price travel listings to Priceline's website. He carved out a successful beachhead in Asia-Pacific for Priceline through its acquisition of Singapore-based online travel agency Agoda.com in November 2007. Priceline also dived into the up-and-coming metasearch travel business when it acquired Kayak in May 2013.
Though Priceline trailblazed a name-your-price service, PhoCusWright's Quinby says its lasting imprint on the travel business and online services does not lie with a specific innovation or product.

"What's most striking about Priceline is their willingness to pivot their business, to anticipate important market trends and key shifts," Quinby said. This active embrace of change made Priceline a mover-and-shaker in its industry.

The quest for innovation continues. "I nnovation in mobile is one of the things we're most proud of," Boyd said. He notes all three of the Web travel firm's major brands — Booking.com, Priceline.com and Kayak — are now known for their mobile products.
"Priceline was very early and out front in developing mobile travel apps and anticipated the very strong shift from desktop to mobile use," PhoCusWright's Quinby said.

What does Boyd think was Priceline's greatest strength during his tenure as CEO? "One of the most important decisions we made in managing our international business was allowing them to run independently," he said, with capable entrepreneurial leaders in all of its units. "By giving them independence and accountability, they were able to take ownership of the business and grow it very substantially."
Macro Hurdles
"Priceline didn't force synergy and integration on the companies they acquired," PhoCusWright's Quinby noted.

Macro challenges posed some of the biggest hurdles. "We've had to go through wars and the financial crisis, which created challenges for our business and the businesses of others," Boyd said. "Fortunately, the online travel business has some nice growth tail winds to help (us) recover from shocks perhaps more quickly than offline businesses do."

Forty-eight-year-old Huston retained his post as Booking.com's CEO after he replaced Boyd as Priceline CEO on Jan. 1. Canadian-born Huston joined Priceline as chief of the European unit in September 2011 from Microsoft (MSFT), where he held posts including CEO of Microsoft Japan.

Huston has overseen key aspects of Priceline's global business since January 2013, including interbrand relations, distribution and geographic expansion. He's enlarging Priceline's global focus, especially in China, Asia and Latin America.
'Need To Stay Humble'

What is Priceline's greatest challenge? "I'd say it's been primarily how as a company we deal with our success," Huston said. "We've grown big very fast and we are in the Internet entirely — a very competitive space. And in order to continue to win we have to stay hungry. So we execute and innovate at a pace that's fast enough to satisfy our customers and maintain our leadership of the space.

"And we also need to stay humble with our travel service providers. We want to be their preferred partners and have win-win relationships. In the e-commerce space, unlike selling a book or a stove or a computer, the product we sell is a service and we can only deliver that to our customers if we have great relationships with their people who provide the services."

Huston sees China and Asia playing major roles in the company's future. "Like any global company, China and more broadly Asia are going to be critical both to today's success and the future. Today, I'm connecting with you from Hong Kong after a trip to India, Singapore, Vietnam, Thailand and China," Huston said. "I do this quite frequently because of the importance of the business."
The CEO says Priceline has two big players in Asia: Singapore-based Agoda and Booking.com, whose hotel reservations footprint includes Asian travelers. He says both are leaders in their space.

Said Huston: "We believe we have the largest accommodation booking agency in Asia, certainly for intercountry travel, and our growth in Asia largely comes through organic execution, mostly in making our products relevant to Asian consumers and making sure we have the right products on the shelf in terms of hotels and accommodation options."
Huston notes that Priceline also stokes Asian demand by localizing Priceline's website for Asian users in terms of language, currency and travel reviews.

"We've also pursued some unique partnerships in Asia," particularly Chinese Web travel firm Ctrip.com International (CTRP), Huston said. "They're a very close partner in China and they've been helping us build a really sizable Chinese outbound business, which is also important to our success in Asia given that Chinese will be the world's biggest travelers in coming years."
Innovation In Steps

How important will continued innovation be in Priceline's future? "Innovation is pretty fundamental," Huston said. "You've heard the adage 'innovate or die' — I don't think that could be better said for what we do.

"Innovation at the Priceline Group comes in many, many small steps and a few big steps. Those are all used to improve the underlying product. The way we do that is by having a really strong data-driven culture. We use a lot of bottom-up experimentation on our websites and deeply listen to users so that we always focus on the needs that they express.
"Innovation is critical, particularly on the Internet, and has to come in all different sizes and forms for us to be successful in the future," Huston said.

As an example of Priceline's innovative verve, Quinby cited Express Deals, a simplified and less opaque version of its name-your-price service for booking hotel rooms.Priceline Group has come a long way since 1998 when a serial inventor and entrepreneur named Jay Walker won a patent for buyer-driven pricing, setting the stage for the first online system that let consumers bid for plane tickets and later, hotel rooms.The company has morphed into the biggest global online travel agency based on revenue, with an especially strong presence in Europe, where it was early to recognize consumers' fading resistance to electronic bookings. Its shrewd overseas expansion has been a lightning bolt that has shot its shares to record highs, making Priceline Group (PCLN) one of the top stocks of the past 30 years.Priceline CEO Darren Huston sees many more opportunities for Priceline going forward. The biggest, Huston told IBD in an interview, is to be "truly loved by customers worldwide as the global leader in online travel.""Our brands are recognized for the outstanding consumer experience they provide," he said. "The way they do that is build it off the best product selection and travel options, great pricing and most simple online experience. That's a big deal. We're now the largest player in the space. Travel is a trillion-dollar industry and our share of that is still less than 5%. So we have lots of opportunities to grow and make a difference."When Priceline began, Walker's unique reverse auction let travelers specify what they would pay for an airline seat or hotel and ask sellers to match it. The prices were "opaque" since buyers didn't know provider names or details like flight times (in the case of air tickets) until after they made a nonrefundable purchase. This system allowed Priceline to hit critical mass as one of the first successful dot-com companies because it offered a novel way for airlines to sell empty plane seats online.After a successful 1999 IPO, Priceline quickly transformed into a poster child of the dot-com boom. It proved that consumers would embrace its name-your-own price service at a time when some travel industry professionals and analysts doubted people would buy travel online without the hand-holding of traditional travel agents and hotel reservation desks.The company got sideswiped in the dot-com bust of 2000-01. Its stock price and business prospects tanked. Walker resigned as vice chairman. Anxious months followed as the company treaded water in the tech recession. A $100 million stock investment by Saudi billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal helped pull Priceline through the tough times.Priceline then found the right person to take the helm. Jeffery Boyd, a multitalented corporate attorney, joined the online travel agency as an executive vice president and general counsel in 2000. The low-key but far-sighted Boyd quickly ascended the corporate ladder, becoming CEO in November 2002.Boyd, now 57, led the online travel agency for 11 years on a phenomenal growth journey. The stock began its most sustained move in May 2006, rocketing 5,366% to an all-time high last month."We've always been a very lean company and looked after our expenses very carefully," Boyd told IBD. "As a result, we've been able to deliver substantial growth in cash flow and earnings to our shareholders."The most crucial decision in Boyd's revamp of the company took place in July 2005 when Priceline acquired a then little-known European hotel reservation website called Booking.com for $135 million. Priceline grasped early on that Europeans, who had been slower than Americans to buy travel online due to a more conservative consumer culture, were starting to take the plunge, especially when it came to booking hotels.The bet proved right. Europe's online travel market soared and Priceline soared with it, ahead of rivals like Expedia (EXPE), Travelocity and Orbitz (OWW), which focused more on the U.S. Booking.com blossomed into the company's most outstanding acquisition, outdoing Internet mogul Barry Diller's acquisition of travel sites Hotels.com and Expedia.com in 2003."Priceline identified international opportunities earlier and made some very, very smart, savvy acquisitions," Douglas Quinby, vice president for online travel tracker PhoCusWright, told IBD. Quinby noted that Priceline concentrated at the get-go on booking hotels, unlike rivals like Travelocity, which also entered Europe but spread themselves thin by also offering flights and other travel products.Almost nine years later, well over 60% of Priceline's bookings come from Europe, mostly via Booking.com, and Priceline has more customers in Europe than the U.S.Boyd says Priceline's "been very pleasantly surprised" by what he terms the long-term rollout of Booking.com's business throughout Europe and around the world. Netherlands-based Booking.com now advertises heavily in the U.S. and is making inroads with American travelers."We've been very happy to see (Booking.com's model) establish traction in virtually all the markets we've moved to," Boyd said.Boyd says the original thinking was that Priceline already had made an investment in the U.K. in a hotel site called Active Hotels. It believed the international online travel business and hotels would grow faster in the coming years than the U.S. business."Booking.com was an excellent fit with Active Hotels because Active had strength in the U.K. with U.K. hotels and customers and Booking.com had strength on the continent of Europe. When we put the two brands together, the blending of those customer bases and hotels created a very significant inflection point for the growth of the business," Boyd said.Travel Provider TiesBooking.com also offered hotels in the region the lowest commission rates, flexibility and the largest traveler-user base of any European hotel reservation website. Like North America-based Priceline.com, the company went out of its way to partner well with travel suppliers.Boyd as CEO also began to de-emphasize name-your-price auctions, which were leveling off in popularity, and added regular fixed-price travel listings to Priceline's website. He carved out a successful beachhead in Asia-Pacific for Priceline through its acquisition of Singapore-based online travel agency Agoda.com in November 2007. Priceline also dived into the up-and-coming metasearch travel business when it acquired Kayak in May 2013.Though Priceline trailblazed a name-your-price service, PhoCusWright's Quinby says its lasting imprint on the travel business and online services does not lie with a specific innovation or product."What's most striking about Priceline is their willingness to pivot their business, to anticipate important market trends and key shifts," Quinby said. As online travel site TripAdvisor (TRIP) shifts to a metasearch business model, analysts suspect the company could post mixed results when it releases Q4 earnings after the close Tuesday.Mark Mahaney, an analyst from RBC Capital Markets, says revenue could modestly beat Wall Street expectations, but he says per-share earnings could miss by 2 cents.TripAdvisor's shift to metasearch means it will generate more revenue by allowing users to book hotels and other travel products directly, with less emphasis on cost-per-click ads from hotels and online travel agencies.Analysts have expressed some caution over this shift in the near term, as IBD has reported.TripAdvisor stock was down 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 83.50. But the stock jumped 9.5% on Friday, buoyed by an earnings beat by online travel Expedia (EXPE). Here was IBD's report. TripAdvisor stock is up 80% in the past year.TripAdvisor's site gets more than 260 monthly visitors and more than 100 million reviews of some 2.5 million hotels, resorts, restaurants and vacation attractions.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect TripAdvisor to report earnings per share minus items of 21 cents, down 28% from 29 cents in the year-earlier period. But revenue is expected to climb 21% to $205.4 million.For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS ex items of 55 cents, up from 50 cents in the year-ago quarter. Revenue is expected to jump 25% to $276.2 million.In a research report on Friday, Mahaney said he expects an EPS of 19 cents on revenue of $207 million for Q4. He said the U.S. travel industry saw year-over-year growth of 5% in Q4, down from 10% in Q3. He rates TripAdvisor stock sector perform."We view Street estimates for Q4 as reasonable, though we see greater possibility of downside vs. upside variance," he wrote.
Expedia (EXPE) rocketed late Thursday after the online travel agency issued fourth-quarter earnings and revenue that beat analyst forecasts on strong hotel room night growth.

Bellevue, Wash.-based Expedia earned 92 cents a share excluding options expenses, amortization and other items, up 46% from 63 cents a year earlier. That was 6 cents above the average estimate of 29 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Revenue rose 18% to $1.152 billion, the second straight quarter of modestly accelerating growth. Analysts expected $1.138 billion.
Expedia shares jumped 12% to 73.20 in after-hours trading, its highest price since early 2005. The stock had closed up 2% at 65.14.
"We feel good about our overall competitive position," Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshahi said in a conference call with analysts after the results were issued.
Khosrowshahi said Trivago, the German-based hotel metasearch business that Expedia acquired in March 2013, saw its revenue soar over 85% for the full year.
"Expedia is doing very well after a difficult first half of the year," said FBR Capital Markets analyst Jake Fuller. "They have gotten themselves back on track."
The company didn't issue a formal outlook for Q1. Analysts are estimating revenue of $1.17 billion and EPS of 33 cents.
For full-year 2013, Expedia said per-share profit minus items and stock-based compensation weighed in at $3.22 vs. $3.10 in 2012. Sales surged 18% to $4.77 billion.
Gross bookings, the dollar value of all travel services bought by consumers, surged 21% to $9.10 billion in Q4. Hotel room nights jumped 25% year-over-year . Domestic room nights grew 18%.
International bookings grew 24%. Domestic bookings increased 19%. Overseas revenue rose 23% vs. 14% for U.S. revenue.
Worldwide air revenue increased 17% in Q4.

"We're seeing Expedia do very well on the air side. We've seen U.S. ticket volume go from down 2% in Q3 to up 6% in Q4. They were up 20% in December. Part of that is because Travelocity's been integrated much quicker than I thought it would," FBR's Fuller said.

Expedia launched its Brand Expedia hotel and air products on the Travelocity-branded U.S. website in Q4 under the marketing deal it signed with Travelocity last August. It said it expects to complete the shift of its other travel products to the site in the first half of 2014.

JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth noted in a Feb. 4 pre-earnings note that Expedia's investing to expand its global footprint through its various brands including Hotels.com and Hotwire against the backdrop of stiff competition from Priceline's (PCLN) Booking.com. The rivalry is pushing Expedia to boost its sales and marketing investments, which is expected to pressure margins in the near term.

Analysts see Expedia (EXPE) lifted by recovering global bookings growth and revenue from its Trivago metasearch unit when it reports fourth-quarter results late Thursday.The consensus estimate of 29 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for the online travel agency to post earnings, excluding options expenses, of 86 cents a share, up 37% from 63 cents in the year-ago quarter, on sales of $1.13 billion, up 16%.Analysts on average expect Expedia to post EPS of 33 cents in the current quarter, up 32% from the year-earlier quarter on revenue of $1.17 billion, up 15%.For full-year 2013, analysts expect Expedia to post revenue of $4.75 billion, up 18% and EPS of $3.17, up 2%.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney noted in a Jan. 17 pre-earnings report that Expedia saw bookings growth rebound in both international and domestic markets in the last quarter following a disappointing Q2. He expects the upbeat booking trend to continue in Q4 and estimates that Q4 global bookings will show a 15% jump from a year earlier, excluding currency factors.He believes that Street estimates for the quarter are "reasonable" and that Expedia is working through a number of challenges it faced earlier in the year, such as margin pressure and a slip in revenue per hotel room nights. Expedia metasearch unit Trivago appears to be adding to the company's coffers. Problems tied to Expedia's dependence on TripAdvisor (TRIP) as a marketing channel also appear to be moderating with TripAdvisor's new hotel metasearch product showing more traction, Mahaney said.Travel review website TripAdvisor was spun off from Expedia as an IPO in December 2011. TripAdvisor has since shifted to a metasearch business model or price search tool that generates revenue by allowing users to book hotels and other travel products directly. This has caused a shift from cost-per-click ads that direct traffic to Expedia and other online travel agency websites.Mahaney has a sector perform rating on Expedia and a price target of 69.
TripAdvisor is finding that it's good to make good on promises.

The latest data from the world's largest provider of travel reviews show that the fallout from a major change to its business model is abating and the path toward growth seems clear. This was a highlight of the company's Q4 results on Feb 11.

For more than a year, TripAdvisor (TRIP) has been shifting to a so-called metasearch business model. Its site lets users directly book hotels, flights and more by clicking on ad listings that give specific prices and other details. Online travel agencies, hotels and others bid to get the best placements for their listings/ads. In the metasearch model, users can sort the listings by price, availability and more.
With metasearch, TripAdvisor, as always, continues to make revenue per click, but the dynamics change. Before the switch to metasearch, the site depended largely on pop-up ads and multiple clicks.

For a time, metasearch results in fewer clicks. It gets complicated, but basically, with metasearch one click can let a travel product purchaser do what before might have take two, three or more clicks. And the site now offers real-time pricing.

As a result of the transition, TripAdvisor's revenue growth from per-click ads started to slow. Advertiser partners held back on bidding on, and placing, ads as TripAdvisor smoothed its new system. And TripAdvisor had to figure out optimum ad prices and more.
TripAdvisor's revenue and stock kept rising during the transition, but both might have risen faster.

In the company's earnings conference call last May, CFO Julie Bradley said Q1 revenue was "negatively impacted by 3% to 5%" by a temporary impact from the metasearch shift. But Bradley also said TripAdvisor would achieve "revenue neutrality" from the metasearch transition by December — it would by then have made up for the losses from the transition.
Some analysts questioned TripAdvisor's projections, saying the impact of the shift to metasearch at first was worse than expected.
As it turned out, however, TripAdvisor made good on its prediction.
"We are pleased to say that we believe the meta transition achieved revenue neutrality in December," CFO Bradley said on the Feb. 11 call.

"Revenue neutrality means that we have reached a point at which the new (metasearch) product generates revenue at the same level the previous model did," TripAdvisor spokesman Kevin Carter later told IBD via email.

Wunderlich Securities, in a research note this month, said TripAdvisor reached revenue neutrality, thanks to higher ad pricing, more bids from online travel providers for placements and an increase in consumers booking travel products via TripAdvisor ads. Wunderlich also said the number of hotel shoppers on the site jumped 28% in Q4 from Q4 2012.

As TripAdvisor CEO Steve Kaufer put it in the Feb. 11 call: "While the estimated financial impact proves to be choppier than we had originally expected, the (ad) bidding landscape matured during the fourth quarter, driving nice sequential upticks in CPC (cost-per-click) pricing and, correspondingly, revenue per hotel shopper. Consumers love the new hotel shopping experience."

Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson says the likelihood is "high" that TripAdvisor's ad revenue will surge as the company builds more features into its metasearch platform. He says these include initiatives to aid mobile bookings and to let independent hotels and bed-and-breakfast operators bid directly for placement through the company's TripConnect tool.

Analysts say TripAdvisor was able to raise its per-click ad rates to roughly three times higher than the industry average because its metasearch website packs all the pricing options and more right on one page. The result is more bookings by users, and advertisers willing to pay more for their listing ads on the site.
Not that TripAdvisor is alone. Priceline 's (PCLN) Kayak, Expedia's (EXPE) majority-owned Trivago and China's Qunar (QUNR) all use the metasearch model.
TripAdvisor's Q4 results reflected its per-click recovery. CPC-based ad revenue rose 17% from the year-earlier quarter to $144.4 million, ahead of some analyst forecasts and up from 13% growth in Q3.

TripAdvisor's overall revenue rose 26%, its biggest jump in three years.TripAdvisor is finding that it's good to make good on promises.The latest data from the world's largest provider of travel reviews show that the fallout from a major change to its business model is abating and the path toward growth seems clear. Priceline (PCLN) stock hit another all-time high Friday after the fast-growing online travel provider late Thursday blew past Q4 earnings estimates. The online travel leader's Q1 guidance fell short of Wall Street expectations, but Priceline is known for conservative guidance — and big beats. Priceline stock was up 3% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 1,322. Priceline…
Priceline (PCLN) continued a string of positive results from online travel companies with fourth-quarter earnings out late Thursday that crushed expectations, though its Q1 guidance fell short.
Profit per share minus items rose 31% to $8.85, far above consensus estimates of $8.29.
Revenue grew 29% vs. a year earlier to $1.54 billion, just beating forecasts for $1.52 billion. Both earnings and revenue have seen double-digit growth for at least the past 17 quarters.
Adjusted EBITDA (earnings before interest expenses, taxes, depreciation and amortization) increased 36% to $578 million, beating estimates of $539 million.

But Priceline forecast Q1 EPS of $6.35 to $6.85. That would be a 15% gain at the $6.60 midpoint but lagging the consensus estimate of $7.19. It forecasts Q1 revenue will rise 15%-25%, or about $1.5 billion to $1.63 billion. Analysts expected $1.65 billion.
Priceline rose about 2% in after-hours trading, near record highs. The stock rose 9.24 to 1,283 during the regular session.
No. 1 in online travel reservations, Priceline has five primary brands: Priceline.com, Booking.com, Agoda.com, Kayak.com and Rentalcars.com. It also has several ancillary brands.
Booking.com is the online travel leader in Europe, and could benefit as that economy recovers. It's the largest of Priceline's business units.

Priceline's report came on the heels of upbeat Q4 results from rivals. HomeAway (AWAY) jumped nearly 13% to a new high Thursday after the online vacation home rental company late Wednesday reported accelerating revenue growth and raised its Q1 guidance. TripAdvisor (TRIP) and Expedia (EXPE) also exceeded estimates when they reported Q4 results earlier this month.
Priceline reported gross travel bookings of $9.1 billion in the quarter, up 39% from a year earlier. For Q1, it expects a 23%-33% increase.
Priceline said Q4 international travel bookings rose 41% to $7.76 billion. It sees a 25%-35% rise this quarter.
Domestic travel bookings in Q4 rose 27% to $1.4 billion. In Q1 it forecasts a gain of 25% to 35%.
Booking.com "continues to solidify its position" as the world's leading online travel brand, CEO Darren Huston said in a post-earnings conference call.
Huston had run that Dutch-based hotel booking unit until he became Priceline CEO on Jan. 1. He succeeded Jeffery Boyd, who remains chairman.
Booking.com is the No. 1 online hotel reservation service in the world, Priceline said. It boasts a 45% share in Europe of bookings made via online travel agencies.
It offers about 425,000 hotels, up from 355,000 hotels as of last November. In 2013, Priceline invested $2 billion to expand the Bookings.com brand, it said.

"We are pleased with results but there is still more to be done," Huston said on the call. Booking.com is less profitable than Priceline, he said, "but we see it as an attractive long-term opportunity."

Heading into Priceline's Q4 report, several analysts were upbeat. "Global travel trends remain choppy but we are encouraged by continuing improvement in Europe and stable growth in the Americas," wrote Brian Fitzgerald, an analyst at Jefferies.Priceline (PCLN) continued a string of positive results from online travel companies with fourth-quarter earnings out late Thursday that crushed expectations, though its Q1 guidance fell short.Profit per share minus items rose 31% to $8.85, far above consensus estimates of $8.29.Revenue grew 29% vs. a year earlier to $1.54 billion, just beating forecasts for $1.52 billion. HomeAway (AWAY) stock hit an all-time high Thursday after the online vacation home rental company late Wednesday reported Q4 earnings ahead of expectations and raised its Q1 guidance. HomeAway revenue rose 26% from the year-earlier quarter to $90.3 million, its biggest gain in two years, beating views of $87.5 million. But HomeAway earned 8 cents a share, missing consensus estimates…

HomeAway (AWAY) stock was up 1% in morning trading in the stock market today, near two-year highs, after Barclays Research upgraded the online vacation-rental firm to overweight from equal weight and raised its price target to 48 from 34.
Barclays said in a research report Monday that it's upgrading the Austin, Texas-based online marketplace for vacation rental homes because of its "improving outlook" for pay-per-booking revenue.
The investment bank says the company should also benefit from growing adoption of booking and payment-enabled listings that will drive ancillary revenues and a growing opportunity in Asia-Pacific.

"In addition, we believe (HomeAway's) recent partnership with Expedia (EXPE) to distribute listings on their sites is evidence of increasing interest by the OTAs in the vacation rentals category that will most likely be expressed through further partnerships or consolidation, rather than organic competition, in our view," Barclays said.
HomeAway stock is up about 50% since early November, and it ranks No. 23 in the latest IBD 50 listing of top-performing stocks.

HomeAway has an IBD Composite Rating of 97, putting it among the top 3% of companies on a number of key factors, including profit and sales growth.HomeAway (AWAY) stock was up 1% in morning trading in the stock market today, near two-year highs, after Barclays Research upgraded the online vacation-rental firm to overweight from equal weight and raised its price target to 48 from 34.Barclays said in a research report Monday that it's upgrading the Austin, Texas-based online marketplace for vacation rental homes because of its "improving outlook" for pay-per-booking revenue.The investment bank says the company should also benefit from growing adoption of booking and payment-enabled listings that will drive ancillary revenues and a growing opportunity in Asia-Pacific."In addition, we believe (HomeAway's) recent partnership with Expedia (EXPE) to distribute listings on their sites is evidence of increasing interest by the OTAs in the vacation rentals category that will most likely be expressed through further partnerships or consolidation, rather than organic competition, in our view," Barclays said.HomeAway stock is up about 50% since early November, and it ranks No. 23 in the latest IBD 50 listing of top-performing stocks.HomeAway has an IBD Composite Rating of 97, putting it among the top 3% of companies on a number of key factors, including profit and sales growth.

HomeAway (AWAY), slated to post fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday, is expected to maintain strong double-digit revenue growth, after its online travel rivals reported generally positive Q4 results.HomeAway is an online marketplace for the vacation rental industry, with 773,000 paid listings in 171 countries via various websites.The analyst consensus estimate is for revenue of $87.54 million. That would be up 22% from the year-earlier quarter and would maintain a stretch of double-digit revenue growth going back at least 17 quarters.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected earnings per share minus items of 14 cents, which would be flat with Q4 2012. HomeAway's year-over-year earnings growth doubled in Q4 2012, but has since slowed to 56%, 45% and 36% the first three periods of 2013.The company has been aggressive with acquisitions, reporting 22 of them in the past eight years as it's become the leader in vacation-home rentals. In December, HomeAway paid about $200 million to acquire Australia-based vacation rental service Stayz Group.HomeAway stock was up nearly 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 42. The company went public in July 2011 at $27. It's a member of the latest IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks.Chad Bartley, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities, has an outperform rating on HomeAway and a 12-month price target of 50."We are buyers of HomeAway for the strong multiyear growth outlook and upside potential from pay-per-book and higher subscription pricing," Bartley wrote in a research report Tuesday.He said TripAdvisor (TRIP), Expedia (EXPE) and Orbitz (OWW) have made positive comments on trends in Europe, "which is nearly 40% of HomeAway's revenue" and a positive trend for its international business.TripAdvisor and Expedia reported Q4 earnings last week, sending both stocks higher.HomeAway has announced a move to a pay-per-booking model that it expects to drive new business. The model is an alternative to the company's existing subscription offering, as IBD has reported.Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.
TripAdvisor reported lower earnings in line with estimates while revenue jumped, but shares fell late Tuesday as the travel website replaced its auditor.
Fourth-quarter earnings fell 28% vs. a year earlier to 21 cents a share minus items, meeting estimates. That followed Q3's 2% EPS drop as the user review travel site adopts a new business model.
But revenue rose 26% to $212.2 million. Analysts predicted $205.4 million.
Auditor Dismissed

But TripAdvisor (TRIP) announced in an SEC filing that it choose to "dismiss Ernst & Young" as its accounting firm, effective immediately, replacing E&Y with KPMG as its new auditor. The company said there were no "disagreements with E&Y on any accounting principles or practices."
But investors seemed spooked. TripAdvisor shares, which were trading modestly higher after hours, reversed lower, though they did pare losses to about 2%.
TripAdvisor boasts more than 100 million reviews that track 2.5 million hotels, resorts, restaurants and vacation attractions.
Last year it launched a metasearch business model for hotels and other travel products. This feature lets consumers compare prices without having to leave the TripAdvisor site.
While the service is a win for consumers, it is also expected to reduce the emphasis on cost-per-click ads from hotels and online travel agencies — the bulk of the company's revenue.
TripAdvisor's click-based ads increased 17% in Q4 to $144.4 million vs. a year earlier. Revenue from display-based ads rose 46% to $32.5 million.

CEO Steve Kaufer cited revenue neutrality in December despite a Q4 drop in hotel shoppers. "We can theorize that the meta experience has pulled more people back to TripAdvisor for that second purchase," he said in the post-earnings conference call.
Tuesday's results show TripAdvisor is making necessary improvements, said Ken Sena, an analyst for Evercore Partners.

"They are clearly in a transition mode at this point but the meta discussion is only part of it," he said. "Ultimately it's about delivering enough value to the hoteliers to justify the spend they are committing to the platform — they all stand to do that if users continue to get satisfaction out of the site."

"Growth of hotel shoppers hasn't decelerated at all and the idea here is if the company finds its footing on the new model the gap between the number of people shopping and the growth in revenue will narrow," said Jake Fuller, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets & Co.
TripAdvisor results follow last week's much-better-than-expected Q4 results from Expedia (EXPE). Expedia and Priceline.com (PCLN) account for roughly 50% of TripAdvisor's revenue.
Revenue from Expedia, the former parent of TripAdvisor, climbed 17% to $46.4 million vs. the same quarter last year.
TripAdvisor pegs 2014 revenue percentage growth in the low 20s. Wall Street expects a 22% gain to $1.15 billion.
Analysts see Q1 revenue up 25% to $276.2 mil. EPS should return to growth of 10%, followed by 19%, 42% and 95% in the following three quarters.
Spending On Mobile
Subscription, transaction and related revenue totaled $35.7 million, up 53%. Selling and marketing expenses jumped 62% to $108.2 million. Spending on technology and content rose 50% to $35.5 million.

"Mobile bookings and conversions tend to be lower and that is where the company is placing a lot of effort to improve the experience for hoteliers so they can monetize that mobile traffic closer to what they can (get) on a desktop," Sena said.TripAdvisor reported lower earnings in line with estimates while revenue jumped, but shares fell late Tuesday as the travel website replaced its auditor.Fourth-quarter earnings fell 28% vs. a year earlier to 21 cents a share minus items, meeting estimates. Spring break is around the corner and Americans are looking forward to the start of vacation season. Priceline (PCLN), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Expedia (EXPE), Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) are highly rated leisure stocks featured in today's Big Cap Screen of the Day. "American consumers still value their vacations," Hunter Keay, managing director at Wolfe Research,…
The stock market held onto moderate gains midday Friday, ignoring a disappointing jobs report before the open.
The Nasdaq was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%. Volume was running higher on both exchanges.

Facebook (FB) hit a new all-time high, up more than 3% in above-average volume. The stock is basking in the afterglow of a successful bounce off its 50-day moving average and a better-than-expected earnings report Jan. 29.

In the social media space, LinkedIn (LNKD) was down 7%, but well off its morning lows. It reported late Thursday that it expects Q1 revenue of $455 million to $460 million, below the $470 million analysts were forecasting. Twitter (TWTR) was up 5% as it sought to recover from a 24% drop the day before. It reported an expected profit of 2 cents a share — a 2-cent loss was forecast — but disappointed with its user growth figures.
Expedia (EXPE) hit a high after reporting Thursday evening earnings of 92 cents a share vs. 63 cents in the year-ago quarter. Analysts were looking for 86 cents. It was up 14%.

The Labor Department reported nonfarm payrolls increased by 113,000 jobs in January. That's better than the previous month's 74,000, but below the 181,000 jobs economists expected.The stock market held onto moderate gains midday Friday, ignoring a disappointing jobs report before the open.The Nasdaq was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%. A scuba diver swims above a reef dotted with colorful fish. An elderly couple ballroom dances on a beach at sunset. A woman sits on the edge of a rock, meditating at twilight.Then "Diamond Resorts International (DRII): simplicity, choice, comfort," a voice says as the six-minute commercial on YouTube ends.Calling itself a provider of "affordable luxury and priceless memories," Diamond offers vacations in 34 countries at 93 managed resorts, 154 affiliated resorts, 52 affiliated hotels and four cruise itineraries.The vacation packages are low-priced — such as five days and four nights in Cabo San Lucas for $292 or four days and three nights in Las Vegas for $92 — and are a marketing tool.The catch is that customers must be creditworthy, age 25 and older, earning at least $50,000 annually and ready to watch a one-and-a-half to two-hour sales pitch for joining Diamond's club. In the club, members buy points to use toward vacation packages.One of the costliest getaways, a nine-day European cruise on Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings' (NCLH) Norwegian Star, costs 20,000 points at peak season. Among the cheapest, a one-week stay in an Ormond Beach, Fla., studio, runs 1,200 points in low season.Funding The FunDiamond plans to increase its sales force 5%-10% annually over the next few years and boost sales to Asian customers, CEO David Palmer told IBD. About 70% of customers finance their purchase at a 15% average annual interest rate. The rate varies by the down payment, which is typically 10%.Diamond bundles customers' loans into securities and resells them to insurance companies and other institutional investors, eliminating its risk in customer defaults. About 6% of customers default on their loans; about 3.5% default on maintenance fees, said Palmer.As a "Silver Elite" member, Lee Huffman of Anaheim Hills, Calif., pays a $2,400 annual maintenance fee and gets 15,000 points every year in perpetuity. The finance manager of a midsize bank in Southern California and his family have used the points to stay at Diamond Resorts in California, Cabo San Lucas, Paris and Sydney."We prefer the comfort, convenience and cost savings of timeshares over hotels even more now that we have a child," said Huffman. He views his timeshare as an asset in his estate that he can pass on to his 3-year-old son.As of Jan. 1, 2014, points start at $7.66 each with a minimum purchase of 2,500 points, for $19,150, according to DiamondResorts.com. Members must also pay annual maintenance fees, which vary based on their membership levels, and incidental assessment fees for renovations or large repairs.Huffman and 524,000 fellow Diamond members can be credited for fueling the company's rapid sales and earnings growth. In its third quarter as a public company, the Las Vegas-based firm exceeded analysts' expectations. It beat earnings and sales forecasts on top of lifting full-year guidance when it reported first-quarter results May 1.Revenue grew 18% year over year to $181 million, eclipsing the $177 million consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) vaulted 37% from a year ago to $67 million, topping JPMorgan's forecasts of $51 million by 31%.Diamond raised its full-year 2014 EBITDA guidance to $265 million to $280 million, from previous guidance of $255 million to $265 million, partly because it managed to refinance a 12% loan at a much lower interest rate. It expects to save it about $22 million a year in interest.Performance Since IPODiamond stock has risen 40% from its $14 IPO price in July 2013.In a conference call with analysts, CEO Palmer said the company uses a "capital-light model with minimal development capex required," which means that instead of building its own properties, Diamond adds inventory by buying out existing resorts. Diamond also collects fees from managing properties in homeowners associations."Unlike its peers, with no significant plans to invest capital in new timeshare development, it sources inventory from recapturing vacation ownership interests from members who default on payment of their homeowners association dues and its bank of unsold points," JPMorgan analyst Joseph Gregg and colleagues wrote in a note May 1.Inside The IndustryAbout 30% of Diamond's earnings come from managing resorts, a task that's very profitable, says Gregg."Diamond is in a position to generate appealing earnings growth, driven by what we view as sustainable operating momentum in vacation ownership and steady uplift in management fees," Gregg and colleagues noted. "We forecast improving free cash-flow performance, given growth in its higher-margin management business."Diamond is the 12th largest company by market cap in IBD's Leisure-Lodging industry group, whose biggest components are Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT), Marriott International (MAR) and Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT). The group is ranked No. 79 in performance of 197 that IBD tracks.Vacation ownership can be a controversial line of business, however, and Diamond is no stranger to complaints."In one year, fees rose by more than 40%. A similar figure the next year. Soon the maintenance fees exceeded the cost of staying in a Diamond Resorts apartment for a holiday through Expedia (EXPE), including airfares," a Gloucestershire, U.K.-based entrepreneur, who did not want his name published, said in an email. "To add insult to injury, it became almost impossible to get a booking for any property except during off peak."Diamond's management fees exceeded rental rates by 47% to 180% for various properties he saw online, he says, and when he refused to pay, he got calls every day — sometimes twice a day — and was told that he would be turned over to a collection agency. Diamond finally canceled his contract after he complained to every agency in the U.S. and U.K. that would listen, he says."I just made a right royal nuisance of myself," he said in an email.Unwanted Diamond points can be had for pennies on the dollar on eBay (EBAY) and timeshare-resale websites. Only 3% of timeshares sell on the resale market, says Jeff Griffen, a senior executive at ResortBailout.com. The East Hartford, Conn.-based firm helps clients unload a timeshare for one to three years in annual maintenance fees plus closing costs.Walking away from a timeshare is like letting a house go into foreclosure, which could result in property liens, stained credit histories and even wage garnishment, according to Griffen. In addition, customers can finance their purchase only through Diamond, he says.Over the past three years, 525 complaints against Diamond were filed with the Better Business Bureau. Owners in Koloa, Hawaii, filed a class-action lawsuit over a $65,822,529 water-intrusion assessment, local media reported.Investing RisksSince owning a timeshare is a luxury that most people can do without, a global or U.S. economic slowdown could deplete demand for new purchases or hinder people's ability to repay their loans."Currently, no effective secondary market exists to resell timeshare," Robert LaFleur and Whitney Stevenson, analysts at JMP Securities, wrote in a note May 2. "If an effective and cost-efficient secondary market develops, Diamond's ability to sell vacation interests through its existing sales channels could be seriously impaired."Among other risks, rising interest rates would increase borrowing costs for both Diamond and its customers, which could squeeze margins and dampen demand.Diamond will be increasingly more dependent on the securities market to get money and maintain growth in vacation-ownership sales, Gregg of JPMorgan says. Growth depends on its success in selling to new customers rather than existing customers.

Priceline (PCLN), slated to report fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Thursday, is expected to maintain double-digit revenue growth, after its online travel rivals reported generally positive Q4 results.The analyst consensus estimate looks for Priceline to report revenue of $1.5 billion, up 26% from the year-earlier quarter.The consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for earnings per share minus items of $8.29, up 22.5%. Priceline stock hit an all-time high of 1,301.64 on Tuesday. Priceline stock was down a fraction, near 1,293, in midday trading in the stock market today."Our channel checks on Priceline and as well as Q4 earnings out of Expedia, TripAdvisor, and Orbitz point to a healthy environment for online travel in Q4," wrote Navad Khan, an analyst with Cantor Fitzgerald, in a research report Tuesday.
