Orbitz (OWW) stock was down 2.5% in midday trading in the stock market today after Cowen and Co. initiated coverage with a rating of market perform, or hold. Cowen also set a price target for Orbitz of $7, right about where it's been trading since early November, and right where it was trading midday Monday. Analysts Kevin Kopelman and Andrew…

Sabre, the owner of travel website Travelocity, filed Tuesday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering of its common stock in a move that's likely to intensify competition in online travel.

The travel technology provider filed a registration statement Form S-1 with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for the proposed IPO of shares of its common stock. The number of shares to be sold and the price range for the proposed offering have not yet been determined.
Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, BofA Merrill Lynch and Deutsche Bank Securities are lead underwriters.

Sabre is filing at a time when IPOs are rising and the global travel and tourism industry is growing. The company has three major business units: Travel Network, Airline and Hospitality Solutions, and Travelocity.

Sabre, which had been publicly traded before, has been privately held by TPG Funds and Silver Lake Funds since 2007. Travelocity originally was a subsidiary of Sabre and was listed on Nasdaq until Sabre bought it and re-merged that business into Sabre as a subsidiary in 2002.
Sabre itself was spun off from American Airlines parent AMR in an IPO in 2000.
Travelocity competes vs. Priceline (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE), Orbitz (OWW) and others. It has lost market share over the years to Priceline and Expedia.

Travelocity announced a strategic long-term marketing pact with Expedia in August to bolster its core travel business. Under the agreement, Expedia will handle the bulk of Travelocity's operations. It will process orders for Travelocity and collect fees from travel suppliers like hotels and airlines. Expedia will also pay Travelocity a commission for sales generated on Travelocity's travel platform.

Cantor Fitzgerald said in a research note Tuesday that a reported decline in Expedia's organic search traffic last week was a "transitory" event and "not a sign of weakness in the underlying business fundamentals" of the company. Cantor said it's maintaining its positive long-term outlook on Expedia and reiterating its buy rating. It has a price target of $75 on Expedia stock, which was down a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 67.
Related: Priceline, Expedia Stock Price Targets Increased

Priceline Faces Complex Customer Satisfaction Issues.Sabre, the owner of travel website Travelocity, filed Tuesday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering of its common stock in a move that's likely to intensify competition in online travel.The travel technology provider filed a registration statement Form S-1 with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for the proposed IPO of shares of its common stock. The number of shares to be sold and the price range for the proposed offering have not yet been determined.Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, BofA Merrill Lynch and Deutsche Bank Securities are lead underwriters.Sabre is filing at a time when IPOs are rising and the global travel and tourism industry is growing. The company has three major business units: Travel Network, Airline and Hospitality Solutions, and Travelocity.Sabre, which had been publicly traded before, has been privately held by TPG Funds and Silver Lake Funds since 2007. Travelocity originally was a subsidiary of Sabre and was listed on Nasdaq until Sabre bought it and re-merged that business into Sabre as a subsidiary in 2002.Sabre itself was spun off from American Airlines parent AMR in an IPO in 2000.Travelocity competes vs. Priceline (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE), Orbitz (OWW) and others. It has lost market share over the years to Priceline and Expedia.Travelocity announced a strategic long-term marketing pact with Expedia in August to bolster its core travel business. Under the agreement, Expedia will handle the bulk of Travelocity's operations. It will process orders for Travelocity and collect fees from travel suppliers like hotels and airlines. Expedia will also pay Travelocity a commission for sales generated on Travelocity's travel platform.Cantor Fitzgerald said in a research note Tuesday that a reported decline in Expedia's organic search traffic last week was a "transitory" event and "not a sign of weakness in the underlying business fundamentals" of the company. Cantor said it's maintaining its positive long-term outlook on Expedia and reiterating its buy rating. It has a price target of $75 on Expedia stock, which was down a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 67.Related: Priceline, Expedia Stock Price Targets IncreasedPriceline Faces Complex Customer Satisfaction Issues.

Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Huntington is trading below a 136.55 buy point in a long cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. For the week, the FTSE 100 tracked toward a 1.9% gain, the Cac-40 was up 1.5% and the DAX showed a 3% gain.Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Priceline (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE) shares rose modestly in the stock market today after Evercore Partners raised its price targets on the two online travel stocks.In afternoon trading Wednesday, both stocks were up less than 1%, with Priceline near 1,169 and Expedia near 69.60.Evercore raised its price target for Priceline to 1,350 from 1,250 based on an expected surge in online hotel bookings worldwide. It cited an estimate by tracker PhoCusWright that only 35% of the $545 billion global hotel bookings market will be online by 2017."We believe Priceline to be the primary beneficiary (of this shift) due to a combination of scale and marketing efficiency, which benefits them as they sell services to suppliers and buy traffic," analysts Ken Sena and Andrew McNellis said in report issued late Tuesday. They see Priceline increasing its share of the hotel booking market to 10% from 6%, with a 38% to 45% share among online travel agencies. Evercore rates Priceline stock overweight.The analysts also raised their price target on Expedia to 64 from 56 based on improving results from its Trivago metasearch unit. Evercore has an equal weight rating on Expedia.Evercore maintained its underweight rating, and 68 price target, on TripAdvisor (TRIP), which was down a fraction in afternoon trading Wednesday, near 84.Related: TripAdvisor Downgraded To Hold On Limited Upside.

The airline, car rental and online travel businesses were carried to safe destinations Wednesday with Q4 earnings reports from three highly rated companies. Spirit Airlines (SAVE), Avis Budget Group (CAR) and HomeAway (AWAY) followed positive results from other travel-related firms. HomeAway said after the market close that it earned 8 cents a share, missing consensus estimates for flat profit of…
Stocks were still mixed in late trading Thursday but have worsened.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and the S&P 500 lost a fraction. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq was up 0.3%. It has given up more than half of its intraday gain. Turnover was again tracking higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Kirby (KEX) pared gains but was still up 7%. Earlier, the stock hit a record high and cleared a 107.03 buy point from a flat base. Late Wednesday, the transporter of petroleum products beat expectations with Q1 earnings that grew 21% to $1.15 a share. That marked a second straight period of acceleration. Sales, which also beat expectations, rose 5% to $589.3 million. The company guided Q2 profit above views.
YY (YY) rallied 6%, regaining all of Wednesday's loss and then some. The stock has slumped 39% since early March but has found support at its 200-day moving average for the past couple of sessions.

Manitowoc (MTW) trimmed a 5% gain to less than 2% ahead of its earnings, to be reported after the close. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the crane-maker's profit falling to 20 cents a share from 33 cents in the year-ago period. Earlier, the stock cleared a 32.90 buy point from a flat base and touched its best levels since June 2008.

KapStone Paper and Packaging (KS) was off its session low but still down 3% following late Wednesday's disappointing Q1 results. The company posted a profit of 36 cents a share, up 71% from a year ago. But that was 6 cents below views. Revenue jumped 72% to $549 million, below views for $554.13 million. In recent sessions, KapStone has found support near 25.

Stocks gave up early gains Thursday to finish mixed, with the Nasdaq hanging on to a narrow gain. The day marked the third straight advance for the Nasdaq.
The Nasdaq rose 0.3%; the S&P 500 was down a hair and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1%. Volume rose on the Nasdaq and fell on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Chipmaker Cavium (CAVM) gained nearly 11% early after reporting earnings that were 59% higher than a year ago, but finished up 4% and in the lower part of its range. It has been a choppy few weeks for the stock, which remains above its 50-day moving average and a 42.51 buy point from a cup base.

Anika Therapeutics (ANIK) rose nearly 3% in above-average volume. The company reported earnings earlier this week that were 362% above the year-ago quarter. The stock seems to be shaping a new base. It is moving in a tight, constructive way, but it would be a late-stage base.

Money managers will be watching the employment report Friday morning. Economists are looking for a gain of 210,000 jobs in April compared to 192,000 in March. The unemployment rate is expected to tick lower to 6.6%.

Goldman Sachs on Wednesday raised its price target on Priceline (PCLN) stock to 1,500 from 1,260 and added the company to its "Conviction Buy List."
Priceline shares were up 2.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today. The company ranks No. 10 in Wednesday's midweek update of the IBD 50 listing of top-performing stocks.
Goldman Sachs analyst Terry Heath, in a research report, said he sees "increasing upside potential" to his already-above-consensus estimates for the online travel company.

"We see Priceline benefiting from a European recovery, mobile traffic growth, share gains in the U.S., and increasing economies of scale, particularly in customer acquisition costs," Heath wrote. "Priceline's mobile footprint, geographic mix and critical mass of hotel relationships should continue to drive considerable long term competitive advantages."

Terry says he's raising his estimates for Priceline's gross profit, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP EPS for 2014-2016 by 3%, 5% and 5% on average respectively to reflect share gains in the U.S. and an improving macro environment. "Our new 2014-2016 estimates are 10%, 15%, and 13%, above consensus," Terry said.

The report notes that Priceline's U.S. shares' gains through its Priceline Express Deals, Kayak metasearch and Booking.com units, as well as mobile offerings, have led to "three consecutive quarters of accelerating growth and domestic bookings outperformance" vs. rival Expedia (EXPE).
The analyst also sees Priceline facing more competition from other online travel firms and rising customer acquisition costs.
RELATED:

Stocks enjoyed solid gains Thursday, finishing near their highs, while earnings reports sparked sharp moves for several stocks after the close.The Nasdaq was up 1.1%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.2%. Volume was lower on both exchanges, according to preliminary figures.The big mover of the day was Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), which was up 26%. On Wednesday evening, it reported earnings and announced a 10-year global pact with Coca-Cola (KO).In after-hours trading Thursday, LinkedIn (LNKD) was down after it offered lowered guidance. The stock has been trying to build the right side of a base.Travel-booking website Expedia (EXPE) was up sharply after it reported EPS of 92 cents a share vs. 63 cents in the year-ago quarter. Before the report, shares were trading below the 50-day line.Web.com (WWWW) was down after reporting earnings. It reported 59 cents a share, 2 cents above estimates. Web.com has been trying to break out of a base past a 32.58 buy point.Athenahealth (ATHN) was up sharply. It missed on earnings, but beat on revenue. Earnings were 34 cents a share vs. estimates of 45 cents. Sales were up 48% from a year ago.The closely watched employment report is due out before the market opens Friday. For January, economists are forecasting 175,000 new jobs. A large deviation from the number could rattle or excite traders.
Stocks opened lower, but quickly turned mixed in powerful volume Friday.
The Dow Jones erased early losses and rose 0.1%, hoisted by American Express' (AXP) 5% leap following its earnings report. The Nasdaq traded down 0.3% and the S&P 500 slipped 0.2%.
Volume surged, more than doubling on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq, boosted by options expirations.

The stock market today opened to weak December housing starts and building permit numbers from the Commerce Department. November industrial activity data from the Federal Reserve met expectations, rising 0.3% with capacity utilization of 79.1%.
Consumers grew less optimistic in January, sending the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index to 80.4, down from December's 82.5 level. Views were for an increase to 83.5.

On the employment front, the Labor Department's JOLTS — job openings and labor turnover survey — showed available jobs increasing to more than 4 million in November, up from 3.925 million in October. Analysts had projected a slight gain to 3.93 million.
In stocks, Intel (INTC) slumped 4% after reporting mixed Q4 results late Thursday.
Video game maker Electronic Arts (EA) spiked 10% after CRT Capital launched coverage on the stock with a buy rating and a 26 price target. The stock has been consolidating since late August.
Online travel broker Expedia (EXPE) popped 4% at the open. Evercore Partners raised its price target on the stock to 64 on Thursday. The stock has been trading tightly and near new highs.
Leading stocks opened on a positive note, with more than 3-in-5 IBD 50 stocks rising at the open. Nu Skin (NUS) slipped 2% out of the starting blocks. Other losses held to less than 1%.

Qihoo 360 (QIHU) sparked up more than 3% in firm trade. Stifel upgraded the China-based Internet security software and content provider to buy, with a 108 price target. The stock is forming the right side of a base.

Align (ALGN) jumped 3% to snatch a new high in strong trade. Standard & Poor's announced late Thursday the dental products provider will join the S&P Mid-Cap 400 Index effective Jan. 24. The stock has been consolidating since late August.Online travel broker Expedia (EXPE) popped 4% at the open. Evercore Partners raised its price target on the stock to 64 on Thursday. The stock has been trading tightly and near new highs.Leading stocks opened on a positive note, with more than 3-in-5 IBD 50 stocks rising at the open. Nu Skin (NUS) slipped 2% out of the starting blocks. Other losses held to less than 1%.Qihoo 360 (QIHU) sparked up more than 3% in firm trade. Stifel upgraded the China-based Internet security software and content provider to buy, with a 108 price target. The stock is forming the right side of a base.Align (ALGN) jumped 3% to snatch a new high in strong trade. Standard & Poor's announced late Thursday the dental products provider will join the S&P Mid-Cap 400 Index effective Jan. 24. Shares are 9% past an early buy point of 58.60 following a Jan. 6 breakout.

Stocks climbed again without convincing volume Monday as all eyes remained riveted on the ongoing standoff in Washington. The Nasdaq jumped 0.6% while the S&P 500 the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.4%. Volume in the stock market today, which was stunted by the Columbus Day holiday, fell on the Nasdaq and on the NYSE, according to preliminary data. Movie-rental…
Stocks stepped sharply lower in thin trade amid quiet earnings and economic calendars Monday, as the market kept watch on debt and budget negotiations in Washington.

The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 0.5% apiece. The Nasdaq held to a 0.3% loss. Volume was weak in the stock market today, down 9% on the Nasdaq and 21% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Friday.

Expedia (EXPE) slumped 7% after Deutsche Bank downgraded the stock to hold from buy. The note cited last week's ouster of the travel deals provider's Hotels.com management team — the second "major brand level management overhaul" this year.
The stock has been correcting since missing analysts' second-quarter earnings expectations and tumbling 27% on July 26.

Liberty Interactive (LINTA) surged 4% in strong trade following an upgrade to outperform from market perform by Wells Fargo. The bank raised the stocks price target from 23 to 24 to 31 to 33, and cited added value from plans to spin-off a separate tracking stock for its QVC shopping network.
The move drove shares to a new high, and 7% past a 24.15 buy point in a cup with handle base.
Among leaders, 90% of the stocks on the IBD 50 list opened lower on Monday. Deep premarket losses narrowed significantly at the open, however, and only a few stocks on the list fell as much as 2%.
Among those, Mylan (MYL) dropped 2%. The Pennsylvania-based generic drug maker was trading just below its Oct. 4 high and comfortably above its 50-day line.

Facebook (FB) slipped 2%, starting the third week of its consolidation below a Sept. 30 high and above its 10-week moving average. Stocks remained narrowly mixed Thursday afternoon, but have improved slightly. Equities had been moderately lower amid mixed economic data and a barrage of earnings reports.

The Nasdaq rose 0.2% after falling as much as 0.5%. The S&P 500 has turned a 0.4% deficit into a 0.1% gain. But the Dow Jones industrial average was still fractionally lower. Turnover was tracking higher across the board in the stock market today.

Harman International (HAR) charged up 16% to its best levels in nearly six years. Before the open, the audio gear maker delivered fiscal first-quarter earnings and sales that grew 20% and 17%, respectively. Both beat expectations. Harman is now 18% above a 71.76 buy point from a flat base.

TripAdvisor (TRIP) rallied 5% to a record high in fast trade. It has staged a solid comeback after recently falling more than 8% below a 79.18 buy point from a cup with handle. TripAdvisor may be rising Thursday in sympathy with Expedia (EXPE), which reported better-than-expected Q3 results late Wednesday. Expedia bolted 16%.

Stratasys (SSYS) edged up almost 1% after erasing a 2% loss. The stock cleared a 113.04 buy point from a fourth-stage cup-with-handle pattern. Late-stage bases are more prone to failure. The 3D printer maker will report earnings Nov. 7. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 5% to 42 cents a share. That would be a sharp slowdown from growth of 29% to 54% in the past four quarters.

Elsewhere, Proto Labs (PRLB) pared a 15% loss to 5%. The comeback pushed the stock back above its 50-day moving average. Before the open, the custom parts maker reported a 28% gain in Q3 earnings and a 29% rise in sales. But the company also announced the resignation of CEO Brad Cleveland.Stocks remained narrowly mixed Thursday afternoon, but have improved slightly. JPMorgan and RBC Capital Markets raised their price targets and Bank of America upgraded Expedia stock to a buy on Thursday. The upbeat Q3…
Stock futures tunneled into deep losses ahead of Thursday's open, as instability in China's markets sent a shudder through global investor confidence for a second time this week.
The stock market today again took significant cues from China, where markets opened in a sell-off after a sharp devaluation in the yuan spooked investors.

The CSI 300, which tracks blue chip stocks on the Shanghai and Shenzhen markets, dropped more than 7% in the first half-hour of trade, triggering automatic shutdown rules put in place on Monday. Chinese investors were already on edge ahead of next week's lifting of a six-month sales ban on large shareholders.
The Shanghai Composite ended with a 7% loss, leaving it 11.8% lower this week. The Shenzhen Composite tumbled 8.2% for a 15.2% loss since Friday's close.
The selling carried powerfully into other markets, sending the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo down 2.3% and pressuring major indexes in Europe to losses in the 3% range near midday.

In the U.S., bonds and the dollar slipped. Oil prices slumped 4%, putting West Texas Intermediate just above $32 a barrel and down 12% this week — undercutting lows from 2008 and touching its lowest mark since December 2003 . Natural gas rose 1%. Gold added a fraction, topping $1,080 an ounce. Copper fell 3%.

There was good news on the economic front. Layoffs announced by U.S. employers declined 27.6% year over year to 23,622 in December — the lowest total in 15 years, according to consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas' Job Cuts Report.

For the year, 2015 had the largest number of job cuts since 2011, but with layoffs tapering toward year's end. In the fourth quarter, layoffs totaled 205,072, down 49% from Q3 and 12% lower than Q4 layoffs in 2014.
Unemployment claims dropped to 277,000 in the week ended Jan. 2, down from 287,000 in the prior week, the Labor Department said. Economist consensus had expected a deeper dip to 272,000 claims.
China-based stocks were clearly taking early hits: NetEase (NTES) and Alibaba (BABA) dropped 5% each.
Dow stocks shifted unanimously lower, and nearly half the index was down more than 2%, with Microsoft (MSFT), Apple (AAPL), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and JPMorgan (JPM) approaching 3% losses.
Only a handful of S&P 500 stocks posted gains, led by Newmont Mining (NEM) and beer brewer and IBD 50 stock Constellation Brands (STZ), up 2% each.
Expeditors International (EXPD) dropped 8% to notch the S&P 500's biggest loss.

Among leaders, Avago Technologies (AVGO) shed 6%. The Singapore-based chipmaker ended Wednesday down 8% and just below its 50-day moving average. Avago's premarket stance implies possible damage to its cup-with-handle base.
NetEase has held its ground after pulling back in Monday's sell-off to test its 50-day moving average. Thursday's premarket action points to a possible open below that line of support.
Meanwhile, Alibaba has been struggling against resistance below its 200-day moving average.

Other losses on the IBD 50 cut across a variety of stocks. Globus Medical (GMED) dropped 4%. When Priceline acquired a little-known European hotel reservation website called Booking.com for $135 million in July 2005, few could have known it would become the moneymaker it is today. For one, the name itself was a little confusing, written as singular and not in the plural form that is more common, at least outside Europe. But resultswise, there's nothing awkward…
TripAdvisor's (TRIP) changes to its advertising model should drive higher cost-per-click pricing, says Stifel Nicolaus, which upgraded the stock to a buy rating on Monday.

TripAdvisor stock, though, was down 1.5% in midday trading Monday. The stock has risen nearly 80% in 2013, and it's No. 16 in Monday's IBD 50 ranking of top stocks. TripAdvisor stock touched an all-time high of 82.20 last month, but now is trading near 74.
IBD's leisure-travel booking group, which includes Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline.com (PCLN), ranks No. 13 out of the 197 industry sectors tracked by IBD. Expedia spun off TripAdvisor in 2011.
TripAdvisor's competition rose in June, when Google (GOOG) launched its "local carousel" rankings, which display hotel search results based on user reviews.
Stifel Nicolaus analyst Michael Purcell says better sell-through rates should result from changes to TripAdvisor's advertising platform.
"TripAdvisor is well-positioned to continue to be the central platform for travel planning," wrote Purcell in a research report. He set a price target of 93 on the stock.

"Our rating upgrade today also has to do with a broader view of the direction of digital media stocks, particularly those with potential upside from increased usage on mobile apps, which TripAdvisor is well positioned for," he said.

TripAdvisor this year transitioned to "meta" searches. Consumers now see hotel prices before they click through to suppliers or travel agents to possibly make a booking. Previously, consumers clicked on a 'show prices' button and pop-up screens displayed prices. Under TripAdvisor's new model, Purcell says, CPC pricing is higher because, since prices are known, consumers are more likely to book when clicking through.
"The meta transition is now fully understood by investors and the efficacy of the platform is valued over that of potential near-term revenue dislocations," Purcell said.

TripAdvisor (TRIP) stock was down more than 2% in afternoon trading in the stock market Tuesday after Cowen & Co. issued a report saying that the provider of online travel reviews has paused a test of its TV ad campaign and seems unlikely to spend the $40-$50 million envisioned in its second-half TV ad budget.

"After testing ads in several markets starting in June, the company has not yet rolled out a nationwide campaign, and we have not noted any further testing since late July. Given the delay, we believe initial results were likely disappointing," Cowen said.
UPDATE: Since this posting, TripAdvisor, through a spokeswoman, has denied that it's making any changes to its announced TV ad plans.

The investment house, though, says the delay in TV spending is positive for TripAdvisor's earnings but is likely to hurt the company's near-term revenue growth prospects. The delay is also seen as a positive for Priceline (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE), due to less broadcast competition.
TripAdvisor announced in February that it planned to spend $40 million to $50 million in offline advertising during the second half of this year to support the launch of its new metasearch platform.

TripAdvisor is shifting to a metasearch model, a price search tool that lets users directly book hotels and other travel products. This is taking the emphasis off cost-per-click, or CPC, ads from hotels and online travel agencies. CPC is an online ad model used to direct traffic to websites.

TripAdvisor stock ranks No. 14 in the latest IBD 50 despite a sell-off last month after CEO Steve Kaufer told an investor conference that the summer travel season has been slower than expected, as IBD reported. But the stock has found support at its 10-week moving average. The stock was trading near 73 Tuesday afternoon, down 11% from its all-time high of 82.20 touched last month just before the CEO comments.TripAdvisor (TRIP) stock was down more than 2% in afternoon trading in the stock market Tuesday after Cowen & Co. issued a report saying that the provider of online travel reviews has paused a test of its TV ad campaign and seems unlikely to spend the $40-$50 million envisioned in its second-half TV ad budget."After testing ads in several markets starting in June, the company has not yet rolled out a nationwide campaign, and we have not noted any further testing since late July. It's Miller time ... again. Manager Bill Miller and assistant manager Samantha McLemore run $1.8 billion Legg Mason Opportunity , which soared 68.03% in 2013. That was '13's top-performing diversified, nonleveraged U.S. stock fund, with more than $200 million in assets, according to Morningstar Inc.
Just like old times. Starting in 1991, Miller's Legg Mason Value Trust topped the S&P 500 for 15 years in a row.

The fund's winning streak derailed in 2006 due to bad bets on housing stocks and other sectors. Miller gave up that fund's tiller in April 2012. He's been a manager of Opportunity since Dec. 30, 1999. McLemore arrived Aug. 19, 2008.
They're building a new winning streak. It has outperformed its midcap value category and the S&P 500 for five quarters in a row, including Q4.
Miller, age 63, and 33-year-old McLemore talked with IBD from their quarters in Baltimore.
IBD: How does this fund's approach differ from Value Trust's?
Miller: Value Trust is a large-cap value fund, whose objective is growth and capital appreciation.
This fund is unconstrained regarding asset class and size. The idea is to have a fund that can migrate, that can own bonds and other sorts of things.
IBD: And are all of this fund's buys of stocks that are distressed?

Miller: Our favorite thing is to buy businesses that are under distress. That's when the perception of their risk is most distorted. I would guess probably close to two-thirds of our buys are close to their 52-week low or have done poorly when the market's done well. We're not restricted to that, but the chance to buy values is better then than when something is on a high list.
IBD: Give me an example, please.
McLemore: When Apple (AAPL) pulled back, we added to that. I don't know if you'd consider that distress. We think the fundamentals are solid, but the stock had come down.
IBD: In 2008 the fund lost 65.5%. What changes in approach have you made since? For example, do you wait for a stock to show signs of a turnaround before buying?
Miller: Oh, absolutely! We're not doing illiquids. Lesson No. 2, we're much quicker to put in hedges.
And we're paying attention to rising vs. falling correlations. If we see correlations rising (among our holdings), we move quicker to things that hedge against that.
IBD: What other steps do you take?
McLemore: When fundamentals weaken, we're quicker to exit.
IBD: Will the housing rebound continue as rates rise?
Miller: Yes. Curt Culver, the CEO of MGIC (MTG), says we're heading into housing nirvana.

We had six years of decline from the peak. Interest rates went down. Since the housing cycle turned up, rates are up. So are stocks. So low rates were not good for housing stocks because fundamentals were so bad. Since the housing cycle turned (up) in 2012, rates are up. So are stocks. Not up (in 2013), but up a ton (in 2012)

In 2012 the builders — Pulte (PHM), Lennar (LEN), KB Home (KBH) — were up triple digits, most of them. (In 2013 they were) flat to down. The ones that didn't do well (in 2012) — like MGIC and eTrade (ETFC), which has a large mortgage portfolio — (were) up triple digits (in 2013).
So we're bulls on the housing cycle. Rates are likely to continue higher. But housing stocks, direct builders, after a pause (last year) will have a great 2014.
IBD: Where does Ellington Financial (EFC) fit in?

Miller: They're less of a direct housing play. They operate in mortgage-backed securities and agency securities. They're really a hedge fund trying to maximize income and grow book value through investing in housing securities, but they can go long and short.
IBD: Best Buy (BBY) earnings per share skyrocketed 350% in Q3, but the stock sold off. Are you concerned too?

Miller: The story is that since the new CFO (Sharon McCollam) came in from Williams-Sonoma, they've done a fantastic job. They are trying to train associates so they are knowledgeable and not trying to rip off customers by steering them to things like insurance for televisions.

People were afraid a year ago that Amazon (AMZN) would put them out of business. Now they've realized that same-store sales have started to turn positive again. The company can be profitable even as Amazon prospers.
It sold off recently because people expected a big margin improvement in the near term. We expect it in the next year or two.
IBD: I see several airline stocks in the portfolio. Is there a consolidation play, or some other strategy?

Miller: There is consolidation. Three of our top holdings are airlines. (The three included Delta Air Lines (DAL) and United Continental (UAL) as of Sept. 30; US Airways has since merged with American Airlines (AAL).) The industry is reporting record profits. And we're early in the industry turnaround. Delta has done the best because of dividends and buybacks. But airlines are trading at a huge discount to cruise line stocks and shippers like FedEx (FDS) and UPS (UPS). So we think there's a lot of room to go with airlines.

United is our favorite. United and Delta have roughly the same revenues and their balance sheets are similar once you adjust for things like capital leases and pension liabilities. But Delta has a $25 billion market capitalization and United has $14 billion. United has 14,000 more employees and 500 more planes.

United will be rationalizing that in the next couple of years, so we see significant margin (improvement) opportunity there. And United will start returning capital to shareholders, which should help the stock as well.
IBD: Is IAC/InterActiveCorp (IACI), which has begun to run up, a play on its wide portfolio of Internet sites?

Miller: This is just a small position for us. It has run up (recently) because it might spin off disparate subsidiaries. But it's more the case that at about six times enterprise value vs. EBITDA that we bought it, it was way too cheap given the value of its underlying assets. (In the past,) CEO Barry Diller has spun off Home Shopping Network, Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP). He's a value creator.
There are a lot of assets that could be spun out. We bought it around 50 when we thought it was worth 70 (and it has gapped up to around 70).
IBD: Netflix (NFLX) is uptrending, but you've trimmed in recent quarters. What's your thesis?

Miller: When the company talked about splitting in two, it caused subscribers to flee. The stock went from over 300 to the low 50s. It was earning over $5 a share on its U.S. business alone. It was hard to believe a company of that dominance would trade at 10 times earnings while it was growing 20% to 30% a year.

What was causing the angst was the money it was spending internationally. (The fund started to buy around 50.) The company looked like it was worth two to three times what we were paying. Then (activist investor) Carl Icahn got involved. The stock started running up rapidly. Now its valuation is similar to Sirius' (SIRI), but Sirius has greater free cash flow and more predictability. The valuation on Netflix properly reflects its current trajectory of growth but one that may not reflect its total addressable market. We've cut back a fair amount, but it's still a 3% position.
IBD: Apple has sold off a little since late last month, but basically has uptrended since June. Investors love it or hate it. What's your view?

Miller: Apple is fascinating. Every person in the market has an opinion. Usually about 90% are tilted to what's the next hot product. Usually the opinion is tilted to what's their next hot product. Can they still be innovative? Will they have an iWatch? Are they going to be in TVs? The questions are interesting but irrelevant when Apple was trading around 400 a few months and around 550 now. They're still cheap.

They have $45 billion of free cash flow and a $300 billion market cap, with $150 billion in cash on their balance sheet, making the biggest buyback in the history of the world, and with a dividend yield over 3%.
We sold in the 650 to 700 range a year ago as it was peaking. We thought it was near fair value.

Since then we've seen that its historical trading pattern was trading on earnings estimate revisions. And it was peaking at the time and began to fall. We calculated that earnings revisions would bottom in the beginning of Q2 and into Q2 as they announced new products like the iPhone 5 and a refresh on their iPads. That happened.

In the past few months earnings estimate revisions have turned higher. So price targets have turned higher. The stock has turned higher. We think Apple is worth 750 to 800 a share. Will it get there? Maybe at some point, but it's still cheap vs. its underlying value.
IBD: Is eTrade (ETFC) a plan on the U.S. economic rebound?
Miller: It's within 10% to 20% of fair value. It had a huge move, which was driven by the correct perception that its mortgage book is rapidly healing.
When the stock was at 9 or 10, we thought it was worth about 18. That was with big losses in the mortgage portfolio mark to market.

Etrade has three things going for it: First, if the Fed starts putting rates up, that'll lead to earnings estimate increases. Second, as individual investors come back to the market, they service them. Third, they're a consolidation candidate via Ameritrade (AMTD) or Schwab (SCHW) or somebody like that.
IBD: Is Morgan Stanley (MS) a similar play?

Miller: What you see is what you get. CEO James Gorman has been transparent that the company needs return on equity higher. And they can do that by combining their sales force with Smith Barney's, which is now under way.
We bought back in the teens when the stock was trading way below tangible book value. Now it's trading above tangible book value, but not much. Earnings estimate is trending higher.

They're a beneficiary of a higher return on equity leading to rising relative price-to-book. And as capital markets improve, they benefit from that. But they're nowhere as cheap as they were when they were trading at a big discount to tangible book.
Citi (C) is still a discount to tangible book. Genworth (GNW) is a huge discount to tangible book. So there are still names out there that have a lot of improvability left.
IBD: A lot of investors are turned off by Amazon's (AMZN) dismal earnings per share record. Why aren't you?

Miller: Our average cost is 5.84. Now shares are pushing 400. They have an almost insurmountable sustainable cost advantage in the retail space. They also have Amazon Web Services, a business in the cloud computing space, where it's also a leader. And they've said (it will be) at least as big as their retail business. Their total business is $75 billion, so AWS might be 5% to 10% of that.

Amazon reminds me of the old telecom TCI under John Malone. Malone is one of the great value creators in all of American business. A dollar invested with him when he took over TCI, when he sold it 25 years later to AT&T (T), was worth $900. A dollar invested in the S&P 500 was worth $22.

My point is that Amazon has a tremendous record of creating value for shareholders since it came public. Malone never reported a profit with TCI. But he built tremendous value. We think Amazon should not report profits. They should grow the business as fast as they can to sustain their competitive advantage.It's Miller time ... again. Manager Bill Miller and assistant manager Samantha McLemore run $1.8 billion Legg Mason Opportunity , which soared 68.03% in 2013. That was '13's top-performing diversified, nonleveraged U.S. stock fund, with more than $200 million in assets, according to Morningstar Inc.Just like old times. Starting in 1991, Miller's Legg Mason Value Trust topped the S&P 500 for 15 years in a row.The fund's winning streak derailed in 2006 due to bad bets on housing stocks and other sectors. Miller gave up that fund's tiller in April 2012. He's been a manager of Opportunity since Dec. 30, 1999. McLemore arrived Aug. 19, 2008.They're building a new winning streak. It has outperformed its midcap value category and the S&P 500 for five quarters in a row, including Q4.Miller, age 63, and 33-year-old McLemore talked with IBD from their quarters in Baltimore.IBD: How does this fund's approach differ from Value Trust's?Miller: Value Trust is a large-cap value fund, whose objective is growth and capital appreciation.This fund is unconstrained regarding asset class and size. The idea is to have a fund that can migrate, that can own bonds and other sorts of things.IBD: And are all of this fund's buys of stocks that are distressed?Miller: Our favorite thing is to buy businesses that are under distress. That's when the perception of their risk is most distorted. I would guess probably close to two-thirds of our buys are close to their 52-week low or have done poorly when the market's done well. We're not restricted to that, but the chance to buy values is better then than when something is on a high list.IBD: Give me an example, please.McLemore: When Apple (AAPL) pulled back, we added to that. I don't know if you'd consider that distress. We think the fundamentals are solid, but the stock had come down.IBD: In 2008 the fund lost 65.5%. What changes in approach have you made since? For example, do you wait for a stock to show signs of a turnaround before buying?Miller: Oh, absolutely! We're not doing illiquids. Lesson No. 2, we're much quicker to put in hedges.And we're paying attention to rising vs. falling correlations. If we see correlations rising (among our holdings), we move quicker to things that hedge against that.IBD: What other steps do you take?McLemore: When fundamentals weaken, we're quicker to exit.IBD: Will the housing rebound continue as rates rise?Miller: Yes. Curt Culver, the CEO of MGIC (MTG), says we're heading into housing nirvana.We had six years of decline from the peak. Interest rates went down. Since the housing cycle turned up, rates are up. So are stocks. So low rates were not good for housing stocks because fundamentals were so bad. Since the housing cycle turned (up) in 2012, rates are up. So are stocks. Not up (in 2013), but up a ton (in 2012)In 2012 the builders — Pulte (PHM), Lennar (LEN), KB Home (KBH) — were up triple digits, most of them. (In 2013 they were) flat to down. The ones that didn't do well (in 2012) — like MGIC and eTrade (ETFC), which has a large mortgage portfolio — (were) up triple digits (in 2013).So we're bulls on the housing cycle. Rates are likely to continue higher. But housing stocks, direct builders, after a pause (last year) will have a great 2014.IBD: Where does Ellington Financial (EFC) fit in?Miller: They're less of a direct housing play. They operate in mortgage-backed securities and agency securities. They're really a hedge fund trying to maximize income and grow book value through investing in housing securities, but they can go long and short.IBD: Best Buy (BBY) earnings per share skyrocketed 350% in Q3, but the stock sold off. Are you concerned too?Miller: The story is that since the new CFO (Sharon McCollam) came in from Williams-Sonoma, they've done a fantastic job. They are trying to train associates so they are knowledgeable and not trying to rip off customers by steering them to things like insurance for televisions.People were afraid a year ago that Amazon (AMZN) would put them out of business. Now they've realized that same-store sales have started to turn positive again. The company can be profitable even as Amazon prospers.It sold off recently because people expected a big margin improvement in the near term. We expect it in the next year or two.IBD: I see several airline stocks in the portfolio. Is there a consolidation play, or some other strategy?Miller: There is consolidation. Three of our top holdings are airlines. (The three included Delta Air Lines (DAL) and United Continental (UAL) as of Sept. 30; US Airways has since merged with American Airlines (AAL).) The industry is reporting record profits. And we're early in the industry turnaround. Delta has done the best because of dividends and buybacks. But airlines are trading at a huge discount to cruise line stocks and shippers like FedEx (FDS) and UPS (UPS). So we think there's a lot of room to go with airlines.United is our favorite. United and Delta have roughly the same revenues and their balance sheets are similar once you adjust for things like capital leases and pension liabilities. But Delta has a $25 billion market capitalization and United has $14 billion. United has 14,000 more employees and 500 more planes.United will be rationalizing that in the next couple of years, so we see significant margin (improvement) opportunity there. And United will start returning capital to shareholders, which should help the stock as well.IBD: Is IAC/InterActiveCorp (IACI), which has begun to run up, a play on its wide portfolio of Internet sites?Miller: This is just a small position for us. It has run up (recently) because it might spin off disparate subsidiaries. But it's more the case that at about six times enterprise value vs. EBITDA that we bought it, it was way too cheap given the value of its underlying assets. (In the past,) CEO Barry Diller has spun off Home Shopping Network, Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP). He's a value creator.There are a lot of assets that could be spun out. We bought it around 50 when we thought it was worth 70 (and it has gapped up to around 70).IBD: Netflix (NFLX) is uptrending, but you've trimmed in recent quarters. What's your thesis?Miller: When the company talked about splitting in two, it caused subscribers to flee. The stock went from over 300 to the low 50s. It was earning over $5 a share on its U.S. business alone. It was hard to believe a company of that dominance would trade at 10 times earnings while it was growing 20% to 30% a year.What was causing the angst was the money it was spending internationally. (The fund started to buy around 50.) The company looked like it was worth two to three times what we were paying. Then (activist investor) Carl Icahn got involved. The stock started running up rapidly. Now its valuation is similar to Sirius' (SIRI), but Sirius has greater free cash flow and more predictability. The valuation on Netflix properly reflects its current trajectory of growth but one that may not reflect its total addressable market. We've cut back a fair amount, but it's still a 3% position.IBD: Apple has sold off a little since late last month, but basically has uptrended since June. Investors love it or hate it. What's your view?Miller: Apple is fascinating. Every person in the market has an opinion. Usually about 90% are tilted to what's the next hot product. Usually the opinion is tilted to what's their next hot product. Can they still be innovative? Will they have an iWatch? Are they going to be in TVs? The questions are interesting but irrelevant when Apple was trading around 400 a few months and around 550 now. They're still cheap.They have $45 billion of free cash flow and a $300 billion market cap, with $150 billion in cash on their balance sheet, making the biggest buyback in the history of the world, and with a dividend yield over 3%.We sold in the 650 to 700 range a year ago as it was peaking. That happened.In the past few months earnings estimate revisions have turned higher. So price targets have turned higher. The stock has turned higher. We think Apple is worth 750 to 800 a share. Will it get there? Maybe at some point, but it's still cheap vs. its underlying value.IBD: Is eTrade (ETFC) a plan on the U.S. economic rebound?Miller: It's within 10% to 20% of fair value. It had a huge move, which was driven by the correct perception that its mortgage book is rapidly healing.When the stock was at 9 or 10, we thought it was worth about 18. That was with big losses in the mortgage portfolio mark to market.Etrade has three things going for it: First, if the Fed starts putting rates up, that'll lead to earnings estimate increases. Second, as individual investors come back to the market, they service them. Third, they're a consolidation candidate via Ameritrade (AMTD) or Schwab (SCHW) or somebody like that.IBD: Is Morgan Stanley (MS) a similar play?Miller: What you see is what you get. CEO James Gorman has been transparent that the company needs return on equity higher. And they can do that by combining their sales force with Smith Barney's, which is now under way.We bought back in the teens when the stock was trading way below tangible book value. Now it's trading above tangible book value, but not much. Earnings estimate is trending higher.They're a beneficiary of a higher return on equity leading to rising relative price-to-book. And as capital markets improve, they benefit from that. But they're nowhere as cheap as they were when they were trading at a big discount to tangible book.Citi (C) is still a discount to tangible book. Genworth (GNW) is a huge discount to tangible book. So there are still names out there that have a lot of improvability left.IBD: A lot of investors are turned off by Amazon's (AMZN) dismal earnings per share record. Their total business is $75 billion, so AWS might be 5% to 10% of that.Amazon reminds me of the old telecom TCI under John Malone. Qunar.com, Chinese search engine Baidu's travel site, just filed for a $125 million U.S. IPO on Monday. Data show there's plenty of demand in China's online travel market to justify such a bullish move. A report issued in late August by research firm PhoCusWright sees gross bookings in China's online travel market more than doubling from 2012 to 2015, to…

Now that the market is in a confirmed uptrend again, the IBD 50 is the go-to place to find top stocks to add to watch lists, with several leaders reporting quarterly results this week. HomeAway (AWAY) and Spirit Airlines (SAVE) are on tap Wednesday, while Actavis (ACT), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Yandex (YNDX) come to the plate Thursday. HomeAway, No. 32…
Buyers were back in the market Tuesday after Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen reassured markets the Fed will continue its accommodative stance.

The Dow Jones industrial average led the way, rising 1.1%. Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) were the strongest-performing blue chips, up close to 2% each. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 gained 0.9%. The S&P 500 showed noteworthy technical action, rising above its 50-day moving average.
NYSE volume was tracking 3% higher than Monday. Nasdaq volume rose 9%.

Janet Yellen's testimony in front of the House Financial Services Committee came and went without much fanfare. Among other things, she said if the economy shows more improvement, the Fed will continue to scale back its monthly bond purchases. She also said "the recovery in the labor market is far from complete" and that monthly asset purchases "are not on a preset course."

In the stock market today, specialty pharmaceuticals firm Mallinckrodt (MNK) soared 11% on news it's buying Cadence Pharmaceuticals (CADX) for about $1.3 billion. The deal will increase Mallinckrodt's presence in hospitals. Cadence's key drug is Ofirmev, an intravenous form of acetaminophen for pain management. Cadence shares gapped up 26%.

Meanwhile, iRobot (IRBT) broke out in heavy volume, rising 16%. Quarterly results have been choppy of late but investors liked the look of its Q4 report. Profit surged 1,000% from a year ago to 11 cents a share. Sales rose 25% to $126.3 million.

On the downside, Proto Labs' (PRLB) recent base-building efforts ran into some trouble, but the stock recovered nicely after early weakness. Shares fell 1% after the quick-turn manufacturer reported disappointing results. Revenue rose 31% to $44 million, barely above the consensus estimate of $43.7 million.

After the close, watch for earnings from network security firm FireEye (FEYE). It's been showing relative strength ahead of the results. It's not profitable yet, but the company shows strong revenue growth in recent quarters. Revenue this time around is expected to rise 77% from a year ago to $56.1 million.

Online travel firm TripAdvisor (TRIP) is also scheduled to report. Shares gapped up on Friday after peer Expedia (EXPE) reported strong earnings. TripAdvisor has been consolidating gains since November. Stocks were steady, trimming some initial losses in weak trade near midday.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each down 0.4%. The Nasdaq narrowed its loss to 0.2%.

The stock market today was not finding any glimmers of progress among political leaders in Washington, but losses were mild and institutional investors remained largely on the bench. Volume dimmed 15% on the Nasdaq and sagged 24% lower on the NYSE compared with Friday's light trade.

Almost 85% of the S&P 500 stocks were down in morning trade. Expedia (EXPE) fell more than 7% in heavy action, the index's biggest loss. Netflix (NFLX) climbed 5% in four times its average volume, the S&P 500's biggest gain.

Losses continued to be broad but relatively shallow among leaders. More than four in five of the IBD 50 stocks were trading lower. Mylan (MYL), Facebook (FB) and Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) held the list's worst losses — down 2% each.

Whirlpool (WHR) dived 5% in powerful selling after Longbow Research said weak September shipments would prevent the company from either topping Q3 expectations or raising its guidance. The appliance maker had been pulling back since a Sept. 19 high. Monday's slip sent shares below their 50-day line of support in heavy trade.

Homebuilder stocks were experiencing some selling pressure, with Ryland Group (RYL), D.R. Analysts expect Priceline (PCLN) to deliver solid results when it issues its first-quarter results after the market close Thursday, with its European business seen holding up. The consensus estimate of 26 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for the online travel agency to post earnings of $5.27 a share excluding stock-based compensation, up 23% from $4.28 in the year-earlier quarter,…
Most analysts expect Priceline (PCLN) to report strong results on market share gains in Europe and the U.S. when it issues its second-quarter results after the close Thursday.

The consensus estimate of 27 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for the online travel agency to post earnings of $9.37 a share, excluding stock-based compensation, up 19% from the year-earlier quarter, on revenue of $1.66 billion, up 25%.
For the current Q3, analysts expect Priceline to post EPS ex items of $15.86, up 28%, on revenue of $2.22 billion, up 30%.

JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth, in a research note Monday, said he expects upbeat Q2 results, with international foreign-exchange-neutral bookings growth in the low- to mid-40% range. This, he says, despite macro concerns in Europe and signs of slightly softer travel demand in Britain. He says Priceline got a lift in Q2 by boosting its U.S. marketing. Anmuth is also incorporating revenue from Kayak in his Q2 estimates. Priceline completed its acquisition of metasearch provider Kayak in Q2.

Observers also say Priceline's European unit Booking.com gained market share in Q2 vs. Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP). But TripAdvisor two weeks ago reported better-than-expected Q2 results, as IBD reported.

Anmuth reiterated his overweight, or buy, rating on Priceline stock and raised his price target to 1,040 from 830. Priceline was trading near 928.50 in early trading in the stock market Wednesday, down 1.5%. The stock hit a 14-year high of 940 on Tuesday, and on Monday hit a 926.50 buy point out of a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Morgan Stanley raised its price target by 33% on July 8 to 1,010 and upgraded the stock to overweight from equal weight on signs that Booking.com is grabbing market share from Expedia in Europe. Jefferies Equity Research raised its price target to 1,005 from 860 on July 16.

Deutsche Bank Markets Research analyst Ross Sandler offered a contrasting view in an Aug. 5 online travel report. He says Expedia's bookings have rebounded from the drubbing it got from Booking.com in Europe in Q2 and has regained the top position in online travel. He notes that Expedia's hotel bookings suffered in Q2 as TripAdvisor shifted to a metasearch model from cost-per-click, or CPC-based, ad revenue.

Metasearch is a price search tool that generates revenue by letting users book hotels and other travel directly. CPC ads are used to direct traffic to other websites. Advertisers pay website owners such as TripAdvisor when an ad is clicked.
Sandler says TripAdvisor's transition to metasearch is stabilizing, but had temporarily disrupted bookings that came to Expedia by way of TripAdvisor.
TripAdvisor was spun off from Expedia in an IPO in December 2011 and draws related-party revenue from Expedia.
RELATED: Priceline Stock Rises As JPMorgan Hikes Price Target.

Priceline (PCLN) shares were up 4% in morning trading Friday, a day after the company reported first-quarter earnings that shattered forecasts but gave a light Q2 sales and profit outlook.
Shares had fallen 3% after hours Thursday, after the results were issued.

The Norwalk, Conn.-based company, which trailblazed a name-your-price service, earned $5.76 a share minus special items, up 35% from the year-earlier quarter. That beat the consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters by 49 cents. But the company has often beaten views by a lot. Priceline beat by 23 cents in Q4 2012.
Revenue surged 26% to $1.3 billion, narrowly topping analyst views of $1.28 billion on strong international bookings. It was the second straight quarter of accelerating growth.

But for the current quarter, Priceline expects revenue growth to slow to 15%-22%, with adjusted earnings per share of $8.87-$9.45. Those are below analyst expectations for 23.3% revenue growth and EPS of $9.58.

JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth said in a research note Friday that Priceline's Q1 was driven by good growth in Europe from Booking.com and higher growth rates at its Asia-Pacific-based Agoda website and Rentalcars.com.

"We believe Priceline is performing very well despite still choppy macro (economic conditions), increased competition, international expansion investments, and the desktop-to-mobile transition," Anmuth wrote.
He reiterated his overweight rating on the stock and price target of 830. Priceline was trading near 768 in the stock market today.

RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney said in a report that Priceline fell after hours Thursday because of less-than-expected international bookings upside and soft Q2 margin guidance. "But we view our long thesis on (Priceline) as very much intact," said Mahaney, who maintained his outperform rating and 900 price target.

The analyst sees the potential for 40% growth in the company's key international bookings segment this year. He also says Priceline is showing that it can successfully expand into the Asia-Pacific and Latin American markets and that rental cars are on the verge of becoming a notable gross bookings driver.
Mahaney also said Priceline appears to be maintaining or gaining market share vs. Expedia (EXPE).

Online travel stocks hit turbulence on worries over increased competition after Expedia (EXPE) missed Q2 profit and sales estimates, sending shares of rivals Orbitz Worldwide (OWW), Priceline.com (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) down as well.
Shares of Expedia were down 23% in the stock market today before the market open on Friday. Shares of Orbitz fell more than 4%, while Priceline.com was down 3% and TripAdvisor 1.4%.
Bellevue, Washington-based Expedia reported that Q2 EPS fell 28% to 64 cents, below views, as sales and marketing costs rose 33%. Revenue grew 16% to $1.21 billion, vs. views of $1.26 billion.
"Expedia is facing increasing competitive marketing intensity, especially in the domestic market vs. Booking.com, TripAdvisor, and others," said Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson in a report.

"The TripAdvisor (transition) has presented some challenges. It appears Expedia is in the difficult position of having to increase marketing spend to continue to push for international share gains, while now facing increased competition domestically."

Expedia lowered EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization) guidance for 2013 from "low double digit, with the possibility of low teens EBITDA growth" to "mid-to-high single digits."
On its earnings call, Expedia management said it's spending more on marketing for its eLong unit in China as well as Trivago.

"The environment remains competitive, especially in the U.S., with three major travel players essentially entering the brand marketing space: Priceline's Booking.com, TripAdvisor and Expedia's Trivago," said Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald in a report.
"Despite these near-term pressures Expedia continues to focus on longer-term growth as they market at eLong, Trivago and Egencia. eLong continues to gain share in China."
Expedia's Q2 gross bookings rose 13% to $10.12 billion from a year earlier, shy of consensus estimates of $10.25 billion.

"Expedia continues to see strong share gains from eLong, although they suffered a temporary business disruption this quarter, which contributed to the miss," said RBC Capital analyst Mark Mahaney in a report.

"There was also continued weakness in Southern Europe and the U.K. Overall, bookings growth was disappointing across geographies for a variety of factors, both competitive and otherwise."Online travel stocks hit turbulence on worries over increased competition after Expedia (EXPE) missed Q2 profit and sales estimates, sending shares of rivals Orbitz Worldwide (OWW), Priceline.com (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) down as well.Shares of Expedia were down 23% in the stock market today before the market open on Friday. Volume started strong on the stock market today, but slipped into tightly mixed action before midday: Trading is higher on the NYSE but a tad lower on the Nasdaq. The market navigated a morning…
Online vacation rental firm HomeAway (AWAY) late Thursday reported Q2 sales and profit that beat views, but its paid listings growth for vacation homes slowed and shares fell late.
Total paid vacation property listings rose 5.3% vs. Q2 2012 to 775,232, slower than the 6.2% year-over-year growth the company reported in Q1.
HomeAway said paid listings growth would have been 10%, but it was held back because of a new program that gives users the ability to consolidate several listings into one listing.
Still, the company would like to be closer to 15% listings growth, CEO Brian Sharples said on a conference call with analysts.
"If you look at 10%, that's not where we'd like to be," he said.
The stock, which rose 6.5% in Thursday's regular session, was down about the same amount after hours, after the release.

At the same time, shares of online travel site Expedia (EXPE) were down 25% after hours, after it released Q2 results that fell far short. The company reported EPS ex items of 64 cents, down 28%, where analysts had expected 79 cents.

"We knew we were facing second-quarter head winds and those which we expected, as well as some we didn't, materialized. Despite this, we remain confident about our long-term strategy," Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshahi said in a statement.

The company's sales and marketing costs soared 33% as it expanded overseas vs. rivals such as Priceline (PCLN) . The company said Trivago, the Germany-based hotel search site in which it acquired a majority stake in March, contributed about 11 percentage points to its sales and marketing growth.

As for Austin, Texas-based HomeAway, it reported sales rose 21% to $86.6 million and EPS ex items rose 45% to 16 cents. Wall Street had expected $85.7 million and 14 cents, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Thursday's report marked a slowdown from the prior three quarters, but HomeAway's sales are seasonal. Adjusted year-over-year EPS rose 56% in Q1, 100% in Q4 and 27% in Q3.
The company slightly tightened its full-year revenue guidance range to $339 million to $341 million, in line with expectations for $340 million. Its guidance had been $338 million to $341 million.

HomeAway this year is working to introduce a "pay-per-booking" listing program, which will compete with its normal "pay-per-listing" subscription program. Property owners will be able to list vacation rentals for free, then pay when the property is booked. Now, they have to subscribe to be listed.

The new program is a risk, because it could cannibalize business from HomeAway's current subscriptions, wrote Deutsche Bank analyst Lloyd Walmaley in a research note Monday. But the move is being driven by changes in the vacation-rental industry, with pressure from startups like Airbnb, which lets users rent out homes, rooms, even couches by the night.
"We would take advantage of any weakness associated with the transition to build positions for the long term," wrote Walmaley, who rates the stock a buy.
HomeAway's subscription renewal rate for properties fell to 72.4% in Q2 from 73.6% in Q1.

That small decline is encouraging, because those renewing know about that impending launch of pay-per-bookings, Sharples says. Pay-per-bookings is in beta testing, and will start rolling out to some users in Q3, he says.

"We're excited for the potential in this new line of business during 2014 and beyond," Sharples said. "We also remain confident that pay-per-booking will not affect our current listings."Online vacation rental firm HomeAway (AWAY) late Thursday reported Q2 sales and profit that beat views, but its paid listings growth for vacation homes slowed and shares fell late.Total paid vacation property listings rose 5.3% vs. Q2 2012 to 775,232, slower than the 6.2% year-over-year growth the company reported in Q1.HomeAway said paid listings growth would have been 10%, but it was held back because of a new program that gives users the ability to consolidate several listings into one listing.Still, the company would like to be closer to 15% listings growth, CEO Brian Sharples said on a conference call with analysts."If you look at 10%, that's not where we'd like to be," he said.The stock, which rose 6.5% in Thursday's regular session, was down about the same amount after hours, after the release.At the same time, shares of online travel site Expedia (EXPE) were down 25% after hours, after it released Q2 results that fell far short. Under the partnership, Egencia and Concur will connect their corporate travel booking and expense management processes into one offering for their clients. Concur's platform…

TripAdvisor (TRIP) added to its stable of niche travel sites on Tuesday, announcing it's acquired Jetsetter.com , a members-only luxury travel deals site, from Gilt Groupe. The purchase price wasn't disclosed.

TripAdvisor said Jetsetter, which specializes in private-sale hotel bookings, will be paired with SniqueAway, TripAdvisor's existing travel deals website. TripAdvisor, which provides travel reviews and related content, also manages and operates websites under 19 other travel media brands such as airfarewatchdog.com and bookingbuddy.com.
"With Jetsetter and our own SniqueAway brand, we now have two leading travel private sale sites under one roof," TripAdvisor CEO and co-founder Steve Kaufer said in the press release.
TripAdvisor said Jetsetter will continue to operate out of New York City and will be incorporated into its Smarter Travel Media unit.

Online shopping provider Gilt Groupe reportedly had been trying to sell Jetsetter since last year. The website was rumored to be losing money and some reports said Gilt, which is said to be preparing an IPO, put Jetsetter on the block in October for an asking price of $50 million. Speculation among some analysts this week was that TripAdvisor paid less than the $50 million.
Travel website Expedia (EXPE) spun off TripAdvisor in an IPO in December 2011. Shares of both TripAdvisor and Expedia were up more than 2% in the stock market today.

Stock futures aimed moderately higher ahead of Friday's open, as investors looked toward home sales data and any news out of the Federal Reserve's conference at Jackson Hole.
Dow futures inched ahead 2 points. Nasdaq 100 futures added 3.75 points and S&P 500 futures were positive to the tune of 1.5 points.

The stock market today opens with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 eyeing their first possible gain in three weeks. New home sales data come out at 10 a.m. ET. The Federal Reserve's conference gets underway in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, but will focus on international banking issues, limiting its potential effect on the day's trade.

Investors will be watching carefully to see whether the Nasdaq behaves normally, after technical issues shut the exchange down Thursday afternoon. The closure will make volume comparisons, which are a central issue this week, difficult late in the day.

Earnings reports have powered heavy trade in a limited number of stocks, but the week's overall action has been quiet. Institutions are holding their positions, which is good. But they are being extremely guarded in their buying of new stocks and adding to existing holdings, which leaves the market in a dead zone.

The "market in correction" warning remains in place. A major index must either shift to new highs or form a bottom and enact a follow through session in order to launch a fresh uptrend. Until one of those happens, investors should be sitting tight and rotating to cash when sell signals occur.
Stocks were active early Friday, led by a 43% surge by smart home software maker Control4 (CTRL). The Salt Lake City-based company went public August 2 and ended Thursday 29% above its IPO price.

China-based social networking platform Renren (RENN) swept ahead 14% in premarket action. The company announced an agreement in which search engine heavy Baidu (BIDU) would acquire a majority share in Renren subsidiary Nuomi Holdings, a group-buying site along the lines of Groupon (GRPN).
Renren shares have declined since shortly after its May 2011 IPO. The stock ended Thursday 76% below its IPO price. Baidu shares rose more than 2% ahead of the open.

Expedia (EXPE) jumped 5% after announcing a marketing agreement with Travelocity. Expedia will provide technology platforms and customers in the U.S. and Canada. Travelocity is owned by American Airlines spin-off Sabre Holdings.
Expedia shares correctly sharply in July and are well below key levels of support.

On the downside, Pandora Media (P) unraveled 9% in premarket action. The Internet radio operator topped second-quarter sales and earnings expectations, but guided third-quarter earnings below consensus views.
The stock has been rallying for nine months and ended Thursday more than 200% above its November low.

Overseas, China's markets took narrow losses Friday and ended unevenly lower for the week, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index down 2.9% and the Shanghai Composite off 0.1%. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 jumped 2.2% Friday, hoisting the index to a fractional gain for the week.

Europe's leading indexes were tightly mixed at midday, and also tracking toward an uneven performance for the week. The CAC-40 in Paris was so far down 1.9% for the week. London's FTSE 100 was ahead 0.1%.

The dollar nicked a three-week high vs. the yen, but slipped against the euro.
