Companies that provide online travel content should be feeling pretty good about themselves after a series of recent deals from suitors with deep pockets. One of those companies, TripAdvisor (TRIP), has seen its shares spike higher in recent weeks thanks to a move by Liberty Interactive to take control of its shares. TripAdvisor is a provider of online travel information…

Shares of Expedia rose 4% in after-hours trading Tuesday, after the online travel firm posted a record increase in hotel rooms booked and handily beat Q4 sales forecasts.The company's earnings per share, however, missed Wall Street's forecast.Bellevue, Wash.-based Expedia (EXPE) reported EPS minus items of 63 cents, up 9% but shy of the 65 cents analysts had expected.Sales jumped 24% to $974.9 million from $787.1 million, the company reported. Analysts had been expecting $930.7 million, according to Thomson Reuters.Besides sales, Expedia's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or EBITDA, beat expectations, Cantor Fitzgerald analyst Naved Khan wrote in a research note. He rates the stock a buy. Expedia said EBITDA rose 14% to $184.6 million.While the average daily rate for a hotel room booked through Expedia fell 3%, room nights booked jumped 33% from the year-earlier quarter, which the company said was a record. U.S. room nights rose less, at 19%, but that was the most in two years, the company said.This also marked the fourth straight quarter of accelerating year-over-year sales growth, from 7% in Q4 2011 to 12%, 14%, 17% and now 24%."Much of our improved results have been the result of our investment in technology and content," Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshahi told analysts on a conference call.But he also said the company expects "competitive intensity" to increase both in the U.S. and abroad.Expedia's expenses rose 26% in Q4, a quicker pace than its sales. That's expected to continue throughout 2013, "especially in the first half," Mark Okerstrom, Expedia's chief financial officer, said on the call. Expedia doesn't give financial guidance, but Okerstrom said marketing expenses and costs will rise more quickly than revenue.Technology and content led Q4 growth with a 32% cost increase, the company said. That spending helped Hotels.com boost its "production speed" by 30% and develop a new Expedia Facebook (FB) app, the company said."Please note that as we introduce new technology, we also experience significantly higher depreciation expenses," Okerstrom said.Expedia is the No. 1 online travel company by visitors, ahead of No. 2 Priceline (PCLN).Expedia had 16 million unique U.S. visitors in December, says market tracker ComScore, to Priceline's 12.3 million. But Expedia's unique U.S. visitors that month rose just 3% year over year, to 19% for Priceline, says Susquehanna Financial analyst Deepak Mathivanan.Expedia, Priceline and other online travel sites face a growth threat from Google (GOOG), Ascendiant Capital Markets analyst Edward Woo wrote in a research note last month.Google's 2011 acquisition of flight information software provider ITA Software, a $700 million deal that regulators reviewed for nine months before granting approval, signaled a "big push into travel information and commerce," Woo pointed out.Keeping Eye On GoogleGoogle probably won't become an online travel agency anytime soon, Woo wrote last month, but he also said "Google could use its dominance in search to direct traffic to its own products, which may lower traffic to Expedia websites."The U.S. Federal Trade Commission in December ended an investigation by determining Google doesn't break any antitrust laws by at times favoring its own content in search results, if that content is pertinent to the search.Expedia is keeping an eye on Google, Khosrowshahi told analysts. "We'll be working with them, while watching to see how their products evolve," he said.Expedia's also taking an "aggressive" stance on growing traffic in Europe, Credit Suisse analyst Stephen Ju wrote in a note, signaled by its December deal to buy a majority stake in German online travel metasearch firm Trivago, expected to close before July. Trivago could help Expedia gain ground vs. Priceline, Ju wrote in a December note. And since Trivago is a "known brand" in much of Europe, it won't be "as dependent on Google for its organic traffic," he said.Expedia, though, already has been growing more quickly in Europe than in the U.S. International sales jumped 35% in Q4, while U.S. sales increased 15%.Hotel revenue jumped 20% in 2012, but flight sales fell 7% because ticket prices fell about 14% from 2011, Expedia said.Expedia shares rose 3.6% in Tuesday's regular session to their highest close since August 2003. Shares are up nearly 14% this year.
Companies are treading volatile waters lately, but Travelzoo (TZOO) CEO Chris Loughlin sees smooth sailing for his travel-centered Internet media company.

Loughlin, who has led Travelzoo since July 2010, is bullish on the company's future. He said just why in a recent interview with IBD, talking about how much revenue Travelzoo generates per employee, the thinking behind share repurchases and the launch of a global iPhone application.
The New York-based company also has received lots of traction in the last year from Local Deals, a Groupon-like discount deal program that's swelled revenue.
Loughlin says lean staffing and efficient management of the company's 343 employees helps Travelzoo get the biggest bang for the buck in the deal/travel market.
"Our revenue per employee is sitting at about $438,000 (based on 2011 sales expectations)," said Loughlin.

Travelzoo publishes email newsletters that provide travel, entertainment and local deals offered by hotels, airlines and others in the travel field. Bookings are done by the travel suppliers, not Travelzoo. It makes money from advertising provided by these suppliers.

"Travelzoo is doing well on revenue per employee when you compare it to Groupon," said Edward Woo, a Wedbush Securities analyst in Los Angeles. Woo rates Travelzoo outperform, or buy, with a 12-month price target of $72. The stock now trades near 25 , down from 90 on July 20.
Loughlin says Travelzoo does a better job of generating revenue per employee than rivals.

Groupon, which has filed for an initial public offering that it might launch in October or November, has said in its IPO filings that it averages $138,000 revenue per sales representative. It didn't provide a figure per all employees, but it says it had 9,625 employees as of June 30, and it reported revenue of $644 million for Q1. At that employee count, that would be about $67,000 per employee. As of the end of 2010, Expedia (EXPE) and its China-based eLong (LONG) unit employed 8,900 persons and had a combined $3.42 billion in revenue, for revenue per employee of about $384,000.
Employee productivity is one reason Loughlin says Travelzoo is a high-growth business.
Ensures Suppliers Deliver
The company stresses that it has more than 250 employees who check each travel deal to ensure suppliers deliver what's promised.
On Aug. 22, Travelzoo announced its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 500,000 of Travelzoo's common shares. This for a company with a float of just 6 million shares.
"We feel that Travelzoo is undervalued," Loughlin said.

He and other company executives say the price/earnings to growth ratio — PEG, a measure of a stock's value — for Travelzoo is about 0.5. They use figures from Morningstar, which uses the forward P/E and the average estimated per-share profit growth for the next five years. That compared with a PEG of 1.2 for Expedia and, for example, 1.1 for Yahoo (YHOO) and 1.0 for Netflix (NFLX).

"If your PEG ratio is below 1, it generally indicates the stock is undervalued," Loughlin said. "So we made an announcement to initiate a share buyback, which is over 5% of the outstanding public float."
Wedbush's Woo says the share buyback is a "positive sign," but isn't a move "that's going to make or break the company." "What's important is that Travelzoo executes on Local Deals," Woo said.
But some analysts wonder if consumers are tiring of the deal phenomenon trailblazed by Groupon. One indicator might be if the slowdown in Travelzoo's Local Deals business continues past the summer.

This month, Travelzoo said its gross revenue from Local Deals fell to $9.9 million in August from $10.8 million in July, which it called a "seasonal slowdown." But Local Deals has ramped up fast. In July-August 2010, when it was just starting the program, Local Deals brought in a mere $119,000 in gross revenue.
"It will be bad if (the decline) is a recurring pattern, but it's too soon to tell," Woo said.

As Travelzoo tries to ramp up business, it's also tapping the power of mobile travel applications. It launched its first iPhone application in late July. The app shows Travelzoo's popular Top 20 list of travel deals. One twist is that it uses the phone's GPS system to pinpoint travel deals in the user's area.
"If you land in New York City, you can bring up your phone and find local hotels on Travelzoo's app," Loughlin said.

The application is available for U.S. iPhone users. It's also in the process of being rolled out to eight other countries.Companies are treading volatile waters lately, but Travelzoo (TZOO) CEO Chris Loughlin sees smooth sailing for his travel-centered Internet media company.Loughlin, who has led Travelzoo since July 2010, is bullish on the company's future. This for a company with a float of just 6 million shares."We feel that Travelzoo is undervalued," Loughlin said.He and other company executives say the price/earnings to growth ratio — PEG, a measure of a stock's value — for Travelzoo is about 0.5. They use figures from Morningstar, which uses the forward P/E and the average estimated per-share profit growth for the next five years. That compared with a PEG of 1.2 for Expedia and, for example, 1.1 for Yahoo (YHOO) and 1.0 for Netflix (NFLX)."If your PEG ratio is below 1, it generally indicates the stock is undervalued," Loughlin said. "So we made an announcement to initiate a share buyback, which is over 5% of the outstanding public float."Wedbush's Woo says the share buyback is a "positive sign," but isn't a move "that's going to make or break the company." "What's important is that Travelzoo executes on Local Deals," Woo said.But some analysts wonder if consumers are tiring of the deal phenomenon trailblazed by Groupon. One indicator might be if the slowdown in Travelzoo's Local Deals business continues past the summer.This month, Travelzoo said its gross revenue from Local Deals fell to $9.9 million in August from $10.8 million in July, which it called a "seasonal slowdown." But Local Deals has ramped up fast. In July-August 2010, when it was just starting the program, Local Deals brought in a mere $119,000 in gross revenue."It will be bad if (the decline) is a recurring pattern, but it's too soon to tell," Woo said.As Travelzoo tries to ramp up business, it's also tapping the power of mobile travel applications. It launched its first iPhone application in late July. The app shows Travelzoo's popular Top 20 list of travel deals. One twist is that it uses the phone's GPS system to pinpoint travel deals in the user's area."If you land in New York City, you can bring up your phone and find local hotels on Travelzoo's app," Loughlin said.The application is available for U.S. iPhone users. It's also in the process of being rolled out to eight other countries.

The major stock indexes closed with losses of more than 1% Wednesday after the indexes made bearish price reversals.
The Nasdaq, which had been up about 1% earlier, closed nearly 1.2% lower. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average slid about 1.4%.
Volume rose across the board, early indications showed. Declining stocks led advancers by more than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq and by 11-to-4 on the NYSE.
The way the indexes reversed course Wednesday quickly dampened the bullish tone of the prior session, when the main indexes made a follow-through rally confirmation.
The number of stocks rising in big volume rapidly diminished in the final two hours of trading.

Apple (AAPL) was a highlight in the stock market today after the company unveiled a series of new products. It introduced the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus, a larger tablet dubbed the iPad Pro, major improvements to its Apple TV franchise and other product upgrades.

But Apple shares fell 2%. Suppliers of components for Apple products were weaker, too. ARM Holdings (ARMH) fell 3%, Avago Technologies (AVGO) nearly 2%, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) more than 1%, Qorvo (QRVO) 3%, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) 1%.

MasterCard (MA) dropped 3%, sinking back to its 200-day moving average, after the credit-card company warned that profit growth would slow in the next few years. The stock has been below the 50-day moving average for a couple of weeks already.

Stericlycle (SRCL) tumbled 6%, dropping to its 50-day moving average, where it now looks for support. The stock closed 5% below the 143.79 buy point of flat base. The medical-waste handling company announced an offering of 7 million depositary shares that represent 10% of certain preferred stock.

WCI Communities (WCIC) went right back below its 25.74 buy point. Stronger-than-expected international bookings drove Priceline's (PCLN) Q3 profit and revenue above views as the online travel firm bucked a challenge in Europe by rival Expedia (EXPE), analysts say.

Shares in Priceline jumped 10.7% in early trading Friday. Shares in travel review site TripAdvisor (TRIP), which on Thursday also reported Q3 results above views, soared 20%. Expedia's shares edged up 1.2%.
Priceline reported Q3 results above estimates after the market close on Thursday and gave higher-than-expected Q4 guidance.
Priceline said Q3 revenue grew 17.4% to $1.7 billion. The firm said global bookings in Q3 rose 41%, well ahead of expectations.

"International bookings growth was driven by strong hotel supply growth as well as solid results at Rentalcars.com," said Raymond James analyst Aaron Kessler, who on Friday raised his price target on the stock to $735 per share from $670.
In Q4, Priceline said it expects international bookings to grow 32%.

"The key take-away for Q3 may, in fact, be that the rising tide of transition from offline to online travel bookings internationally is strong enough to support material growth for multiple players," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report. "Priceline continues to be a share taker in international online travel, something that was in question following Expedia's strong Q3 results."
TripAdvisor on Thursday reported per-share profit of 46 cents, beating views. Expedia reported Q3 results that beat analyst views on Oct. 25.
Prior to Priceline's earnings release on Thursday, IBD's leisure/online travel group was ranked No. 76 out of 197 industry sectors.
At Nomura Securities, analyst Brian Nowak says Priceline is weathering Expedia's challenge.

"(In Q3), Priceline removed investor concerns that its European business is being dramatically impacted by Expedia's growth gains, as the company said they are continuing to grow faster than their competition in the major markets," he said. "We estimate that Priceline grew faster than Expedia internationally (off of a much larger base)."
For the September quarter, Priceline reported a per-share profit of $12.40 vs. analyst views of $11.81. Earnings per share were up 25% from the year-ago period.
Macquarie capital analyst Tom White, in a report, said Priceline's Q4 guidance, despite weakening economies in Europe, was upbeat.

"Commentary on stabilization in Priceline's European business (for now at least) was an incremental positive," he said. "Macro risk in Europe is unlikely to abate any time soon, but management's constructive comments around stabilizing trends and the company's robust international gross bookings guidance highlight the resiliency of its business model, in our view."Stronger-than-expected international bookings drove Priceline's (PCLN) Q3 profit and revenue above views as the online travel firm bucked a challenge in Europe by rival Expedia (EXPE), analysts say.Shares in Priceline jumped 10.7% in early trading Friday. Stocks traded moderately higher around midday Friday, after pulling back from their session highs.

The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 added 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.2%. Volume surged across the board from Thursday's levels, boosted by quadruple witching for options and futures contracts.

Expedia (EXPE) jumped 5% in huge volume, hitting a new multiyear high and clearing a 59.60 buy point from a cup-shaped base. The online travel broker got a lift from Cantor Fitzgerald starting coverage with a buy rating, as well as Deutsche Bank upgrading the stock to a buy. Cantor Fitzgerald said Expedia was in the early stages of a turnaround and had prospects for further margin expansion. Expedia sports an IBD Composite Rating of 92 out of a best-possible 99.

Apple (AAPL) added nearly 1% in big trade, as iPhone 5 sales began and fans flocked to Apple stores around the world. The tech giant has hit a fresh all-time high and moved back above 700, after closing below that level Thursday. The stock, No. 5 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup, is well extended from a 619.97 handle buy point.

IHS' Composite Rating has slumped to a mediocre 73.

In economic news, Spain appeared to be making progress toward achieving reforms and gaining an EU bailout. Reuters, quoting unnamed sources, reported that Spain is considering freezing pensions and speeding up a planned rise in the retirement age to 67 from 65. A decision could be announced as early as next week.

A group of Google (GOOG) rivals on Tuesday told European regulators that the search giant's Android mobile software is a Trojan horse used to monopolize the mobile marketplace and control user data.

FairSearch — an advocacy group backed in part by Microsoft (MSFT), Expedia (EXPE), Nokia (NOK), Oracle (ORCL) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) — says it has filed a complaint with the European Commission. That's the intergovernmental agency that's investigating antitrust claims against Google.
The complaint says Google is using an "anti-competitive strategy," according to FairSearch.

"Google is using its Android mobile operating system as a 'Trojan Horse' to deceive partners, monopolize the mobile marketplace and control consumer data," the FairSearch coalition's Thomas Vinje said in a statement.
Google shares traded up a fraction in the stock market today.
Android is free, open-source software, and as such it amounts to "predatory distribution," the group alleges.
Android's cost "makes it difficult for other providers of operating systems to recoup investments in competing with Google's dominant mobile platform," the group says.

Almost exactly a year ago, TripAdvisor filed a similar claim against Google in Europe.A group of Google (GOOG) rivals on Tuesday told European regulators that the search giant's Android mobile software is a Trojan horse used to monopolize the mobile marketplace and control user data.FairSearch — an advocacy group backed in part by Microsoft (MSFT), Expedia (EXPE), Nokia (NOK), Oracle (ORCL) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) — says it has filed a complaint with the European Commission. Stocks opened higher Friday on better-than-expected GDP and consumer sentiment data.

The S&P 500 led, up 0.7%. The Nasdaq climbed 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average improved 0.5%. Volume was down a fraction on the Nasdaq and 15% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Thursday.

Consumer optimism edged up slightly more than expected in July, lifting the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index to 72.3 in its initial estimate for the month. The index had slipped to 72 in June, and economists had expected a flat reading.
U.S. gross domestic product rose 1.5% in the second quarter, slightly above forecasts but the slowest pace of growth since Q3 of 2011.

Expedia (EXPE) spiked 22% after Q2 earnings slipped, but less than expected, and sales forecasts topped analysts' views by a wide margin. A 16% gain in hotel bookings easily compensated for an 8% decline in airline ticket revenue.
The stock cleared a 50.76 buy point in a flat base.

Among IBD 50 stocks, medical management services provider HMS Holdings (HMSY) bolted 4% after squeezing past earnings expectations. Second-quarter revenue stopped short of expectations, but the company said the Supreme Court's health care decision in June was a "great outcome for HMS." The company said it had signed six new states as clients during the quarter due to the law.
The stock is building a handle with in a cup base.
Priceline.com (PCLN) jumped 5% in heavy trade. The online travel heavyweight has been trying to retake its 10-week line and shape the right side of a base since mid-June.

On the downside, Cerner (CERN) dumped 5%. The maker of medical tracking and management software cleared consensus sales and earnings forecasts for the second quarter. Q3 sales and EPS guidance was to the low side of analyst projections. Full-year earnings guidance topped views, but revenue was on the low side.

Earnings minus items are pegged at 41 cents.
Web travel company Expedia (EXPE) spun off TripAdvisor in a December IPO.

Piper Jaffray analyst Mike Olson said in an email interview that he sees "solid underlying travel trends," for TripAdvisor, "even in Europe, where many have expected a slowdown to emerge." As a result, Olson says there's potential for a slight upside to consensus figures with the company's second-quarter results.
Global payments and e-commerce company eBay (EBAY) dodged a big hit from Europe's woes and edged profit and sales views in Q2 results issued July 18, as we reported.

Olson notes that only about 40% of worldwide travel bookings today are online, with only 15% of worldwide travel ad spending on the Internet. "Over time, we expect travel ad spending to shift increasingly online, following the bookings, and TripAdvisor is the company best positioned to benefit from this trend," Olson said.
Piper Jaffray rates the stock overweight, with a price target of 52. TripAdvisor was trading near 45.50 early Friday, up nearly 1%.
Citigroup analyst Mark Mahaney said in a July 10 report that risk-reward factors are "fairly balanced" at current valuation levels for the stock.
Mahaney sees TripAdvisor's upsides as a potentially large market, its leadership status in travel media and growth drivers like global expansion, mobile, vacation rentals and content syndication.

On the downside, Mahaney sees competitive challenges from Google (GOOG) and other rivals, as well as economic challenges. He has a neutral rating on the stock and a target price of 46.TripAdvisor (TRIP) is slated to release Q2 results after the close Tuesday, and the consensus estimate of 18 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for the travel review and content provider to post earnings per share of 36 cents on revenue of $202.8 million. Kayak is a familiar name to many travelers as the site for searching other travel sites. The company was founded in 2004 by the co-founders of Expedia (EXPE), Travelocity and Orbitz (OWW), when they observed a problem with the business model of the traditional online travel agencies, or OTAs.

Customers used the sites to comparison-shop, but then would make the actual booking through the airline's or hotel's site. They hoped that the "meta" site, Kayak, would help hang on to customers' eyeballs.

Kayak filed to go public back in November 2010, boasting impressive revenue and profit growth. But it had to wait quite a while for the right moment. Most recently it tentatively scheduled a May 30 date, until the notoriety surrounding the Facebook (FB) debut drove other IPOs off the market for more than a month.

Kayak is playing it safe with a small offering of 3.5 million shares, which at the proposed price range would give it a market cap of around $1 billion. In a report last week, IPO Desktop chief Francis Gaskins wrote that the valuation seemed fair based on other OTA stocks.
THE COMPANY

Kayak was founded in 2004 and launched its website the next year. In the pre-IPO roadshow, executives described it as more of a search engine than a travel-booking site: the key to success is crawling over the various OTAs, hotel, car-rental and airline sites to get the best matches for what the customer is seeking. Currently, Kayak has relationships with more than 300 such sites.

Kayak's services are free to customers. It derives revenue from advertising and from referral fees from its partners, either from a per-click or per-thousand-impressions basis. Expedia and its affiliates, including Hotels.com, accounts for 23% of revenue.

In the first quarter of this year, Kayak processed more than 310 million queries, up 45% from the year-ago quarter. About 17% of the queries came through a mobile app that Kayak successfully launched in 2009, up from 12% last year.
But the company said the increase in more use was also responsible for a decline in revenue per thousand queries, as mobile doesn't provide as much of a platform for advertisers.

Kayak has been working to expand its market share by improving its "booking path," by giving customers ways to book on its own site instead of simply by referral to other sites. The prospectus says that its share of the hotel booking path rose to 39% in the first quarter from 2% in the year-ago quarter.

Kayak is also seeking expansion internationally. Currently, it operates in 15 countries outside the U.S., and last year, it acquired Germany's swoodoo and Austria's checkfelix.com to broaden its European footprint.
RISKS/CHALLENGES

Kayak operates in a highly competitive industry, complicated by the fact that many of its competitors are also its partners. Probably the most complicated relationship is with Google (GOOG). Kayak and Google have their own contract that expires in October, but last year, Google acquired ITA Software, from which Kayak licenses much of its technology, and launched its own hotel-search product. Kayak's contract with ITA expires at the end of next year, and Google might choose to change the terms.
The company has pursued a fairly acquisitive growth strategy. On top of the two European buys, it also acquired SideStep and JaBo Software. Acquisitions bring expenses and integration risks.

Kayak's goal to expand internationally also carries risks since it will enter markets in which it has no experience. Marketing strategies, customer wants, intellectual-property protections and financial regulations all vary from country to country. The travel industry overall is sensitive to economic downturns, given that it's a luxury for most people.
THE RESULTS
Revenue in the first quarter of the year rose 39% over the year-ago quarter to $73.3 million. Net income totaled $4.2 million, reversing a year-ago loss due to an impairment charge.
Adjusted for the charge, income rose 174%.
USE OF PROCEEDS

Kayak expects to raise $72.7 million from its offering of 3.5 million shares, or $84.1 million if the underwriters exercise their options in full. It will use the money for general corporate purposes.
THE MANAGEMENT
Daniel Hafner
Chief executive and director
Co-founded the company after working at Orbitz for three years. Before that, he spent three years as a consultant with Boston Consulting Group. He holds an MBA from Northwestern University.
Paul English
President, chief technology officer and director

Co-founded the company after spending three years as an executive at Intuit (INTU), after it acquired his startup Boston Light Software. From 1989 to 1995 he was a senior executive at Interleaf. He holds an MS in computer science from the University of Massachusetts-Boston.
Melissa Reiter
Chief financial officer and treasurer

Joined in 2009 and was promoted to her current position in March. From 2006 to 2009 she held various positions at Potbelly Sandwich Works; from 2002 to 2006 she worked at Orbitz and before that spent 11 years at Arthur Andersen. She holds a BBA from Miami University in Ohio.
Kayak Software Corp.
Norwalk, Conn.
kayak.com
Lead underwriters:
Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank
Offering price: $22-$25
Expected date: July 20

Earnings and revenue growth are key metrics for investors looking for top stocks to invest in.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Leaders with Rising Estimates: top-rated companies that analysts are raising earnings estimates on.
Here are the top six Rising Estimates equities ranked by expected EPS growth in the stock market today.
Topping the list is Evercore Partners (EVR), which provides advisory services on mergers, acquisitions, divestitures and the like. Consensus is that its EPS will spike 440% this quarter.
Evercore is a boutique investment bank that's filling a void left when many of the largest banks focused on mortgages and other services, leaving investment advice to companies like Evercore.
Its stock consolidated in the first half of 2012, bottomed at 20.57 intraday on July 27 and then began rising. It's since climbed 98% to 40.70 Thursday, up 0.7% for the day, at an all-time high.

LinkedIn (LNKD), the social network site for professionals, is projected to record 100% higher EPS for the quarter as it expands by providing career advice and bringing employees and employers together in an era of lingering high unemployment.
LinkedIn began trading on May 20, 2011 at 45 a share and closed Thursday at 168.18, up 274% since its IPO and down 0.2% for the day.

Michael Kors (KORS), which began trading in December 2011 at 20 a share, has met with tremendous acceptance. The luxury apparel, accessories and footwear retailer is forecast to report an 86% jump in EPS this quarter.
Kors turned heads when it reported a blowout holiday quarter on Feb. 12, which caused shares to gap up 8.8% for the day. Shares hit an all-time high 64.84 on Feb. 19, but have retreated a bit since.
Its share price has nearly tripled from its IPO to a 59.28 close Thursday, down 0.3% for the day.

Soufun Holdings (SFUN), a Chinese real estate marketing and listings company, is forecast for 53% higher EPS. It sports a hefty 7.1% dividend yield, which may or may not be attractive to investors, depending on investing strategy.
Like many U.S. counterparts, it's seen profit and sales grow at double- and triple-digit rates lately amid a hot real estate market.
After consolidating in early 2012, it stock began rising again on Aug. 1 and has since soared 145% to close at 26.85 Thursday, up 0.7% for the day.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) provides specialized payment services to companies that operate commercial fleets, and is forecast to post a 37% EPS increase in EPS this quarter.
It's also No. 1 on the elite IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks. Earlier this month, it cruised past estimates, fueled by global expansion.

It's benefited from an improving economy as companies shipped more goods of all sorts. Shares more than doubled from a midsummer low 34.82 on July 23 to close at an all-time high 69.81 Thursday, up 2.3% for the day. It's trading well above its 50-day and 200-day averages.

TripAdvisor (TRIP), the travel information provider spun off of web travel site Expedia (EXPE) in December 2011, is also on the Leaders with Rising Estimates list. TripAdvisor is expected to report a 21% EPS rise this quarter.
After a post-IPO surge, shares began consolidating last July. It's formed a long cup or saucer-type base and closed up 0.6% Thursday, 7% off its all-time high 49.35, reached on Feb. 6.

Web travel agencies like Priceline (PCLN) and Expedia (EXPE) might enjoy a moderate upswing from U.S. vacation travelers this summer based on the results of a TripAdvisor survey issued on Tuesday.

TripAdvisor's (TRIP) annual summer travel survey says that 86% of U.S. travelers are planning leisure trips this summer, up from 81% last year. Over a quarter, or 27%, say they'll spend more on leisure summer travel than they did in 2011, while 47% plan to spend the same amount as last year vs. 26% who expect to spend less.
TripAdvisor, which runs a travel review website, says 70% of travelers plan to stay at a hotel this summer, up from 67% in 2011.

The company also found found that 86% of U.S. survey respondents say that recently falling gas prices won't have an effect on their leisure travel plans this summer. But 10% said they expect to take more trips by car as a direct result of lower prices at the pump.

Priceline may benefit from a mild upswing in U.S. leisure travel this summer. Some analysts say its Europe-based Booking.com unit has been gaining market share among U.S. travelers vs. rivals like Orbitz (OWW) and Travelocity. Tracker ComScore says Priceline's U.S. traffic surged 27% year-over-year in Q1 vs. 25% in Q4.
TripAdvisor's U.S. traffic trend is also upbeat. ComScore says it jumped a robust 35% in Q1.
Expedia shares soared to a record high in late April after the company issued a Q1 report driven by strong gains in hotel-room bookings. The stock is trading near that high.
RELATED: TripAdvisor Q1 Handily Beats Forecasts.

Revenue likely rose 27% to $1.04 billion.For the current Q2, analysts expect Priceline to post EPS, excluding stock-based compensation and one-time costs, of $7.37, up 34% from $5.49 in the year-ago quarter and revenue of $1.39 billion, up 26%.Analysts are mostly positive on Priceline and its prospects in Q1. Some are assessing the impact of the upcoming London Summer Olympics and the European football finals on Q2 and Q3 results.S&P Capital IQ equity analyst Scott Kessler is looking for 32% revenue growth in the quarter. European hotel bookings should lead the way once again."We don't see any change to that story," Kessler said.The S&P analyst notes that rival online travel agency Expedia's (EXPE) surprise beat in its Q1 earnings report on April 26 shows that a European slowdown is having little impact on overseas sales by online travel agencies. Priceline does the bulk of its business in Europe. Expedia's shares surged nearly 27% on April 27, a day after it reported a Q1 profit of 26 cents per share, beating Wall Street's 16-cent forecast. Expedia spinoff TripAdvisor (TRIP), an ad-supported user-generated reviews site, shot up 17% on May 2 following its own blowout results.Priceline shares closed Monday at 737.65, up just 0.2% vs. Friday but up nearly 58% so far in 2012.In the current quarter and Q3, Kessler says the London Summer Olympics — July 27 to Aug. 12 — will have a largely positive impact on Priceline's European bookings. So will the final games of the European football championships that will take place in Warsaw, Poland, and Kiev, Ukraine, from June 8 to July 1."Priceline has significantly more (hotel room) supply in Warsaw and Kiev than their competitors," Kessler said.Kessler has a hold on Priceline stock and a target price of 725.Citigroup analyst Mark Mahaney said in an April 9 report that he believes Q1 consensus views are reasonable. But Mahaney says changing currency trends and soft economic conditions in Europe will undercut significant upside to analyst forecasts.Mahaney goes on to say that Street revenue, EPS and bookings views for Q2 are also "ballpark reasonable," though he thinks earnings might be a bit on the aggressive side. He also doesn't think Priceline will guide above Street Q2 estimates given its typically conservative guidance.Mahaney has a buy on the stock and a target price of 850.JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth has an overweight rating on Priceline and raised his target price on Monday to 810 from 730 on signs of strong Q1 results based on the upbeat hotel bookings being posted by other Web travel firms.Nomura Securities International analyst Brian Nowak upgraded Priceline on Monday to neutral from reduce on the company's improving U.S. and Asia business prospects. He has a 725 target price on the stock.
Travel website Expedia (EXPE) shares are traveling south Wednesday on a downgraded ticket from Lazard Capital, which now rates the stock as neutral.
Expedia was down 3.1% in afternoon trading Wednesday after Lazard analyst Jake Fuller dropped his rating from buy.

The company reported 62% earnings-per-share growth in Q1. That strength has pushed Expedia shares up almost 50% since it reported results on April 26, but Fuller's "concern is that slower 2Q revenue growth and flat-to-down margins could undermine confidence in the turnaround story."
Fuller also notes that softer air travel trends in the U.S. could make it difficult for Expedia to meet "elevated" expectations.

Rival TripAdvisor (TRIP) was down 2%, but Priceline (PCLN) was up a fraction. TripAdvisor (TRIP) shares were up 17% in after-hours trading Tuesday, after the provider of online travel reviews and more issued results that beat analyst views on an upsurge in ad and subscription revenue.
TripAdvisor said it earned 35 cents a share in the first quarter, unchanged from the year-earlier period but 6 cents higher than the average estimate of 17 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Sales jumped 33% to a record $183.7 million, beating analyst forecasts of $174.40 million.
Excluding items, TripAdvisor said it earned 38 cents a share, also flat with a year earlier but 4 cents higher than analyst estimates.

The company didn't give specific guidance, but Chief Financial Officer Julie Bradley told analysts the company expects 2012 revenue "to trend above the midpoint" of TripAdvisor's earlier guidance calling for growth in the mid- to high-teens. Analysts have forecast 17.5% growth. Its 2011 sales rose 31% to $637 million.

"We had a strong start to 2012," TripAdvisor CEO Steve Kaufer said in a conference call with analysts. "Our better-than-expected revenue and profit performance was driven primarily by stronger hotel shopper growth, which was up over 30% year-over-year, as well as slightly better (cost per click, or CPC) prices."
Last month, online search leader Google (GOOG) reported a 12% dip in its average CPC price, which it said stemmed from a greater proportion of still-lower-paying mobile ads.

TripAdvisor was spun off from Web travel company Expedia (EXPE) in December, and closed its first day of trading at 27.67. Shares hit an all-time high of 37.89 early in Tuesday's regular trading before fading to end the session at 36.53, down 2.6%. The stock had been on the now twice-weekly IBD 50 rankings of top stocks since April 2, but fell off the latest list publishing Wednesday.

The Newton, Mass.-based company said CPC revenue rose 20% from the year-earlier quarter to $144.9 million. This is revenue it gets each time a site user clicks on ads for a flight, hotel or other travel service. It made up 79% of the company's total revenue in the quarter.

TripAdvisor, which also provides customer reviews of travel destinations, restaurants and more, said its display ad revenue rose 17%. Subscription and other revenue had the biggest jump of its three breakout segments, surging 67%.
Analysts liked the Q1 numbers.

"We continue to believe TripAdvisor is well-positioned to benefit from growth in online travel advertising, given that only 15% or so of U.S. travel ad spend is online while 65% of U.S. travel bookings are online," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in an email interview. "That seems like a gap that needs to close over time."

JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth said in an investor note Monday that TripAdvisor got a lift in the quarter from strong travel industry metrics. Market tracker ComScore says the number of U.S. unique visitors to TripAdvisor's site soared 47% in Q1 from the year-earlier quarter, in line with 48% growth in Q4. These figures are way up from a 14% rise in Q3.

But Anmuth says TripAdvisor's challenges include hotel user growth rates and the impact that Google's rival travel review business might have on TripAdvisor. Anmuth also says that Expedia is reducing its spending for CPC ads on TripAdvisor.

But Olson says that based on company filings, Expedia's spending with TripAdvisor hasn't fallen as far as expected. And he says other online travel agencies such as Priceline.com (PCLN) are raising their ad spending with TripAdvisor, now that the company isn't under the umbrella of rival Expedia.

Nomura Equity Research analyst Brian Nowak said in an April 2 report that he expects TripAdvisor's CPC ad revenue to rise 10% in 2012 after jumping 30% in 2011. He pegs TripAdvisor's overall revenue growth in 2012 at 19%, toward the top end of TripAdvisor's guidance.TripAdvisor (TRIP) shares were up 17% in after-hours trading Tuesday, after the provider of online travel reviews and more issued results that beat analyst views on an upsurge in ad and subscription revenue.TripAdvisor said it earned 35 cents a share in the first quarter, unchanged from the year-earlier period but 6 cents higher than the average estimate of 17 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Sales jumped 33% to a record $183.7 million, beating analyst forecasts of $174.40 million.Excluding items, TripAdvisor said it earned 38 cents a share, also flat with a year earlier but 4 cents higher than analyst estimates.The company didn't give specific guidance, but Chief Financial Officer Julie Bradley told analysts the company expects 2012 revenue "to trend above the midpoint" of TripAdvisor's earlier guidance calling for growth in the mid- to high-teens. Analysts have forecast 17.5% growth. Its 2011 sales rose 31% to $637 million."We had a strong start to 2012," TripAdvisor CEO Steve Kaufer said in a conference call with analysts. "Our better-than-expected revenue and profit performance was driven primarily by stronger hotel shopper growth, which was up over 30% year-over-year, as well as slightly better (cost per click, or CPC) prices."Last month, online search leader Google (GOOG) reported a 12% dip in its average CPC price, which it said stemmed from a greater proportion of still-lower-paying mobile ads.TripAdvisor was spun off from Web travel company Expedia (EXPE) in December, and closed its first day of trading at 27.67. Shares hit an all-time high of 37.89 early in Tuesday's regular trading before fading to end the session at 36.53, down 2.6%. The stock had been on the now twice-weekly IBD 50 rankings of top stocks since April 2, but fell off the latest list publishing Wednesday.The Newton, Mass.-based company said CPC revenue rose 20% from the year-earlier quarter to $144.9 million. This is revenue it gets each time a site user clicks on ads for a flight, hotel or other travel service. It made up 79% of the company's total revenue in the quarter.TripAdvisor, which also provides customer reviews of travel destinations, restaurants and more, said its display ad revenue rose 17%. Subscription and other revenue had the biggest jump of its three breakout segments, surging 67%.Analysts liked the Q1 numbers."We continue to believe TripAdvisor is well-positioned to benefit from growth in online travel advertising, given that only 15% or so of U.S. travel ad spend is online while 65% of U.S. travel bookings are online," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in an email interview. "That seems like a gap that needs to close over time."JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth said in an investor note Monday that TripAdvisor got a lift in the quarter from strong travel industry metrics. Stocks continued to hold near their best levels of the session late Thursday. Most of the major stock indexes were on pace for a fifth straight gain.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% and the S&P 500 rose 0.7%. Both were looking at their fifth straight up day. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.4%. Turnover was tracking higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Cabela's (CAB) was off its session high, but still up 14% after blowing past views. Before the open, the outdoor equipment retailer delivered Q1 earnings that jumped 75% to 70 cents a share. It beat by 11 cents. Thanks to strong demand for guns and ammo, sales rose 29% to $802.5 million. Both top- and bottom-line growth were the best in years. The stock cleared a 62.32 buy point from an irregular flat base.

PulteGroup (PHM) bolted 6% despite reporting mixed Q1 results earlier Thursday. The stock is in a double-bottom base with a 21.70 buy point. But the pattern is a third-stage base. Generally, first- or second-stage patterns are preferred.

Overstock.com (OSTK) reversed early losses and gained 5% to its best levels in almost three years. It's now 17% past a 17.75 buy point from a cup base cleared April 19. Overstock's base corrected 39%, which is deep. Last week, the online retailer delivered Q1 results well ahead of expectations.

Proto Labs (PRLB) shaved an earlier 8% loss to about 2%. It also climbed back above its 50-day moving average. The maker of custom parts sold off as a warning about its profit margin offset better-than-expected Q1 results. Proto Labs recently had a failed breakout, but it found support near the 45 level.

Computer maker Dell (DELL) announced Thursday that it is acquiring Make Technologies, a provider of applications modernization software and services. The deal is Dell's fifth acquisition this year and third this week.

Round Rock, Texas-based Dell said the addition of Make will further expand the capabilities of its tech services business. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Dell expects to complete the purchase in its fiscal second quarter.

Privately held Make provides software and services that allow enterprise customers to transition business-critical applications from legacy systems to open standards-based platforms, including Internet cloud infrastructure. Such changes can reduce operating costs for companies, Dell says.
Make Technologies is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and has about 100 employees. Its customers include Expedia (EXPE), Exxon Mobil (XOM), Fidelity, General Motors (GM) and TD Bank.

The deal will complement Dell's purchase of Clerity Solutions, announced Tuesday, says Steve Schuckenbrock, president of Dell's services unit. On Monday, Dell announced it will buy thin-client computing firm Wyse Technology.

"The addition of Make Technologies and Clerity Solutions to Dell Services positions us to lead in the fast-growing applications modernization space," Schuckenbrock said in a statement. "We have the capabilities to help customers with all their modernization needs — from re-hosting and re-platforming to code re-engineering. These offerings will enable Dell to support the thousands of commercial and public sector customers looking to migrate business-critical applications to open, standards-based architectures, including the cloud."
ISI analyst Brian Marshall estimates the Make deal was worth less than $100 million.
With three acquisitions this week, Dell's senior vice president of corporate strategy, Dave Johnson , is the "busiest man in tech today," Marshall said.

Expedia (EXPE) shares were down 5% in after-hours trading Thursday after the online travel agency issued Q4 earnings that beat earnings estimates but missed on sales by more than $25 million.

Bellevue, Wash.-based Expedia said it earned 58 cents a share excluding options expenses, amortization and other items, unchanged from 58 cents in the year-earlier quarter and 5 cents above the 53-cent average estimate of 24 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Sales rose 7% to $787.1 million, but analysts were expecting $812.4 million.
Thomson Reuters says its estimates take into account the spinoff of Expedia's TripAdvisor (TRIP) unit late last year.
For full-year 2011, Expedia said profit minus items rose 9% to $2.75 a share, while sales jumped 14% to $3.45 billion.
The company didn't issue an outlook for Q1. Analysts were expecting sales of $786.4 million and per-share earnings of 23 cents.
During Q4, Expedia said it repurchased 3.1 million shares on a pre-reverse split basis for $83 million. For the year, it repurchased 10.6 million shares on a pre-reverse split basis for $283 million.

Shares of TripAdvisor, Expedia's spinoff, plunged 14.6% Thursday after the travel-related content firm was downgraded to hold from buy by Benchmark analysts and its Q4 earnings issued late Wednesday missed expectations. TripAdvisor reported per share EPS of 23 cents and sales of $137.80 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EPS of 24 cents. But TripAdvisor's Q4 sales of $137.8 million beat views of $133.7 million.
Nomura Securities International analyst Brian Nowak said in a Thursday note to investors that the earnings miss was driven by lower margins.

Expedia rival Priceline (PCLN) wasn't affected much by the misses by TripAdvisor and Expedia. Shares of Travelzoo (TZOO) were up 29% midday Wednesday on reports the company might put itself up for sale.
Reuters reported that the struggling online travel company is in the process of hiring a financial adviser. Travelzoo declined to comment on the reports.

The company's current market value is around $400 million. Travelzoo bills itself as an Internet media company. It offers online travel and entertainment deals to subscribers, who often get the offers via email. That puts it in competition with Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline.com (PCLN), in providing travel deals on flights, hotels and vacation packages.
Travelzoo recently entered the local deals market, putting it in competition with Groupon (GRPN).

Shares of Travelzoo have been on a downward slide since July 21, when it posted financial results that missed sales and earnings forecasts, hurt by higher costs and slower growth in Europe. Priceline, though, handily topped forecasts when it reported fourth-quarter results Feb. 27, on a strong jump in global hotel reservations. Expedia beat earnings when it reported quarterly earnings Feb. 8, but it missed on sales.Shares of Travelzoo (TZOO) were up 29% midday Wednesday on reports the company might put itself up for sale.Reuters reported that the struggling online travel company is in the process of hiring a financial adviser. Priceline, though, handily topped forecasts when it reported fourth-quarter results Feb. 27, on a strong jump in global hotel reservations. Expedia beat earnings when it reported quarterly earnings Feb. 8, but it missed on sales.
With all its fiscal problems, Europe may not seem the best place to do business. But it's been a great place for leisure-travel Web operator Priceline (PCLN) .
Year-over-year traffic at Priceline's prized Europe-based hotel site Booking.com has been growing close to 30% the last couple of quarters.

Austerity measures or not, the European leisure travel market remains the largest in the world in terms of money spent on travel, says Raymond James analyst Aaron Kessler, citing research from PhoCusWright.
And Priceline, through its Booking.com site, is the leader and fastest-growing company in the European online hotel booking market.
Since online penetration in Europe is still only about 25% for hotels, "there is still a lot of market share to be gained over the next few years," Kessler said.

Priceline has morphed into an international company. Growth in the U.S. from Priceline.com's famous "Name Your Own Price" product has slowed while Booking.com and Asian website Agoda.com have grown rapidly.
U.S. Growth
"The U.S. is doing okay, but it's not driving the growth," Kessler said.
It grew 13% in 2011 and will grow about 10% this year, he figures.
In the third quarter, the last reported by Priceline, international bookings grew 61% over the prior year after growing 79% in the second quarter.
About 80% of the company's profits come from international markets, and more than 50% from selling hotel rooms to European travelers, says analyst Mark Mahaney of Citigroup.
"If any Internet consumer company has material exposure to Europe, it is Priceline," he said.

"(Priceline's) stock is very sensitive to the market's perceptions of Europe," he said. "If we had talked two months ago, we would have talked about how much correction Priceline's stock went through."
As anxiety over Europe eased in recent weeks, Priceline's stock broke out.
On Feb. 13, shares jumped nearly 5% to 571 on news of a Greek austerity deal. On Feb. 21, the stock reached a 10-year high of 593.
"People are a little more positive that Europe is stabilizing," Kessler said.
Europe is still a fluid situation.

After reporting a blowout third quarter in early November, Priceline tamped down expectations for the fourth quarter, typically a light period in the travel industry anyway. Some of the reasons included foreign-exchange head winds and economic uncertainty, including concerns over Greece's potential default.

The Norwalk, Conn.-based company expects quarterly revenue to rise 27% to 32% to $928.7 million to $965.3 million. It guided per-share profit of $4.90 to $5. Both were lower than Wall Street views at the time.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters now see modest upside to Priceline's guidance, estimating fourth-quarter per-share profit of $5.05. They see 2011 earnings of $23.16, for a 72% gain over 2010, but have 2012's profit growth slowing to 28%.
"Given the law of large numbers," Kessler said, "It's hard to imagine growth will accelerate from 2011."
Fourth-quarter and full-year results will be reported Feb. 27 after the market close.
"Europe is the single biggest question mark," said Mahaney.
Despite what happens in Europe, Mahaney says Priceline's strong business fundamentals "are well intact."
"This is a company with a very good management team and a very good business model, and it continues to take share from competitors Expedia (EXPE) and Orbitz (OWW)."
In the U.S., Priceline is the second-largest online travel agency after Expedia in terms of unique visitors, according to ComScore.
Priceline has consistently grown faster than Expedia and No. 3 Orbitz in international markets, Mahaney wrote in a November note.
Citigroup said Priceline's share of international bookings among the top three online travel agencies rose from 39% in 2009 to 46% in 2010.
It estimates Priceline's share of bookings in the third quarter will top 55%.
Citigroup's channel checks show that Priceline's Booking.com, which is reported under international bookings, is gaining traction in the U.S. as well.
Citigroup says 75% of total bookings come from Europe, Asia and Latin America. It estimates Asia and Latin America comprised more than 10% of total bookings in 2011.
Mahaney views Priceline's U.S. business as "a countercyclical hedge."

In the U.S., Priceline's "Name Your Own Price" program was once a popular way to land discount air fares. But when the airline industry reduced commissions to travel agencies, the pricing advantage fell.
Priceline and other online travel firms switched their focus to hotels. And the "Name Your Own Price" program for hotels was a draw during the recession. But interest has waned.
Increasing Competition
Chief Executive Jeffery Boyd pointed out in a third-quarter statement that the "Name Your Own Price hotel business is challenged by increasing competition in the discount space."
On Jan. 23, Priceline announced it would "kill off" "The Negotiator," played by actor William Shatner, starting with the launch of a new TV ad campaign.
The first commercial in the campaign shows The Negotiator rescuing passengers in a bus teetering off a bridge before it falls off with him apparently still in it.

Though Name Your Own Price is still a key differentiator, customers "don't have to negotiate themselves to get a deal," Priceline said. Thousands of hotels are available every day "at rates we've negotiated for them."
Booking.com alone has more than 170,000 hotels to choose from, up from 105,000 in late 2010. Priceline says it's the top online hotel reservation service in the world.

Hotel room nights sold through Priceline sites jumped 47% in the third quarter vs. the prior year to 40.6 million. Airline tickets rose just 7%, following a string of low-single-digit growth or low-single single-digit declines.
Priceline's rental-car business grew 37% in the quarter thanks largely to its acquisition of TravelJigsaw in 2010.

"There's not a lot not to like (about Priceline)," Kessler said. "The biggest concern for investors is the European macro environment."With all its fiscal problems, Europe may not seem the best place to do business. Priceline says it's the top online hotel reservation service in the world.Hotel room nights sold through Priceline sites jumped 47% in the third quarter vs. the prior year to 40.6 million. Airline tickets rose just 7%, following a string of low-single-digit growth or low-single single-digit declines.Priceline's rental-car business grew 37% in the quarter thanks largely to its acquisition of TravelJigsaw in 2010."There's not a lot not to like (about Priceline)," Kessler said. "The biggest concern for investors is the European macro environment."

Travelzoo (TZOO) CEO Chris Loughlin says being a bit traditional in selling travel can be a big plus in Europe, the world's top travel market.

Unlike in the U.S., many Europeans still shy away from booking travel online, Loughlin told IBD in a recent interview. Most Europeans still prefer to make their actual reservations by phone — even if they found the original deal on the Web, he says.

Loughlin, who built up Travelzoo's business in Europe before becoming CEO in July 2010, says this trait provides a selling opportunity for Travelzoo, which lets subscribers book deals both electronically or by talking with a customer rep by phone.
"Some of the revenue (Travelzoo gets) is what I would call 'classical' travel revenue," Loughlin said.

The company's Travelzoo (Europe) unit, started in 2005, concentrates on four main markets: Britain, France, Germany and Spain. The company publishes email newsletters that provide travel, entertainment and local deals.
Phone reservations sound like a small offshoot in a world where online travel packs an ever bigger punch.

But data from online travel tracker PhoCusWright show that Travelzoo, which bills itself as an Internet media company, is tapping a lingering and potentially lucrative European consumer preference. PhoCusWright says only 33% of Europe's total travel sales of $290 billion in 2010 were booked online.
The online share is rising, yet two-thirds of travel in Europe is still bought by phone or in-person at physical travel agency offices.
Loughlin says this is why Travelzoo gives its subscribers the option of completing travel arrangements by phone.

Travelzoo isn't the only vendor lifted by phone reservations in Europe. Expedia (EXPE) spokesman David McNamee says Expedia provides customers in all European markets the opportunity to book travel reservations over the phone. Priceline (PCLN) spokesman Brian Ek says the company's Amsterdam-based Booking.com website also offers the option of phone bookings in all of the countries and languages they support. But Ek says the website doesn't "actively promote" the phone feature.

Still, Priceline is aware of the offline travel bonanza in Europe. CEO Jeffery Boyd said in a May 5 conference call with analysts that "a very substantial amount of business" comes from offline channels in Europe and that Priceline's in a "good position to gain" share.
Travelzoo also seems to be gaining share. In Q1, Travelzoo's European revenue surged 53% from the year-earlier quarter to $9.4 million. The company's overall revenue rose 30% to $37 million.
Europe now accounts for about 25% of the company's revenue. Total subscribers in Europe rose 29% to 5.1 million as of March 31. Travelzoo has 23 million subscribers worldwide.
Europe has become a key battlefield for Priceline, Expedia and Travelzoo as the U.S. market has leveled off over the last several years.

The U.S. lags Europe and Asia-Pacific in travel sales. PhoCusWright says Europe is expected to keep its lead as the world's largest general travel market. It says total gross travel bookings for Europe in 2012 are expected to hit $317 billion, vs. $290.4 billion for Asia-Pacific and $288.4 billion for the U.S.
Loughlin says Travelzoo's policy of checking the reliability of the deals it offers through 250 deal experts in 23 offices worldwide also resonates with European consumers.

Revenue for Local Deals in Europe, Travelzoo's Groupon-like discount program, tripled in the first half of Q2 to $3.4 million from the first half of Q1. Travelzoo so far has published Local Deals in 28 markets across Europe. Its fastest-growing European Local Deals market is Germany.

Travelzoo has an opportunity in Europe based on the size of the market and its ability to offer traditional travel features like phone-based reservations, says PhoCusWright analyst Carroll Rheem. But Rheem says Europe comes with a special set of challenges.

For one, each culture's travel preferences can vary quite a bit. For example, she says French consumers have a close connection to former French colonies like Morocco and Tunisia, where French is spoken.
"With deals (in Europe), you have to hit the right spot," Rheem said.
Rheem says travel players like Travelzoo can't just set up one European site. "It has to be done country by country, unlike the U.S., which is much more homogenous," Rheem said.
Online travel firms, including Travelzoo, Priceline and Expedia, have responded to Europe's varied market by opening local offices and European language websites to serve specific markets.

Stocks held near session highs and in modestly positive territory in early afternoon action Friday.
The Nasdaq gained 0.5%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 both tacked on 0.2%. Volume was tracking slightly higher on the Nasdaq, but slightly lower on the NYSE.
For the week, the Nasdaq is on pace to finish about 2.2% higher, ending a three-week losing streak. The S&P 500 is on track for a 1.8% gain; the Dow, a 1.6% rise.
Economic news has come in mixed Friday. The Commerce Department said U.S. first-quarter GDP expanded at a 2.2% annual rate, down from Q4's 3% growth and below expectations for 2.5%.

The final reading of the April University of Michigan consumer sentiment index came in at 76.4, topping expectations of 75.8. Meanwhile, employment costs rose 0.4% in Q1, lower than the expected gain of 0.5%.

On the earnings front, Starbucks (SBUX) gapped down and slid 5% in brisk trade. Late Thursday, the coffee giant delivered fiscal Q2 results that topped views, but gave a soft full-year profit outlook. Starbucks pegged earnings for 2012 at $1.81 to $1.84 a share vs. views for $1.86. The stock remains well-extended from its last buying range.

Seagate Technology (STX) lost 7% in fast trade after being hit with two downgrades, but it was off its low for the session after finding support just above its 50-day moving average. Craig Hallum cut the disk-drive maker to hold from buy, and Bank of America/Merrill Lynch lowered shares to neutral from buy.

On the upside, Expedia (EXPE) gapped above its 50-day line and soared 27% in reaction to its blowout quarterly results late Thursday. Thanks to strong hotel bookings, the online travel firm's Q1 earnings surged 62% to 26 cents a share, beating expectations by 12 cents. Sales climbed 12% to $816.5 million vs. views for $790.1 million. JPMorgan raised shares to neutral from underweight Friday.

TripAdvisor (TRIP), which was spun off from Expedia in December, jumped 9%. And Priceline.com (PCLN) rose 4% in fast trade, nearing a new multiyear high as it continued to rally off support at its 10-week line.

Amazon.com (AMZN) surged 15% in massive turnover. Late Thursday, the e-commerce giant reported first-quarter results that blew past analyst expectations. It posted earnings of 28 cents a share, down from 44 cents in the prior year but well above the 7 cents expected. Revenue rose 34% to $13.2 billion, above views for $12.9 billion.

Amazon (AMZN  -  Free Report) is leaving no stone unturned to fortify presence in the healthcare sector.Reportedly, the company is in talks with a Seattle-based start-up called Xealth to work on a project related to medical supplies. Notably, the start-up assists the patients to manage their health with the aid of its digital health tools and prescriptions.The pilot project also welcomes the participation of two hospitals namely Providence Health Systems and University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. In fact, both these institutions have invested in Xealth.Amazon is striving to make the patient’s access to medical supplies easier and comfortable with the help of this project. Notably, this project will allow the doctors to prescribe medical products necessary for their patients after a surgery or in general cases through the hospital’s online portal.This will enable the patients to place a purchase order for the items that their doctor has recommended just by logging into their personal page on the hospital portal. The patients will then get them delivered at their doors via Amazon’s efficient delivery system.Medical Supply Market to BenefitWe believe the latest move of the company serves the interests of the patients to a great extent and of the doctors as well, which will be beneficial for the healthcare sector.Further, it is in sync with its strategy of bolstering presence in the medical supplies market.Per the report from Energias Market Research, the global market for medical supplies is expected to reach $140.5 billion by 2023 by growing at a CAGR of 6.3% between 2017 and 2023.Amazon is well poised to reap benefits from this growing market on the back of its aggressive retail strategies and robust e-commerce platform.Additionally, new parents and patients with severe illness who require medical support quite often are likely to be attracted by the new project.Moreover, the company might integrate the online pharmacy supply into this project with the help of PillPack.All these endeavors are likely to bring more customers to the company’s platform, driving its top-line growth in this sector.Coming to the price performance, shares of Amazon have returned 53.6% on a year-to-date basis, outperforming the industry’s rally of 30.6%. Growing Focus on Healthcare SectorAmazon’s strong efforts toward healthcare sector will help it to gain momentum in the sector. The recent move holds a lot of potential for future growth.Recently, the company ventured into the high-potential pharmaceutical industry with the PillPack acquisition. Upon the completion of this buyout, Amazon would be selling prescription medicines online.Further, the company teamed up with Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase for a healthcare venture in order to bring down health-care costs and improve facilities for their U.S. employees.Additionally, a team has been built within the company’s Alexa division to focus more on health & wellness with the help of its voice assistant. This has strengthened the company’s presence in the digital healthcare sector.Consequently, Amazon’s e-commerce platform is completely ready to disrupt this sector. These strong efforts will help the company to expand its benefits from this particular sector which holds immense growth potential.Amazon.com, Inc. Revenue (TTM) Amazon.com, Inc. It has been about a month since the last earnings report for Expedia Group, Inc. (EXPE  -  Free Report). Shares have added about 10% in that time frame.Will the recent positive trend continue leading up to its next earnings release, or is EXPE due for a pullback? Before we dive into how investors and analysts have reacted as of late, let's take a quick look at the most recent earnings report in order to get a better handle on the important drivers.Recent EarningsExpedia Group reported first-quarter 2018 adjusted loss of 46 cents per share as against earnings of 84 cents in the last reported quarter. However, the loss was lower than the Zacks Consensus Estimate of a loss of 60 cents. Notably, the company had reported a loss of 15 cents in the year-ago quarter.However, revenues in the quarter under review increased 8.6% sequentially and 15% on a year-over-year basis to $2.5 billion beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2.46 billion. Robust performance of HomeAway, Core OTA, Brand Expedia, Hotels.com, Expedia Partner Solutions and Egencia, which accelerated the company’s gross bookings and stayed room nights numbers during the quarter led to the upside.Expedia recorded gross bookings of $27.2 billion in the first quarter, up 15.2% year over year and 37.3% sequentially. The figure came ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $26.6 billion.Revenues by SegmentCore OTA segment revenues (76.8% of total revenues) increased 13% year over year and 3.2% on a sequential basis to $1.92 billion. The segment witnessed 11% year-over-year growth in gross bookings which came at $21.1 billion.Moreover, trivago revenues (12.8% of revenues) grew 12% year over year and 48.3% sequentially to $319 million. This was attributed to its share in rest of world (ROW) region which grew 20% from the year-ago quarter.Egencia revenues (6% of revenues) increased 23% on year-over-year basis and 10.2% sequentially to $151 million. This was driven by strong performance in quarterly bookings which exceeded $2 billion for the first time. Additionally, the segment acquired new clients and client base grew 20% from the year-ago quarter.HomeAway (9.4% of revenues) generated $234 million in the quarter, which increased 26% from the year-ago quarter and 21.2% sequentially. HomeAway witnessed 46% year-over-year growth in gross bookings, which came in at $3.9 billion in the quarter. Also, the segment experienced 36% growth in the stayed room nights on a year-over-year basis.Revenues by Business ModelMerchant model generated revenues of $1.3 billion (52% of revenues), which were up 13% year over year and 8.4% sequentially.Agency division generated revenues of $658 million (26.3% of revenues), which grew 15% from the prior-year quarter and 4.6% sequentially.Advertising & Media yielded $282 million of revenues (11.3% of revenues), which increased 10% from the year-ago quarter and 31.8% sequentially. This was driven by 14% growth in Media Solutions business. Moreover, HomeAway (9.4% of revenues) generated $234 million in the quarter, which increased 26% from the year-ago quarter and 21.2% sequentially.Revenues by GeographyExpedia generated $1.35 billion (54% of total revenues) from domestic regions, which went up 8% from the prior-year quarter and 7.1% sequentially. Revenues generated by international regions were $1.15 billion (46% of revenues), up 23% on a year-over-year basis and 8.5% from the previous quarter.Revenues by Product LineLodging revenues (64.4% of total revenues) came in $1.61 billion, rose 15% from the prior-year quarter and inched up 0.6% sequentially. This was attributed to 16% year-over-year growth in stayed room nights for Brand Expedia, Hotels.com, Expedia Partner Solutions and Egencia. Further, Expedia added 50,000 new properties to its global lodging portfolio, which exhibited 74% year-over-year growth.Air revenues were $242 million (9.6% of reveneus), which were up 11% year over year and 37.5% on a sequential basis. This was driven by 1% increase in air tickets sold and 10% growth in revenues per ticket.Operating DetailsAdjusted EBITDA plunged 40.3% year over year and 69.1% on a sequential basis to $124 million. Notably, Trivago and Home Away EBITDA decreased 28% and 21% year over year, respectively. However, Core OTA EBITDA increased 7% from the year-ago quarter whereas Egencia EBITDA came in line.Expedia incurred operating loss of $165 million in the reported quarter, compared to $73 million loss in the year-ago quarter. This came on the back of accelerated growth in cost of revenues.Moreover, selling and marketing expenses grew 19% year over year, primarily due to increased marketing expenditure on Trivago and HomeAway. Further, growing head counts in Egencia and HomeAway, continuous investment on cloud migration and inorganic impact from acquisitions also increased operating expense.Balance Sheet & Cash FlowAs of Mar 31, 2018, cash and cash equivalents were $3.42 billion compared to $2.84 billion as of Dec 31, 2017. Short-term investments totaled $1.03 billion, which increased from $468 million in the last reported quarter.Further, Expedia generated nearly $1.48 billion of free cash flow in the first quarter. The company paid quarterly dividend worth $46 million (30 cents per share) at the end of the first quarter.Also, Expedia repurchased nearly 2.5 million shares for a total of $268 million year-to-date as of Apr 24, 2018.GuidanceThe Zacks Consensus Estimate for Expedia’s total revenues for the second quarter is currently pegged at $2.9 billion and that for earnings is projected at 84 cents.However, the company expects Trivago to continue to weigh on revenues and earnings in the second quarter.Expedia reiterates its guidance for adjusted EBITDA growth of 6-11% and 10-15% for 2018. Further, it expects Trivago EBITDA contraction between 200 basis point (bps) and 400 bps. Subscription revenues are expected to decrease in the mid-20% range.The company expects to narrow the gap between revenue per room-night and average daily rates in 2018. It also expects to expand its global lodging portfolio by adding more than 180,000 in 2018.How Have Estimates Been Moving Since Then?In the past month, investors have witnessed an upward trend in fresh estimates. There have been seven revisions higher for the current quarter compared to six lower.Expedia, Inc. Price and Consensus  Expedia, Inc. Price and Consensus | Expedia, Inc. QuoteVGM ScoresAt this time, EXPE has an average Growth Score of C, however its Momentum is doing a bit better with a B. The stock was allocated a grade of A on the value side, putting it in the top 20% for this investment strategy.Overall, the stock has an aggregate VGM Score of B. If you aren't focused on one strategy, this score is the one you should be interested in.Based on our scores, the stock is primarily suitable for value investors while also being suitable for those looking for momentum and to a lesser degree growth.OutlookEstimates have been trending upward for the stock and the magnitude of these revisions looks promising. It comes with little surprise EXPE has a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). We expect an above average return from the stock in the next few months.

Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN  -  Free Report) plans to expand in Ohio with its sixth fulfillment center in West Jefferson.For the last few years, the company has been spending heavily on its new fulfillment centers. These are important in order to provide the level of service that customers have started expecting from Amazon.In addition, there is exciting news for Amazon’s Prime members. The company has announced that it will now offer exclusive discounts to Prime members who shop at Whole Foods, as well as deep discounts on select, best-selling products. Those are in addition to the incremental 10% off already saled items. The Prime benefit at Whole Foods Market will rollout nationwide, starting this summer.Meanwhile, the company has been implementing perks for its Prime members in Whole Foods since it acquired the grocery chain last year for $13.7 billion. It already offers 5% cash-back benefit to the prime members who use Amazon Prime Rewards Visa card while shopping at any Whole Foods store.We believe, the company’s continuous efforts in making Prime more customer friendly will continue to drive subscription base of the service, improving the top line further.Over the last year, the company has outperformed the industry it belongs to. Shares of Amazon have gained 63.3% compared with the industry’s growth of 46.3%.Amazon’s strong focus on enhancing the Prime service aided by exciting discounts, free delivery within a short period of time, expanding movies & video portfolio and many more, has helped the company achieve this feat.More on the HeadlinesThe latest fulfillment center spans more than 855,000 square feet and will create 1,500 new full-time jobsApart from that, this new facility will be primarily focusing on smaller items such as electronics, books, housewares and toys.The world’s largest online retailer has been strengthening its presence in Ohio where it has invested over $2 billion in the state, both in customer fulfillment infrastructure and compensation to its employees in the state. In the last few years, Amazon has announced multiple facilities in the state with healthy business environment and skilled manpower.The online giant has created more than 6,000 full-time jobs in Ohio. Using methodology developed by the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, Amazon estimates its investments in Ohio have created an additional 9,000 indirect jobs on top of the company’s direct hires.Bottom LineWe feel, Amazon must maintain its U.S. market share, while expanding globally in order to retain its leading position. For this, the company needs to invest more in fulfillment as well as technology and content, especially in international markets with less penetration and higher growth rates.Although increased expenses might hurt the company’s bottom line in the near term, we believe this is necessary for the company to maintain its dominance in this highly competitive market.Amazon.com, Inc.
